HEADLINE: U.S. Shift in Calculating Auto Prices

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Commerce Department said today that it would include rebates and other discounts when it calculated average car prices.
United States auto makers have been pressing the agency for months to change the way it calculates car prices, arguing that the Government's numbers make it appear as if car prices are rising sharply. 
 Efforts by the industry were accelerated late last year, when the Government reported that the average vehicle cost more than $20,000. In the first quarter, the Commerce Department said, the average fell slightly, to $19,112.
During a meeting with reporters last month, the chief economist for the Chrysler Corporation, Van Bussmann, said a survey sponsored by the company had come up with a much lower figure, $16,700.
Mr. Bussmann attributed the difference to the failure of the Government to deduct rebates and other option discounts from the average.
A spokesman for the department's bureau of economic analysis, which provides a quarterly average for auto prices in the United States, said today that the agency hoped to include rebates by the end of the year.
"This is something we've known about all along, but we need to have a way to gather the data," said Evert Johnson, a spokesman for the bureau. "We think we know how to do that in terms of rebates, but we need some help from the manufacturers to gather some other data."
For years, the Government has asked Detroit for a detailed account of each transaction. But the auto industry has been reluctant to provide that information because of fears that it would be used by competitors.
The result has been confusing statistics that seem to undermine the contention by Detroit that car prices have kept pace with inflation.
Since 1981 the average provided by the Commerce Department has shown a constant rise in auto prices, while Chrysler's data display a brief period of increases, followed by several years of steady prices.
Officials of the department attributed the difference to averaging techniques spurred by a lack of data from the auto industry.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
McDonnell May Halt MD-11 Work

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation may temporarily halt production of its largest airliner, the MD-11, next year because of a severe shortage of orders for the 300-seat plane, the company said today.
The company emphasized that it was working to avert a shutdown, which could mean temporary layoffs for thousands of workers and cast doubt on the future of the MD-11 program. 
 A company spokesman, Tom Williams, said the chances for such a temporary shutdown were slight. "It's something that's very serious, that we don't want to do," he said. "But it's something you have to honestly look at."
He said the company was likely to receive more orders for the MD-11.
Without new orders for the three-engine jet, McDonnell Douglas may deliver as few as 10 next year, industry officials have said.
The MD-11 is made at the company's factory in Long Beach, Calif., where 10,000 workers are employed. That plant also produces the smaller MD-80 and MD-90. The company would not say how many people were employed making each type of jet.
Mr. Williams said a decision on halting MD-11 production for as much as half of 1996 would have to be made within five months.
Other options include slowing production again, a move that would force the company to further increase efficiency or absorb higher per-jet costs. Another option is to persuade some customers to take delivery sooner on MD-11's ordered for later years.
Mr. Williams said unexpected delays in completing a Saudi Arabian order considered pivotal to 1996 production had also contributed to problem.
McDonnell's shares fell $1.125 today, to $52.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
All three global producers of big airliners -- including the Boeing Company, the market leader, and second-ranked Airbus Industrie of Europe -- have made sharp production cuts during the airline recession of the 1990's. Last week, Boeing announced 7,000 job cuts and new production cutbacks because of delivery delays by carriers.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cold Snap in East Pushes Natural Gas Price Up Again

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Natural gas prices rose sharply for a fourth consecutive session yesterday, lifted by a cold snap on the East Coast.
But heating oil and crude oil prices weakened as traders took profits after last week's strong gains. The declines helped push the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities down 0.35 point, to 231.94. Copper prices recovered. 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, natural gas for March delivery surged 5.6 cents, to $1.538 for 1,000 cubic feet, the highest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since Jan. 5. The contract has risen 20.1 cents, or 15 percent, since last Tuesday.
Some traders attributed the rally to the East Coast's coldest weather of the season, with freezing temperatures as far south as northern Florida.
"If the traders have to put their wooly mittens on and bundle up for the weather, often times we'll see that reflected on the trading floor," said Tom Knight, manager of East Coast products trading for the Fina Oil and Chemical Company.
Natural gas prices were depressed to near three-year lows by mild weather in December and January.
Heating oil futures ended lower despite the cold, after an early advance. Mr. Knight said traders took profits after a crude oil rally that began last week stalled at $18.93 a barrel.
The March heating oil contract fell 0.24 cent, to 49.20 cents a gallon, and March crude oil fell 19 cents, to $18.59 a barrel. March unleaded gasoline fell 0.05 cent, to 57.30 cents a gallon.
Copper prices rebounded from a 12-week low. On the Commodity Exchange of New York, copper for March delivery fell as low as $1.28 a pound, its lowest since Nov. 16, before recovering to settle 0.55 cent higher at $1.318 a pound.
Copper is heavily used in electronics production and building construction. Economists have lowered their demand forecasts as a result of rising interest rates in the United States, the Japanese earthquake, and other factors likely to slow economic growth.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens During Day As Wall Street's Rally Cools

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen and slipped from its highs against European currencies yesterday after Friday's rallies in stocks and bonds in the United States cooled.
American stocks and bonds surged on Friday, pulling the dollar higher, after the Government reported that fewer jobs were created in January than most experts had expected, easing investors' concerns about inflation. Strong demand for American securities typically bolsters the dollar because foreign investors need dollars to buy American stocks and bonds. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average did rise yesterday, but only 9.09 points, while Treasury prices fell.
"There was early demand for dollars on expectations of continued gains for stocks and bonds," said Stephen Jury, chief dealer for Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. "But bonds came down, and the Dow didn't really do anything. So the interest in dollars -- which was quite strong -- waned."
After reaching a high of 1.5347 German marks early yesterday, the dollar retreated, settling at 1.5308 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.5267 marks on Friday. The dollar slipped to 99.41 Japanese yen from 99.85 yen.
The dollar's decline against the yen stemmed partly from purchases of yen by Japanese companies that are bringing money home from overseas operations before the end of their fiscal year on March 31, currency dealers said. Such year-end yen buying usually starts around the beginning of February, said Belal Khan, chief customer dealer at Bank of Tokyo in New York.
On Friday, the dollar dipped at first after the weaker-than-expected report on January employment damped speculation that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again soon. Higher rates often help the dollar by making interest-earning deposits in the United States more attractive. But the same news that initially hurt the dollar helped the stock and bond markets, and that then prompted interest in buying dollars.
In other currency trading, the British pound came under pressure yesterday amid concern about the stability of Prime Minister John Major's Government. A growing rift within his Conservative Party over integration within the European Union and a threat by Ulster Unionists to withdraw their support in Parliament has led investors to question how long Mr. Major can hold office.
In New York trading, the pound fell to $1.5590, from $1.5635 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Japan's Builders: Quake Beneficiaries

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 6

 BODY:
As a penalty for bribing public officials, one of Japan's largest construction companies, the Taisei Corporation, was prohibited last month from seeking new business for 18 days. Then on Jan. 17, the great earthquake struck.
Within hours, the suspension was lifted in the emergency and Taisei dispatched 1,100 workers to Kobe to help clear the city's rubble and restore public services. 
 Japanese construction companies like Taisei stand to gain as a result of the earthquake.
Indeed, the biggest beneficiary of the disaster will be Japan's construction industry, which has become generally infamous in recent years for bribery and bid-rigging and which, some evidence suggests, may possibly have contributed to the earthquake's destruction through shoddy construction practices.
Rebuilding Kobe, critics say, could provide a chance to reform Japan's construction system, which has produced some of the world's costliest yet drabbest buildings. It could also offer an opportunity to enhance urban planning, which has been given short shrift in Japan, resulting in cities with jumbles of ill-matched buildings on impassably narrow streets and with few parks and green areas.
Some foreign companies, which feel locked out of the construction market here, hope that the earthquake reconstruction may provide them with a new chance to participate. Imported building materials, foreign construction methods and foreign contractors could help reduce the costs of reconstruction. Owners of Western-style homes say they seemed to hold up relatively well in the quake.
"I would have to say that this event could cause a revolution in people's thinking about housing," said Charlie Barnes, the Japan representative of the Engineered Wood Association, formerly known as the American Plywood Association.
But whether things will really change remains to be seen. While Government officials in the Kobe area are talking about freeing space for wider streets and more parks, it would be a logistical nightmare to buy all the land needed from thousands of property owners. Japan's Cabinet decided a year ago that emergency reconstruction work did not have to be put out to bidding, a decision that conforms to World Trade Organization guidelines. This suggests that foreign companies will not get a chance to compete initially, though rebuilding may be opened up over the longer term.
Yet rebuilding highways, railroads, bridges, ports and tens of thousands of buildings in the Kobe area will be a huge job. The government of Hyogo Prefecture, which encompasses Kobe, estimated on Thursday that the earthquake damage would cost $95 billion. Beyond the spending in the Kobe area, the earthquake will almost certainly cause Japan's building codes to be stiffened, resulting in other construction work to strengthen highways, bridges and buildings around the country.
In anticipation of a bonanza for construction companies, investors have been bidding up some Japanese construction stocks furiously, even as the stock market has sunk since the earthquake. Shares of Fudo Construction, which is strong in the Kobe area, have more than doubled from 510 yen before the quake to 1,350 yen today.
But some analysts doubt that the windfall will be that great. Toshiyuki Johno of CS First Boston estimated that about $20 billion to $30 billion a year would be spent on earthquake reconstruction for the next two years. That is about 2.5 to 4 percent of Japan's total spending on construction, which amounts to about $800 billion a year.
In addition, construction companies will be under pressure not to charge too much for earthquake-related work, because of its humanitarian aspect. And shortages of lumber, steel and other material may drive up their prices, cutting the construction industry's profits.
"What is open to question is how much money they will be making," said Mark Brown, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities in Tokyo.
The industry could use a boost. With Japan's economic slump, orders received by the top 50 construction companies have dropped three years in a row. The figure for orders last year, 19.2 trillion yen, or $192 billion, was 2.7 percent below the 1993 figure and 26.3 percent below the 1991 peak of 26.05 trillion yen.
But construction companies also hope to use the earthquake to repair their own tarnished images. Some have pitched in on the cleanup without discussing as yet how much they will be paid.
Some companies also donated food and other supplies. "We recognize the construction companies' social mission," said Hiroyuki Asano, a spokesman for Taisei, which shipped five truckloads of food to the disaster area.
Five Taisei executives were convicted last year of bribing mayors and governors to win public works contracts. In all, more than 22 construction industry executives from seven companies have been prosecuted for bribery in the last couple of years.
Collusion among companies on winning bids is acknowledged as a widespread practice. And the construction industry is sometimes reported to pay off yakuza, or gangsters, to avoid disruptions at the workplace. Some smaller companies involved in such tasks as hauling gravel and disposing of rubble are controlled by organized crime, said Raisuke Miyawaki, a former director of the criminal investigation bureau of the National Police Agency. Mr. Miyawaki said that "1 to 3 percent of the public works budget may go to the yakuza."
But the industry's image might be sullied further if it is proved that any shoddy work worsened the destruction caused by the quake.
Despite the reputation for engaging in shady practices, the Japanese construction industry has generally enjoyed a reputation for good quality workmanship once it wins the bids.
The finger-pointing since the earthquake has mostly been directed at Japan's building codes, which are criticized as inadequate. Less attention has focused on the possibility that construction companies may have skirted the codes.
"I can't conceive of it at all in Japan," said Masafumi Fukuda, senior officer for construction management in the Ministry of Construction. Some industry officials say that the fact that contractors win bids through bribes or collusion rather than by offering a low price removes some of the incentive to cut corners.
Still, disturbing questions have been raised by investigators as they sift through the rubble. Pieces of wood were found in some damaged pillars that hold up elevated tracks of Japan's bullet train. Experts said the wood could have weakened the columns. Other experts asserted that welds were done in the wrong places in the pillars of the collapsed Hanshin Expressway.
What is in little dispute is that construction costs in Japan are very high. Even the Construction Ministry, which generally protects the industry, has embarked on a program to cut costs, which it estimates run 13 to 40 percent higher than in the United States and Britain.
Others say the disparity is even greater. Yuji Noga, a Tokyo architect who designs Western-style homes, estimates that a 1,420-square-foot home that can be built in the United States for $84,000 will cost $200,000 to construct in Japan.
High costs of material in Japan are one factor. But if imported materials were used, costs here would still be more than twice as high as in the United States because of different construction practices, said Mr. Noga, who is vice chairman of the U.S.-Japan Housing Industry Roundtable, a group of Japanese and American companies that promotes the sale of imported homes in Japan.
But numerous regulations still hinder such building imports. American companies have difficulty getting visas to allow construction workers to come to Japan. American plumbing fixtures are routinely rejected.
Boosters of imported housing say that American-style construction, known here as 2-by-4 construction because of the size of the lumber used, is more resistant to earthquakes than the traditional Japanese homes..
But Dr. Fumio Kamiya, head of the timber structures group at the Ministry of Agriculture's Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, said he found no difference in Kobe between the sturdiness of 2-by-4 buildings and modern Japanese-style houses. "Almost all the timber buildings that collapsed were built 30 to 40 years ago," he said.

HEADLINE: $1.6 Trillion Clinton Budget Received With Tepid Praise

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton sent his $1.6 trillion budget to a skeptical Congress today, vowing to control, if not reduce, the Federal deficit and challenging the new Republican majority to show how it would pay for its own deeper cuts in taxes and spending and keep its pledge to balance the budget by 2002.
"Republicans are saying we took a walk on the deficit, but none of them voted for the President's plan that got us where we are," said the President's budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, defending the Administration's decision to hold the budget deficit steady at about $200 billion a year into the next century, after reducing it for three years running. "And we will see as time unfolds what they intend to do to bring the deficit down. We haven't seen anything yet." 
 Mr. Clinton proposes to save $144 billion over the next five years -- about $63 billion to finance his proposed tax breaks for families with children and for college education, and the rest to reduce the deficit. He would eliminate 130 mostly small programs, for savings of about $2 billion, and consolidate 270 others in the first of what are likely to be far deeper cuts adopted by Congress.
On Capitol Hill, Republicans generally offered tepid praise for Mr. Clinton's direction but dismissed his plan as too timid.
"While the President has taken some positive steps as far as discretionary spending is concerned, he has shown no interest in doing the heavy lifting needed to eliminate our budget deficits," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, chairman of the House Budget Committee. "This budget lacks courage. It takes no action to control the growth of entitlement spending, which must be done if we are to reach a balanced budget by the year 2002."
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said Mr. Clinton's plan "raises the white flag of surrender at the red ink of Government spending."
The majority leader, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, said the President's budget would lend momentum to Republican efforts in the Senate to pass a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, as the House of Representatives already has.
Some Democrats were not much more supportive. Senator Jim Exon of Nebraska, the ranking member of the Budget Committee, said the budget would satisfy neither side of the aisle and "falls short, way short, of the deficit reduction we need."
"He has dropped the ball." Mr. Exon said.
And Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat who recently headed a bipartisan commission on how to overhaul spending for entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security, said both parties were avoiding hard choices because the budgeting procedure only calls for making estimates five years into the future.
Indeed, curtailing the growth in entitlement spending, which rises automatically every year, has been one of the most difficult issues facing the Government. Mr. Kerrey's commission could not agree on how to do it and Mr. Clinton has punted as well.
Last year, the President proposed deep shifts in Medicare spending to help finance his health care proposals, and his aides said he remains committed to that goal. But the President opposes cutting Medicare to finance tax cuts, and today he sought to put the onus for any such decisions squarely on the Republicans.
"My budget cuts spending, cuts taxes, cuts the deficit, and does not cut education or Social Security or Medicare," Mr. Clinton said in unveiling it this morning. "That is a good budget. It continues to reduce the deficit without undermining the things that I believe the Federal Government should be doing. And I wish to work with the new Congress to achieve these objectives. I hope that they will submit budgets which do the same."
In fact, Mr. Clinton would eliminate some education programs in order to help finance his larger goal of new tax deductions for post high-school education. And while he would cut the deficit as a percentage of the domestic economy -- and in relation to how it was anticipated to grow before he took office -- in absolute terms it would remain about the same.
Over and over today, Administration officials sought both to defend that reality and to put it in context.
"When we got here, the deficit was out of control," Ms. Rivlin said. "It was nearly $300 billion and headed up, confidently predicted to go over $400 billion by the end of the decade. We had to get the deficit under control, and we did. It is now under $200 billion, $100 billion lower than in 1992, and this budget keeps that control and keeps the budget headed down as a percent of Gross Domestic Product. It was 4.9 percent in 1992; it is 2.7 percent of G.D.P. now. It will be 2.1, or less than half what it was in 1992 by the end of the decade."
Ms. Rivlin has long been one of the Administration's biggest deficit hawks. In a confidential memo to the President that caused an uproar when it became public last fall, she pointed out that the price of dramatic deficit reduction or increased spending on the President's domestic agenda would be cuts in other programs, like entitlements. Almost alone among the President's senior advisers, she argued in favor of deeper deficit reduction as the budget was being drafted in December, but she lost out to political advisers who urged the President to press ahead with his 1992 campaign pledge -- initially deferred in favor of deficit reduction -- of tax breaks for the middle class.
Today, Ms. Rivlin stoutly defended Mr. Clinton's efforts to encourage investment in education as worthy social and budgetary goals. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin reflected mordantly on how little public or political credit the Administration has received for its success in reducing the deficit to date, but insisted that if the question came under serious scrutiny by the public, Mr. Clinton would still have the upper hand.
"If the elections in '96 were decided on whether the President fulfilled his promise to get the deficit under control," Mr. Rubin said, "I don't think the Republicans would get a single electoral vote."
Mr. Clinton proposed generally modest increases in spending for crime control, for stepped-up border patrols to deter illegal immigration, for high-priority environmental programs and for his national service program. He would save money by restructuring five departments, consolidating some functions and eliminating others, and by extending into the turn of the century caps on discretionary domestic spending that had been scheduled to expire in 1998.
The Administration is expected to outline the specifics of additional spending cuts this spring when Vice President Al Gore completes his second round of studies aimed at "re-inventing" government.
For their part, the Republicans said they would spell out specific prescriptions for cutting spending, in Mr. Kasich's words, "When we get it ready." Mr. Domenici said that meant late April or early May.

Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: How Some Programs Would Fare"
 President Clinton proposes spending $1.612 trillion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, with a deficit of $192.5 billion. The pie slices represent the percentage of the total budget devoted to each spending category.
 
AGRICULTURE 3.9%
 Remains at $62.3 billion next year, sparing farm subsidies from the budget ax, at least for now. Several programs would receive increased financing, including the food stamp program and a nutrition program for children and pregnant women.
 
MILITARY 16.0%
 A slight cut, by $6 billion to $258 billion, but maintains financing for training and higher troop salaries at the expense of buying fewer new warships and fighter jets than at any other time in decades. Republicans vow to reverse the proposed reduction in the coming fiscal year and add perhaps another $6 billion.
 
ENERGY 1.1%
 An increase of $300 million to $17.8 billion despite Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary's boast that the Energy Department is making the biggest "contribution to deficit reduction" of any Federal agency. One increase is $90 million to accelerate the American-Russian program to improve security for nuclear materials.
 
ENVIRONMENT 0.5%
An increase about $138 million, to nearly $7.37 billion. More than half the money would be spent on local projects, mostly financing water treatment or the cleaning up of toxic waste sites. But the agency's research and regulatory activities would grwo by more than $400 million and at $3.4 billion it would be almost twice as costly as it was in 1989.
 
HOUSING 1.6%
 A decrease of $600 million to $26.3 billion. Future savings are expected from a massive consilidation of grants and services into just three programs.
 
JUSTICE 1.0%
 A 20 percent increase over last year to $16.5 billion, mainly to finance the Administration's anti-crime law. About $4 billion of the new money would be used to help cities hire more neighborhood police; $370 million would be added to help cover expenses for states with large numbers of illegal aliens. The Immigraiton and Naturalization Service's budget would increase 27 percent to $2.6 billion.
 
MEIDCARE, MEDICAID, SOCIAL SECURITY 39.0%
 No policy changes were proposed in these mandatory spending programs.
 
TRANSPORTATION 2.3%
 A cut of $700 million to $37.3 billion. A reorganization over five years is projected to save about $6.4 billion. The independent Interstate Commerce Commission, which regulates portions of the rail, bus and truck industries, would be eliminated.

HEADLINE: Gingrich Promoted a Company That Has Employed His Wife

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The wife of Speaker Newt Gingrich has been earning $2,500 a month plus commissions by working for a company to which her husband has lent his support.
The business, the Israel Export Development Company, is backed by American investors and is trying to establish a free-trade zone in Israel. Marianne Gingrich, a former county planner in Ohio, was hired by the investors to find American commercial tenants for the trade zone, which is to operate free of most taxes. 
 Mrs. Gingrich was hired last September, while her husband, a Georgia Republican, was the minority whip in the House, The Baltimore Sun reported on Saturday. The Wall Street Journal reported today that she was hired after Mr. Gingrich told Israeli officials that he supported the free-trade zone.
Mr. Gingrich's spokesman, Tony Blankley, said today that the job did not involve any dealings with the United States Government and therefore did not pose a conflict for the couple. The Sun said that the company's investors included prominent business executives like the president of CBS, Laurence Tisch, the clothing magnate Sy Syms and the real estate developer Robert V. Tishman.
"There is no conflict of interest," Mr. Blankley said. "She's gone halfway around the world to avoid one."
Mr. Blankley said Mr. Gingrich was always a strong supporter of free trade. "He was giving advice to a friendly Government about what their policy should be," Mr. Blankley said. "He wasn't acting in an official capacity. There is no conflict with his Congressional responsibilities. No one can describe even in theory what the conflict is because there isn't one."
The Journal reported that Mr. Gingrich said he was first informed of the proposal for a free-trade zone in 1993 by his friend, former Representative Vin Weber, and Jack Kemp, former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
"I lobbied him," Mr. Weber, who worked for the company until about eight months ago, was quoted by The Journal as saying. Mr. Gingrich then met with supporters of the free-trade zone when he and his wife visited Israel in August 1993.

HEADLINE: Whitman Tax-Cut Plan Faces Problem

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In calling for the swift enactment of the remainder of her proposed 30 percent income tax cut, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said a new round of cuts were possible because her tax reductions had helped accelerate the state's economic growth.
But New Jersey's recovery, like that of most of the Northeast, remains a sluggish, uphill grind. That fact was underscored on Friday, less than two weeks after Mrs. Whitman announced her tax cut proposal, with a Federal employment report that showed New Jersey had lost 40,000 jobs in January and that its unemployment rate had jumped by a full percentage point, to 7.2 percent. 
 Although its economy has performed better than those of neighboring states for most of the last year, experts say the reason is not something special about New Jersey but rather a vibrant recovery nationwide generally. And like her counterparts in neighboring states, Mrs. Whitman must contend with deeply rooted economic problems.
"When you look at the industries that dominate this region, there is a cap on growth," said David Hensley, a regional economic analyst for Salomon Brothers. "New Jersey is part of that story."
In her 1995 budget message, Mrs. Whitman proudly contrasted New Jersey's growth to that of other states in the region. In recent months, employment in New Jersey has been expanding at an annual rate of 1.8 percent, double the nine-tenths of 1 percent expansion in New York, and triple the six-tenths of 1 percent expansion in Connecticut.
But the comparison obscures more telling data, indicating New Jersey has been left in the dust of brisk national expansion. Even before its downturn in January, New Jersey's rate of job growth had ranked 33d among the states, while New York and Connecticut were close to the bottom of the list, ranking 45th and 48th, respectively.
Since the employment report on Friday covered only the nation's 11 largest industrial states, a revised ranking of the states for January is not yet available. But among the 11 states, New Jersey's 7.2 percent unemployment was the second worst, with California, at 8.8 percent unemployment, coming in last.
Several of New Jersey's biggest industries have been hurt by broad economic shifts that are not expected to reverse course, even as the national economy grows more robust. With their vast markets in health care, the state's pharmaceutical makers and insurance companies have been squeezed -- and laid off thousands of workers -- because of the growing ability of health maintenance organizations and hospital buying groups to drive down costs.
In New Jersey, like other states across the Northeast, manufacturing is afflicted by relatively high wages and outmoded factories, even while thousands of auto plants, steel mills, plastics makers and other manufacturers in the Midwest and South are straining to keep up with rising demand for their goods.
Nor is New Jersey immune to the problems confronting the rest of the region, particularly among the banks and brokerage houses of Manhattan, which have slashed jobs and salaries because of higher interest rates and a weak stock market. Several of the largest Wall Street firms operate satellite data processing offices in New Jersey, and many of New Jersey's most highly paid residents commute to Wall Street jobs.
Although Mrs. Whitman calls her state "the pocket of hope for the region," even her top advisers acknowledge that the tax cuts she proposes -- a 15 percent cut in income tax rates by next January, coming on top of the 15 percent cut already in place -- are meant more to redistribute the state's tax burden and pave the way for long-term growth than to fuel an immediate upturn in the state's economy.
Indeed, Mrs. Whitman's budget and tax-cutting proposal has so far satisfied many analysts as economically viable, if politically difficult.
"There is nothing wildly optimistic in these changes," said Steven Hochman, assistant director of state ratings for Moody's Investors Service, one of the rating agencies that will judge Mrs. Whitman's fiscal proposals in determining the state's standing in the credit markets.
Although Moody's had not yet assessed every detail as of yesterday, or met with Mrs. Whitman's staff, Mr. Hochman said his firm was impressed by revisions they had made in forecasts of economic growth made last July. The revisions reflect lower expectations for growth during the next two years.
New Jersey officials now project job growth in their state of 1.8 percent this year, and 1.5 percent in 1996, compared to their earlier growth forecasts of 2 percent and 1.8 percent, he said. Forecasts of income growth in the state have also been scaled back.
Since they have taken into account the prospect of continued sluggishness, even with a reduced income tax rate, Mr. Hochman said Mrs. Whitman's plans "seem realistic."
One of the most difficult questions facing the New Jersey Governor and her counterparts in New York and Connecticut is whether tax cuts will lead to an immediate economic stimulus, as people seize on the lower deductions from their paychecks to spend more money. Will that spurt in spending offset the economic blow of layoffs, particularly among state agencies, where Mrs. Whitman plans to cut 3,350 jobs?
Such uncertainties have troubled economists across the nation. They contend that economic performance, something that is influenced by a complex array of variables, from interest rates to international trade competition as well as tax policy.
Nonetheless, some advisers to Mrs. Whitman assert that New Jersey's economy is stronger than those in neighboring states because of the first 15 percent cut in income taxes, and that the additional 15 percent reduction was bound to help.
"We've seen a clear increase in consumer confidence, and confidence in New Jersey's future," said Peter J. Calderone, the Labor Commissioner. He said the strongest increase in the state's employment in the last year had been in retail sales jobs, reflecting higher spending.
Another robust sector of the state's labor market is in business services, a broad category of employment that includes jobs in computer processing, printing, and consulting. Mr. Calderone said New Jersey, far more than its neighbors, had benefitted from the growth of small businesses that are filling the void of corporate layoffs.
No one can be sure what the short-term impact of Mrs. Whitman's proposal will be. But Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers University and chairman of Mrs. Whitman's council of economic advisers, said it was the state's long-term prospects that mattered most.
"Disentangling all the causal factors is impossible," he said. "But the long-term strategy is to lower costs in New Jersey and make it more competitive, and to that extent this proposal is right on target."

HEADLINE: Care at Most Child Day Centers Rated as Poor

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA 

 BODY:
The care provided by most American child-care centers is so poor that it threatens children's intellectual and emotional development, according to a four-state study of hundreds of such centers made public yesterday.
The study, conducted by child psychologists and economists at four universities, concluded that infants and toddlers -- the group researchers say most need security and stimulation to thrive later on in life -- were worst off. As many as 40 percent of infant and toddler rooms provided poor care. 
 Over all, 12 percent of the centers studied were actually unsafe or unsanitary, and only 1 in 7 offered the kind of warm relationships that teach children how to trust adults and the intellectual stimulation that helps children become ready for school.
"I think the most important finding," said Barbara Reisman, executive director of Child Care Action Campaign, an advocacy group based in New York City, "is that in 76 percent of the centers, safety and health needs were being met, but the need to grow and develop were not."
The study, "Cost, Quality and Child Outcomes in Child Care Centers," was conducted by researchers at the University of Colorado at Denver, the University of California at Los Angeles, the University of North Carolina and Yale University.
The researchers examined 400 care centers in California, Colorado, Connecticut and North Carolina in the spring of 1993, and tested 826 children from those centers to see what impact their child-care experience had on their intellectual and emotional development.
The study is the latest of several condemning the quality of American child care, whether in centers or in family day care, where one adult cares for a small group of children in a home.
"What used to be the best-kept secret in America keeps getting rediscovered: the quality of child care in America is mediocre at best," said Jay Belsky, a professor of human development at Pennsylvania State University who was not part of the study. "The mistake would be concluding that only parents can care for young children and that day care is inherently problematical. When high-quality stable care is provided, there is good evidence that children thrive."
The problem, Professor Belsky and others said, is that good care is so scarce.
The study was made public as debates intensify over whether the Federal Government should contribute to child care at all, and as Congress considers proposals to force welfare mothers to work, which would increase demand for child care.
In 1991, according to the Department of Labor, 58 percent of mothers with children under 6 were working, mostly full time. Among employed mothers with children under 5, 28 percent placed their children in child-care centers and a third used family day-care homes.
Last April, a study of family day care by the Families and Work Institute, a private research organization, also concluded that quality was so poor that in more than a third of the cases, children's development might suffer.
That study and this latest one found examples of high-quality child care when centers had more adults taking care of children, paid better wages and hired employees with training in how to care for children.
The study released yesterday also found that the highest-quality centers were those with access to extra money from Federal or state governments, universities or employers providing care at a work site. The study concluded that to provide higher quality care, centers had to spend about 10 percent more than those that provided mediocre care.
"What's new about this study is that it was done by economists as well as child psychologists, and what it says is that we know what to do with the money -- those centers that have more resources use them well," Ms. Reisman said.
But the study also noted that many parents either did not recognize quality child care or did not demand it. Ninety percent of the parents interviewed rated their child care as good, while the researchers found most poor or mediocre. Intense economic competition among centers means that most charge similar fees, regardless of quality.
The researchers found that states with stricter child-care regulations had more centers of higher quality.
To measure quality, the study used standards set by the National Association for the Education of Young Children. These include staffing ratios of 1 adult for every 3 to 4 infants, 1 adult for 4 or 5 2-year-olds and 1 adult for 8 to 10 4-year-olds. The Washington-based organization also calls on child-care providers to have a child-development certificate, which usually means a provider has had nine months of training.
The researchers recommended teaching parents how to evaluate quality child care, setting higher state child-care standards and providing more Federal and state money for child care.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Contract and a Job, But Very Little to Cheer

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J.

 BODY:
THE moment the 250 men had anticipated for a year and three months finally arrived Friday night.
"The time is 7:04," Luis Ginorio announced, as if for posterity. "We have a contract." 
 A contract! But no one cheered or clapped. It was so quiet in the smoke-choked union hall that you could hear someone squish a cigarette on the cracked linoleum tile. The workers who had their jobs back slowly filed out.
"The union is intact, and stronger," said Mr. Ginorio, a union administrator. But members of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union Locals 1733 and 1932 were tired. They had fought for one of the great unions, in the city that spawned the American labor movement. And they had paid for it.
Some members almost lost their houses. Marriages were strained, savings exhausted, holidays left uncelebrated.
They had been out on strike for only two months. Then they had been locked out of their jobs at 10 textile companies in Paterson and its surrounding towns for more than a year. When the union voted to return, unconditionally, management said no. Replacement workers had been hired for less pay. And some union members had given in and gone back as scabs.
To some people, it would seem the workers are back to square one. The contract they agreed to is almost the same as the one they had before. They were making approximately $13 an hour; now management has the option of cutting that by 80 cents. And they waived the right to sue for back pay.
BUT what they won was the right to keep their union, said Vince Falone, one of the die-hards. "Now they have to bargain with us as a group," he said.
CP Associates, the management bargaining group, began negotiating as it faced a Federal court injunction that would have required the 10 companies to take back the workers and pay millions in back pay, said a union lawyer, Joseph Fine.
"I don't think the employers were willing to bet the farm on that," Mr. Fine said. "I also think they were surprised at how resolute the unions were."
Mr. Falone was obviously proud. "Me? I was raised with unions. It's in my blood," he said. He began working in the textile dye houses in 1950. His father had worked in them in the 1930's. "My father used to take me to meetings when I was a kid," he said. "He was shot at during a strike."
His father had told him inspiring stories about "The Big One," the 1913 Paterson silk strike, and how it made labor and unions a celebrated cause.
"The union was family," Mr. Falone said. "I went to Korea and came back to work in the dye houses. It was coming home."
Mr. Falone applied for his pension during the strike, but continued to picket, he said. "They were trying to break us," he said. "They couldn't do it."
COMPANY bosses had been fighting Local 1733's leaders. Last February, the local's president and vice president, Joseph and Raymond LaBarck, were found guilty of extorting about $400,000 from employers to ensure labor peace. The LaBarck brothers, company lawyers said, called the October 1993 strike when their extortion demands went unmet.
But union members say the lockout never had to happen. When the strike began, union workers from 20 companies walked out. The workers, all represented by Locals 1733 and 1932, came from companies represented by two bargaining units, the Silk and Rayon Association and CP Associates. Within six weeks, the union negotiated a contract with the Silk and Rayon Association and its members returned to work.
CP Associates counts 300 workers who crossed the picket lines. Union representatives count about 250.
The National Labor Relations Board had determined that CP Associates had intimidated workers by threatening to fire them if they didn't resign from the union.
Most workers who crossed, Mr. Fine said, simply could not make ends meet. The union was able to give temporary jobs to between 40 and 70 of the locked-out workers, at $4 to $5 less an hour than they made at the textile companies. Some members collected unemployment.
Domingo Garcia, who began working for the dye houses in 1954, said he collected unemployment checks for about six months, then supported his wife and three children with savings. "Of course, that's gone now, too," he said with a chuckle. "I might celebrate what has happened now, but I don't have the means to celebrate. So I'll just go home."
The union would probably celebrate victory once workers returned to their jobs within the next 20 days, said Corrado Meola, a shop steward at Trio Dye in Paterson. "It was a struggle and a sacrifice," he said. "But in the end, we're all happy."

HEADLINE: Mr. Pataki's Port Authority Problem

 BODY:
The commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are growing uneasy about Gov. George Pataki's choice of George Marlin, a Conservative Party leader with no significant managerial experience, to be the agency's executive director. Their doubts are not misplaced. The commissioners should resist whatever pressure Mr. Pataki brings to bear and insist on a more obviously qualified nominee.
Of the 12 commissioners, 6 from each state, only 2 -- both appointed by former Gov. Mario Cuomo -- have said they will vote for Mr. Marlin. The others remain publicly uncommitted, though several have told The Times privately that they are troubled by Mr. Marlin's inexperience and by his narrow political focus. 
 With a budget of $2.7 billion, the Port Authority plays a critical role in the regional economy. It operates the three major metropolitan airports as well as bridges, tunnels, the PATH commuter trains, the World Trade Center and the seaport. Mr. Marlin's selection is a political payback to the Conservative Party, whose endorsement was crucial to Mr. Pataki's victory. The appointment may help him politically but it is not good government.
Mr. Pataki has done some worthy things since taking office, but doling out a large number of jobs on the basis of kinship or political ties is not one of them. The choice of Mr. Marlin is a particularly offensive act of patronage. The Port Authority needs a seasoned administrator who will approach controversial issues, like selling some of its major assets, with an open mind.
Mr. Pataki violated Port Authority etiquette by not consulting New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, before settling on Mr. Marlin. Although Mr. Pataki has since apologized, Ms. Whitman has yet to throw her support behind Mr. Marlin or to say whether she will urge her commissioners to support him. Her voice will count for a lot; she should raise it in opposition.
Both Governors have a lot on their plates. They do not need the distraction of a fight over Mr. Marlin. An important test of leadership is the willingness to admit a mistake. Mr. Pataki can meet that test by withdrawing Mr. Marlin's name and joining Ms. Whitman in a search for a demonstrably superior candidate.

HEADLINE: Poland: Frustrations of Democracy

 BODY:
For President Lech Walesa of Poland, leading a constitutional state has proved more frustrating than leading a revolution. He has been fighting with the elected parliamentary majority, a coalition of parties descended from the old Communist dictatorship, and now threatens to exercise his power to dissolve Parliament and force new legislative elections.
Though Mr. Walesa portrays himself as a beleaguered defender of market reform and democracy, many Poles see him as a clumsy and sometimes undemocratic maneuverer primarily seeking his own re-election this November. Winning will not be easy. The former electrician and Nobel laureate, who led the Solidarity union movement to power in the 1980's, must overcome abysmal poll numbers that reflect a reputation for erratic leadership. 
 Poland's bold economic reforms of the early 1990's are now producing impressive growth statistics. But ironically, the political heirs of the old Communist dictatorship, not Mr. Walesa, could become the main beneficiaries.
Mr. Walesa accuses the governing parties of endangering reform by delaying privatization and proposing an unsound budget. He warns that they tried to turn back the clock with a repressive press law and proposed an anti-Western ideologue as defense minister. These charges have some truth, and Mr. Walesa did, in fact, skillfully use his presidential powers to turn back the press law.
But most of his interventions have been inept. While faulting the government's economic program, he offers no clear alternative and has alarmed many with his own authoritarian tendencies. Last fall he supported a group of generals trying to undermine the civilian Defense Minister.
The electoral gains of the old left in Poland in 1993 are part of a trend in Eastern Europe. Voters exhausted by high inflation and unemployment have turned to reformed leftist parties promising fewer shocks and higher social welfare benefits. Similar platforms have brought leftists back to power in Lithuania, Hungary and Bulgaria. Delivering on these promises has proved harder than making them, and reforms have suffered.
It will take time for voters in these countries to sort out what they really want and who is capable of delivering it. Meanwhile, America's interest is in maintaining the possibility of democratic choices and respecting the choices the voters make as they gain experience in democratic life, sometimes finding their way through trial and error. Mr. Walesa would be wise to do the same. Constant confrontation is not always the best way to serve democracy.

HEADLINE: The President's Sensible Budget

 BODY:
The budget President Clinton released yesterday might seem tame by comparison with the government-gutting promises of Republicans. The President would wipe out no department or major program. He would not balance the budget, but instead projects $200 billion deficits as far as his budget officials can see. He barely nicks entitlement programs and achieves savings through hundreds of reasonable, though unexciting, spending reductions.
But the Administration's plan exudes common sense. The deficit would fall as a percentage of economic activity -- the best gauge of the Government's tug on private capital. By avoiding a mindless rush to balance, the President preserves valuable investments in education, training and research. His budget provides a worthy alternative to an expected Republican onslaught on government. 
 Goaded by the G.O.P., the President made his task harder by proposing tax credits, as previously announced, of up to $500 per child and up to $10,000 per family for education and job training. He exempted Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and defense -- more than half the budget -- from sizable cuts, forcing bigger cuts on everything else. The budget plan calls for spending over the next five years about $130 billion less than what it would cost to continue this year's Federal programs. Most of the service cuts would come out of housing, transportation, energy and other discretionary programs. Mr. Clinton would eliminate 131 mostly small programs, consolidate 271 others and cut the Federal payroll to the lowest level in 30 years.
The G.O.P. is likely to embrace nearly every one of Mr. Clinton's cuts and impose even more. The Administration will fight to preserve its national service, training and education initiatives. The President proposes "skill grants" for unemployed and low-paid workers to buy vocational training. He would spend more on early childhood education and nutrition, tuition grants for low-income families and a variety of programs to stimulate commercial technology. Investment in civilian infrastructure, research, education and training would rise from $136.6 billion this year to $137.8 billion next -- an increase that does not make up for inflation and that pales next to Mr. Clinton's election-year promise to boost investment by $50 billion a year. Yet he will be lucky to push even measly increases past Congress.
The President backed off from cutting Medicare and Medicaid, even though the two programs are projected to rise over 9 percent a year and account for about 40 percent of the increase in Federal spending over the next several years. Burned by last year's debacle over reform of private health insurance, he seems content to let the G.O.P. take on popular entitlements.
Some critics ridicule the Administration for a weak-kneed attack on the deficit. But lowering the deficit to 2 percent of domestic output, half its recent level, while preserving a modicum of public investment is a responsible turnabout.

HEADLINE: Orange County Offers Plan To Repay 77% to Investors

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif. Feb. 7

 BODY:
Officials of Orange County, Calif., offered today to give municipalities that had put money into the county's ill-fated investment pool 77 percent of their money back immediately, plus notes and liens that could result in full repayment within 15 years.
The settlement was approved by the county's five-member Board of Supervisors. It represents a first step toward resolving the conflicting demands of the 186 municipalities that invested in the county-run pool, which lost more than $1.7 billion through a risky investment strategy that failed. 
 Under the plan, the county would issue $255 million in 15-year recovery notes to cities, water and school districts and other public agencies invested in the pool. In addition, all investors would receive 77 cents for every dollar they had put into the pool. The county, since filing for bankruptcy protection on Dec. 6, has liquidated the pool.
Any settlement will have to be approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court judge, John E. Ryan. In addition, approval is needed from 80 percent of pool participants, excluding the county, said Orange County's bankruptcy lawyer, Bruce Bennett.
"We really do need a broad consensus to make this agreement work," Mr. Bennett said.
The proposed settlement gives preferential treatment to school districts, most of which were required by law to invest in the pool. They would receive recovery notes representing 13 percent of their investment -- 13 cents on the dollar -- along with the immediate cash and a claim against future proceeds from any litigation relating to the bankruptcy. Orange County is seeking $2 billion from Merrill Lynch & Company, which sold it the investments.
Other pool participants would get a different package. A greater percentage of the returns to these participants would come from future litigation proceeds.
In theory, all pool participants could eventually receive 100 percent of their investment back.
The settlement plan depends on whether investors will buy the county's recovery notes, which are taxable securities backed by Orange County's full faith and credit.
The notes' face value will specify a low rate of interest similar to that on many short-term securities. But the county said it would have the option of switching to a long-term rate. The notes pay interest only for eight years, then both principal and interest for a further seven years, according to the settlement plan.

HEADLINE: Clinton Rescue Plan Buoys The Price of Mexican Bonds

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Foreign and domestic investors showed signs of new-found confidence in Mexico's battered financial markets today as the Government succeeded in selling its first Treasury bonds since a new international rescue package was announced last week.
The interest rate on the 91-day bond, though still much higher than comparable rates in the United States, plunged nearly 10 percentage points in today's auction, to a yield of 15.40 percent, reflecting strong demand. Officials at the Mexican central bank said it was the largest one-time drop in percentage points ever for the Treasury bonds, which are called tesobonos. 
 Financial analysts in the United States and Mexico saw the steep drop in rates, and the rise in bond prices, as an indication that the international rescue package of about $50 billion announced by President Clinton last Tuesday was calming the market.
On Monday, the first $7.8 billion in funds from the package was deposited at the Mexican central bank. That raised the bank's international currency reserves to more than $11 billion and greatly eased worries that Mexico might not be able to pay off its short-term debts, especially for the tesobonos, which are indexed to the value of the dollar.
Mexico has more than $20 billion of the bonds falling due this year.
"This is the kind of positive signal the Mexican Government was looking for," said Luis R. Luis, chief of emerging-markets research at Scudder, Stevens & Clark in Boston. "Interest rates have an important role as a signal of confidence in Mexico."
Mr. Luis, however, was reluctant to read too much significance into today's auction. He said the Government was extremely conservative in offering only $240 million worth of bonds, about half what had been offered at recent weekly auctions. In addition, last week's auction was canceled because market conditions were so depressed before the international package was announced.
"They wanted to have a manageable auction this week that would be highly successful because that was what the market expected," Mr. Luis said.
Interest rates for the 182-day Treasury bond also dipped about 10 percentage points. But the yield on the 364-day bond did not vary much, remaining slightly above 20 percent.
Stephen P. Dexter, a portfolio manager at the Kemper International Fund in Chicago, said that the high rates for the longer bonds indicated that many investors continued to be wary of the Mexican market.
"Investors may be willing to creep back in for above-average yields on the short end, but they are not that confident yet to go for 364-day paper," Mr. Dexter said. "You still could easily see rates go back up at future auctions if, politically, things look less stable than they are now."
Mr. Dexter noted that many United States investors continued to stay out of Mexican stocks, as well, worried about the effect of the devaluation of the peso on company earnings and the Government's ability to control inflation. The Mexican stock market drifted again today, with its main index slipping 1.72 points -- just under one-tenth of 1 percent -- to close at 1,962.26.
The peso held steady, at 5.335 to the dollar.
Analysts said it appeared that European investors had led the charge to buy the Mexican bonds today, with United States investors preferring to stay on the sidelines.
Alexander Anderson, research director at Abaco, a Mexico City brokerage firm, expressed optimism that today's bond auction marked a clear turnaround in Mexico's financial markets.
"Obtaining the $50 billion meant that Mexico's problems are probably over," Mr. Anderson said. "I know that's not the perception on Wall Street. But I think that all we have now is a problem of perception, not of economic or financial reality."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Drops on Worries About a Slowing Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper prices tumbled yesterday as traders saw demand for the metal easing with slowing economic growth.
Natural gas and cotton prices also fell sharply, dragging the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities down 0.43 point, to 231.51. Lumber prices rose strongly. 
 Wheat prices surged on signs of stronger export demand. The White House announced that the Agriculture Department would soon offer China new export subsidies for purchases of American wheat despite a trade dispute between the two countries. On the Chicago Board of Trade, March wheat rose 3.5 cents, to $3.7325 a bushel.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, copper for March delivery fell 2.35 cents, to $1.2945 a pound.
Copper prices peaked last month, but since then higher interest rates in the United States and dimmer prospects in China have put pressure on prices.
"The reason for the copper rally was strength in North America and China, so the market is quite soberly looking at its two bulwarks being cut down a little bit," said James Steel of Refco Inc., a large Chicago-based commodities brokerage firm.
March natural gas deliveries fell 11.7 cents, to $1.421 for 1,000 cubic feet, on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders took profits from a four-day rally that had raised prices 20.1 cents, or 15 percent.
In other energy trading, the March crude oil contract fell 13 cents, to $18.46 a barrel, and March heating oil slipped 0.07 cent, to 49.13 cents a gallon. March unleaded gasoline fell 0.31 cent, to 56.99 cents a gallon.
March cotton plunged 1.64 cents, to 90.28 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange, continuing its pattern of working lower in violent lurches since reaching a 14-year high of 94.7 cents Jan. 30.
Lumber prices jumped the permitted daily limit on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, possibly reflecting fears of a possible rail strike in Canada. Spruce 2-by-4's for March delivery jumped $10, to $325 for 1,000 board feet.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Sell China More Wheat Despite Trade Rift

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Three days after imposing record sanctions on China for its piracy of American-made movies and software, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would expand subsidized wheat sales to Beijing, rather than let European farmers win a bigger share of the Chinese market.
The move points up the complexity of trying to punish a major trading partner even as the Government grapples with protecting the interests of American businesses that are trying to gain a larger foothold there. 
 Indeed, the decision was approved by Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, who imposed the sanctions against China on Saturday. It means that China will pay about $20 million less for its new purchases of one million metric tons than it would if it bought the wheat on the commercial market.
"It may sound strange but this is for the benefit of U.S. farmers, not for the Chinese," Mr. Kantor said. "We want to build our market share in China. So you have to go after them with a scalpel, not a hatchet."
In fact, when Mr. Kantor announced more than $1 billion in sanctions against China on Saturday, he carefully excluded a number of Chinese-made products from punitive tariffs, for fear of hurting American companies. There was no punitive tariff placed on toys, for example, so that American retailers would not be harmed. There was no tariff placed on electronic components, because American computer makers feared they would be put at a disadvantage to their Japanese competitors.
But the wheat subsidy for China is bound to raise questions among those who have contended that American policy is inconsistent. They contend that the penalties announced with such fanfare on Saturday are being eroded by tariff cuts and trade concessions in other areas. On Jan. 1, for example, the United States included China in a list of nations that would no longer have to pay tariffs on a range of goods imported to the United States, including toys. By some estimates, China's savings from those cuts will amount to $2 billion, or twice the size of the sanctions imposed last week.
Under the conventions of trade law, the United States had no choice but to cut those tariffs, because of President Clinton's decision last year to extend "most favored nation" trade status to China. That status means that China receives all trade benefits accorded to any other American trading partner.
Australia's Ambassador to the United States, Don Russell, was among the first to criticize the Administration's decision today. "It seems a bit strange if you are trying to be a bit stiff with the Chinese that you offer them cheaper-than-cheap wheat," Mr. Russell said. "It is a big gift to the recipient."
Mr. Russell was speaking from considerable self-interest: Australia does not subsidize its wheat sales, and has argued that its farmers are badly harmed by the subsidy war between the United States and Europe. American officials, however, said Australia had no more wheat left to sell to China this year.
Since July 1, the United States has subsidized the purchase of three million metric tons of wheat by China and has agreed to finance additional amounts after that.
The Agriculture Department is authorized to spend up to $800 million on the wheat subsidy in the current fiscal year. Under President Clinton's new budget that figure would rise to $959 million.
For years, farm groups, legislators from farm states and the Agriculture Department have contended that the export subsidies are needed as long as other nations subsidize their own grain sales. The amount of the subsidies will be kept in check, however, under the new version of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that was passed by Congress last year. The agreement, which will be supervised by the new World Trade Organization, calls for subsidies to decline gradually.
Moreover, the value of the subsidies has fallen significantly in the last year because the market for wheat has been quite tight -- meaning that farmers have less of a need for government help. Still, some economists say that American consumers are the biggest losers from the program, because the subsidies, by expanding the market for wheat, have the effect of raising the price of grain on the American market.
Over the last year, the unified political front put forth to defend the subsidies has begun to crack. The North American Grain Export Association, a trade group for companies that sell American grain abroad, called last year for an end to the program. The export companies contend that the subsidies actually hamper the effort of American farmers to prepare for tougher competition as markets are made freer.
Mr. Kantor, in an interview today, said that the apparent contradiction in the Government's trade policy was no contradiction at all. The reality of the marketplace, he said, is that "you have to pick your punitive actions with surgical precision."
"In this business, you have to walk and chew gum at the same time," he said. "You can't be a slave to a false notion of consistency that is not in our interest."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of United States Treasury securities ended slightly higher yesterday, as the Government embarked on the first leg of its big quarterly auction with the sale of $17 billion in new three-year notes.
The 30-year bond was up 1/32 , to a price of 9812/32 for a yield of 7.64 percent, unchanged from Monday. Rates on shorter-maturity bills improved an average three basis points, with the rate for a three-month bill at 5.78 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 The credit for keeping investors bullish went to comments from a Fed official who said that the economy was nearing the slower growth that the central bank has been aiming for by raising interest rates. Traders said those comments helped to lift the market early, lending credence to the view of some that the Fed may be near the end of its interest raising cycle.
A Federal Reserve Board governor, John P. LaWare, speaking before the Washington Community Reinvestment Association in Everett, Wash., late Monday afternoon, said, "We may be at the cusp of what we're trying to accomplish." His comments were made too late Monday to have an impact on the New York Treasuries market.
Mr. LaWare also said that it was too early to tell if the Fed was through raising rates and that coming economic data would be the key in helping the Fed decide if and when to raise rates again. But, some analysts said, these remarks may have been ignored.
"Believe it or not, there are actually people out there who think the Fed is done tightening," said James Hale, fixed-income analyst for MMS International in San Francisco. But, he added, there have been several times since the Fed began raising interest rates a year ago when the market has misinterpreted Fed comments.
At the three-year note auction, the yield was 7.34 percent, about where everyone had expected it would be, up from the last three-year note auction. The decline in prices after the auction, Mr. Hale said, was merely the result of dealers selling in an effort to push down prices ahead of today's auction of 10-year notes and tomorrow's 30-year bond sale.
The Treasury also announced plans to sell $9 billion of previously announced cash management bills this Thursday to meet short-term borrowing needs beyond the cash raised through securities sold at the Government's regularly scheduled auctions. The minimum denomination for the sale is $1 million.
Today's $12 billion auction of 10-year notes should do well, Mr. Hale said, because the market is "decidedly bullish." He said he believed that many fund managers had a lot of cash on hand and may put the money to work this week.
Traders said a positive nonfarm productivity report also helped to underpin market strength, but only marginally.
Productivity rose by 1.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1994, a big gain by any standard, but especially good considering their stage of the business cycle, accordinbg to Christopher A. Low, senior economist for the HSBC Group in New York. "It's certainly a good sign that this far into the business cycle you continue to see such large gains in productivity," Mr. Low said. "It indicates that business is keeping costs down and avoiding inflation."
In the municipal market, prices rose for the third consecutive day, pushing yields to their lowest level in five months, as supply fell short of demand.
Yesterday's largest scheduled negotiated offering, a $186 million sale of hospital and nursing home mortgage revenue bonds by the New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency, went well.
The scarcity of new issues allowed the New York bonds' yields to be lowered at least 10 basis points, instead of having to raise yields to attract investors.

HEADLINE: U.S. Productivity Grows For Fifth Year in Row

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
American business productivity improved in 1994 for the fifth consecutive year, pushed up by the largest growth in output since 1984, the Labor Department reported today. At the same time, businesses held labor costs to the smallest gain in 30 years.
The Government also reported that consumer credit grew in December at its slowest pace in five months. 
 Productivity -- defined as output per number of hours worked -- jumped 2.2 percent last year, faster than the 1.5 percent advance in 1993, the Labor Department said. It was the fifth straight annual gain since productivity fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in 1989.
Businesses held growth in unit labor costs, which typically account for two-thirds of the cost of a product, to nine-tenths of 1 percent, the smallest increase since an eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in 1964. Costs have tapered off each year since 1990, when they rose 5.1 percent.
"It says there is very little risk of inflationary pressures building," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist with Morgan Stanley & Company.
Economists watch growth in productivity for clues regarding long-term economic trends. Productivity is an indicator of the nation's living standards and the competitiveness of its products overseas. Strong productivity is likely to hold off inflationary pressures.
Some analysts maintain that growth in productivity will slow and possibly decline as companies continue to add workers and the current business cycle continues.
Others, like Mr. Roach, disagree.
"Employers are getting more out of their workers by re-engineering existing manufacturing and service processes, by using more information technology and by outsourcing," Mr. Roach said.
"It's all part and parcel of the productivity revolution of 1990's," he added, "and I believe it's ongoing."
Growth in productivity slowed to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.8 percent in the final three months of 1994, from a strong 3.2 percent in the previous quarter.
Output jumped 5.2 percent last year, compared with a 4.1 percent increase in 1993. It was the largest increase since an 8.2 percent surge in 1984, when the Government began keeping output records.
Manufacturing productivity rose 4.9 percent in 1994, compared with a 3.2 percent advance in 1993.
Total business productivity, including farming, increased 2.3 percent, up from 1.5 percent in 1993. Business productivity rose 1.7 percent in the fourth quarter.
Separately, the Federal Reserve said today that outstanding consumer credit rose $7.4 billion in December to $911.2 billion.
The Fed said installment debt climbed at an annual rate of 9.8 percent in December, the slowest rate in five months, compared with 16.5 percent in the previous month and 15.9 percent in October.
Analysts are predicting a slowdown in consumer spending and debt this year, but the sharp drop-off in December was not expected by economists.
Consumer credit includes all household debt not secured by real estate. The totals are adjusted for seasonal variations.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "U.S. Productivity" shows index of output per hour of all people in nonfarm businesses from '90-'1994. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances as Traders React to Rise in Bond Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar gained against most leading currencies yesterday, helped by an early rally in the American bond market.
"The bond market is showing constructive gains, and as long as that happens the dollar will hang in there," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. 
 Bond prices retreated later in the day, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond ending the day unchanged at 7.64 percent. Yields and prices move in opposite directions. Strong demand for United States securities often helps the dollar because foreign investors buy them with dollars. The dollar also backed off earlier gains.
The dollar rose as high as 1.5378 German marks yesterday, its highest level since Jan. 17. In New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.5365 marks, up from 1.5308 marks on Monday. The dollar edged up to 99.44 Japanese yen from 99.41 and rose to 1.3025 Swiss francs from 1.2944 francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5565 from $1.5590.
Bond prices surged in early trading on a growing belief that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to raise interest rates again soon with inflation under control. Traders and analysts said this perception was confirmed by comments from a Fed official.
John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor, told a conference in Everett, Wash., late Monday that the Fed "may be at the cusp of what we're trying to accomplish" by raising rates to control inflation.
Mr. LaWare said that while he could not rule out the possibility of more rate increases, the Fed was wary of pushing the economy into recession.
Mr. Lawrie at Mellon Bank said: "We used to think rate increases helped the dollar. Now the prospect of no increases helps the bonds, and that helps the dollar."
The dollar's recent gains have been pronounced against the German mark as investors see less need to use the mark as a safe haven from riskier markets, analysts said.
Many investors flocked to the mark last month as the financial crisis in Mexico deepened, raising concern about the fate of other emerging markets. The Mexican peso, stable yesterday at 5.335 pesos to the dollar, has fallen 35 percent since the Government devalued the currency in December.
"We're continuing to see a flow out of the Deutsche mark against other European currencies," and that has benefited the dollar, said Jim Raphael, a currency trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City.
