HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Everybody Is Shut Out at the White House Talks

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
At the end of the White House night game, it was Players 2, Owners 1. Except there were no winners -- not the players, not the owners, not the President.
By the time player and ownership groups left the White House, where they had waded through the most unusual negotiating session in baseball labor history, they had no agreement because the two ideas the players agreed to the owners rejected and the one idea the owners accepted the players rejected. 
 Neither was happy about the other's actions, and their departure left the talks in chaos and confusion. No one knew where they were headed next. The players didn't say what their immediate plans were, but the owners' negotiating team was planning to leave Wednesday.
No one knew either if Bill Usery Jr. would remain the mediator of the impossible dispute. It seemed highly unlikely.
Asked whether Usery had outlived his usefulness, Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said at a late-night news conference: "I will make no comments. I will speak to him tomorrow."
But a few moments earlier, Fehr said that the owners' disclosure of some of the details of Usery's suggestions was damaging.
"The clubs knew that by disclosing these ideas," Fehr said, "it becomes very difficult for Mr. Usery to remain involved."
Usery's status was in doubt because he had enraged the players by making a series of suggestions or proposals or recommendations that they felt were far closer to the owners' positions than theirs. That, the players believed, was why the owners agreed to accept the mediator's ideas, including a 50 percent tax on portions of payrolls above $40 million.
The players, on the other hand, accepted the idea of binding arbitration that was put forward by Vice President Gore and that President Clinton plans to send to Congress Wednesday. They also were prepared to play the 1995 season, another Administration suggestion, while a Presidential fact-finding commission developed matters to be used for negotiations for a new agreement following the season.
The clubs, Fehr said, did say they would agree to binding arbitration on the level of a payroll tax if the players agreed to the remainder of Usery's suggestions. The players rejected that idea, saying they wanted to submit all of the issues to binding arbitration.
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, who has spent little time in the talks but arrived here Monday and led the management contingent to the White House, and others among his group explained that the parties should negotiate their own agreement and not have one imposed by Congress or an arbitrator.
"Binding arbitration is not the solution to this dispute and we reject the idea," Selig said. "For one thing, Congress has made it clear it is not prepared to consider the necessary legislation." He added that the clubs did not want to "put the future of Major League Baseball and its 28 franchises at risk under such a precedure."
The clubs rejected the fact-finding idea, they said, because baseball has had enough studies performed on it and another commission would uncover nothing new. On the other hand, they said, Usery had been involved in the strike for four months and knew the issues intimately.
If anyone knew how to arrive at a reasonable and fair compromise, it was Usery, they said.
But Fehr vehemently disagreed, citing Usery's responses to questions about his payroll tax proposal.
"We asked him how much would be raised by the tax, who gets it, what does it do to players' salaries," Fehr said. "He said: 'I don't know. I'm not an expert in economics and I don't understand the stuff.' "
Union officials said Usery's 50 percent tax would cost the players $1 billion in salaries over the six years of the proposed agreement.
Among the Usery ideas the players objected to was the plan to grant service credit for the 52 days of the strike but the credit would be limited for 24 players whose service status in terms of years would change. In other words, Jack McDowell, who needs 19 days to become a free agent, would not be granted that status.
"We were mystified by the one-sidedness of the proposals and felt somebody was playing politics," Lauren Rich, a union lawyer, said. "If this is a balanced proposal, the owners ought to be prepared to support it in binding arbitration. We think it's totally unsupportable. Usery could not give us justification for the proposals."
Selig said that by not accepting the mediator's suggestions, the union showed it was not interested in compromise.
"The proposal is far from perfect," he said. "It's generous to the players; it requires clubs to make concessions. This compromise proposal is a step in the right direction."
Usery proposed that the 1995 season be played under the system, except for the pension plan, that had been in effect before the clubs implemented a salary cap Dec. 23.
In 1996, he said, salary arbitration should be eliminated for players with four and five years of major league service and they be made unrestricted free agents instead. In 1997, salary arbitration would be eliminated for three-year players and the 17 percent of the two-year class that qualifies now. Those players would not be granted free agency.
Fehr said he was surprised by the mediator's suggestions, although he said Usery told the players they were not final or formal.
David Cone, one of five players who attended the White House evening, said the players would be prepared to campaign for Clinton's binding-arbitration bill.
"If the American people call their representatives and they want this," the Kansas City pitcher said, "and Congress wants to do the right thing, the players can put the uniforms back on and we can let the lawyers and experts take this case over because that's what really should happen here. We're baseball players. We want to play baseball. We want to put the uniforms on. If this issue is so damn complicated, maybe the lawyers should be in binding arbitration and the players should be on the field."

HEADLINE: Paroled Rapist Is Charged In Sex Attacks in Bronx

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC 

 BODY:
A string of sexual attacks in the Bronx was carried out by a man who was paroled from prison a year ago after serving 13 years for rape, the police said yesterday.
At the time he carried out the attacks, they said, the man was dutifully checking in with his parole officer and even attending required rape counseling sessions. 
 Parole officers had told the police that the suspect, Johnny Rosado, lived in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, near the Parkchester complex, where several attacks took place. But the police did not connect him to the assaults until last weekend.
When he was questioned on Sunday, he was released because investigators lacked probable cause for his arrest. It was not until Monday, when two private security guards saw him trying to get into an apartment building by pushing several buzzers, that he was finally arrested, the police said.
The police said Mr. Rosado, 40, who is unemployed and lives at 1936 East Tremont Avenue, would typically corner women inside apartment building elevators and force them at knife-point onto the roof, where he would rape or sodomize them.
The suspect, who had been in prison since 1980 on a rape and sodomy conviction, was released on parole in January 1994, and had been checking in weekly with his parole officer, said David Ernst, a spokesman for the State Division of Parole. According to the terms of his release, he was also regularly attending counseling for sex offenders.
"Under law, he was held as long as he could be held," Mr. Ernst said, adding that Mr. Rosado had been released early for good behavior.
The police said that even though parole officials notified them of his presence in the neighborhood, Mr. Rosado was not caught earlier because victims' descriptions of the rapist did not fit the suspect's profile closely enough.
After his arrest on Monday, victims in three of the eight Bronx attacks picked him out of a lineup and photo array, said Detective Kim Royster, a police spokeswoman, who added that the victims, all women, ranged in age from 16 to 28. She said investigators had evidence linking Mr. Rosado to all eight incidents, which she said occurred between Jan. 8 and Feb. 5.
Imprisoned in 1980 on charges that carried a sentence of 9 to 18 years, Mr. Rosado became eligible for parole in 1988 but was denied release four times before he accumulated enough "good behavior" time to earn his release, Mr. Ernst said.
Prisoners in New York state prisons earn a day of good-behavior time for every two days spent in prison if they stay out of trouble, Mr. Ernst said. The accumulated time is deducted from prisoners' maximum sentences, though they are placed on parole after release.
On Monday, the two plainclothes security guards approached Mr. Rosado after they spotted him pressing doorbells at random in what was apparently an attempt to gain entrance to 1430 Parkchester Road, one of 172 brown-brick apartment buildings that house some 40,000 people in the sprawling Parkchester Condominium complex just north of the Cross Bronx Expressway.
"It seemed he was just waiting for an opportunity," said Dennis Cowan, director of security at the Parkchester Condominiums, describing how the two guards watched Mr. Rosado enter the apartment building and stand in the foyer. "He told the security officers that he was waiting for a friend. At that point they asked what apartment, and he couldn't answer."
Mr. Rosado tried to flee when the security officers escorted him from the building, Mr. Cowan said. "My guys grabbed him and brought him down," he said. "The Police Department came in and assisted us at that point."
Detective Royster said Mr. Rosado was charged with three counts of sodomy and two counts of rape, as well as sexual abuse, robbery, criminal possession of a weapon and criminal trespass.
"His method of operation was to follow his female victims into elevators," she said. "Once the elevator reached an upper floor, he would force his victims out of the elevator at knife-point or by choking them from behind to the roof top. There he would engage in sexual or deviate sexual intercourse."
"Money and jewelry were taken in several incidents," the detective said, adding that the arresting officers did not find a knife in Mr. Rosado's possession when he was arrested.
Residents at Parkchester Condominiums expressed dismay that neither the police nor the complex's management notified them of the rapes.
"I didn't hear anything," said 17-year-old Rose Clair, a high school student at the Bronx Outreach Center who lives at 1430 Parkchester Road and was visibly shaken when she heard that the suspect was seized just inside the doorway to her building. "I'm angry," she said. "It's wrong, but I'm glad they caught the guy."
Mr. Cowan said Parkchester managers were considering posting notices about the rapes on the day Mr. Rosado was arrested.
"Rape has not been a serious problem here," said Mr. Cowan, adding that the Police Department informed him only on Friday that they were pursuing a serial rapist in the area.

HEADLINE: United Nations Reports Serbian Helicopter Sorties in Bosnia, a Violation of Flight Ban

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Serbian helicopters flew a large number of sorties into eastern Bosnia and Herzegovina last week in violation of a United Nations ban, the Security Council was told today.
A total of 62 helicopters flying too low for aerial surveillance were spotted by United Nations observers on the ground on Wednesday through Saturday north of the Muslim enclave of Srebrenica, a representative of the United Nations Secretary General told the Council. The representative, Undersecretary General Chinmaya Gharekhan, said that one large contingent was flying in military formation. 
 The westward flight of 15 helicopters in formation from Serbia into Bosnia was reported by Dutch observers over the weekend; the fuller tally was collected since then.
Those flights, along with sporadic helicopter sorties into northwestern Bosnia from Serb-held areas of Croatia, have raised concerns here that the Bosnian Serbs are being resupplied with ammunition and spare parts during a four-month truce in their war with Bosnian Government forces.
The United States, already exasperated by the Bosnian Serbs' refusal to accept an international peace plan while the truce is in force, is pressing Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali for a thorough investigation into the flights.
The flights near Srebrenica are thought to have originated at Surcin or other military airfields in Serbia under the control of the Yugoslav Army. Mr. Gharekhan told reporters that there was no absolute proof that the flights originated in Serbia, in part because United Nations observers were barred from monitoring radar at airfields near the border last week.
"But the fact that there were a large number of helicopter flights, that is an established fact," he said.
If the helicopter flights into eastern Bosnia are traced to fields in Serbia, they could place the Belgrade Government in clear violation of a United Nations ban on military flights over Bosnia. The sorties would also violate a promise by the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, to prevent all supplies except relief goods from reaching Bosnian Serbs across his border.
A formal report from the Secretary General confirming any violation of Serbia's pledge could lead to the automatic reimposition of economic sanctions against Yugoslavia for its role in aiding the Bosnian Serb combatants.
In September, the Security Council eased sanctions involving cultural exchanges, participation in international sports events and access to the Belgrade airport and the port of Bar to reward Mr. Milosevic for his willingness to cut supply lines to the Bosnian Serbs.
The United States is demanding to know why United Nations observers were barred from Serbian airfields at a critical time.
Washington is reported to have some unspecified independent evidence, officials here say, that the flights originated in Serbia, which with Montenegro makes up what is left of Yugoslavia.
Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, left for a meeting at the White House today after hearing the report from the Secretary General's representative.
The stepped-up American activity in the Security Council comes as the Clinton Administration, making another turn in its Bosnia policy, said it would end official contacts with the Bosnian Serbs' political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his associates because of their continuing refusal to accept the internationally brokered peace proposal.
"There is no point in shuttling up the hill from Sarajevo to Pale to listen to the kind of crap which is dished out by Karadzic," Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke said in an interview Monday with the National Public Radio program "All Things Considered."
He added that Dr. Karadzic would not be invited to a conference of Balkan leaders being planned by France, unless the Bosnian Serbs accept the peace proposal. The peace plan, intended as a foundation for negotiations, would reduce the territory captured by the Serbs to 49 percent from 70 percent.
In a statement issued in Belgrade, the Yugoslav Army General Staff called the reports of flights "primitive fabrications" and denied any violation of the no-flight zone in Bosnia.
In the Security Council, President Milosevic is getting some support from Russia, a traditional ally of the Serbs. The Russian position that has emerged over the last day or two is that there is no reason to act precipitously on incomplete evidence against Serbia.
On the matter of barring United Nations monitors from radar sites and bases, the Russians say that President Milosevic never promised free access and allowed it only as a gesture of good will.
Although the truce, negotiated in December by former President Jimmy Carter, has been holding in much of Bosnia, the situation around the northwestern Muslim enclave of Bihac has remained tense, United Nations officials said today.
The area's 180,000 people are running desperately short of food supplies, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today in Geneva.
Food shipments are being restricted because Fikret Abdic, a rebel Muslim leader opposing the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, has demanded 50 percent of the aid cargoes, a demand the United Nations has rejected. Troops loyal to Mr. Abdic, along with armed Serbs from Croatia, are also barring relief convoys from some of the safest roads, forcing them to take more perilous routes.
The impunity with which Serbs have crossed from areas under United Nations protection in Croatia to join in fighting against Bosnian Government forces has also angered the Croatian Government. Last month Croatia asked United Nations forces to leave its territory, arguing that the peacekeepers were only making life easier for Croatian Serbs and thereby enabling them to defy both the Croatian and Bosnian governments.
Today the Security Council formally called on Croatia to reconsider its request. Many diplomats here fear that the withdrawal of United Nations forces from Croatia will lead to a widening of war in the former Yugoslavia. Reports that helicopters may be ferrying arms for coming battles have only deepened such concern.
"We're in a very ironic situation," Mr. Holbrooke said on Monday. "Things have not been as peaceful in the Balkans in years as they are today, and yet we are one spark away from a much wider war, and that spark could come in either Croatia or Bosnia."

HEADLINE: The New Volunteers -- A special report.;
Program With 60's Spirit Butts Against 95's

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Feb. 1

 BODY:
On New Year's Eve, Kerri Goncher packed up her 1987 Toyota Supra in Chicago and drove here in 34 hours straight to begin teaching the severely emotionally disturbed and sometimes violent children who end up at the Little Canyon Center run by the Arizona Baptist Children's Services. She will earn $4.50 an hour plus an annual $4,725 educational grant.
Ms. Goncher's bouncy enthusiasm for a low-wage public service job may be just what President Clinton had in mind for the Americorps public service program.
In its first five months of operation, the program has placed 20,000 Americans like Ms. Goncher, a recent University of Wisconsin graduate who hopes to become a teacher, in a wide variety of public service jobs tutoring children, serving as police cadets, repairing housing projects and monitoring contamination of rivers in 350 programs around the country. 
 Mr. Clinton has hailed the program as perhaps his proudest achievement and one that is already "changing the way that government works." In his proposed budget for the fiscal year 1996, he is asking $812.5 million out of a $1.6 trillion budget to finance 47,000 Americorps members.
Congressional Republicans are threatening to kill Americorps, calling it a costly throwback to an era of big government. Some say that it will make it harder to recruit volunteers without incentives and that it is unnecessary because many participants will just get government assistance to do what they would have done anyway.
And instead of Mr. Clinton's hope that Americorps would evoke the spirit of the Kennedy years, when the Peace Corps drew instinctive support, Americorps has come to reflect the opposite: the anti-government ethic and budget roadblocks now facing almost any new Federal program.
With its self-consciously businesslike name as the Corporation for National Service, its bottom-up structure controlled by state commissions appointed by mostly Republican governors, and its scaled-down stipend, the program was designed as a public service program for an anti-government era.
"I like to think of our role as an investment banker investing in local communities, rewarding the programs doing well with growth possibilities and making sure those not working are not refunded," said Eli Segal, who heads the program and has the title of chief executive. "This is a like a start-up business, designed with the support of moderate Republicans, which believes that delivery systems as close as possible to the customer will bear fruit in terms of quality."
But, businesslike oratory aside, Congressional Republicans say Americorps is just another government program at a time the nation needs fewer of them.
"If you're going to get to a balanced budget and your choice is having a nice little government bureaucracy that runs people around the country doing nice things or taking care of people with severe disabilities," Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, said in a recent interview, "where is each one on the priority list?
"It just strikes me that on any reasonable list that gets to a balanced budget, this is a long way below the line of what doesn't survive."
In his Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton advertised his proposal for a national service program as a way to help students pay for their education while serving their country and being imbued with the spirit of service to others. Interviews with Americorps members and organizations that employ them indicate that the program is already creating extraordinary interest among young people and tapping into a nascent spirit of public service on college campuses.
But they also indicate that it could be difficult for the program to meet the most exacting standards for selfless activism that some will hold it to and that the timing of the program could not be worse, given the budget realities in Washington.
"I really think that as long as the government is going to play some role, this is the best way they can do it, and that you can use a program like this to jump start a lot of positive activity for very little money," said H. Daniels Duncan, president of the United Way in nearby Mesa, where six Americorps workers are putting together what organizers hope will be a network of 3,000 community volunteer workers. "The issue is, Is a little money too much money right now?"
 
The Beginning
A Network Of Activists

Americorps formally began last September with a $376 million budget for 20,000 participants. The budget for the fiscal year 1995 is $580 million for 33,000 members.
Participants receive a small living allowance, approximately the minimum wage, limited health care coverage and child care, plus a $4,725 tuition grant for each year of service -- about 1,700 hours of work. People can serve for two years and get a maximum tuition grant of $9,450, which can be used for current or future college costs or to repay existing loans.
Americorps incorporates some existing programs like Vista. It is separate from the Job Corps, which provides job training ever year for about 65,000 disadvantaged young people.
Americorps is producing an enormous variety of public service work, much of it historical social service activity, some of it reflecting current conservative trends.
In New Orleans, the Youth Action Corps founded by Americorps works on projects as diverse as wetlands preservation and tutoring in low-income areas. The South Carolina Victim Assistance Network works with crime victims and advocates for victims rights in law-enforcement centers, shelters and crisis centers around the state.
At what is called the SalmonCore program, students from the Yakima Indian Nation in Washington State are cleaning out polluted settling ponds at a former Department of Energy site to grow fish to help replenish the dwindling salmon run in the Columbia River.
In the New York area, activities include tutoring and mentoring disadvantaged young people through the I Have A Dream Foundation and working as cadets in the Police Cadet Program of the New York City Police Department.
In Iowa, Sarah and Rebekah Swan, 19-year-old twins, are members, Sarah working at a Family Violence Center in Des Moines, Rebekah at the Alzheimers Association of America in Cedar Rapids.
Donald Davis, 45, a carpenter and painter, decided after 14 years in the Army that he wanted to work with young people. He is now working at two elementary schools in Florence, S.C., organizing social service projects for youngsters.
Michael Davis, a student at Eastern Michigan University, and Michelle Cooper, a student at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, tutor as part of the program. In Boulder, Colo., Pakou Cha, a University of Colorado student who speaks Hmong, Spanish and English, tutors children, many of whom speak little or no English, at the San Juan del Centro Family Learning Center.
The program's goal has been to provide opportunities for as diverse a group as possible, from the Ivy League graduates who once might have joined the Peace Corps to high school dropouts working on their general equivalency degree and trying to stay out of trouble.
"I had thought of being an architect, but it was like a fading dream," said Timothy Moore, an 18-year-old high school dropout and former gang member in New Orleans. "Americorps really changed my life. It gave me good things to think about."
 
The Mechanics
Conservatism And Public Service

The program in Arizona reflects Americorp's structure and scope -- from working on environmental issues with Navajo elders to passing out condoms and pamphlets about sexually transmitted diseases in Tucson's red-light district.
Programs are selected by a 25-member board appointed by Gov. Fife Symington, a conservative Republican, and headed by Lieut. Col. Gary Smith, who works in the anti-drug program of the National Guard.
Most participants, like Ms. Goncher, augment existing operations. The most ambitious new project spawned by Americorps is the Border Volunteer Corps, a $2.6 million program with 103 Americorps members working in 25 projects along the border.
Richard H. Carter, the program's director, said, "There is a new park now, immunized children, trained migrant farm workers, people working in environmental programs, community gardens, new homes in the Indian nations, restored homes."
But Republican critics in Washington say that its incentives will draw people from other volunteer activity, that it is more expensive than the government is saying and that in the end it is not true volunteerism but a government job.
"All those volunteer programs that have been working so beautifully cannot compete with this type of program," said Representative Bill Goodling, the Pennsylvania Republican who is the new head of the House Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee. "You really kill volunteerism with a program like this."
Social service organizations here and elsewhere scoff at the idea that Americorps will have a negative impact on volunteerism.
"We've had a lot of volunteers, but most don't last more than a day or two," said Maggi Castagna, education coordinator at Little Canyon Center, which has about 36 emotionally disturbed students ranging in age from 6 to 17, and where Ms. Goncher augments the three teachers and three technicians. "They just find that these kids are out of their league."
On the other hand, it is less clear how much Americorps is creating new public service workers and how much it is just creating a more attractive environment for people who would be doing similar work.
In Arizona, Jennifer Larkin, 25, was holding down three part-time positions with the Y.M.C.A., working with children before and after school and in the 118-degree heat at summer camp. "I really felt I was being used," she said.
Now she gets her health care covered and the educational grant helping to organize volunteer programs for Parents Anonymous, which works to prevent child abuse and neglect.
Dorothy Cuppernell, 20, whose husband is with the United States Army in South Korea, originally got into the Americorps program in North Carolina because it was one of the few options available to a young mother that provided day care.
She said her first position was at a school where she barely felt needed. Now, in Phoenix, she is at Tumbleweed, a small social service agency that runs shelters and group homes for teen-age runaways. And the program pays $75 of the $99-a-week child care cost for her 3-year-old daughter.
Barbara Tenes, 27, who works at another Tumbleweed shelter, was previously a youth-care worker for another social service agency and joined Americorps partly because of the opportunity for child care for her four children. Americorps has a maximum amount it will pay for child care and she is still waiting to find out how much the state will pick up to see if she can afford to stay in the program.
"I'm doing basically what I was doing before," she said.
The majority of Americorps members are young people without children or with minimal interest in health insurance.
"There's not enough money in this to do it unless you really want to serve," Ms. Goncher said.
But, in the current budget-cutting environment, critics say, it is likely that unless the program can document that it is increasing the volunteer pool, it could run into problems in Congress.
 
The Future
Productivity Vs. Priorities

Americorps' future may depend at least as much on how people in power view government as how they view the program.
Mr. Gingrich says he has no great criticisms with the way the program has been run, but he still thinks it is not needed.
"I'm glad that Americorps vaguely resembles the Peace Corps," he said. "I'm willing to bet money 20 years from now it won't. If you looked at HUD, at the Model Cities Program, the Appalachian Commission, you'll find they will gradually be politicized, they will have a few scandals, they will then adopt more rules and regulations, and presently they will be a mess."
So far almost all the criticism of the program has come from Washington. In the states and among those in academia who study volunteerism, there is general agreement that the Federal Government can play a positive role in fostering public service and volunteerism and that the current moment is a propitious one for doing it.
Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College of Columbia University, who has studied volunteerism on campus, said the nation was seeing a resurgence of public service on campuses and that a recent study showed that 64 percent of college students took part in some form of public service.
What is needed, Dr. Levine said, are structures and incentives that allow that service to be sustained. In its ability to foster a broad-based ethic of community service, he said, Americorps is admirable and right for the times.
"The last Administration talked about a thousand points of light," Dr. Levine said, "but that hasn't produced the kinds of programs that America needs. This is real, it's tangible, it's worth doing well.
"This isn't recruitment for national activity. It's making things better at the local level, which seems consistent with everything that's happening in the country."
Whether it is consistent with current budget realities is another issue.
"Show me the priority list that keeps this alive and show me what what you kill in order to keep this alive," Mr. Gingrich said. "The President's answer is, 'Don't have a balanced budget, and your grandchildren will be glad that you borrowed the money from them to do this in your lifetime.'
"I think, frankly, that's wrong."

HEADLINE: District of Columbia Cuts Business Taxes Over Mayor's Protest

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
One day after learning that the city, amid a financial crisis, had maintained the appearance of having a balanced budget only through accounting tricks, the Washington City Council voted to give businesses a $ 41 million tax cut on commercial and residential property.
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. reacted immediately, attacking the bill as "unconscionable" and vowing to veto the measure, which passed on a 7-to-5 vote. 
 The action comes shortly after the Mayor proposed ceding significant parts of city government responsibilities, including the public welfare, court and corrections systems, to the Federal Government in order to reduce a projected $ 722 million deficit in the budget.
It also comes hard on the heels of a statement by the city's chief financial officer, Robert Pohlman, that the municipal government balanced its budget for the last three years only through accounting sleight of hand, according to an article in today's Washington Post.
Mr. Pohlman said the maneuvers used during the administration of former Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly included counting 15 months of income as coming within one budget year and carrying uncollectable debts as loans.
Mr. Pohlman, who also was a ranking member of the financial staff for Ms. Kelly, said all the individual policies he mentioned had been disclosed as they were used.
However, he said that as a whole they had undermined the city's financial status, leaving it with a debt that will cost it more than $ 60 million in interest this year.
He added that the actions could have been useful if they had won the city time to bring its spending under control. But, he said, no management controls were started to stop the spending.
In attacking the business tax cut, Mr. Barry, who has typically enjoyed a good relationship with business in the city, criticized business people for pushing for the rebate in the current financial crisis.
"The business community, which is a very important community and I support that community, wants to contribute nothing," he said. "The citizens in Washington are going to contribute and have services reduced by $ 224 million."
But business leaders praised the bill's passage.
"The Council woke up today to the economic reality that tax increases kill job growth," said John McDaniel, chairman of the Greater Washington Board of Trade. "For the future of the region, let's hope that this is the start of a new trend."
Councilman Harold Brazil, the bill's proponent, said the Mayor could make further cuts in spending and employees to restore the money the city would lose.
But Mr. Barry said the city had cut all it could, and the bill's passage effectively added $ 41 million to the deficit.
In another effort to deal with the financial situation, Mr. Barry said he would support a Council member's bill to create a financial review board that would develop a four-year financial plan to guide the city out of its budget morass.
The review board would have no taxing authority, the Mayor said, but it would review the city's annual budget.
"This is a way for us to get ahead of our finances," said the Council member, Kevin Chavous.
The seven-member panel would consist of two mayoral appointees, two appointed by the Council and one each by the district's delegate to Congress and the two chairmen of House committees that oversee city affairs, Mr. Barry said.

HEADLINE: Hard Queries For Director About Savings In the Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, was besieged today with questions from members of Congress in both parties who wanted to know why Mr. Clinton had not proposed more substantial measures to reduce the Federal budget deficit or to control the growth of benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid.
Ms. Rivlin argued within the Administration for more aggressive steps to reduce the deficit, but she defended the President's new budget request in testimony today before the House Budget Committee. 
 She said it would have served "no useful purpose" for the Administration to propose specific ways of saving money in Medicare. "As a tactical matter," she said, "it seemed more advisable to work with Congress" on a bipartisan approach.
Representative Wayne Allard, Republican of Colorado, called Mr. Clinton's request "a status quo budget." Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, said: "This is a very timid budget. The President has abdicated his leadership responsibility and said to Congress, 'You do the job.' We will."
Democratic Representatives like Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, Bill Orton of Utah and Glen Browder of Alabama joined the Republicans in criticizing the President's budget on the ground that it did not do enough to reduce the deficit. Under Mr. Clinton's request, the deficit would rise to $196.7 billion next year, from the $192.5 billion projected for this year and it would remain around $190 billion a year through 2005.
That is substantially less than the record deficit of $290 billion in 1992, but it falls far short of the commitment made by Mr. Clinton as a Presidential candidate. In his campaign book, "Putting People First," Mr. Clinton said his economic plan would "cut the deficit in half within four years and assure that it continues to fall each year after that."
Some Republicans, like some moderate Democrats, said they placed a higher priority on deficit reduction than on strict party loyalty. They said that to prevent big increases in the deficit, they would consider scaling back the tax cuts proposed in the party's election manifesto, the Contract With America.
Representative David L. Hobson, Republican of Ohio, said, "More important than a tax cut is to get the deficit under control." He said the size of the tax cut might need to be re-examined. And he asserted that Ms. Rivlin "obviously isn't excited" about the budget she was defending. "It was hard for her to defend," Mr. Hobson said. "Her heart is not in it."
Republicans pointed out that the deficits envisioned in Mr. Clinton's budget would require the Treasury to borrow large amounts of money. Government debt held by the public would rise to $4.8 trillion in the year 2000, up from $3.4 trillion last year, and interest payments on that debt would rise 53 percent, to $310 billion in 2000 from $203 billion last year.
Ms. Rivlin said that Federal spending should not exceed Federal receipts over the course of a business cycle, but she opposed rigid requirements to balance the budget every year. "It would be self-defeating to get to balance by cutting the public investment we need to make the economy grow faster," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The White House budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, testified before the House Budget Committee yesterday. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In America;
Marina Madness In Jersey

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Soon after winning election on a promise to cut taxes, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey asked the public to submit ideas on how she could cut spending. A real estate broker suggested she unload the state-owned marinas, which offer picnic and recreation areas and low-cost docking facilities for small pleasure boats.
Mrs. Whitman thought that was a great idea and promptly announced that two of the four state marinas would go on the market for $7 million. Besides needing all the cash she could get her hands on to pay for her tax cuts, Mrs. Whitman had a philosophical problem with the marinas. She argued that the state had no business being in a business that competed with private business. 
 A hitch developed when state officials learned that one of the targeted marinas, the Leonardo State Marina on Raritan Bay in Monmouth County, could not legally be sold. Back in 1947, when private owners deeded the marina to the state, they were aware of the possibility that politicians and developers might try to exploit the property. They insisted on a clause that read: "In the event the state will no longer use the marina as a public facility, the marina reverts back to the original deed owners or heirs."
When Larry MacPhee, the grandson of one of the owners, heard that the marina was to be sold, he erupted angrily. "The state is stealing the land from its citizens," he said.
Mrs. Whitman reconsidered. Only one marina would be sold, the Forked River Marina in Ocean County. As it turned out, it would have been wise to reconsider that sale as well.
Despite an aggressive marketing campaign, there was no rush to purchase the marina. By October, Mrs. Whitman's asking price of $7 million for two marinas had tumbled to $1.7 million for one.
Still no takers.
An auction was scheduled for Dec. 15. According to Fred Rudkin, the state's Supervisor of Marina Services, a single bidder showed up just minutes before the auction was to begin. As there were no other buyers in sight, the minimum bid of $900,000 was offered.
"SOLD!" said the State of New Jersey.
"It seemed unusual," Mr. Rudkin noted, "but I've never been involved in one of these before. Most auctions, I always figured you have more than one person."
Workers at the marina were stunned and disbelieving when they heard that the facility had gone so cheaply. In fact, the sale (which will not be finalized for several months) was a much worse deal than they thought. Out of the $900,000 sale price, the state has to pay back $608,000 that had been drawn from a Green Acres fund over the past few years to purchase two additional acres of land for the marina.
The Green Acres program uses money from bond issues to preserve open spaces. When land purchased with Green Acres money is sold to private interests, the original expenditure has to be returned to the fund. The state also determined that even though it is selling the marina, it will still need to use a maintenance building it put up on the property. According to legislators, the state plans to pay the new owner $279,000 for the use of the building. Thus the net that the state will realize from the sale of its marina is an embarrassing $13,000.
Thirteen thousand dollars! For an entire marina, Mrs. Whitman netted the price of a used Volvo.
Even the $13,000 net, which is the best face you can put on the deal, is not real. Over the past five years, $1.6 million in capital improvements, paid for by taxpayers, were made at the marina. That money, if the sale is finalized, will be lost.
The smoke and mirrors of "Whitmanomics" is starting to haunt New Jersey. The Forked River Marina debacle did not involve huge sums of money, but it is symptomatic of economic policies that are as ineffective as they are incoherent. New Jersey lost 40,000 jobs in January, and the unemployment rate rose to 7.2 percent. Property taxes are surging. And two new analyses of Mrs. Whitman's income tax cuts show that they are weighted heavily in favor of the rich over the middle class.
Mrs. Whitman's example is being followed by Republicans across the country. They come in, they cut taxes willy-nilly, and then their entire budgetary policy becomes a scramble to fill up the gaping holes where the tax revenues used to be.
It's an extremely destructive way to run a government.

HEADLINE: Stop the Dishonest Debate on Social Security;
Dr. Townsend's Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
James Gollin (Op-Ed, Feb. 1) pays tribute to the perspicacity of Dr. Francis E. Townsend without naming him. Truth is, Dr. Townsend's name is usually skipped, even though President Franklin D. Roosevelt acknowledged his role in the passage of the Social Security Act. 
 Among the unsung advantages of Social Security on Mr. Gollin's list are creation of millions of jobs by easing older people out of the work force; and generation of a huge amount of economic activity by the $292 billion in benefits.
On Sept. 30, 1933, Dr. Townsend, a penniless country doctor in Long Beach, Calif., wrote a letter to his hometown newspaper after watching in horror three elderly women rooting through his garbage can. In his letter he outlined what became known as the Townsend Plan, a unique idea to use old-age payments as a Depression buster.
"I suggest," he wrote, "that the national government retire all those who reach (the age) of 60 on a monthly pension of $200, on condition they spend the money as they get it."
In an economy with 25 percent unemployment, he figured this would create 12 million jobs for younger workers and circulate "two to three billion in fresh money each month."
In less than two years Dr. Townsend's letter had erupted into a club membership of almost three million. The club was powerful enough to attract harsh criticism from leading economists, including Paul Douglas (later a Senator) and even Winston Churchill, who observed archly in Colliers magazine: "The Townsend Plan is an attempt to mint the moonlight into silver and coin the sunshine into gold."
In August 1935 Congress hurriedly passed the Social Security bill proposed by F.D.R. It was the Townsend Plan on the cheap: $10 a month to people 70 and over.
Frances Perkins, then Secretary of Labor, wrote later that President Roosevelt had told her: "We have to have it. The Congress can't stand the pressure of the Townsend Plan unless we have a real old-age insurance system."
Mr. Gollin validates the two premises in the 60-year-old letter by Dr. Townsend, who has earned one of those slots in history reserved for myopic visionaries whose ideas live long after their creators' names have been forgotten.
 
PHIL WILLON
Palos Verdes Peninsula, Calif.
Feb. 3, 1995

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: Two Leaders Seek Laurels Along Peru-Ecuador Border

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Over the last half-century, a border dispute with Peru has inspired Ecuadoreans to produce 500 books on the subject -- about 10 volumes for each of the 48 miles of Amazon jungle now being contested.
So two weeks ago, when President Sixto Duran Ballen ordered troops to resist Peruvian attacks, the 73-year-old leader seemed reborn, invigorated by a burgeoning nationalism. 
 Gone were memories of an infirm politician who spent most of November in a Washington hospital, which prompted his enemies back home to plant stories of his death on local radio stations.
Instead Mr. Duran Ballen could be seen daily on the whitewashed balcony of the Spanish-colonial Presidential Palace, pumping the air with his right fist, and leading crowds in chants of "Not One Step Back!"
Gone were the tear-gas-tainted memories of opposition to his free-market changes of the last two years -- a national protest by Indians, three general strikes and recurrent strikes by state oil, telephone and electricity workers determined to block sale of their industries to non-state companies.
On Tuesday night, flag-waving crowds welcomed Mr. Duran Ballen home from a diplomatic tour of South America. It was hard to remember that only six weeks ago, "Sixto" dolls were the hottest sellers among the effigies that Ecuadoreans burn on New Year's Eve in a traditional protest against politicians.
"Physically and politically, Sixto has revived," said Benjamin Ortiz Brennan, editor of Hoy, an influential newspaper. "At the beginning of December it seemed that he was going to die or resign. But Ecuador is a nation wounded in its dignity. It is a nation with a defeat complex."
On Tuesday night, a $500 million war-tax bill sailed through Ecuador's Congress, normally one of Latin America's most divided legislatures. Controlling only 9 congressional seats out of 77, the President has watched Congress impeach or force the resignation of four Cabinet ministers since September.
With a chance to restore the national honor, few Ecuadoreans worried, at least publicly, that the border conflict between two poor countries is costing each side $10 million a day. From islanders on the Galapagos to Indian tribes in the Amazon, thousands of Ecuadoreans suddenly have been unified by the challenge of redeeming national honor.
Standing up to Peru seems to offer collective therapy for the national psychic damage caused by the loss of half of Ecuador's territory to Peru in a 1941 war. Though only a small fraction of this nation of 11 million people is old enough to actually remember the war, it still resonates in this normally placid nation.
Over the last two years Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, has visited Ecuador three times in an effort to mend fences. But the idea of Mr. Duran Ballen making the two-hour flight to Lima became such a traumatic issue that one congressman proposed a national referendum on the issue.
In March Peru's Ambassador to Ecuador was nearly expelled. His error? He commissioned an opinion poll on the border question, which showed that about half the Ecuadoreans thought Ecuador should end the conflict through negotiations.
"This poll and the Ambassador's comments are unacceptable interference by a foreign diplomat in the internal affairs of a country," Ecuador's Foreign Ministry declared.
Today, having bathed in the nationalist fountain of youth, Mr. Duran Ballen may now be its political prisoner. Across the border, President Fujimori is equally determined to declare victory and is seeking re-election in two months.
There are some parallels with South America's last border war, which began when Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands in 1982.
Although Ecuador has cut inflation in half and has increased economic growth, a battlefield defeat could cut short Mr. Duran Ballen's mandate and shake Ecuador's 15-year-old democracy.
"If Ecuador is defeated, it would be disastrous," an Ecuadorean journalist said. "Sixto would not be able to survive the Galtieri effect," a reference to the resignation and brief imprisonment of Argentina's President, Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, after Britain triumphed in the Falklands. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Peace Talks to Resume
 BRASILIA, Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- Ecuador and Peru will resume talks to end their border conflict with the help of three Latin American countries and the United States, the Peruvian Deputy Foreign Minister, Jose Ponce Vivanco, said today.
Mr. Ponce told reporters that Argentina, Brazil and Chile had agreed to send high-level diplomats to a new round of talks, in Brasilia. The United States will be represented by its Ambassador in Brazil, he said.
 Mr. Ponce said the diplomats would be arriving in Brasilia tonight and Thursday and talks would begin immediately. Face-to-face talks between Ecuador and Peru broke down on Sunday after six days of negotiations when Ecuador requested more time to study a cease-fire proposal put forward by mediators.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
Under pressure by health plans, more doctors and hospitals are accepting predetermined fees for large groups of customers. In essence, those doctors and hospitals are taking on the same sort of risks as an insurance company that hopes the premiums it collects will be greater than the claims it pays. [Page A1.]
 
A Wall Street conference will discuss ethics -- in private. [D7.] 

Companies
 
A $2.3 billion cable sale by Viacom appeared threatened after a House committee approved a bill that would repeal a tax break for minority-owned media companies. The tax break is central to Viacom's plan to sell its cable television systems. [D1.]
 
The sport utility vehicle has proved to be more than a fad. Auto makers from Mercedes-Benz to Ford to Toyota are planning to offer new types of four-wheel-drive models. [D1.]
 
Directors of Morrison-Knudsen may hasten the departure of William Agee, the chairman and chief executive. [D1.]
 
A British publisher has offered to buy The Journal of Commerce, people familiar with the details of the offer said. [D1.]
 
Ketchum Inc. plans to shut down later this year. The fund-raising counseling company has begun to wind down operations. [D2.]
 
Ameritech will accept competition in its local market in Illinois. The move could accelerate telephone deregulation. [D4.]
 
Taco Bell introduced a new lower-fat menu. [D4.]
 
Don't throw out that Listerine bottle: A man won $1,000 in a Warner-Lambert contest for the oldest Listerine bottle. [D4.]
 
A new standard for linking computers with office machines like faxes, telephones and copiers is being discussed by I.B.M. and some Japanese companies. [D4.]
 
CBS said fourth-quarter earnings fell 4 percent. [D7.]
 
A landmark in Alzheimer's research was reported by researchers at Athena Neurosciences in collaboration with Eli Lilly. [A20.]
 
A heart drug by SmithKline Beecham was shown in studies to be unexpectedly effective in reducing mortality. [A21.]
 
International
 
Mexico's weakened banking system could undermine efforts to rescue the economy. The plunge in the peso has made it harder for businesses and homeowners to meet loan payments, and a wave of defaults would worsen an existing recession. [D1.]
 
West European companies are increasingly heading east to take advantage of cheap labor in the former Soviet bloc. [D1.]
 
The Mexican state oil company will proceed with a sale of its petrochemical businesses after several years of delays. [D6.]
 
Japan's trade surplus swelled in 1994. [D7.]
 
Markets
 
Stocks were little changed. Intel and Amgen led a strong rally in Nasdaq stocks, pushing the Nasdaq index up 4.80 points. [D10.]
 
Treasury prices were mixed. [D15.]
 
The dollar slipped. [D18.] Crude oil prices fell. [D18.]
 
Today's Columns

HEADLINE: Mexico's Banks: A Weak Link in the Rescue Plan

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Even with an international rescue plan worth about $50 billion in place, Mexico's efforts to revive the economy appear threatened by the nation's weakened banking system.
Before the peso was devalued on Dec. 20, Mexican banks were already burdened with too many bad loans and too little in capital reserves. Now with the peso worth 36 percent less against the dollar than it was seven weeks ago, many Mexican companies are faced with loan payments they cannot meet. 
 If they were to default on their loans, the banks would not have enough money left to help the nation's industries expand exports and help generate sufficient economic growth to sustain a recovery.
And if weaker banks went under, the Government would have to prop up the banking system. The result, some analysts say, is that Mexico's recession could worsen and the current-account deficit could grow, despite the financial-assistance plan announced last week in Washington.
"The weak links in this whole chain of support for the economy are the Mexican banks," said Chip Brown, an analyst with Morgan Stanley in New York. "We just don't know how capable they are of meeting their obligations."
The decline of the Mexican peso from 28.9 cents on Dec. 20 to a little over 18.4 cents today has made it harder for businesses, homeowners and farmers to make loan payments. And the bank portfolios of overdue loans have expanded ominously, according to Government reports and analysts' studies.
Another problem looming for the banks involves $8 billion in certificates of deposit, redeemable in dollars, that are about to fall due. Analysts think that many of the investors -- including Americans -- who hold the certificates will pull their money out of this country, leaving the banks even shorter on funds.
With some frightened investors already putting their money elsewhere, financial analysts fear that the banks will have increasing trouble retaining enough funds to meet the Government's minimum requirement that capital equal 8 percent of assets. And, in a country where the rate of savings is even lower than in the United States, a recession from the peso's devaluation would leave many Mexicans with even less to save.
Industrial and other companies serving a shrinking domestic market would not give banks much new loan business, and some banks would struggle just to stay solvent. A number of banks already hard pressed to meet the capital-to-assets requirement have been so weakened by the peso crisis that banking analysts and Government officials doubt they can survive more difficult times ahead.
A study of Mexican banks prepared by Moody's Investors Service concluded last month that the peso's devaluation would "accentuate pre-existing weaknesses -- in particular, very poor asset quality and very poor reserve coverage," while also limiting the banks' ability "to withstand deregulation and increased competition."
The largest banks -- Banamex, Bancomer and Serfin -- are considered too well established to fail, though they have also been hurt by the peso's devaluation, analysts say. But many smaller ones are on the edge. Banpais, Mercantil Probursa and Bancrecer are viewed as particularly weak.
Last month, the Government rushed through two laws to prevent a widespread collapse in the banking system. One lets troubled banks increase their capital by selling bonds that can be converted into shares.
The Bank Protection Fund, a Government program supported by monthly payments from the banks, announced that it would buy such bonds. Government officials insist this is not intended as a step toward renationalization of the banks.
The second new law allows foreign banks to gain 100 percent control of existing Mexican banks. Financial analysts expect American and Spanish banks already established here, like Citibank and Banco Santander, to bid for some of the troubled Mexican financial institutions.
Last October, the Government allowed 18 foreign banks, half of them from the United States, to set up in Mexico. The prospect of American bankers controlling Mexican capital has raised nationalist protests, but Government officials say that Mexico cannot recover from its financial crisis without an infusion of capital. Even Mexican bankers acknowledge that the damage to their industry has been so great that there may be few alternatives but to allow foreigners into the country.
"It is preferable to have a national bank managed efficiently by foreigners," Ricardo Guajardo Touche, the director of Bancomer, said recently, "than to have a national bank managed by Mexicans but inefficiently."
That was a rare public statement by a Mexican banker acknowledging any sense of crisis. The Mexican Government has established a regulatory system that is considered tougher than those of countries like Venezuela, where 19 banks in trouble were recently nationalized, but analysts and economists here say it is nearly impossible to get the banks to openly discuss their condition.
Previous currency devaluations also strained the Mexican banking system. After a devaluation in 1982, the President at the time, Jose Lopez Portillo, accused bankers of pulling billions of dollars out of Mexico and plunging the nation into economic chaos. Without warning, he nationalized all banks except Citibank, which continued to operate independently.
A decade later, the Government sold the banks back to private investors, who for the most part were not bankers but industrialists, stock market investors and speculators. A Mexican shrimp exporter, Carlos Cabal Peniche, ended up owning two of the banks. Last September, he was charged with fraudulently lending himself $700 million of the banks' money, and has been hiding from the authorities since.
As the nation's economy slowed down in 1993 and the first half of 1994, Mexican banks were hit by a large increase in the number of loans that fell past due. According to documents from the National Banking Commission, Banpais saw its portfolio of overdue loans increase 150 percent last year.
Requests for representatives of the Mexican banks to discuss their problems were rebuffed. Jose Ortiz Izquierdo Cruz, a spokesman for Banamex, the country's largest bank, said, "There is no one in the bank who can talk to the newspapers or give any information."
Several attempts to reach the president of the Association of Mexican Bankers, Jose Madariaga Lomelin, were also unsuccessful. A statement provided from one of the association's vice presidents, Antonio Del Valle, called the current situation "supremely positive."
An American banker working in Mexico, who asked not to be identified by name, explained that Mexican bankers feared that talking too much about weaknesses in the system would make such problems inevitable. "If responsible people don't want it to happen, a run on deposits won't happen," he said.
Cynthia A. Harlow, a vice president of CS First Boston in New York, said the situation in Mexican banks was quite serious. "The degree to which we see a severe crisis depends on how long interest rates stay at current levels," she said.
Mexico's key overnight interest rate between banks, which was 10 percent in January 1994, has soared to more than 50 percent now, taking most other rates with it. Credit-card issuers charge more than 80 percent annual interest, while variable-rate mortgages -- nearly all mortgages in Mexico -- can top 40 percent.
A senior Mexican official said that the first banks likely to be sold were Banco Union and Banca Cremi, which had been owned by Mr. Cabal Peniche and are now being run by Government administrators. Several smaller regional banks also look likely to be acquired by larger Mexican or foreign banks. Banco Santander is known to be interested in entering retail banking here.
An American banker here said that several American institutions had expressed interest in the smaller banks, but that he did not expect to see "anybody rushing to do it in the next month."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Precarious Balancing Act" tracks year-end results for Mexican banks from 1991 through Sept. 30, 1994. Figures represent total assets, loans, and past-due loans. Also listed are past-due loans as a percentage of all loans, as of Sept. 30, 1994. (Source: CS First Boston based on reports to the Mexician National Banking Commission)

HEADLINE: Germans, Too, May Trim Public TV

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Most politicians have a love-hate relationship with television, loving it when it fawns and hating it when it sneers. Chancellor Helmut Kohl seems to be tilting toward the latter.
For days now, Germany's political debate has been speckled with the fallout from Mr. Kohl's threat to curb the public television network, which has become a vast institution since it was set up by the Western allies after World War II but which has been losing viewers lately as commercial stations have grown. 
 Such has been the furor in Germany that one critic has labeled the Chancellor "Berluskohl," drawing a comparison to the attempts by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy to control the public broadcasting systems that compete with his own private networks.
As in other European countries, Government-supported television has dominated the airwaves in Germany, and privately owned stations have begun to grow only since the mid-1980's.
From a wider perspective, the debate seems part of the soul-searching in the United States as well as in Europe over the role of publicly financed television in a rough-and-tumble era of free-market values, galloping technological advance and competition with growing private networks.
Just last weekend, John Birt, the director general of the venerable British Broadcasting Corporation, publicly challenged British television and other journalists to re-examine their professional ethics. The European Union in Brussels is in the middle of a heated discussion over regulations governing the ownership of commercial television. And in the United States, the new Republican leadership in Congress has raised the possibility of curbing publicly supported broadcasting.
In Germany, the issue came to a boil when Mr. Kohl's close relationship with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia became the butt of satire on the Cologne-based West German Broadcasting, the biggest and most powerful of the 11 separate, publicly financed stations in Germany's federal states that are grouped together in the ARD network, widely known as the First Channel.
An angry Mr. Kohl supported calls for an overhaul of the bloated and supposedly independent First Channel, whose staff totals 24,000 people. The network is financed in part by advertising and in part by the $15 compulsory license fees that Germans pay every month if they own a television set. Five of the 11 member stations lose money and are supported by the six others.
The network is widely held to be both corrupt -- with freelancers complaining that they must bribe officials to get work -- and, as in Italy, closely tied to the political parties that govern the states where the individual stations are based.
The Cologne station, for instance, is seen as close to the opposition Social Democrats. Adversaries of the left-leaning Radio Bremen station call it Radio Hanoi. Most of the criticism is coming from the only two German states run by Mr. Kohl's allies -- his Christian Democrats in Saxony and the Christian Social Union in Bavaria.
The Chancellor's attack, however, unleashed a flurry of other concerns over freedom of information, the future political slant of public broadcasting and the financial prospects of private television. Germany's advertising market is Europe's biggest, worth some $3.2 billion a year. It has drawn in major publishing houses, including the conservative Springer group, as owners of private stations.
One of the biggest private networks, Sat-1, is run by a Bavarian, Leo Kirch, who is a friend of Mr. Kohl.
The commercial stations, moreover, have generally been friendlier to Mr. Kohl than the Cologne station and some of the others in the public network, which he and his allies accuse of wielding disproportionate political influence. The Cologne station earns more in license fees than any other First Channel station, makes a quarter of all the programs shown nationally on the network and produces one-third of its political documentaries.
"What makes the Chancellor mad is that there is a broadcaster here, namely WDR, that has the nerve to have its own opinions and publishes opinions that are not identical with the Chancellor's," said Friedrich Nowottny, the director of the Cologne affiliate. The station took Mr. Kohl to task for his stand on the Chechnya crisis, implying that his response was too feeble and concerned only with public relations.
Michael Glockner, a spokesman for the small Radio Bremen station, said, "the whole issue is about political control and influence" over the network.
Mr. Kohl contends instead that the issue is economic, and he has supported the position of the two principal crusaders against the public network, Prime Ministers Kurt Biedenkopf of Saxony and Edmund Stoiber of Bavaria. They threatened to pull their stations out of the network unless the system is reformed to save money and to reduce the number of stations in the network, thereby possibly rooting out some of its most troublesome components.
The idea of saving money strikes a chord with many Germans who, already laboring under increased taxes to finance German unification, have seen their monthly fees for the public system increase by almost 50 percent over the last seven years.
The percentage of Germans watching the stodgy programming of the two state channels has fallen to less than one-half since the inception of private broadcasting 10 years ago.
Advertising is another central issue. By law, neither public network may run advertisements after 8 P.M., while the private channels face no such restrictions.
In supporting a reform of the working group, Mr. Kohl has opposed both more advertising on the publicly financed channels and higher fees for viewers, meaning that the squeeze would be on the network to cut personnel and the number of regional stations.
At the back of most politicians' minds is the effort to frame a new law to govern the ownership of private television, which might end the current limit of 49.9 percent on a company's stake in a private television station.
Once a new law is enacted, many commentators expect private television to proliferate as publicly financed television recedes, heralding a new era of market-driven choices for German television viewers.

HEADLINE: Some Familiar Faces Return to Power in Panama

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PANAMA, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Ernesto Perez Balladares took office here last September promising to "close the Noriega chapter" of Panamanian history. But his first five months as President have witnessed a systematic rehabilitation of dozens of figures from the 20 years of corruption and brutal military rule that preceded the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega by American troops in 1989.
At the same time, Mr. Perez Balladares, an American-educated banker and economist popularly known as El Toro, for his burly build and aggressiveness, has not hesitated to tweak the United States when there is political gain to be had. The message is clear: the Democratic Revolutionary Party, founded by Gen. Omar Torrijos as the political arm of the Panamanian military and inherited by General Noriega, is back in power and intent on settling old scores. 
 As his Housing Minister, Mr. Perez Balladares chose a doctor who has been accused by human rights and medical groups of aiding soldiers who tortured political prisoners. One former military officer nicknamed Captain Blood has been put in charge of a prison, while others with what diplomats delicately call "checkered pasts" have been given jobs as ambassadors or as advisers to Government officials.
"In some respects, it has been a return to the good old days," said one Latin American diplomat here. "You don't see the brutality of the Noriega era, but El Toro has had to make many appointments to satisfy the P.R.D.'s political base."
Shortly after taking office, Mr. Perez Balladares pardoned more than 200 people accused or convicted of crimes ranging from corruption to the murder of an American teacher on the night of the 1989 invasion, saying they were victims of political persecution. Those who benefited included General Noriega's puppet President, the head of the chief paramilitary group of the Noriega period and a colonel who led a coup attempt in 1990, as well as Mr. Perez Balladares' own first Vice President, Tomas Altamirano Duque.
Gerardo Gonzalez, president of the governing party and a member of the National Assembly, defended the President's actions, saying they were a necessary step toward "national reconciliation and harmony" and noting that several members of opposition groups had also benefitted from the amnesty decree.
"We are trying to normalize the situation without falling into the trap of new persecutions," Mr. Gonzalez said, adding there are "thousands of people with cases still pending" who should probably also be pardoned.
In its recently published annual report for 1994, however, the Panamanian Human Rights Committee described the amnesty decree as "a measure to favor political associates of those who govern" and that "encourages impunity and impedes the full clarification of responsibilities" for crimes committed in the Noriega era.
Drug trafficking and money laundering also continue to be problems, though diplomats here say the situation has improved markedly since the Noriega era and is probably no worse than it was under Mr. Perez Balladares' predecessor. There are now rules intended to prevent large flows of cash into the country, like the currency declarations all arriving passengers are required to fill out. But Panama's use of the American dollar as its own currency makes it an attractive target for cash-rich cocaine cartels in neighboring Colombia.
When the fifth anniversary of the American invasion came around in December, the new Government decreed a "day of national mourning," staged a re-enactment of the initial attack on the neighborhood of El Chorrillo and ordered Panamanian flags lowered to half-staff. The issue of flags and where they fly has always been an explosive one here, since it was just such a dispute 30 years ago that sparked the riots that led to the negotiation of the Panama Canal Treaties.
By custom, the American military bases from which the attack on Dec. 20, 1989, was launched should also have brought their American flags down to the same level. But irritated American authorities refused to comply, and the standards of the two countries flew in the former Panama Canal Zone at different heights.
Thus far, the United States has not made much of a fuss, at least in public, about the re-emergence of figures from the Noriega era that it once criticized as crooks and thugs. Members of the opposition say that is out of gratitude for Mr. Perez Balladares's decisions to offer temporary safe haven to 8,600 Cubans at the height of last summer's refugee crisis and later to allow Gen. Raoul Cedras to come here as an exile as part of the settlement that restored President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power in Haiti.
But the Cuban refugees are now being sent back to the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and Panamanian politicians and journalists predict that American skepticism about Mr. Perez Balladares will grow as other issues come to the fore.
Leading the list of problems that could sour the relationship is the case of an American soldier who was killed here in 1992, one day before a visit by President Bush. Based on evidence that included eyewitness testimony, the Panama Government quickly ordered the arrest of three suspects, one of whom was Pedro Miguel Gonzalez, a son of the leader of the ruling party.
The younger Mr. Gonzalez promptly disappeared for the next two-and-a-half years, only surfacing again late last month, when he surrendered directly to Mr. Perez Balladares. An indictment against Mr. Gonzalez and another suspect was unsealed in the United States on Monday, adding to the discomfiture of Mr. Perez Balladares.
The elder Mr. Gonzalez said his son "was arrested only because he was a militant of our party." Opposition leaders predict that the Government will do all it can to assure an acquittal, pointing to the dismissal this week of the prosecutor in the case as a sign of things to come.
The Government has also been unsettled by what is officially described as either a coup attempt or assassination plot against Mr. Perez Balladares in mid-January. More than a dozen low-ranking police officers and former military officers have been arrested in the incident, but their motives remain unclear.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In December, children in a Panama City neighborhood, El Chorrillo, re-enacted an invasion by American forces five years earlier. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Bid for Journal of Commerce By British Company Is Seen

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The British company that publishes The Economist magazine has offered to buy The Journal of Commerce, the New York-based financial daily, according to people familiar with the details of the offer.
Publishing executives speculated that if the paper was sold by its current owner, Knight-Ridder Inc., it could be a vehicle for a large-scale expansion in the United States by the Economist Newspaper Ltd., the company that owns the widely respected Economist magazine. 
 The Economist's offer for The Journal of Commerce was said to be worth about $90 million to $100 million. After negotiations among senior executives of both companies in recent months, Knight-Ridder was said to have set $130 million as the asking price for the newspaper, whose full name is The Journal of Commerce and Commercial.
The publication has a circulation of about 21,000, so the purchase price would likely be in the range of $5,000 a subscriber. While that would be a very high price, it is not known whether the deal would include other information services related to the newspaper.
Even at that price, the deal could also represent a significant expansion for Pearson P.L.C., which owns 50 percent of the shares of Economist Newspapers. Pearson is the publisher of The Financial Times of London, the salmon-pink chronicle that is considered to be a bible for international financiers.
The Journal of Commerce is a staid 168-year-old publication that focuses largely on international trade and transportation issues. Published five days a week, it has always focused much of its coverage on maritime news, though it has been expanding its scope in recent years.
For many years, executives at Knight-Ridder, one of the country's largest newspaper companies, have toyed with proposals to expand the paper. But it has long been understood that it would take an investment of tens of millions of dollars to compete more aggressively with other American business publications like The Wall Street Journal, Forbes, Fortune and Business Week.
The Journal of Commerce has about 70 news employees, people there said, while The Wall Street Journal has a total news staff of about 470 people.
The Economist also owns Roll Call, a twice-weekly newspaper published in Washington.
Spokesmen for Knight-Ridder and Pearson declined to comment when asked about the possible sale yesterday. Marjorie M. Scardino, the chief executive for The Economist in London, was traveling yesterday and could not be reached, her office said.
Don C. Becker, publisher of The Journal of Commerce, did not respond to telephone calls to his office.
The Journal of Commerce could provide a buyer with a springboard for an expansion in the United States, but people familiar with the newspaper said there would be substantial hurdles as well.
The publication is widely respected and is believed to be modestly profitable, but it derives much of its revenue from shipping advertising. A new publisher who tried to broaden the reach of the newspaper, therefore, could risk the loss of a main source of revenue. If shipping companies came to feel that the publication was no longer directed at their industry, for example, they could abandon the newspaper before it established a new advertiser base.
Some newspaper executives, however, said the paper's specialization in world trade could position it to appeal to the kinds of influential readers who buy The Financial Times. Although The Financial Times has American readers, the newspaper's executives have said they have not been able to compete for American advertising because most Financial Times readers are in Britain and Europe, and American advertisers have more efficient ways of reaching financial and business readers in the United States.
Publishing executives say Knight-Ridder has been ambivalent about The Journal of Commerce for a long time. Some analysts have argued that in recent years The Journal of Commerce did not quite fit into any of the businesses that interested corporate executives at Knight-Ridder's headquarters in Miami.
The company has been sharply expanding its various businesses that provide financial information, especially through electronic data services. But most of Knight-Ridder's newspapers are traditional metropolitan dailies, including The Miami Herald, The Detroit Free Press and The Philadelphia Inquirer.
Reports of The Economist's interest in The Journal of Commerce may help solve a recent mystery in New York news media circles. On Jan. 1 Pearson began leasing the famous "zipper" billboard in Times Square in Manhattan. The sign, which displays electronic news headlines, had been leased by Newsday since 1986.
