HEADLINE: Suspect in Subway Firebombing Pleads Not Guilty

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
Looking gaunt and hobbling in pain from burns over 40 percent of his body, Edward Leary made his first appearance in a courtroom yesterday and pleaded not guilty in connection with the Dec. 21 subway firebombing that injured him and 47 other people.
The 49-year-old unemployed computer technician from Scotch Plains, N.J., slowly entered the courtroom in sneakers and appeared to have difficulty as he took his seat in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. With a scruffy beard and disheveled appearance, he looked starkly different from the earlier photographs of a healthy-looking, clean-cut man that were taken before the explosion. 
 His lawyer, Stephen J. Murphy, agreed to allow a television cameraman and still photographer in the courtroom to humanize his client. "I felt that it was in his interest," Mr. Murphy said, "that the public see he's not the monster that the police and public officials have portrayed him to be in their initial rush to condemn him."
At the hearing, Mr. Leary was arraigned on a 39-count indictment that charges him with attempted murder, assault, weapons possession and attempted grand larceny, all as part of the Dec. 21 firebombing. The authorities have said that the bombing was part of a scheme to extort money, but that the crude device accidently ignited in Mr. Leary's hands as he carried it on a crowded southbound No. 4 train in the Fulton Street station in lower Manhattan.
The indictment also charges him in connection with a Dec. 15 incident on a subway train in Harlem in which a teen-age girl's backpack suddenly caught fire, injuring her and burning a 13-year-old boy.
As Mr. Leary was appearing in court, five other people who were injured in the blast remained in the burn unit at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, said a spokeswoman, Kathy Robinson. A 60-year-old patient, Reufield Edey, who was burned over two-thirds of his body, is still in critical condition, she said.
Mr. Murphy said his client, who has been undergoing skin grafts on the lower part of his body and legs, was still "in a substantial amount of pain."
"This is his first time coming in front of the media, in which he has been vilified," the lawyer said, explaining that Mr. Leary had been nervous before coming to court. "He is a very frail man. He is a very mild man. He's not a violent, aggressive person."
Mr. Leary's wife, who has often spoken publicly in his defense since the bombing, did not appear in court because she was at work, Mr. Murphy said.
Mr. Leary was moved from the New York Hospital to a locked ward at Bellevue Hospital last Friday. After his appearance yesterday, he was transferred to a medical ward on Riker's Island, said Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the city's Department of Correction.
Mr. Murphy promised in court yesterday to allow the prosecution to take a handwriting sample from Mr. Leary. Prosecutors declined to say why a sample was needed.
The authorities have said that they found six pages of notes in Mr. Leary's house indicating that he planned to detonate bombs with motion-sensing devices and remote controls and to shoot people in the subway system.
But Mr. Murphy has contended that the notes were actually for a science-fiction novel Mr. Leary was planning to write. Yesterday, Mr. Murphy gave more details of the novel, saying it involved "a box that would cost about $ 10 million to $ 12 million, that has to be wheeled into Grand Central station by 6 or 10 people, that has C.I.A. codes in it that can't be broken."
He added that in the novel, the box would be used in a scheme "to help the homeless."
"Also, the box can't go off," Mr. Murphy said in explaining the novel. "That is the theory in the novel. It is a deterrent, not a weapon."
He said the notes were the work of a creative mind, not someone bent on careless destruction. "It shows a much more complex mind than would put two bottles of gasoline" in the subway, he said.
The bespectacled Mr. Leary did not speak during the brief arraignment, instead staring blankly around him.
Mr. Murphy said that while his client was badly hurt in the blast, the most harmful effects had been suffered by the Learys' 9-year old son, whose friends and schoolmates have "made fun of him."

HEADLINE: Directors May Hasten Agee's Departure

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Confronting what is perhaps the worst financial crisis in the company's 82-year history, the directors of Morrison Knudsen Corporation plan to meet here Thursday to debate whether William J. Agee, the chairman and chief executive, should be forced to leave immediately.
Only last week, as the company disclosed that it would report a substantial loss for 1994, it offered a vague timetable for Mr. Agee to leave the company later this year. Its official plan was for a search committee, which includes Mr. Agee, to seek a chief executive officer to lead a turnaround of the giant construction and transit equipment manufacturer. Mr. Agee, who has held his posts since 1988, planned to hold on to the chairmanship until 1998, when he turns 60. 
 But now some members of the board are resisting Mr. Agee's gradual exit. That resistance reflects concern that Mr. Agee has allowed the company's employee morale and business to deteriorate, that he has not kept directors and shareholders adequately informed about its problems and that he has been remiss in attempting to cope with the troubles of the company -- which is based in Boise, Idaho -- from his seaside estate in Pebble Beach, Calif.
"Succession is the key issue, and that has been accelerated," one individual close to the board said. He added that several directors believed that the company must act quickly to reassure its bank lenders and its employees -- "all its constituents, really" -- that new leadership was in place to cope with the emergency.
According to several people close to the board, opposition to Mr. Agee is led by two notable newcomers to the board, William P. Clark, a national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan, and Zbigniew Brzezinski, who held the same job under President Jimmy Carter.
Both joined the board last year, and have been known to have pressed Mr. Agee and senior Morrison Knudsen executives for better information about the company's mounting troubles.
A spokesman for Mr. Agee said today that he was not available for interviews.
On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Morrison Knudsen stock closed today at $9.875 a share, unchanged. The stock plummeted 24 percent on Feb. 1 when the company first projected a loss and disclosed Mr. Agee's plans.
At that time Morrison Knudsen also said its financial picture had eroded to the point where it no longer complied with terms set by its banks who have extended more than $300 million in unsecured credit. Its default on those terms gives the banks the right to press for repayment, a demand that the company cannot now meet. Thus its continued access to credit hinges on its ability to persuade its lenders, led by J. P. Morgan & Company, that it is putting its affairs in order.
In addition, for Morrison Knudsen to obtain new business, it must demonstrate sufficient financial strength to obtain the surety bonds that are required of contractors who bid on large construction projects. Bonding companies that issue these bonds guarantee that the company will complete the work it has agreed to do and they therefore must be satisfied that Morrison Knudsen has the financial wherewithal to do so.
Apparently at Mr. Clark's insistence, the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett has been hired to advise the independent directors, and lawyers from the firm will be present at Thursday's meeting. In addition, several directors have informed the board that they have retained individual counsel as the company's troubles have mounted.
The company is already facing lawsuits filed in United States District Court in Boise by five law firms representing shareholders who contend that the company misrepresented its financial health and that of one of its subsidiaries, MK Rail Inc. The company sold a portion of MK Rail, which makes and remanufactures locomotives, to the public last April. After selling initially at $16 a share, the stock closed unchanged today at $9.875 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Clark, reached at his office this evening in Paso Robles, Calif., refused to discuss the agenda for Thursday's session. "Going into such a meeting, it is not appropriate for me to comment," he said.
His board ally and longtime friend, Mr. Brzezinski, also declined to comment on what the board would deal with. However, asked today whether the board still expected Mr. Agee to remain as chairman for up to three more years, Mr. Brzezinski said, "I don't think that is the case." He added, "It is possible that will change, but I don't want to prejudge the board."
If Mr. Agee is forced to leave Morrison Knudsen, it would be his second unceremonious departure from a troubled company. In 1982, after launching a corporate takeover that backfired on him, he left the Bendix Corporation as chairman and chief executive after it was acquired by the Allied Corporation, now Allied Signal Inc.
Among other members of the board are Peter Lynch, the former manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund and the chairman of the Morrison Knudsen audit committee; John W. Rogers Jr., the president of Ariel Capital Management, a money management firm in Chicago; Gerard R. Roche, the chairman of the Heidrick & Struggles executive search firm in New York; Robert A. McCabe, the president of the Pilot Capital Corporation in New York, and Irene C. Peden, an accounting professor in Seattle.

HEADLINE: Paris Journal;
Homeless Man Finds Niche: The Cars' Caretaker

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Philippe Hermand wants everyone to know that he is not one of the clochards, the scraggly outcasts who sleep on the streets or under the bridges of the Seine when the river is not overflowing its banks.
"I sleep in the street, but I get up every morning, wash and shave and take care of myself," he said. "I just happen to live in the zone, that's all." 
 "The zone" is limbo, where thousands of men and women have ended up after being forced out of their apartments by rising rents and unemployment, now running over 12 percent in France.
Paris has never been without its clochards. But the Paris municipal authorities estimate that 5,000 to 7,000 homeless people now live on the streets of the capital. Associations for the homeless say there are more, and perhaps as many as 400,000 in the country as a whole.
Mr. Hermand believes the French may be on the verge of a social or political explosion, like the 1968 riots that ultimately brought down de Gaulle.
"If there's a blowup, I'll be out there with them," he said. "But it isn't just France -- it's a worldwide crisis."
Mr. Hermand may be homeless, but he is not faceless. By making himself useful to neighbors fortunate enough to have a roof over their heads, he has even become a little famous.
What he does is help people avoid parking fees, a favorite Parisian pastime. On the Rue de Sontay in the fashionable 16th arrondissement, where he lives, people can park legally only two hours a day between 9 A.M. and 7 P.M.; their cars are required to display recent parking receipts for 10 francs, or about $2, an hour, obtainable from dispensers midway down the block.
Needless to say, Parisians will do almost anything to avoid paying. They will even give their car keys to Mr. Hermand, 48, a former convict who served 13 1/2 years for armed robbery before he landed on the street four and a half years ago.
He invented the job himself, keeping one step ahead of the parking agents who swoop down on the block three or four times a day. The agents are called "contractuels" because they are not police officers but civilians paid by the city to make sure the parking fees are paid, and they are about as well liked as tax inspectors.
So Mr. Hermand is constantly on the move, a short figure dressed in black, with a Chicago Bulls cap and headphones he uses to listen to Diana Ross as he runs up and down the street slipping meter receipts under the windshield wipers just before the ticketers get there.
"I made the mistake on a rainy day just after New Year's of thinking that they wouldn't come, and all the cars got a fine," he said. He told residents that the $15 tickets were a little New Year's present for the city, but promised not to let his guard down again.
"The people here on the street are family to me," he said, "and if your car is towed away it's an 800-franc fine," or $160.
Mr. Hermand lives off the tips his well-dressed and well-housed middle-class neighbors pass on to him.
"I'd miss him if he left," said Jean Clavero, a cobbler who lets Mr. Hermand bathe and shave in his shop every morning. "He brings me my coffee every day."
Robert Giovannoni, a physical therapist who met him in the cafe that Mr. Hermand uses as his office, said he had treated him for broken bones in one hand suffered in a fight with a car thief.
"If we had more guys like him, the streets would be a little safer," Mr. Giovannoni said, "But I wouldn't give him my car keys -- he used to be a stunt driver," he joked. .
Mr. Hermand said he had been looking desperately for a room to rent ever since one of his parking clients offered to pay his rent for a year. "I can't find anyone who'll rent to me," he said, "even though I know there are rooms available. It's really a war between us and society."
Philippe Chavance, co-founder of a tenants' rights group, called Right to Housing, said the housing market in Paris was in a crisis, with rents having risen faster since they were deregulated in 1986 than incomes have. High unemployment even leaves some middle-class families unable to afford housing, he noted.
The tenants' group recently occupied a former school in the Rue du Dragon on the Left Bank that a developer wanted to turn into luxury apartments.
"We have been trying to get the city administration to recognize that when there are people living in the streets at the same time as there are apartment owners hanging onto vacant apartments they don't want to sell, there is a housing crisis," Mr. Chavance said.
With France now in a presidential election campaign, the homeless problem is as political as unemployment is. The Rue du Dragon occupation has attracted much attention from people eager to embarrass Mayor Jacques Chirac, who is one of the candidates.
The tenants' group claimed victory when Mayor Chirac finally requisitioned several hundred vacant apartments for the homeless, promising the owners to find other housing for them if the buildings were renovated.
But there is widespread public cynicism about whether the candidates, now led in public opinion polls by the conservative Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, will do anything meaningful about the homeless problem after the elections this spring.
"Politicians are all no good," Mr. Hermand said. "In this life, you have to fend for yourself."

GRAPHIC: Photo; An estimated 5,000 to 7,000 homeless people live on the street in Paris and as many as 400,000 in the country as a whole. One of them is Philippe Hermand, who, for tips, helps people in the capital avoid parking fees. (Patrick Artinian for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ketchum Inc. Has Plan To Close Later This Year

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Ketchum Inc., for many years the nation's largest fund-raising counseling company, has begun to wind down operations and will close later this year, Robert Carter, its president, said last night.
"While we are fully booked with fund-raising commitments throughout the country, the firm's inability to make a reasonable profit in the foreseeable future made this difficult decision a prudent business move," Mr. Carter said. Word of the company's plan began circulating in fund-raising circles yesterday after it started notifying clients that it would fulfill its contracts but would not extend them. 
 Ketchum Communications, the worldwide advertising and public relations group that was spun off from the fund-raising operation years ago, will not be affected by Ketchum Inc.'s closing. A related partnership, Ketchum Canada Inc., will also be unaffected, Mr. Carter said.
Mr. Carter said the company, which is privately held and based in Pittsburgh, fell victim to a failed expansion into Britain, too much debt resulting from a 1986 purchase of a Pittsburgh office building and a slowdown in fund-raising drives by nonprofit hospitals unsure about the future of health-care financing.
He said the company was also hurt by its emphasis on full-time employees, instead of consultants paid by the project. Ketchum Inc. has 70 employees, down from 200 employees five years ago, in Pittsburgh, Boston, Charlotte, N.C., and other cities.
The decision to close Ketchum Inc. comes at a time of intense competition for charitable dollars. Data gathered by the National Center for Charitable Statistics indicate total giving, adjusted for inflation, has been declining since 1989.
In campaigns for major gifts "the market has matured and many, many colleges and hospitals and other institutions that in the early days hired a firm like Ketchum and paid them a healthy retainer to have a manager on-site for a year or two years now have their own staff to run their campaigns," said Russ Reid, president of Russ Reid, Inc., a prominent fund-raising firm for direct mail and television campaigns, based in Pasadena, Calif.
"The old-line firms are going to have to adapt to a new market if they want to survive," Mr. Reid said.
Since its founding in 1919, Ketchum Inc. has raised billions of dollars for hospitals, youth and social services organizations and religious charities. Mr. Carter said that in the past decade it raised more than $1 billion just for higher education, including campaigns for St. John's University, Georgetown University and Northeastern University.
"This is very sad because they were for years the biggest and one of the best," said Jack Schwartz, the retired president of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel Inc., a trade association. "This shows that the field of professional fund raising is much more difficult today, with much greater competition for the philanthropic dollar and with many organizations relying on their own staff and using professional firms primarily as consultants, which makes it very hard to make a profit."
Carlton G. Ketchum, one of the company's founders, helped start the trade association in 1935 to raise standards among professional fund-raisers. Mr. Ketchum, who died in 1984 at age 92, served as the association's first president.

HEADLINE: Walesa Suggests He Will Accept New Premier

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Easing concerns about a political stalemate, President Lech Walesa suggested today that he would accept the nomination of the Speaker of Parliament, Jozef Oleksy, as Poland's new Prime Minister.
But it was not clear how long it would take Mr. Oleksy to form a new Cabinet, and in particular to find a Defense Minister and a Foreign Minister acceptable to Mr. Walesa. Both posts are vacant and have been a source of serious friction between Mr. Walesa and Poland's leftist coalition Government. 
 Mr. Oleksy, a former senior member of the old Communist Party, was chosen on Tuesday as the new Prime Minister by the coalition after Mr. Walesa forced the ouster of Prime Minister Waldemar Pawlak.
Mr. Walesa's spokesman said the President was "not opposed" to Mr. Oleksy and that the two men would probably meet on Thursday. But some analysts suggested that while Mr. Walesa would accept Mr. Oleksy, he might not stop his attacks against the coalition, a fragile grouping of two parties rooted in the Communist past. It could be weeks, those analysts suggested, before a new Government line-up is in place.
Mr. Walesa had pressed the 16-month-old coalition Government to remove Mr. Pawlak on the ground that he stalled economic changes introduced by former governments. But his intervention also seems to be aimed at improving his own weak standing in the opinion polls. Once the national hero considered most responsible for bringing about the end of Communism, Mr. Walesa is trailing all the other potential candidates in the presidential election, which is to be held sometime before the end of year.
The choice of 48-year-old Mr. Oleksy to replace Mr. Pawlak, a 36-year-old politician from the Polish Peasants' Party, was welcomed as an improvement even by newspapers ideologically opposed to Mr. Oleksy and his party of former Communists, the Democratic Left Alliance.
Mr. Oleksy would be the first Prime Minister since the collapse of Communism in Poland to have come directly from the former Communist Party.
He was a minister in the last Communist Government and at one point served in the department of ideology of the Communist Party. In an interview in 1993, Mr. Oleksy said he "took care of the economic branch of the ideology department in a period when the party was looking for ways to make the economic transition."
Since he became Speaker, Mr. Oleksy has generally been considered a pragmatic politician. He has told American businessmen that he is in favor of a market economy and recently expressed frustration with the policies of the slow-moving Mr. Pawlak.
Mr. Oleksy, who has never visited the United States, told European Union lawmakers at a meeting last month that he wanted Poland to join NATO as soon as possible, a much firmer stance than the one expressed in vaguer statements he made 18 months ago.

HEADLINE: West European Companies Head East for Labor

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
Political leaders of the 15 nations in the European Union keep warning their electorates that high unemployment won't go down until rigid high labor costs do -- jobs will just flow east to central Europe, where it's cheaper to hire people.
Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., is a company that proves the point. Dr. Eberhard von Koerber, who heads its European operations, says the multinational engineering and electrical giant began shifting some of its operations eastward when Communism collapsed in 1989. 
 Today, Dr. von Koerber said, "it's like a shot of adrenaline to sit in Berlin and realize that one hour away by car, in a country where you no longer need a visa to travel, labor costs are only 5 to 10 percent of what they are in Germany."
The emergence of a low-cost, highly trained labor market in central Europe is one reason why, despite the economic recovery, unemployment in the western part of the Continent remains high: 10 percent in Germany, 12.6 percent in France and more than 20 percent in Spain.
Despite higher productivity and much lower unemployment in the United States, even a few American jobs are moving east as American and other investors seek a foothold in central Europe.
Since 1990, A.B.B. has eliminated 40,000 jobs from North America and Western Europe, and created 21,150 jobs in the newly capitalist countries to the east. It now owns 45 companies there that generated well over $2 billion in orders over the last two years.
The realignment has benefited the Swiss-Swedish conglomerate, which reported net profit of $444 million for the first nine months of 1994, compared with just $187 million for the comparable period in 1993. The complete earnings for last year will not be available for another month.
"The opening of central and Eastern Europe is really a unique opportunity for improving European competitiveness and re-engineering our very sclerotic economic structure," Dr. von Koerber, 56, said during an interview here.
"In Poland, we bought turbine manufacturing plants and restructured the companies by injecting our latest technology, standards of management and incentives to increase productivity," Dr. von Koerber said. "Once this was established, we focused on moving labor-intensive processes from operations in Western Europe."
At the 4,000-worker Zamek plant near Gdansk, Poland, the company now makes some kinds of turbines that it used to produce in Switzerland and Germany. A.B.B. employs a total of 8,000 people in Poland and almost as many in the Czech Republic, where it has boiler and chemical plants.
On the average, its employees in central Europe work 400 more hours a year than the company's workers in Western Germany do. Each hour a Polish worker spends on the job costs A.B.B. an average of $2.58, compared with $30.33 in Germany, according to the company.
A.B.B. is now exploring the possibility of using satellite telecommunications technology to move power plant engineering control operations from Mannheim, Germany, where engineers cost nearly $50 an hour, to Poland and Russia, where they cost only a fraction of that amount.
"With satellites, you can have them on line with computer operations in the West," Dr. von Koerber said, "and in time there could be fewer engineers in Mannheim and more in Poland and Russia."
Like other European companies, A.B.B. has been required to work out protection for its Western workers who lose their jobs. "Retraining an engineer from one kind of engineering to another is not such a problem," Dr. von Koerber said. "Retraining a welder to be a systems analyst, or even a waiter, is more difficult."
Most A.B.B. employees whose jobs were eliminated in Western Europe preferred to take union-negotiated buyout packages and generous unemployment benefits rather than undergo retraining for service jobs, he said. Many business executives contend that the social safety nets in most Western European countries encourage chronic unemployment rather than job creation.
Revising European social policies to encourage more job creation was one of the top priorities agreed on by leaders of the European Union nations in their meeting in Essen, Germany, in December. Dr. von Koerber doubts that it will happen soon.
"I don't think it will come voluntarily from the top, and I don't see the politicians really having the will to attack this on a scale that costs them votes," he said. "The issue is dropping from the agenda. The economy is recovering, and when the sun is shining you don't buy umbrellas."
Western investment in the most dynamic central European market economies -- the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia -- is still only a fraction of what those countries say they need to make the transition from Communism successfully.
In the Czech Republic, foreign investment has amounted to about $3 billion since 1991, Karel Dyba, the Czech Economics Minister, said recently. It has been on a comparable scale in Poland and Hungary, and money has continued to flow eastward for manufacturing plants despite the resurgence of former Communist parties that now govern both of those countries.
"The question is not whether they're moving back to Communism -- that won't happen," Dr. von Koerber said. "But there have been signs of slowdown and delay in the privatization and reform process which we don't like. As long as they're just being cautious about the speed of moving towards a market economy, it doesn't worry us. But we are concerned that some day they could change direction, not just speed."
Russia is a bigger worry for A.B.B., which is one of the largest European investors there, with more than 1,350 employees in more than a dozen Russian companies. President Boris N. Yeltsin's control over Government policies, including the commitment to continued movement toward democracy and a market economy, has been questioned since he ordered the army's destructive invasion of the secessionist province of Chechnya.
But most officials believe that investment capital will inexorably just keep moving east as long as labor costs remain high in the West -- leapfrogging Russia if conditions look uncertain there.
International bankers say that foreign investors have been sinking about $1 billion a year into Russia, but put $35 billion into China last year alone.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
With New Year, Clinton Finds Himself Mired in Old Ways

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
This was to have been the week that President Clinton laid out his own vision of a smaller Federal budget. Instead, it has become the week that Mr. Clinton fumbled another high-profile nomination and failed in a no-holds-barred bid to settle the major league baseball strike.
The White House has repeatedly vowed to break that self-destructive pattern of allowing problems of its own making to overshadow initiatives. But with a Surgeon General-designate who is being portrayed as an abortionist, and in a baseball dispute thrown into the hands of a reluctant Congress, Mr. Clinton has presented his Republican rivals on Capitol Hill with two easy ways to attack his principles and cast doubt on his leadership. 
 Today, the White House said the President did not regret having tried to save baseball from the money squabble between players and owners, even though it exposed him in the end as powerless to do anything about the dispute. Mr. Clinton's aides held out hope that the Congress might yet come to see the fate of the national pastime as its legitimate business.
But as Republican leaders on Capitol Hill made plain that they did not see settling the six-month-old strike as their problem, White House officials acknowledged that the President's decision to wade into baseball's messiness might, at least in the short term, make Mr. Clinton appear weak.
And as it mounted a full-scale effort to save Mr. Clinton's nominee for Surgeon General, Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr., the White House conceded that it had made a substantial mistake in announcing that an obstetrician-gynecologist was Mr. Clinton's choice to become the next Surgeon General while it had been unprepared or unwilling to give complete answers about abortions he had performed.
"There is no one on the staff who would say that we have served the President and the nominee as well as we could," Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said today. "We should have done a better job."
For more than a year, aides to Mr. Clinton have told themselves that even if things were not going their way, the President would be in fair shape if he and the aides could only avoid making what they consider stupid mistakes. With Republicans holding sway in Congress, Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledge that they have even less hope of scoring the kinds of successes, like the passage in 1993 of the President's economic plan, that have helped compensate for public relations gaffes like the Presidential haircut aboard Air Force One.
Now the Republicans are poised to override Mr. Clinton's objections in pushing for a balanced-budget amendment and a harder-edged crime bills. And some Administration officials say the ultimate effect of self-made failures on issues like baseball and nominations may be to convey the same sense of Presidential impotence as last year's foreign-policy breakdowns.
It was Leon E. Panetta, who took over last summer as Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, who vowed to cure the White House of its penchant for stumbling, and for a time he appeared to have succeeded. Just as Mr. Clinton's foreign-policy team put together triumphs in Haiti, North Korea and the Middle East that quieted complaints about past flip-flops and indirection, Mr. Panetta imposed a sense of discipline over even the President, who agreed to be more careful about what he said in public.
But today, White House officials said that Mr. Panetta stood aside last month when Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, and Bruce Lindsey, a deputy White House counsel, persuaded Mr. Clinton to start the quest that ended in failure late Tuesday night when baseball's players and owners rejected hours of his personal entreaties.
Mr. Panetta was also among the Presidential aides who pushed hardest last week for Mr. Clinton to go forward in announcing Dr. Foster's nomination, the White House said. They said that Mr. Panetta and others had been aware at the time that Dr. Foster had performed abortions, but conceded that the White House had not taken time then to prepare a strong defense of that record.
A senior White House official tonight blamed that failure on a blindness to the prospect that opponents of abortion would choose Dr. Foster's nomination to pick a fight over the issue. But some officials also said the timing of the announcement had been driven in part by Mr. Panetta's determination to head off complaints that the White House had been too slow to fill what at the time were four high-level vacancies.
Because Dr. Foster had won acclaim for leading a campaign against teen-age pregnancy, the White House also hoped to use his appointment to send a signal of Mr. Clinton's commitment to that effort. The President's aides regard the fight against teen-age pregnancy as the kind of controversy-free quest to which he should devote time in a Republican-dominated atmosphere in which he must be cautious about confrontation.
But the failure to prepare for a showdown left the Administration to issue incomplete accounts of Dr. Foster's abortion record, which even advocates of abortion rights have denounced as misleading.
Had abortion and the baseball strike not interceded, this week still would not have been smooth sailing for the White House. While it spelled out a vision of a smaller Government, the budget that Mr. Clinton sent to Congress on Monday would have in any case become the focus of prominent Republican complaints that it did too little to cut the Federal deficit.
Aides to Mr. Clinton were not pretending that the last few days had been their most successful.
"One of the things you learn at the White House is that even the smallest mistakes are magnified," a senior White House official said tonight. "You can't afford to make any."

HEADLINE: Robert Mier, 52, Dies; Taught Urban Planning

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Robert Mier, a professor of urban planning and public administration at the University of Illinois at Chicago and a leading expert on economic and social issues facing American cities, died on Sunday at his home. He was 52 and lived in Chicago.
His family said he died of a form of lymphoma that resulted from his exposure to the chemical defoliant Agent Orange during the Vietnam War. 
 Mr. Mier's wife, Joan Fitzgerald, said her husband had applied for disability connected with his exposure and had received a letter granting his claim two days before he died.
Mr. Mier was the architect and chief proponent of Chicago's highly regarded 1984 development plan, which he created as the city's director of economic development. Known as Chicago Works Together, the plan became a national model for other large cities struggling to retain their industrial and economic base while making neighborhoods easier to live in.
Some of his major accomplishments included a new $175 million public library, an export program for small businesses and a community-based general delivery system. Over all, he led efforts to keep factories open and to help neighborhoods control their own economic development.
At the University of Chicago, he founded the Center for Urban Economic Development in 1978. During its 17 years, the center has helped communities help themselves with technical assistance and research.
Mr. Mier also served as a consultant to cities here and abroad. In the wake of the 1992 Los Angeles riots, he was asked by the American Planning Association to conduct seminars for planning directors in Southern California.
Born in St. Louis, he graduated from the University of Notre Dame with a degree in civil engineering in 1965. He received a doctorate in city and regional planning at Cornell University in 1974.
He served as a Navy lieutenant in Vietnam, but later resigned his commission because of opposition to the war.
Besides his wife, Mr. Mier is survived by two sons, Brian and Brendan, both of Chicago; two daughters, Lian Mier, of Huntsville, Ala., and Shelly Fitzgerald, of Chicago; a sister, Nell Newton, of Washington; a brother, Fred Boehm, of St. Louis, and two grandsons.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Victorville Journal;
Boom to Bust in the Distant Suburbs

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VICTORVILLE, Calif., Jan. 5

 BODY:
There is not a lot for teen-agers to do in this windswept high-desert town, where the bleak gray landscape is broken by swaths of tract houses with tall television antennas.
Most weekends, a handful of students from Victor Valley High School are out on empty street corners, dressed as clowns or cartoon characters and hired by desperate realtors to wave the few passing cars toward houses that have been on the market for months. 
 Wearing a bright-red cowboy hat almost as tall as she is, Shanna Page, 17, earns $30 a day by wiggling an oversized foam-rubber hand toward Century Homes, a cluster of new houses that is nestled, like almost everything else here, along the edge of Interstate 15.
But few passers-by are interested in buying a house, Shanna said; more often they stop to ask about places to eat as they travel through on their way to Las Vegas.
Victorville and the other towns in Victor Valley -- Hesperia, Apple Valley and Adelanto -- are about 100 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles. They were fed by the economic boom of the 1980's when people were willing to drive two hours or more over the mountains to their jobs in exchange for a modest home with a lawn and a two-car garage.
The recession of the 1990's left the towns stranded here in the Mojave Desert, with many residents ready to flee farther east, out of California altogether, but they are burdened with homes they cannot sell. As many as 300 houses are put up for sale every week in Victor Valley, said Gene Binsbachar, executive vice president of the Victor Valley Association of Realtors. The backlog of unsold houses is now up to 3,500 in the valley, still home to about 250,000 people.
The local economy suffered an added blow with the closing two years ago of George Air Force Base on the edge of town, with the loss of 5,000 jobs. Political wrangling has delayed redevelopment of the base, with plans for a prison, a civilian airport and small industries still on the drawing board.
In recent months, economic statistics indicate that the area has felt the first warm breath of the upturn that has tentatively begun in Los Angeles and Orange Counties. But few people here said they had noticed. "For Sale" signs still swing in the breeze on nearly every street, almost as numerous as the spiky Joshua trees that are the flora of the high desert.
Leaning back behind a desk inside a tiny model home, Bill Johnson, an agent for an investment company, said the houses that are selling these days are going for 25 percent below their assessed valuation. The prices have been driven to these artificially low levels, Mr. Johnson said, by developers who need cash for other projects. People selling their own houses in order to avoid agents' fees and the banks selling repossessed houses have no choice but to sell at cut rates.
Mr. Johnson said the two-bedroom 1,031-square-foot house he was trying to sell that day was on the market for $69,900, though it had been recently appraised at $86,800. A four-bedroom 1,700-square-foot house appraised at $117,800 was for sale for $94,900.
More than three dozen repossessed houses are for sale by the Veterans Administration and the Federal Housing Authority after the buyers walked away from low-interest mortgages, losing their down payments. On his desk, Mr. Johnson had lists showing the F.H.A. had 30 houses for sale and the V.A. had another 14.
Standing in his open garage on the other side of the Interstate, with a welding torch in one hand, Gordon Leisgang talked of the bind that people are in here if they want to leave.
"If I lose my job, I'm heading back east to my family," said Mr. Leisgang, 34, who works for a trucking company that he said has been swept by rumors of cutbacks. "But how can I move? The most I could get out of my house is about three-quarters of what I paid for it."
The happiest people are those who have found ways to avoid the freeways. "I made the commute to L.A. for over a year, easily over two hours each way," said Mr. Bins bachar of the realtors' association. "I just couldn't hold up to it any more."
In the 1980's, the population of the Victor Valley increased by 250 percent, said Brad Kilger, economic development director for the city of Apple Valley. A child of that boom, Apple Valley was incorporated in 1988 and now has 50,000 residents.
But the bust followed the buildup almost immediately. From a high of 1,100 building permits issued in Apple Valley in 1990, Mr. Kilger said, the number fell to 250 last year.
On streets where families gather on Sundays to relax in the shade of their open garages, the empty and unsold houses create a forlorn air.
"The whole attitude of this area has changed," said Jeff Sheeler, a mechanic whose house, surrounded by the carcasses of broken cars, is for sale. "A lot of people I know have moved out toward Las Vegas, and a lot of others wish they could."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Mixed In Uneventful Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in what many traders called an uneventful session.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 1/32 , to 9811/32, for a yield of 7.64 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. Shorter-maturity bill rates, reflecting an increase in investor demand, dropped as much as 6 basis points for a three-month bill, to 5.72 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 The Treasury is halfway through its quarterly sales of new debt.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said yesterday's auction of 10-year notes went as well as could be expected, with most of the interest coming from dealers.
The 10-year notes at auction came in at an average yield of 7.54 percent, in line with market expectations.
The Treasury will sell $11 billion of 30-year bonds today. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the new long bond was being offered at a price to yield 7.60 percent, up a basis point from the day before.
"One thing is for sure," Mr. Burtnick said, "the market is already beginning to focus on Friday's January producer price data."
"But many economists have already begun to lower their P.P.I. estimates, and that has elminated some of the market's anxiety about owning longer maturities." Investors were concerned that if the Producer Price Index comes in strong tomorrow, it would be bad for long bonds, raising expectations of another Fed interest rate increase coming sooner, rather than later, and causing prices to fall.
Estimates call for an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for January, analysts said. The only economic data released yesterday was the Commerce Department's wholesale inventory for December, up two-tenths of 1 percent, down from a revised gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in November. The slower rise in the wholesalers' inventory was accompanied by a 2.2 perrcent jump in sales in December, suggesting that the Fed's seven interest rate increases over the span of a year have not sapped consumer demand.
While the numbers are not considered important by dealers, they are useful to economists who forecast gross domestic product data.
In the municipal bond market, yields dropped for the first time in three days as some investors began to find the price of some issues a little expensive compared with other fixed-income investment like Treasury or corporate securities.
The price of municipal debt has increased rapidly, with the lack of supply not being able to satisfy demand. General obligation bonds maturing in 20 years are yielding about 78.6 percent of comparable government securities, according to Bloomberg Fair Value analytics. In mid-December the ratio was 85.8 pecent. Traders generally consider municipal bonds expensive when they yield less that 82 percent of comparable government securities.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, the Walt Disney Company sold $400 million of notes in Europe due in 2000, with interest linked to the performance of a portfolio of live-action films.
The lead manager, CS First Boston, said the notes paid 2 percent interest semiannually, plus an additional amount of interest based on the revenues generated by the portfolio. The issue is priced at par and will be available in the United States under Securities and Exchange Commission rules that allow Eurobonds to be sold.
According to London bankers, the studio has used this method of borrowing twice before.
The bond is likely to appeal to smaller fund managers with a good understanding of the risk, and could be linked to 24 or 25 films.
Walt Disney last issued a similar seven-year bond in October 1992. The interest rate, 7.5 percent for the first 18 months, fell to 1.5 percent thereafter.

LENGTH: 1305 words

HEADLINE: Four-Wheeling No Longer Just a Fad

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Why, oh why, do city folk and suburbanites keep buying four-wheel-drive sport utility vehicles?
They are clunky, they are pricey and they get the same gas mileage as a giant Cadillac Fleetwood. On the freeway, they whistle in the wind. And don't even ask what an alignment costs. 
 Sweeping such cavils aside, auto companies are betting hundreds of millions of dollars that car buyers' tastes have permanently shifted toward the beefy vehicles with the inelegant name. In the next few years, everyone from Mercedes-Benz to Ford to Toyota plans to offer new types of sport utility vehicles. They cite marketing surveys, common sense and even anthropological studies to explain why they think buyers will pounce on every vehicle they make.
While many motivations are no doubt herding buyers to sport utilities, perhaps the most important, and certainly the most primal, is fear. Hence, the radio advertisements some Jeep dealers have been running this winter in New York and several other cities.
The scene: With wind howling in the background, a phone rings.
Sleepy Woman: "Hello?"
Man: "They've taken mom to emergency."
Announcer: "So what would you rather see in your driveway on a night like this? A car . . . or a Jeep Grand Cherokee?"
Of course, the combination of a huge snowstorm and a hospitalized mother may occur only rarely. But buyers say they feel safer knowing that they can send power to all four wheels, should they ever need to. Most never do. In fact, the predominant use for four-by-fours is for commuting.
"It's more insurance or security than a necessity," said Steve R. Yoder of Peoria, Ariz., a suburb of Phoenix. Though he said he very rarely used the four-wheel-drive capability of his vehicles -- a Ford Explorer and Chevrolet Suburban -- Mr. Yoder said he was delighted with both of them. Only one thing disappointed him: the gas mileage, which he said was about 14 miles a gallon for the Explorer and 9 miles a gallon for the Suburban.
Mr. Yoder said his local gasoline station allowed customers to pump up to $50 of fuel after one swipe of a credit card through the pump. To fill up the Suburban, he said, he often had to swipe his card through twice.
"You get these extra perks you weren't expecting when you buy the beast," Mr. Yoder said. "But it's our choosing."
This year the auto makers plan to produce up to 400,000 more such beasts than they did in 1994, when they sold 1.556 million. That would be an increase of 26 percent.
"Are there going to be that many more buyers?" said Christopher W. Cedergren, senior vice president of the Autopacific Group, a consultant in Santa Ana, Calif.
The auto companies certainly think so. Women in particular like the sturdiness of trucks, and they like sitting high in traffic. Combined with those truck attributes, four-wheel drive helps people feel more in control at a time when their lives seem more chaotic. At least, that's what auto executives say.
"If you talk to the anthropologists we deal with, people want more and more to control their lives," said Jim Perkins, general manager of the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation. "You don't carry a gun, necessarily. But you try to stay above your problems."
Chevrolet contracted with an anthropologist last year to determine whether the passion for "sport utes," as they are sometimes known, was a fleeting fancy or a durable trend. After interviewing owners, the anthropologist emphatically concluded that the shift to sport utilities would last.
Bombing down a freeway in a jumbo Suburban, watching blinkers flare to life on puny sedans as they skitter out of the way, one gets a sense of, well, mastery. Watching the digits flip past as one fills the 42-gallon gas tank, however, provides a less pleasant frisson.
Still, as more people buy trucks and crown themselves kings and queens of the road, those left in sedans may feel compelled to join them, if only to see ahead in traffic.
For sociological reasons besides rising anxiety, Mr. Perkins predicted that the sport utility segment would continue to grow. He cited the same rebellious compulsion believed to have spurred the sales of mini-vans. Baby boomers picked mini-vans over the station wagons in which they rode as children, according to a widely held industry theory, in part because they could not stand the thought of becoming like their parents.
Future growth in sport utility sales, Mr. Perkins predicted, will "be fueled by these people who grew up in a van and now wouldn't touch a van."
G.M. offers the broadest line of sport utilities. And Chevrolet is now shipping to dealers yet another contender, a chunky sport utility called the Tahoe that is slotted between the compact Blazer and big Suburban. The price of the base two-door version of the Tahoe starts at $22,640, while the four-door, four-wheel-drive version starts at $29,195.
From less than 8 percent of the light-truck market in 1980, sport utilities rose to 24.4 percent in 1993, then dipped to 24.2 percent last year, according to an analysis by the Ford Motor Company. The share slipped last year, because Ford and G.M. shut down some production to prepare for new sport utility models.
Drawing some of the most affluent new-vehicle customers, sport utilities have become one of the most profitable lines for the Big Three auto makers. Auto analysts estimate that the Chrysler Corporation makes at least $6,000, and perhaps as much as $8,000, for every Jeep Grand Cherokee it sells.
The vast majority of sport utilities are sold with four-wheel drive. The question is, why? It is a cliche of the industry that most buyers never use the four-wheel capability, which they can generally switch on and off. "Nine out of 10 customers don't use it," said Lloyd Johnson, fleet manager of Fletcher Jones Toyota in Las Vegas, Nev.
Indeed, a study by Ford found that 63 percent of people said they primarily used their compact sport utility vehicles for commuting to work; 1 percent primarily for hunting, camping, or fishing, and none for driving "off road." Only 20 percent said they used their vehicles off road.
And in focus groups with customers, Chevrolet learned some surprising definitions of "off road." In Chicago, one buyer firmly said he had gone off-roading in his vehicle, said Kurt Ritter, Chevrolet's manager of truck marketing.
"He said, 'Yeah, there was an accident on the Eisenhower, and I had to go over the curb to avoid a stranded motorist,' " Mr. Ritter recalled with a laugh.
Dealers say owners are perfectly happy using their four-wheel drive only rarely. Ron Miller, general sales manager of a Ford dealership in Cherry Hill, N.J., said he frequently had customers tell him that they used their four-wheel drive only twice -- and then went ahead and traded in their old four-wheel-drive Explorers for new ones. "They get it because of the security of knowing that it's there," he said.
Such peace of mind has its price. Four-wheel-drive capability can drive up the price of a new vehicle by $1,000 to $2,650. Then buyers pay a penalty in fuel economy of 10 percent or more, even if they never use the four-wheel drive. The reason is that the equipment needed for the capability, including a heavy transfer case, easily weighs more than 200 pounds. That also inhibits the performance of a vehicle.
"It's like running with ankle weights on," said Csaba Csere, the editor in chief of Car and Driver magazine. Mr. Csere said most people who bought four-wheel drive could get by with front-wheel drive, and the less expensive option of traction control.
He added, "It's ironic that today's yuppies, who generally regard themselves as having greater environmental consciousness than their parents, wind up driving vehicles that are no more fuel efficient than their parents' were."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Comes the Devolution

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A quick insight to illuminate the political landscape: China, Russia and the United States -- all in their own ways -- are sending power long concentrated in their capital cities out to the boondocks.
Curiously, when Americans see this happening in China, we tut-tut about "warlordism." After Beijing-centric Deng dies, political power in China will probably devolve to centrifugalmen in a half-dozen regions, thereby reflecting economic reality. 
 Beijing's central grip will be broken because it has raised government-army-business corruption to a national scale -- but such corruption works best, mafia-style, in alliances among regional "families."
Meanwhile, devolution continues apace in Russia, which is down to 150 million people; its hope of gaining back population is in the immigration to the motherland of Russian-speaking "near abroad," unhappy in the broken-off states.
Chechnya's bid for independence, brutally repressed, reminds the varied peoples of the unmanageably farflung Russian Federation that Moscow rules by force. But the successor to Boris Yeltsin will have to submit to the stronger centrifugal force, recognizing that ever-greater autonomy within each republic is the way to maintain sovereignty over all.
The American tut-tutters at this trend call the coming devolution "dismemberment." They foresee nothing but Balkan-like trouble in breakups, and pose a legitimate question about the control of nuclear weaponry in China or Russia if either nation sinks into anarchy.
But is anarchy the necessary result of the flow of power to the people? Would not downsizing benefit nations that have over-conglomerated? Even Europe, after a decade of rhetoric about continental integration, is now finding new respect for local culture and national identity.
On devolution, it ain't what you do, it's the way you do it. The U.S. is pointing the way to the orderly dispersion of political power. By striking down "unfunded mandates" beyond safety and civil rights, the new Congress is taking burdens of taxation off states. By turning the administration of welfare, Medicaid and ultimately Medicare to states, the nation is allowing for diversity and encouraging competition.
That's the new direction in our democracy. You might think that by our example, we could influence this historic devolution in countries that we want to see turn democratic.
But U.S. policy works toward the opposite goal. Clinton diplomats and most of the foreign policy establishment fear the new direction and seek "stability" above all.
In China, Mr. Clinton at first ties trade advantages to human rights, then abjectly caves in. Beijing, having taken our President's measure, participates in the most brazen piracy of U.S. intellectual property. But when the trade negotiator Mickey Kantor huffs and puffs about retaliation, his house is blown down by Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary, who announces a junket this month of 50 American oil men to Beijing.
As a result, hard-line Beijing centrists claim victory: Li Peng can argue that only a strong national government can continue to humble the U.S. in trade.
In the same way, by putting all our diplomatic chips on the continuance of the current regime in Moscow, we take the side of the two men -- the shrewd authoritarian Yeltsin and the nutty authoritarian Zhirinovsky -- who stand for an all-powerful central government against the forces of devolutionary change.
Time to open our eyes. What's good for our democracy could be good for nascent democracy in Russia and the un-Communist devolvers in China. We should stop touting order imposed from the center for others even as we come to reject that course for ourselves. On the contrary, we should encourage others to go with the flow of centrifugal political forces all over the world.
Nobody denies that the U.S. national interest is in responsible control of nuclear arsenals. We should invest heavily in incentives to dismantle, subsidize non-weaponry work by nuclear scientists and put in place a space shield to deter secessionist blackmailers.
But today we should face up to the likelihood of some dispersion of control, and stop our wishful thinking that a small circle of leaders in China and Russia will be calling the shots tomorrow.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball Outlook Appears Gloomy

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
From the bargaining table to the mediator's office to the White House to Congress, the strike that defies settlement continued gathering potential outlets for failure today.
While President Clinton sent his binding-arbitration legislation to Capitol Hill and Labor Secretary Robert Reich began campaigning publicly for it, negotiators for striking baseball players and owners left town. They will be back to lobby for and against the bill, which is opposed by Congressional leaders, but their travel plans do not include any visits to the bargaining table. 
 The parting comments of high-ranking people drew a stark outline of how far apart the two sides were after a failed week in Washington.
"It's regrettable that the two opportunities we had to try and call a truce last night did not prove productive," Donald Fehr, the players union chief, said before leaving the Mayflower Hotel this afternoon.
John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, chairman of the owners' negotiating committee, left early this morning, saying as he headed for the door, "I believe the next move is for consideration to be given to Mr. Usery's report."
Harrington referred to the suggestions for a settlement presented to each side Tuesday by Bill Usery Jr., the mediator. The owners accepted them; the players rejected them, bitterly showing that the suggestions were closer to the owners' positions than theirs.
Fehr was talking about the two Administration ideas that the players accepted and the owners rejected: binding arbitration or the return to work for the 1995 season under the existing agreement while a Presidential fact-finding commission developed points of negotiation for after the season.
It came as no surprise that the two sides could not agree on anything generated by the mediator or the White House; nothing else has induced agreement. The two sides may now disagree on something else: Usery's future in the talks.
Given Tuesday's developments, it seemed highly unlikely that the union would continue to have faith in Usery's ability to mediate the dispute. Fehr said he would not comment on that issue until he spoke with Usery. The mediator, who visited Capitol Hill today to brief the Congressional leaders, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich, stood ready to continue.
Asked if Usery's effectiveness had been damaged, Reich said at a news briefing: "I don't know. That's for the players and the owners to decide. Mr. Usery said to the President last night that he is perfectly happy to continue serving as long as the players and the owners want him to continue."
Clinton has received mixed reviews for his efforts. Harrington, for one, said, "I think the President found out that he shouldn't have been involved."
Therein lay yet another difference between the two sides. The players emerged from the White House with glowing praise for Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. In fact, one person with the union, who did not attend the Tuesday evening meeting at the White House, suggested today that Gore "could be a big help on this."
It is not very likely, though, that the Vice President will be asked to help. Nor is it very likely that any other would-be mediator would be willing to jump into the once-more broken-down talks.
In conversations with reporters today, Reich related an observation Usery offered at the White House Tuesday night, quoting him as saying, "In my decades of dealing with labor-management disputes, I have never dealt with a dispute that had so much rancor and bitterness and distrust."
Reich commented that he has seen it, too, saying, "I have never seen this degree of animus."
Strong feeling exists among nonparticipants, Reich added. "The fans are getting fed up," he said. "The President is exasperated. I'm at the end of my tether."
But the strike goes on. Fehr said he was returning to New York to set up a series of meetings with players and agents. He also said he would attempt to hold "a series of background press conferences so people can begin to understand the new and different era we're in."
With spring training scheduled to begin next Thursday, the clubs will continue to plan for their teams of strikebreaking players. It is not a prospect that will gain the Administration's endorsement.
"The Administration is opposed to the permanent replacement of striking workers," Reich said. "This is a policy, a management decision, that has had very negative results wherever it's been tried. It undermines worker-management relations. It undermines trust with a lot of negative connotations for the industry itself. So I would very much stand by the public interest and public policy that the owners do not pick permanent replacements."
The striking players are soon expected to complete details for their own games. They have been putting together a plan to have 100 to 150 of the sport's best players participate in weekend games throughout the country under Reebok sponsorship.
Today was calm and serene compared with the bizarre nature of the Administration's initiative on Tuesday.
The players were particularly puzzled by one development. During one of their meetings with Usery's staff, union officials said, one of the other mediators told them that the clubs had been given completely different suggestions from those the union had received from Usery.
For the next several hours, the union people thought Usery's suggestions to them were a ruse.
"We now know that was not correct," one union lawyer said.
What they learned was correct, among other things, was the Usery suggestion that the two sides agree, beginning in 1996, to a 50 percent tax on the portion of payrolls over $40 million. The union contended that such a tax would cost the players $1 billion over the six-year term of a possible agreement; the clubs said their computations showed only $215 million.
The union cited Usery's tax as evidence that despite his four months in the talks, he didn't know what he had been hearing.
"We asked him how much would be raised by the tax, who gets it, what does it do to players' salaries," Fehr said. "He said, 'I don't know. I'm not an expert in economics and I don't understand the stuff.' "
Richard Conn, Usery's spokesman, said the mediator was not available for comment on any matter today.
With no talks planned and no chance for a negotiated agreement in sight, the National Labor Relations Board becomes a focal point of the dispute. The board is investigating a new union charge, against the clubs' decision not to sign players.
Would the players return to work if the board acted against the clubs?
"We would have to evaluate that when it happens and look at the situation at the time," Fehr said. "If the owners had restored the status quo, as they said they would, we'd be in a position to consider those things, but obviously we're not."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times: Baseball;
One Fan to Congress: Just Do It, Pass the Bill

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
WHEN baseball was the national pastime instead of the national joke, the President always threw out the first ball. But now baseball has thrown out the first President.
The first President caring enough to try to solve one of its labor disputes. 
 "It's just a few hundred folks trying to figure out how to divide nearly $2 billion," President Clinton said Monday. "They ought to be able to figure that out in time for the rest of America to enjoy this baseball season."
But after six months and a White House meeting, those few hundred folks, meaning the owners and players, still haven't figured it out.
At the White House meeting Tuesday night, the President suggested binding arbitration. Labor agreed; Donald Fehr acknowledged that the union was "prepared to arbitrate everything." Management disagreed; Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, asserted that binding arbitration was "not the solution," adding that the owners "reject" it.
"Clearly," the President would say of the owners and players, "they are not capable of resolving this strike without an umpire."
That umpire is the legislation the President will ask Congress to enact that would create binding arbitration by a three-person board. All Congress has to do is pass the bill, not settle the dispute. Just do it. But this Republican Congress doesn't seem inclined to consent to this left-handed Democrat's wishes.
If the President's participation were rated in a scouting report, he showed he wasn't able to hit with power. He had no authority to order binding arbitration. But at least the Prez cares about baseball, at least he's trying.
To those who argue the President has more important problems, he does. Budget, deficit, welfare, Bosnia, Haiti, Mexico. But if he could invest an hour or two Tuesday night in a White House dinner for new members of Congress, who surely represent the fabric of America, he could invest an hour or two the same night in trying to settle a dispute that had ripped another area of that fabric.
Baseball is a small part of America's economic fabric. Especially in Florida and Arizona where spring training is a rite of income. Especially in the major league cities where thousands of jobs depend on the teams and the games.
Yes, the President surely was hoping to get some votes in 1996 from baseball fans if he had succeeded in hastening a solution. He also risked losing votes from those who think either the President is too important to be concerned about baseball, or that baseball isn't important enough for the President to be concerned.
But baseball's continuity has twice concerned other Presidents who were shouldering much more serious issues.
Not long after the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt was asked by Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis for guidance now that the nation was involved in World War II. In a Jan. 15, 1942, letter, the President wrote:
"I honestly think it would be best for the country to keep baseball going."
During World War I, the nation's Provost Marshal, Major Gen. Enoch Crowder, surely with President Woodrow Wilson's blessing, issued in June 1918 a "work or fight" order: all men of draft age who were deferred for one reason or another should apply for war-essential employment. Motion-picture actors and opera singers were exempt, but baseball players weren't.
Newton Baker, then the Secretary of War, asked that the 1918 baseball season be curtailed. It ended on Labor Day, with the teams playing anywhere from 122 to 129 games instead of the scheduled 154 games. In the World Series, the Boston Red Sox, with a left-hander named Babe Ruth winning twice, defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4 games to 2. Two months later the war was over.
But now the Congress and President Clinton aren't the only people in Washington involved in the baseball mess.
The National Labor Relations Board has warned the owners of the "peril" of having imposed a signing freeze on players last Monday. The owners might be subject to the N.L.R.B.'s issuing another unfair labor practice ruling, another sad sign of baseball's times.
To a baseball fan, N.L. always meant National League. Now it's merely the first two initials of a governmental agency.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Usery Meets a Dispute Even He Can't Settle

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Garment workers and mine workers have turned to Bill Usery Jr. So have General Motors, the Chicago school system and Toyota. All had a desire to see if Usery could step in and settle long, intractable and sometimes violent disputes.
The Federal Government still turns to Usery during the most dire national crises, and more often than not, Usery, a Secretary of Labor in the Ford Administration, does what he is asked. 
 Then came the major league baseball strike, as big a conundrum as there is in labor relations these days. And now, because of the fractious dispute that Usery was drawn into last fall, the ticker-tape parade of automatic success may have stopped for the nation's most notable mediator.
The 71-year-old Usery stepped into the dispute Oct. 4 at the urging of President Clinton. Four months later, his efforts have not proved successful. And the fight not only between owners and players, but also over him, has become so ugly that Usery's future in the process is now in question.
No one has asked Usery to resign in the wake of the failure to reach agreement after five hours of negotiations Tuesday night at the White House. Clinton, disappointed as he was, still asked Usery to continue to seek a settlement.
Today, a Clinton spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, described Usery's work as "courageous and historic." Usery was also praised by Robert Reich, the Secretary of Labor, who called Usery in to settle a violence-marred seven-month coal strike in 1993, a dispute that involved 17,000 workers and led to one death. "He has an extraordinary record of settling strikes and settling disputes," Reich said. "He is the best mediator in the country."
No matter. Speculation reigned today that angry players -- who split the cost of Usery's $120,000-a-month mediation fee with the clubs -- may try to force Usery out because of some settlement suggestions Usery made.
Donald Fehr, executive director of the Players Association, would not discuss his views of Usery or what he planned to say in a conversation he hoped to have with the mediator today. But the night before, a genuinely perturbed Fehr picked at Usery's presentation, questioning the mediator's inability to answer specific economic and financial ramifications of his suggestions.
"When we ask an individual, 'Can you tell me why you made this recommendation, what is your rationale, how do you write the numbers, what are your assumptions, how much money do the players lose or gain, how much money do the clubs lose or gain?' and the answer is, 'I don't know, Don,' it is not possible to take it seriously," Fehr said. "And it is very regrettable that that happened."
"I think Bill Usery, in many respects, has done everything that he could," Fehr added. "But, as I suggested to him the first day I met him, this would be far and away the hardest mediation he'd ever have to do. He agrees with that tonight."
Fehr also added that because the owners had revealed some of Usery's suggestions, "it becomes very difficult for Mr. Usery to stay involved."
Usery declined to meet with the news media today. Reich said Usery had told the President he would stay on if both sides wanted.
But the union's dissatisfaction with Usery may put the mediator in an untenable position. Indeed, even though the club owners were very supportive of Usery on Tuesday night, John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox said he did not know what the clubs would do if the players fought to force the mediator out.
"If they're going to fight against him, it's not going to be very productive," Harrington, the owners' chief negotiator, said.
The owners have endorsed many of the informal recommendations made by Usery. And they reserved their anger for the fact that the process in which Usery's recommendations would be enforced did not unfold, hinting that it did not because of intense player opposition.
The raw feelings between the parties are nothing new, of course. But the venom sent Usery's way by one side is equally stunning. And the troubles Usery has found in baseball are likely as bitter as any he has ever experienced.
Even before Tuesday's White House initiatives failed, Usery told reporters how the strike had become the toughest case he had faced in three decades.
"The parties were very, very far apart," Usery said. "And trying to narrow those issues in a single recommendation that had any hope of bringing them together is almost impossible."
Still, Usery has yet to surrender hope that good-faith bargaining will prevail. "He would so much prefer to have both sides settle this themselves because he feels that the bargaining table is the ultimate expression of democracy in the work place," Usery's associate, Richard Conn, said earlier this week.
The question is, will Usery be around to see it?
That probably won't be known until it is determined what can be salvaged of the working relationship between the union and Usery. Salvaging may not be possible, unless the players can put aside their anger over the mediator's informal recommendations.
"He got into some historical areas that were absolutely no-nos without any knowledge of the history or the consequences, which absolutely blew the union's mind," Tom Reich, a lawyer who represents players and who participated in some negotiating sessions here, said today.
"Second, he did not have a good handle on what the economic consequences are. The third thing is, he made representations to them that he did not keep, such as there was not going to be a proposal presented to the President as his final proposal. So, with all due respect to Mr. Usery's distinguished past, I am totally in accord with the union's negative response to Mr. Usery's activities in the last few days."
Such statements underscore the gulf within a gulf that has developed, making it more than understandable why even a Bill Usery can call this the toughest challenge of his career.

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts in New York Will Give Small Businesses a Real Boost

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Cut, but Be Fair to the City" (editorial, Feb. 2) on Gov. George E. Pataki's budget for New York State, was a reasonably fair description of the plan, the politics that surround it and the policy implications of the whole matter. Reasonably fair, that is, until you start again with that old politics-of-envy refrain that infects so many of your editorials. 
 Why, when the budget relieves 400,000 people from any state tax burden at all, must you carp about cuts that apply to families making more than $100,000 a year? Is their wealth so fabulous that they should get no relief from New York's burdensome tax structure?
Most households with that income have two wage earners, and many are small-business owners for whom the personal income tax is the tax they pay on their business's profits. Do you know there are more than one million such enterprises in New York State? If they earn $100,000 in a year, they earn it with 60-hour work
weeks, sweat, toil, sometimes tears.
Higher income families are the most likely to take their tax saving and start a new small business. Most small businesses start that way, and that's the best reason for supporting Governor Pataki's tax cuts.
Because they are a flat, across-the-board reduction and not progressive, the tax cuts may stimulate the new business start-ups New York so seriously needs.
You refer to "the rewards of the tax breaks" as if they were some political payoff, a reward of the kind New York City is accustomed to receiving from its Democratic legislators in Albany. But that's wrong. The tax cuts are policy, designed to stimulate the economy into creating jobs. They are not a cash version of political pork.
 
MARK P. ALESSE
State Director, National
Federation of Independent Business
Albany, Feb. 2, 1995

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against the Yen After Data on Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen yesterday after a report showed that Japan's chronically large trade surplus persisted in 1994.
The report, issued during overnight trading in Tokyo, showed that Japan's trade surplus swelled to $145.82 billion in 1994 from $141.51 billion in 1993. Its trade surplus with the United States grew to $55 billion in 1994, which means that Japanese exporters have a wealth of dollars to sell when they take revenues home. In addition, dollar selling by Japanese companies often picks up before the end of their fiscal year on March 31. 
 The trade report "kind of blew away the theory that a stronger yen would would erode the trade surplus," said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 98.90 yen from 99.44 yen on Tuesday. The dollar fell to 1.5305 German marks, from 1.5365 marks on Tuesday, and to 1.2955 Swiss francs from 1.3025 francs.
But the weakness of the dollar failed to drive it below the tight currency ranges that have dominated trading in recent weeks.
In other currency trading, the British pound again came under pressure. Dealers have been concerned about the ability of Prime Minister John Major to stop a growing rift within the ruling Conservative Party over increased economic integration within the European Union. Dealers were selling pounds to buy marks yesterday, and the pound fell to a five-month low of 2.3756 marks before recovering in New York to 2.3814 marks.
The pound's weakness spilled over into dollar trading. The pound fell to a one-month low of $1.5502 in New York before recovering to settle at $1.5534, down from $1.5565 in New York on Tuesday.
Separately, the Federal Reserve confirmed yesterday that it bought $2.6 billion worth of dollars in November to prop up the value of the dollar. The Fed said it spent German marks to purchase $800 million in dollars and spent yen to purchase another $800 million in dollars on Nov. 2, in one of the largest one-day interventions in recent years.
The following day, the Fed spent more yen and marks to buy an additional $1 billion in dollars. The Fed bought an equal amount of dollars with the yen and marks it spent, said Peter R. Fisher, executive vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at a quarterly briefing on the Fed's foreign exchange dealings yesterday.
In both interventions, one other foreign central bank -- which the Fed declined to name -- participated in the yen sales, Mr. Fisher said.
