HEADLINE: A Troubled Orchestra Faces Radical Surgery

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
The Louisville Orchestra, an ensemble long renowned for its adventurous recording series and its festivals devoted to contemporary music, is facing the fight of its life. And musicians and orchestra managers elsewhere in the country are watching with concern, since a proposed restructuring of the orchestra may have ramifications for other ensembles as well.
The management and board, fretting over a $710,000 accumulated deficit, a projected deficit of $410,000 for next season and an expected drop in income, are demanding that the players abandon the three-year contract they negotiated in 1993 and accept a radical makeover. Under their plan, only 45 of the orchestra's 67 musicians would keep their full-time positions; the other 22 would become part-time players. 
 The proposed new contract also calls for salary cuts and a shrinking of the orchestra's season to 40 weeks from 45. All told, the budget for salaries would be reduced to $1.93 million from $2.41 million.
The board has given the players until March 7 to accept its terms, and has raised the stakes by announcing that subscription marketing and fund-raising events for next season will be suspended until an agreement is reached. Moreover, the Greater Louisville Fund for the Arts, which has several board members in common with the orchestra, has said that the orchestra's annual $1 million grant -- about one-fifth of its budget -- may be in peril. By starving itself of ticket income and contributions, the board is preparing to invoke a clause of the 1993 contract that allows it to dissolve the orchestra for lack of operating funds.
The musicians, who have already made staff and salary concessions totaling $300,000 this season, were stunned by the restructuring proposal, which may cost some players as much as half their incomes. Base pay in Louisville is just under $24,000, low by regional-orchestra standards and roughly one-third the salary New York Philharmonic players earn in a 52-week season.
"This is a proposal designed to encourage the orchestra's bargaining unit to cannibalize itself," said Liza Hirsch Du Brul, the lawyer representing the musicians. "It sets up the expectation that some players will be betting with themselves that they'll be among the 45, and that if the majority will be O.K., they can outvote the minority. This orchestra has already seen cut and betrayal after cut and betrayal, but it will probably not cannibalize itself."
It is not only among Louisville's musicians that the plan is playing badly. Although financial strains have led other orchestras to adopt multiple-tier arrangements of full-time, part-time and occasional freelance players -- the Kansas City Symphony, the Syracuse Symphony and the Columbus Symphony, among them -- none are as prominent as Louisville. And musicians elsewhere fear that if the plan goes through, their own managements will pursue similar restructuring in future negotiations.
"A two-tier system is something a lot of us had hoped we'd gotten rid of," said Robert Levine, the principal violist of the Milwaukee Symphony and the editor of Senza Sordino, the newsletter of the International Conference of Symphony and Opera Musicians. "My first job was in an orchestra with a three-tier system. It takes a toll on musical cohesiveness. And it creates tensions between the full-time and part-time players. The idea has been floated here, not formally, in contract negotiations, but I've heard management fantasize about it."
For the Louisville musicians, all this could not come at a worse time. The orchestra's last music director, Lawrence Leighton Smith, retired in July, and the players worry that experienced conductors will be wary of working with a two-tier ensemble.
Right now a war of numbers is raging in Louisville. The musicians have hired two consultants, Ron Bauers of the University of Nebraska and William Thompson, a former associate director of the conservatory at the University of Missouri, to produce their own audit.
Instead of a $410,000 deficit next season, Mr. Bauers and Mr. Thompson project a $96,000 surplus. They point out that the orchestra's endowment of more than $9 million is among the highest in the country for an orchestra of its size, and that other orchestras with similar budgets -- the New Jersey Symphony and the Florida Orchestra of Tampa -- have larger deficits but have not resorted to the draconian measures proposed in Louisville.
Mr. Bauers and Mr. Thompson also say that management's pessimism runs against recent trends. They say, for example, that although subscription sales have dipped, single-ticket sales have risen, accounting for a $3,300 weekly increase in box office income between 1992 and 1994. They point to a nearly 400 percent increase in corporate donations and an 82 percent increase in private giving between 1990 and 1994. The management budget predicts drops in all those areas.
"If the board and management want to abandon the obligations to the musicians," Ms. Du Brul said, "the onus is on them to prove that there's a financial crisis. Not only haven't they done that, but they make these demands in the context of not having honored anything in the 1993 contract."
The board, not surprisingly, sees a very different financial picture.
"Mr. Bauers's report does not take certain critical factors into account," said Ted Rosky, a member of the board, who sees the contribution trend figures as flawed because they include one-time gifts and income from special, nonrecurring events. He also said that changes in the market had kept the endowment from generating as much interest income as the orchestra had expected. Like all arts organizations, the orchestra is also fearing cuts in government support, which this year totals about $270,000. And competition from Louisville's other cultural assets -- including a theater, a museum and a newly renovated theater used for pop concerts -- has cut into the orchestra's audience at a rate of 6 percent a year.
"Many people in the community believe that when the orchestra went full time in 1981, it went too far, too fast," Mr. Rosky said. "At the time, the arts economy was booming, and it was envisioned that the opera and ballet would make extensive use of the orchestra, but those organizations have been financially pressed as well. In fact, the orchestra has been losing about $300,000 a year."
But Ms. Du Brul contends that the proposed restructuring has "an ideological purpose," and musicians both in Louisville and around the country agree. They regard the move as rooted in the 1992 Wolf Report. Commissioned by the American Symphony Orchestra League, a management organization, the report suggested that there were too many full-time, salaried orchestras for the American arts market to bear.
Wayne S. Brown, the orchestra's executive director, is also on the board of the league, but vehemently rejects the players' suggestion that the Louisville Orchestra is a crucible in which the league's agenda is being tested.
"What I think this all boils down to," Mr. Brown said, "is that the operation cannot continue to expand in scale. We have an orchestra with a $4.6 million budget in a community of less than a million people, and that's probably as far as we can go. So the question we face is, how can we reposition the orchestra in the market available to us? It's vital that we and the players find common ground for the sake of the institution, and that we do it before it's too late."
Management is holding a trump card. If it does dismiss the orchestra after the March 7 deadline, the institution and its board will continue to exist, and could reconstitute the Louisville Orchestra on its own terms.
"Long term," said Mr. Rosky, the board member, "there will be an orchestra in Louisville. Short term? That's a good question."

COMPANY: LOUISVILLE ORCHESTRA

HEADLINE: In a Mixed Session, Dow Slips 2.02 Points

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For the second consecutive session, stock prices closed mixed but little changed yesterday, except for a modest rally among Nasdaq issues, where two stocks accounted for much of the rise.
A weak dollar, hobbled by a report of a widening Japanese trade surplus with the United States, helped drag down stock prices. 
 After rising nearly 16 points, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.02 points, to 3,935.37, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.38 point, to 481.19. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 4.80 points, to 783.77.
Much of the rise in Nasdaq stocks came from the Intel Corporation and Amgen Inc.
Shares of Intel, the semiconductor maker, hit a 52-week high of 7615/16 before closing at 76 5/8, up 3 5/8. A Merrill Lynch analyst said Intel, a favorite of institutional investors, seemed to be selling more Pentium microprocessors than expected, despite a widely publicized flaw.
Shares of Amgen, a biotechnology company, also set a 52-week high, of 76 1/8, before closing at 70 3/4, up 5 3/8. Traders speculated that Amgen might be bought by the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, but neither company would comment.
Almost as many stocks fell as gained on the New York Stock Exchange, rising stocks outnumbering decliners, 1,134 to 1,054.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.03 point, to 261.67, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.80 points, to 445.94.
Stock traders are likely to be on the sidelines today in advance of tonmorrow's important Producer Price Index, a measure of wholesale inflation that often moves markets. And the Treasury Department completes its $40 billion quarterly refunding today by selling about $11 billion of benchmark 30-year bonds. Bond traders are often reluctant to buy other kinds of bonds while the Government is selling its bonds, a hesitancy that often influences the stock market, too.
Corporate earnings for many stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, the stock gauge most widely followed by market professionals, have come in at surprisingly high levels helping to support stock prices, however modestly.
Bloomberg Business News reported that nearly 60 percent, or 225 of 390 reporting stocks of the S.& P. 500, reported positive surprises. And the median for positive earnings surprises was 7.7 percent.
Shares of International Cabletel, a provider of telecommunications services, rose 2 1/2, to 33 1/2, in part because a Salomon Brothers analyst recommended the stock. And shares of the Cablevision Systems Corporation rose after Dan Dorfman reported a rumor on the CNBC cable channel that the AT&T Corporation might

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senator Lays Out Pain of Balanced Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Democrats like to note that Republicans keep promising to balance the Federal budget but never seem to get around to saying how they plan to do it, much less who will suffer as a result. But one Republican with a substantial say in the matter has detailed notions about how to eliminate the deficit, and now he is laying them out -- suffering and all.
He is Senator Judd Gregg, a conservative freshman from New Hampshire whose personal fiscal views, like those of other first-termers, might ordinarily inspire yawns. But Mr. Gregg is different: this winter the majority leader, Bob Dole, designated him to comb through the Federal budget's $850 billion in mandatory spending programs, like Medicare and Federal pensions, in search of savings to apply to the deficit. 
 So, Mr. Gregg's views on deficit-cutting carry weight. And as it turns out, they include something to offend just about everybody.
Mr. Gregg jokes that this job is unpleasant enough that his working group meets in a phone booth, which is nearly true: only 5 of the 53 Republicans senators have been regulars at its meetings. Perhaps a dozen more have dropped by once or twice.
In an interview last week, Mr. Gregg, who turns 48 on Tuesday, spent an hour describing cuts and shifts in spending on Federal benefit programs that he said would save at least $350 billion through the end of the decade, and much more after that. These programs include freezing most Federal welfare spending for five years, as Republican leaders proposed today; lowering cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security recipients and Federal pensioners; overhauling the generous retirement system for Federal workers, and raising Medicare premiums for the well-off elderly.
He would also raise the retirement age for the baby-boom generation and its successors and encourage workers to leave the Social Security system for private pension plans -- both moves, he says, that are necessary to keep Social Security from busting the bank in the next century.
Congress has ruled out altering Social Security; whether the rest will make it into Mr. Gregg's formal budget-cutting proposal later this month is unclear. But if the Republican Senate does not produce a serious plan to reduce the explosive growth of Federal benefit programs, he said he would not hesitate to offer his own.
"In New Hampshire, people respect you if you tell them what the problem is and tell them what the solution is," he said.
His solution is open to challenge by doubters who call some of its savings illusory and by critics who assert that it would neglect society's neediest. But it would be hard to call it the easy way out of the deficit morass. Its main elements shrink programs, like health care and retirement, that millions of voters and scores of lobbies guard jealously.
"Unless you really get into health care accounts and pension accounts, you do not solve the short-term issue," Mr. Gregg said. "And you cannot solve the long-term issue unless you solve the short-term issue."
Mr. Gregg calls some of those lobbies, especially those representing the elderly, "outrageous scaremongers." The real threat to economic security, he said, is a deficit that promises to bankrupt the Government within a few decades.
Still, some of Mr. Gregg's proposals seem to have a streak of ideological purity that belies the complexity of both the deficit and of national politics.
While House Republicans would attach certain Federal strings to welfare block grants, for example, like limiting payments to unwed mothers, Mr. Gregg would simply let the states run them as they choose. Indeed, he would eventually end Federal welfare grants, lower Federal tax rates to reflect that and tell the states to pay for the programs by raising taxes themselves.
Such straightforward logic troubles some in Congress who note that many states -- like New Hampshire, which does not even have an income tax -- have little appetite for a tax increase, and might cut support for the poor to unacceptable levels. Mr. Gregg agreed that was a problem -- but with state control, he said, comes state responsibility.
"He's one of the most conservative men in the Senate," said a top aide to a Democratic senator. "The difference between Judd Gregg and us soft, pudgy liberals is that I don't have the stomach for that gamble. And it's a big gamble."
True enough, but not all of Mr. Gregg's allies are ideological conservatives. Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican who is a paragon of moderation, has sat in on Mr. Gregg's budget meetings and says his ideas have much merit.
"I think the moderates are deficit hawks," Mr. Chafee said. "They are willing to take some serious steps to do something about it."
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which is responsible for many of the programs Mr. Gregg wants to trim, said he not only agreed with many of Mr. Gregg's views, but also might even go farther in some areas.
"I don't find the public unwilling to sacrifice if they think the sacrifice is fairly shared and we explain why," Mr. Packwood said.

HEADLINE: Delta Limits Commissions, Stirring Outrage of Agents

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
In the most dramatic escalation yet of a simmering dispute between Delta Air Lines and travel agents, the airline imposed a limit yesterday on commissions for domestic air fares, and agents reacted with the fury of partners scorned.
Their anger was stoked by fear that if Delta succeeded, the other major carriers -- all of which are also looking to cut costs -- might soon follow suit. 
 "If the other airlines go along, it will put about 10,000 agencies out of business," said Blake Fleetwood, head of the Planetarium/American Express agency in Manhattan.
Jeanne Epping, chairman and president of the American Society of Travel Agents, said she was "shocked and outraged" by Delta's decision.
Agents also smarted at Delta's statement that the upper limit was effective immediately, not giving the trade group time to complain again to the Justice Department, as it did last fall when Delta lowered commissions on international fares to 8 percent from 10 percent.
Until yesterday, Delta had continued paying 10 percent on domestic bookings. Now, though, it will pay a maximum of $50 for any round-trip domestic ticket with a base fare above $500, and $25 for any one-way domestic ticket with a base fare above $250. The caps, which the carrier estimated would affect about 20 percent of its tickets issued by travel agents, apply to all tickets issued for travel in and between the continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands.
Consumers will not realize any savings on ticket prices as a result of the move. Indeed, some travel agents noted that they would have less incentive to book clients on Delta than on competing carriers that would pay them higher commissions.
Robert W. Coggin, senior vice president for marketing at Delta, argued that the realities of today's marketplace required substantial changes if the airline was to compete successfully. Delta has a goal of lowering annual operating costs $2 billion by mid-1997.
"It is no longer economically feasible to pay a fixed 10 percent commission for the distribution of all Delta tickets," Mr. Coggin said.
In the four quarters ending in June 1994, the airline paid $870 million in domestic commissions.
An industry analyst, Robert A. Moss, president of Travel Intelligence Inc. in Lexington, Mass., said, "I have to assume Delta made its decision yesterday because it wasn't bloodied after lowering the commission on international fares."
Carlson Wagons-Lits Travel, with more than 4,000 travel agencies worldwide, criticized Delta as "shortsighted."
"It doesn't cut costs; it just transfers them onto the backs of consumers via the travel agent," said Doug Cody, a spokesman for Carlson Wagons-Lits, which is one of Delta's most important customers.
Ivan Michael Schaeffer, president and chief executive of the Woodside Travel Trust of Bethesda, Md., with more than 130 agencies, described Delta's action as "inequitable and unfair." It fails to recognize that agents are not adequately compensated for their work when they write tickets for the Delta Shuttle or during fare wars, he said.
Mr. Coggin of Delta said the carrier realized that agents were not making a profit on every ticketing transaction. But commissions paid on high-revenue tickets, he said, "should not be used to subsidize the costs of a travel agent's other business transactions."
Delta said it decided on the commission limit, rather than reducing the base commission rate on all its domestic tickets, after considering its cost-reduction program and the specific costs that travel agents incur in writing tickets.
It said that to address "the legitimate business needs of travel agents who have contractual relationships with corporate customers," it would allow agents to continue collecting commissions up to 10 percent on that part of their business through March 31.
To do so, an agent must submit an affidavit to Delta stating that the agency has contractual obligations with one or more corporate accounts that need to be renegotiated as a result of the action taken yesterday.

HEADLINE: The Welfare Enigma

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
If anyone knew for sure how to lift people out of poverty, Americans would embrace the solution eagerly. It would make everyone's life safer and more prosperous.
But no one does know, and no one has known since people first started thinking and talking about the problem in biblical times. 
 Every plan to overhaul the nation's welfare system that has been proposed for the last 25 years has died on the vine, unable to resolve contradictions that are endemic to the debate.
The problem is not that anyone defends the existing system: politicians and scholars from all points on the political compass agree it is a mess, a costly hodgepodge of conflicting Federal and state programs that, as Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr. said today, have "destroyed responsibility, diminished personal dignity and created economic disincentives that bar people from success."
Nor is there disagreement over goals. The welfare reform proposals of Presidents Nixon, Carter, Reagan and Clinton approached the matter from different perspectives, but their goals were the same: to get as many people as possible off welfare and onto payrolls and somehow to break the chain of dysfunction that keeps some families on relief for generation after generation.
The plan outlined today by Mr. Shaw, a Florida Republican, has the same goals but is grounded on three new principles: tough love for poor people, less cost for the Federal Government and more flexibility for the states.
But however worthy the goals and however sensible the principles, it will probably not become law either unless its Republican sponsors come to grips with the seemingly intractable contradictions that bedeviled all the other proposals of the last quarter century.
For instance, the least expensive and most efficient welfare system would simply give poor people cash, no strings attached. That would eliminate the bureaucracy that is one of the system's most costly and despised aspects. But simple handouts go against the grain. Most Americans believe that people who can work ought to. And getting people to work costs money.
The difficulty is that jobs are scarce in the inner cities and rural communities where welfare beneficiaries generally live. Many people on welfare are uneducated and have few skills. Job-training programs are expensive and often fruitless.
The Republican plan would require that, after two years on welfare, people take jobs or become part of some work program. But what jobs? What programs? Who would pay for them? So far, those questions have not been addressed.
The Government has succeeded in bringing only one group of Americans out of poverty: the elderly.
Thirty years ago, a third of the aged lived in poverty, and tens of millions of others avoided destitution only by living with their children. Now, mostly because of expanded Social Security benefits and the advent of Medicare, the poverty rate among the elderly is substantially lower than it is for other Americans, and the vast majority of older people are financially self-sufficient.
Federal assistance to the elderly has been universally accepted. Why? Because the aged are not expected to work. So the trade-off between work and benefits does not arise.
Another contradiction is what to do about people's welfare checks after they go to work. If they are going to be cut off from public assistance, there is little incentive for welfare beneficiaries to take low-paying jobs. But if Government payments continue after they go work, they will have more income than those they are working with side-by-side who have never been on welfare.
And what about those on welfare who simply cannot work because they are mentally or emotionally unstable or physically disabled? By some estimates, 20 percent or more of welfare recipients fit into this category. Theoretically, they could be covered by a Government program called Supplemental Security Income, which used to be called aid to the aged, blind and disabled, or their children could be placed in foster care.
But the S.S.I. program has been rife with fraud, and the Republicans have promised to crack down. Furthermore, it would cost considerably more to put adults on S.S.I. and children in foster homes than to make welfare payments.
The architects of welfare programs have also never resolved what to do about the root of most welfare cases -- unwed mothers. All politicians from Senator Phil Gramm of Texas to the Rev. Jesse Jackson want to discourage teen-age pregnancies, but hard as they have tried over the years, the problem has become worse.
Still, few politicians if any advocate mandatory abortions for women on welfare who become pregnant, and few would require women on welfare to use implanted contraceptives to prevent further pregnancies.
The Republican solution is to disallow welfare payments to unmarried mothers under 18 and to prohibit additional payments to women who have children while they are on welfare.
Liberals object to this idea because they think it punishes innocent children, and many conservatives are opposed because they fear it would encourage abortions.
Most social workers who have spent time with poor, young women doubt that changes in welfare policy would prevent pregnancies. In a paper published in this year's Rockefeller Institute Bulletin, Jan L. Hagen and Liane V. Davis, both professors of social work, described their interviews with mothers on welfare.
One woman who they said was typical told them: "You're young, you're madly in love with this guy and you go and have this baby. Welfare doesn't have nothing to do with your having babies. Nothing. Nothing whatsoever."
A final contradiction upon which previous efforts to change the welfare system have become snagged involved the relationship between Federal and state requirements.
No one disputes Mr. Shaw's assessment that "the welfare problems of the South Bronx are not the same as the welfare problems of South Dakota."
But many experts question the Republican solution to turn the matter over to the states and to freeze for the next five years the amount of Federal money spent in each state.
Isabel V. Sawhill, an academic specialist in welfare policy who recently left a top position in the Office of Management and Budget to take an endowed chair at the Urban Institute, a research organization here, said she could not understand why some governors had embraced the Republican plan.
"I think they're kidding themselves about how much they can save through administrative efficiency," she said. "I'm afraid they're either going to pass the burden on to local governments or they're going to leave people homeless and have to take the blame for it."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Kohl Criticize Chechnya Assault but Stress Support for Yeltson

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
President Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany today criticized Russia's assault on Chechnya but said it was nonetheless vital to continue supporting President Boris N. Yeltsin, warning that anti-democratic forces could take power in Moscow if the West abandoned him.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kohl -- the two Western leaders who are closest to Mr. Yeltsin -- faulted Russia for using such heavy force and urged it to end the war in the breakaway region of Chechnya as quickly as possible even as they gave the Russian leader their strongest embrace since Moscow first attacked Chechnya in December. 
 At a joint news conference at the White House, Mr. Kohl said, "If we were to push the forces of reform and the President into a corner, isolate them, and say, 'We give up on you -- there's nothing we can do here,' then this will immediately bring us back to the old, bad structures of the past."
Mr. Kohl is in Washington for one day to discuss Chechnya, Bosnia, expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and other issues with Mr. Clinton and to meet the new Republican leaders in Congress.
To demonstrate concern about the crisis in Chechnya, Mr. Clinton announced today that the United States would provide $20 million in emergency aid to Chechnya to provide food, medicine and shelter.
Although many members of Congress have faulted the Administration for standing by Mr. Yeltsin despite Russia's offensive in Chechnya, Mr. Clinton said it was important not to let disagreements over the issue derail Washington's overarching strategy of improving ties with Moscow and encouraging reform there.
"You have to be willing to deal with the rough spots in the road, say where you disagree and stay on course," Mr. Clinton said, urging Russia to negotiate a peace settlement with the Chechens.
Mr. Clinton said he and Mr. Kohl had told Mr. Yeltsin that they feared that the conflict in Chechnya would undermine Russia's moves toward democracy and free markets. At the news conference, where Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kohl boasted of their own and their countries' strong ties, the two leaders warned Mr. Yeltsin that foreign aid could be threatened if he reverses his moves toward democracy and capitalism.
"Today the Chancellor and I remained determined to stick to our course of patient, responsible support for Russian reform," Mr. Clinton said. "But help can only be extended if Russia stays on the course and continues the hard work of building democratic institutions and implementing market-oriented reforms."
Both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kohl asserted that notwithstanding his role in invading Chechnya, Mr. Yeltsin could still be trusted. Noting that the Russian leader kept his word by withdrawing all Russian troops from East Germany as promised, Mr. Kohl said, "I personally have experienced Boris Yeltsin as a man on whom one can rely absolutely."
While Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kohl were reaffirming support for Mr. Yeltsin, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott told a Congressional subcommittee that the Administration's strategy was to concentrate on supporting specific policies, rather than specific personalities.
At the hearing, Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican who heads the Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, criticized the Administration for cozying up to Mr. Yeltsin despite his role in Chechnya and his closer ties with opponents of economic reform.
Mr. McConnell told Mr. Talbott, "Instead of being champions for democracy, we have become cheerleaders for Yeltsin, a President that is at this point virtually indistinguishable in practice from politicians you suggest we should dread."
Mr. Talbott denied that the Administration was focusing all its attention on Mr. Yeltsin, saying it was trying to maintain contacts with a range of reformers in Russia.
But he, too, urged Mr. Yeltsin not to veer from the road toward democracy and free markets.
"Chechnya has raised questions old and new about where Russia is going and what kind of state it will be in the next century," Mr. Talbott said.
At their news conference, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kohl dwelt upon a concern that sent Mr. Yeltsin into a rage in December at a conference in Budapest: expanding NATO. The two leaders said the alliance would definitely expand eastward, but sought to reassure Russia that this would not pose a threat.
"We agreed that the inevitable process of NATO expansion will be gradual and open, that there will be no surprises," Mr. Clinton said.
The two leaders sought to reassure nations of the former Warsaw Pact that adding new countries to NATO is in no way intended to create new divisions in Europe.
Mr. Kohl said, "The extension of NATO is part of an overall security concept, which is intended to make sure that we do not get new boundaries within Europe, and that is why a close partnership with Russia and Ukraine is especially important."

HEADLINE: Record Lows Afflict the South, But Little Crop Damage Is Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Temperatures across the Southeast fell to record lows yesterday, the third consecutive day of abnormally cold weather brought by a high-pressure system.
Orlando, Fla., a tourist center in Central Florida, had a record low of 30 degrees for the date. Other cities posting record lows: Greer, S.C., 9 degrees; Bristol, Tenn., 1,; Huntsville, Ala., 14, and Columbus, Ga., 18. Key West, Fla., the southernmost part of the continental United States, tied its record of 49 degrees, set on Feb., 9, 1895. 
 In Georgia, 12 counties kept their schools closed after the State Department of Transportation warned that roads were still icy from the snow that fell early on Wednesday. More snow was forecast for last night in some areas. There were also school closings in other Southern states as well.
In Florida, crops mostly avoided frost damage because of low humidity. A National Weather Service meteorologist, Scott Carroll, said, "Farmers don't want to see freezing temperatures at the ground, which is what frost is. It didn't get a chance to form." Many farmers also sprayed crops with water to protect them from the cold.
Florida Citrus Mutual, the big growers' cooperative, said the economic effect of the cold on the Central Florida citrus belt would not be severe. Still, fruit pickers have been scurrying to harvest as much fruit as possible, and processing plants have been running around the clock.
In South Florida, the cold meant a banner sales day for Beach True Value hardware in Fort Lauderdale. "If I had more space heaters, I'd be selling them, but I can't seem to find any more," said Sandy Sadar, the store's co-owner.
At Myrtle Beach, S.C., two kayakers drew stares as they paddled through the 47-degree water of the Atlantic. "I guess it does take some insanity," said Chris Jensen, a Coastal Carolina University student. "It's pretty cold, but it's exercise."

HEADLINE: Dow Dips by 2.69 as Stocks Close Mixed

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday with many investors on the sidelines ahead of today's report on producer prices for January.
It was the third consecutive session in which stocks were mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 2.69 points to close at 3,932.68, while the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1 point, to 480.19. But the Nasdaq composite index rose 1.67 points, to 785.44, led by strong gains in computer chip issues. 
 The market was weighed down by worries that today's Labor Department report on producer prices would show a pickup in inflation. Many traders were waiting to see if the inflation numbers confirm Wall Street's view that the economy was slowing enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising short-term interest rates again.
 "If we get worse-than-expected numbers, look out," said Guy Truicko, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management, "There's definitely a lot of complacency with regard to future interest rate rises."
 Stocks rallied sharply last Friday after the Government's employment report for January suggested that the economy was slowing to a pace at which the Federal Reserve could curb its policy of raising short-term interest rates. Higher interest rates mean higher borrowing costs for companies, cutting into earnings.
"The consensus is now that the Fed has done enough with the rates," said Bill Allyn, head of trading at Jefferies & Company. "Maybe Friday will just fortify that consensus, or it could maybe create a crack in the armor of that camp."
Semiconductor stocks led the rise in technology shares amid speculation that the industry's monthly book-to-bill report would show strong demand.
"The chips are up on the book-to-bill, and it's pulling the computer and systems up with it because you have to put those chips in something," said Thomas Schlesinger, an equity strategist at A. G. Edwards.
After the market closed, the Semiconductor Industry Association said the seasonally adjusted book-to-bill ratio rose to 1.10 in January from a seasonally adjusted ratio of 1.07 in December. A book-to-bill ratio of 1.10 indicates that for every $100 worth of products shipped, or billed, manufacturers received $110 of new orders, or bookings.
Shares of the Intel Corporation rose 7/8, to 77 1/2; Micron Technology Inc. gained 2 1/4, to 50 1/8; Hewlett-Packard added 2 7/8, to 106 1/8, and Apple Computer ended up 15/16 at 43 5/8.
AST Research Inc.'s AST Computer and Texas Instruments Inc. said they had reached a cross-license agreement covering personal computer patents, settling litigation between the two companies. Texas Instruments gained 3 3/8, to 78 3/8 ,and AST added 7/16 , to15 7/16 .
Amgen Inc. fell 4, to 66 3/4, after the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said it was not in acquisition talks with Amgen. Amgen surged 5 3/8 Wednesday on rumors of a deal. An initial public offering of Information Storage Devices Inc., a maker of circuits for voice recording and playback, jumped 12 1/4 from its starting price at $15.
America Online Inc. leaped 3 1/8, to 65 7/8, after reporting Wednesday that its fiscal second-quarter revenues more than tripled.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell. The American Stock Exchange index was up 0.39, to 446.33.
The N.Y.S.E. Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.46, to 261.21. The average share was down 5 cents.

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
A Street Conservative -- George John Marlin

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
As the new executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, George J. Marlin, a self-described "street-corner conservative" from Queens, now faces a fundamental philosophical challenge: running the kind of expansive governmental agency whose very agenda he might otherwise oppose.
The Port Authority's mission from its inception has been to use its quasi-governmental powers, coupled with its ability to issue bonds and condemn property, to promote the economies of the two states, something very much at odds with the beliefs of free-market conservatives like Mr. Marlin. 
 Indeed, the new Republican Governors of the two states have made it clear that some of the Port Authority's responsibilities, like managing the region's airports, may be better left to the private sector, and Mr. Marlin may be just the person to carry out that transformation.
Last month, Gov. George E. Pataki recommended Mr. Marlin for the $170,000-a-year post, which technically is filled by the Port Authority board but in fact has for two decades been subject to nomination by New York's governor with the consent of New Jersey's. This week, after expressing reservations about Mr. Marlin's lack of administrative experience, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman told Mr. Pataki that she would go along with his recommendation.
The son and grandson of New York City police officers, George John Marlin, 42, is an investment banker, amateur historian and editor of anthologies of the English writer G. K. Chesterton's wit. Unlike his predecessors at the Port Authority, all of whom were steeped in public sector administration and crisis management, Mr. Marlin has never served in government.
Nor, in his previous attempt at public office, did he even come close.
As the mayoral candidate of the Conservative and the Right-to-Life parties in 1993, he received 15,912 votes, or less than 1 percent of the total. During the campaign, Mr. Marlin portrayed himself as the lone conservative champion of the city's forgotten neighborhoods, a philosophical son of Archie Bunker's Queens running against Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani, who, he said were both liberals.
"Whoever said there's no Democratic or Republican way of picking up the garbage was wrong," Mr. Marlin said, referring to the comment by former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, a Republican. "You have to have an underlying philosophy, principles that are built on that, and from there you establish public policy. I have a world view: government is fundamentally failing the city."
"We have to make government small," he said in an interview last year. "It's government that drives business out."
Mr. Marlin has given few clues as to how he would reconcile his aversion to big government with his new job. In earlier interviews, though, he said he favored selling the land beneath the region's three major airports to private investors and exploring the sale of the World Trade Center, too -- asset sales that, once bondholders are paid, might prove less of a windfall.
Some maintain that Mr. Marlin, a true outsider, is a natural for the job.
"George Marlin is a highly intelligent guy, a very thoughtful person and a very caring person," said Michael Long, the state Conservative Party chairman. "While he has a strong point of view, he's also a very logical individual who knows you have to work within the system."
Mr. Marlin, a lanky 6-foot-6 look-a-like for the actor Edward Herrman, was born Dec. 9, 1952, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, to a family of what he calls "Al Smith Democrats." He attended Monsignor Clancy High School in Jackson Heights, Queens, and graduated from Iona College with a degree in political science and philosophy. He then went to work for Marine Midland Bank in Buffalo, where he met his wife, Barbara.
But a few Buffalo winters brought the Marlins back to New York City, where they Marlins bought a 90-year-old row house in Glendale. Mr. Marlin joined United States Trust Company as a portfolio manager and specialist in public finance. Barbara Marlin is an executive secretary at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the investment banking firm.
Mr. Marlin was the first enrolled Republican in his family. As a 13-year-old, he distributed campaign leaflets for William F. Buckley Jr., the Conservative candidate for mayor in 1965. Later, he forged links with political leaders and elected officials as the representative of a coalition of police officers who were laid off during the city's 1975 fiscal crisis.
But it was the dispute over condom availability in the public schools that propelled him into politics a generation later, and helped earn him the nomination of the Conservative Party in the 1993 mayoral race. (He flatly opposed the Board of Education's condom plan as pre-empting parental prerogatives.) His effect on the mayoral campaign was marginal, though, and largely nonideological: All three major candidates never debated together because Mr. Dinkins demanded that Mr. Marlin be included -- to help undermine Mr. Giuliani's conservative support.
Mr. Marlin's mayoral campaign slogan was "It's our city, fight back," by which he meant, he said, that all of the city's neighborhoods needed to fend off "social engineers" employed by the government who had abrogated power and arrogantly exercised it.
He acknowledged that his predominantly white ethnic neighborhood might no longer be representative of the city. But he described it as emblematic of the bootstrap spirit among immigrants that is revitalizing other neighborhoods.
"This is a formula that worked," he said then. "These neighborhoods, when they thrive, the city thrived. But they've been hurt and government has hurt them."
The Marlin home looks much like it might have a century ago, the drawing room crammed with the New York and political memorabilia and books by and about Chesterton that constitute Mr. Marlin's avocation. One anthology, which Mr. Marlin edited with two friends, includes two relevant quotations:
"What we need, as the ancients understood, is not a politician who is a business man, but a king who is a philosopher," Chesterton wrote. He also said, "He is a very shallow critic who cannot see an eternal rebel in the heart of the conservative."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Seeking stability, Wells Rich Greene BDDP sets up a satellite shop.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
ONE of Madison Avenue's best-known creative teams will run a satellite shop spun off from Wells Rich Greene BDDP.
Charlie Moss, the agency's vice chairman and corporate creative director, and Stan Dragoti, the Hollywood director who has collaborated with him on advertising campaigns since 1968, have become chairman and president of a creatively focused spinoff named Moss/Dragoti. The embryonic agency will be based in space adjacent to the Wells Rich office in midtown Manhattan. 
 The satellite, indicative of a growing trend for larger agencies to set up such spinoffs, is part of ambitious efforts by Wells Rich to regain its footing after two years of problems caused by the loss or resignation of important accounts like Alka-Seltzer Plus Cold Medicine, Continental Airlines, I.B.M., Reckitt & Colman and Seagram's spirits brands.
"We've gone through a lot of restructuring and changing people at the top," said Kenneth S. Olshan, chairman and chief executive at Wells Rich Greene BDDP Communications, the parent of Wells Rich, which is owned by BDDP Worldwide in Paris.
"We hope what we're doing is evolving the agency into something with a different configuration that will be very competitive for the future," he added.
Moss/Dragoti embodies that, Mr. Olshan said, because it is aimed at a pressing client need: to hire the "very senior people" at agencies who "have the ability to work very quickly to solve problems."
"Don't fire your agency," he added, as if talking to a potential client of Moss/Dragoti. "When you run into a corner and you can't solve a problem, here are two great guys -- who are grown-ups -- to solve it for you."
Adweek has called Mr. Moss, 56, a copywriter, the "creative soul" of Wells Rich; he was the first creative staff member hired in 1966 by Mary Wells Lawrence, the agency's co-founder. Mr. Dragoti, 60, joined Wells Rich to head the art department in 1968 after stints as an art director at Compton Advertising and Young & Rubicam.
The pair was responsible for a popular series of humorous commercials for the American Motors Corporation, featuring actors like Robert De Niro, Richard Dreyfuss and Herb Edelman pitching oddball car models like the Matador and the Rebel. There are many agency executives, and not a few consumers, who can still recall the catch phrase "Hey, Javelin!" from one spot.
Mr. Dragoti left Wells Rich in 1971 for a film career that has included directing the hit comedies "Mr. Mom" and "Love at First Bite." But for the last two decades, the duo has continued to work together on a transcontinentally commuting basis, producing campaigns like "I <heart> New York" for the New York State Department of Economic Development, "Midasize" for the Midas International Corporation and "Hertz. Exactly" for the Hertz Corporation.
"A strategic creative resource -- that's the way we see ourselves," Mr. Moss said, adding, "We enjoy working together so much, and have wanted to work together full time for such a long time, this is a natural thing to happen."
Mr. Dragoti said: "I guess I'm an ad junkie. I'd rather do a big idea on the small screen than a small idea on the big screen."
Mr. Moss said spinoffs like Moss/ Dragoti; Amster Yard, from McCann-Erickson Worldwide, and Castle Underwood, from TBWA Advertising, "really speak to getting back to working more directly with clients, being more hands-on about the work and ideas being what really drive the business -- ideas that solve problems."
Moss/Dragoti will work for Wells Rich clients and seek its own accounts; for instance, the spinoff will handle the creative portion of the Hertz account while Wells Rich will continue handling account management and other services. Moss/Dragoti has also landed the account of Parallel Communications, a paging systems company in New York, for which the billings were not disclosed.
Moss/Dragoti will be owned by Wells Rich Greene BDDP Communications; Mr. Moss and Mr. Dragoti have been granted undisclosed stakes that Mr. Moss described as "a healthy participation." They also plan to make nontraditional compensation arrangements with clients such as taking equity interests.
"We feel we've made a lot of money for people over the years," Mr. Moss said, "and we think we can do it again. Why not share in that?"
There will be no successor to Mr. Moss at Wells Rich. Mr. Olshan said Linda Kaplan Thaler, who left J. Walter Thompson New York in June to join Wells Rich as executive vice president and executive creative director, would now become the senior creative executive. Two advertisers that have worked with her, Clairol and Toys "R" Us, recently awarded Wells Rich an account and an assignment, respectively.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Journal of Commerce Is Sold for $115 Million

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The British company that publishes The Economist magazine will pay $115 million to buy The Journal of Commerce from Knight-Ridder Inc., the companies said yesterday.
The Economist Group will buy The Journal of Commerce Inc., the New York-based company that includes the 21,000-circulation daily financial newspaper and its foreign editions, shipping magazines, industry directories and electronic data services that provide specialized trade and tariff information. 
 The sale must be approved by the boards of both companies.
Marjorie M. Scardino, the chief executive of the Economist Group, said yesterday that the international trade specialization of The Journal of Commerce Inc.'s products made it an attractive growth vehicle for The Economist Group in the United States and internationally.
Some analysts said the price was toward the upper end of prices recently paid for newspaper companies. Tod A. Jacobs, a newspaper analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, estimated the price at 13 times the cash flow of the Journal of Commerce company and double its annual revenue, which he estimated at $55 million to $60 million.
Mrs. Scardino acknowledged that "it's not a bargain price."
"We paid partly for the brand name because we believe in quality," she said.
When asked her plans for the newspaper, Mrs. Scardino said, "We intend definitely to grow it." But she said sharp circulation increases were not necessarily the key to success for a publication like The Journal. She added that it was unlikely that there would be any substantial change in the newspaper's focus on international trade.
The newspaper's publisher, Don C. Becker, said it now accounts for about 35 percent of the company's revenue. Mr. Becker will remain as the newspaper's publisher and the president of the company.
James K. Batten, the chairman of Knight-Ridder, said in a statement that his company, which owns 29 daily and nondaily newspapers and financial data information services, was "developing a strategy that moves us away fom the specialized market The Journal of Commerce serves."
Knight-Ridder said it would use the proceeds of the sale to reduce debt and buy shares. Shares of Knight-Ridder were unchanged at $51.125 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
The 168-year-old Journal of Commerce was bought in 1927 by Ridder Publications, one of the companies that merged to become Knight-Ridder in 1974.
The Economist magazine's corporate parent is the Economist Newspaper Ltd., a private company of which Mrs. Scardino, who is American, is the chief executive. The company's formal name includes the word newspaper because The Economist, which has always been bound like a magazine, used to refer to itself as a newspaper and was published on newsprint. The company calls itself the Economist Group.
Half the stock of the Economist Newspaper Ltd. is owned by Pearson P.L.C., the British company that publishes The Financial Times of London and owns, among other businesses, Madame Tussaud's wax museums. The Economist Newspaper Ltd. has its own board and is not controlled by Pearson.
In addition to The Economist, the weekly news and business magazine, the Economist Group publishes other magazines including CFO, a magazine for financial executives, and sells analyses and forecasts on countries and businesses to business clients. It also publishes Roll Call, a newspaper that covers Congress.

HEADLINE: Bradley Switches to Offense;
A Senator Seeks to Fill a Leadership Void in Washington

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
In the last two weeks, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey has suggested on a radio show that President Clinton could face a primary election challenge in 1996 and issued a press release attacking the President's budget. He also delivered a nearly two-hour speech on the Senate floor, denouncing what he called Mr. Clinton's failure to adequately slash the deficit or address the enormous problems facing cities and children.
"That's not thinking about tomorrow," he said repeatedly in the Senate speech Tuesday, playing off Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign theme song, "Don't Stop (Thinking About Tomorrow.)" 
 Today, he delivered another major address, at the National Press Club, where he outlined proposals for promoting parental responsibility and campaign reform -- drawing questions, as he so often does these days, about a possible Presidential candidacy.
But a more likely explanation of Mr. Bradley's recent actions is that he is simply stepping into a void in the Senate's Democratic leadership, trying as best he can to influence the President on fiscal and urban policy -- and speaking his mind because he feels he can.
In 1990, he said, he was forever changed -- "liberated," as he puts it -- by the near-death experience of almost losing his Senate seat to Christine Todd Whitman, who went on to become Governor of New Jersey, chiefly because he was respectfully silent on the tax policy of his fellow Democrat, Gov. Jim Florio, with which he disagreed.
"For 12 years, I was very cautious and I spoke primarily from my mind, and after '90, I decided to speak from my heart as well as my mind, and decided to as much as possible be candid with people and tell the truth," he said in an interview in his office earlier this week. "After the narrow win, when I hadn't spoken out on how I felt in terms of the Florio tax increase, I decided that was never going to happen again.
"I decided I would no longer be restrained from saying what I really felt about issues, that there was a role in American politics for a truth teller and that I was going to try as much as possible to fill that role, because it was essential and because it actually fit my personality, and I had kind of been suppressing that part of my personality for a long time."
In more than 30 years in public life, there has never been a hint of scandal involving Mr. Bradley, a former Rhodes scholar and New York Knick, who seems ideally suited for this self-appointed role.
Mr. Bradley said he does not feel his criticism of the President constitutes a betrayal. "I think frankly he should benefit from having people tell him the truth," he said.
And while it may be frustrating for the President to be undercut by a member of his own party, Senator Bradley is not seen as malicious by the White House, but merely excessively candid.
George Stephanopoulos, senior advisor to the President, said: "Bill Bradley is a well-respected Senator with a lot of strong views on a lot of subjects. And I believe we agree on more than we disagree on, but that doesn't mean there won't be differences at times."
In the Senate, Mr. Bradley is something of a loner and a charmingly idiosyncratic figure, who on a recent afternoon loped into his office, where a plant had been potted in a sawed-off basketball, and produced a piece of fruit from his pocket. "Hi, would you like an apple?" he said by way of introduction.
Seated at his desk, surrounded by modern art and family photos, Mr. Bradley said he chiefly wanted to prod the President to further reduce the deficit and to speak out more about race and diversity.
However uncalculated the effect, distancing himself from the President could well help Mr. Bradley in his increasingly Republican home state as he campaigns for a fourth term, which he said he would seek in 1996.
Meanwhile, as a member of the Senate minority, Mr. Bradley said he must rely on a defensive strategy to block passage of some legislation, like the repeal of parts of the crime bill.
In the 1965 basketball biography about Mr. Bradley, "A Sense of Where You Are," the author John McPhee wrote, "The depth of Bradley's game is most discernible when he doesn't have the ball."
There is some evidence that as a legislator, Mr. Bradley is actually most effective then, too. While in the minority from 1980 to 1986, he invented a strategy to cut tax rates and do away with many special provisions and tax shelters. Even while remaining largely behind the scenes, he became a chief engineer of the 1986 tax reform.
In today's speech, he advocated equally sweeping changes, and further challenged assumptions about political allegiances, saying:
"Never in American history has a new vision begun in Washington; never has it been the sole property of either political party. In fact, to initiate a frank discussion of our current American condition requires us to throw off many of the barnacle-encrusted categories with which we are accustomed to talking about this nation's problems.
"This could seriously disrupt the respective moral allegiances and political turfs of both the Democratic and Republican parties."
He added, "I would like to start making that disruption happen" because neither the market approach favored by Republicans nor the governmental solutions often offered by Democrats can work without the communal ties, the human connections, that he said are increasingly rare.
After reeling off statistics about the soaring rate of illegitimate births, he suggested that parental responsibility should be enforced.
"Policy should send a very clear message," he told the audience. "If you have sex with someone and she becomes pregnant, be prepared to have 15 percent of your wages for 18 years to go to support the mother and child."
He also suggested that campaign finance reform be accomplished by allowing taxpayers to contribute up to $200 for Congressional campaigns for Congress by checking a box on their tax returns, with all the money equally divided among candidates.
And when asked, inevitably, about his Presidential intentions, he did not entirely dismiss the possibility, though it seems remote, since he has done no fund-raising.
"For 16 years, I kept issuing Shermanesque statements" denying any interest in running, "and nobody believed them," the Senator said, grinning. "So now, as a change of pace, I've decided to be ambiguously definitive, or is it definitively ambiguous?"

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bradley's Speech to the Press Club

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Here are excerpts from a speech delivered to the National Press Club by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company.
Today, I will suggest that any prescription for America must understand the advantages and limits of both the market and government, but, more importantly, how neither is equipped to solve America's central problems, which are the deterioration of our civil society and the need to revitalize our democratic process. 
 Civil society is the place where Americans make their homes, sustain their marriages, raise their families, hang out with their friends, meet their neighbors, educate their children, worship their God. It's in churches, schools, fraternities, community centers, labor unions, synagogues, sports leagues, P.T.A.'s, libraries, and barbershops. It's where opinions are expressed and refined, where views are exchanged and agreements made, where a sense of common purpose and consensus are forged. It lies apart from the realms of the market and the Government, and it possesses a different ethic.
The market is governed by the logic of economic self-interest, while the Government is the domain of laws with all their course of authority. Civil society, on the other hand, is the sphere of our most basic humanity -- the personal, everyday realm that is governed by values such as responsibility, trust, fraternity, solidarity and love. . . .
What both Democrats and Republicans fail to see is that the Government and the market are not enough to make a civilization. There must be a healthy, robust civic sector, a space in which the bonds of community can flourish. Government and the market are similar to two legs on a three-legged stool. Without the third leg of civil society, the stool is not stable and cannot provide support for a vital America. . . .
Public policy . . . can help facilitate the revitalization of democracy and civil society, but it cannot create civil society. We can insist that fathers support their children financially, but fathers have to see the importance of spending time with their children. We can figure out ways, such as parental leave, to provide parents with more time with their children, but parents have to use that time to raise their children. We can create community schools, but communities have to use them. We can provide mothers and fathers with the tools they need to influence the storytelling of the mass media, but they ultimately must exercise that control. We can take special interests out of elections, but only people can vote. We can provide opportunities for more deliberative citizenship, at both the national and the local level, but citizens have to seize these opportunities and take individual responsibility.
We also have to give the distinctive moral language of civil society a more permanent place in our public conversation. The language of the marketplace says, "Get as much as you can for yourself." The language of government says, "Legislate for others what is good for them." But the language of community, family, citizenship, at its core, is about receiving undeserved gifts. What this nation needs to promote is the spirit of giving something freely without measuring it out precisely or demanding something in return. . . .
Above all, we need to understand that a true civil society in which citizens interact on a regular basis to grapple with common problems will not occur because of the arrival of a hero. Rebuilding civil society requires people talking and listening to each other, not blindly following a hero. I was reminded of that a few weeks ago, the temptation of the knight in shining armor, when a cover of a national magazine had General Colin Powell's picture on it and the caption was something like, "Will He Be the Answer to Our Problems?" If the problem is a deteriorating civic culture, then a charismatic leader, be he the President or a general, is not the answer. He or she might make us feel better momentarily. But then if we are only spectators thrilled by the performance, how have we progressed collectively?
A character in Bertolt Brecht's "Galileo" says, "Pity the nation that has no heroes," to which Galileo responds, "Pity the nation that needs them." All of us have to go out in the public square, and all of us have to assume our citizenship responsibilities. For me, that means trying to tell the truth as I see it to both parties and to the American people without regard for consequences. In a vibrant civil society, real leadership at the top is made possible by the understanding and evolution of leaders of awareness at the bottom and the middle; that is, citizens engaged in a deliberative discussion about our common future.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Drops Slightly Ahead of Price Data Today

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell slightly against leading currencies in quiet, directionless trading yesterday as dealers awaited January producer price data for indications on the direction of the United States economy and interest rates.
"The dollar has been locked in a tight range," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal in New York. "We haven't had any substantive information on the economy all week. The market is marking time." 
 In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5286 German marks from 1.5305 marks on Wednesday and to 1.2927 Swiss francs from 1.2955 francs. The dollar was unchanged at 98.90 Japanese yen. The British pound, which had touched a one-month low of $1.5502 on Wednesday, rose yesterday to $1.5575 from $1.5534.
In early trading in New York, the dollar followed the bond market lower as fixed-income traders braced for yesterday's sale of $11 billion in 30-year bonds, the last part of the Treasury's $40 billion quarterly debt sales. Bond traders were also worried that a report on producer prices due today will show higher inflation.
But stronger-than-expected demand at the Treasury auction helped lift the dollar. Increased interest in American bonds tends to bolster the currency, as foreign investors and United States interests leaving overseas markets must first buy dollars to purchase the securities.
Still, the dollar's gains were capped by weakness in the secondary market for bonds, where investors were selling in anticipation of a rise in producer prices. Inflation erodes the value of securities that pay a fixed rate of return.
While inflation is at the lowest level in decades, many dealers and analysts expect that current strong economic growth will force prices higher.
John Rothfield, an international economist at Nationsbank in Chicago, said he expected a jump of five-tenths of a percent in the Producer Price Index for January. "I don't think the bond market would digest that very well," he added. A slump in United States bonds would hurt the dollar.
But higher inflation could help prod the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates again. The Fed has raised rates seven times since last February in an effort to cool the economy and forestall inflation.
Higher United States rates mean better returns on dollar deposits and thus tend to attract capital flows into the currency.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The $20 Billion Inquiry

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
This Clinton-Mexico affair reminds me of the time a fellow editor came up to my desk in the newsroom, put a piece of paper in front of me and told me to sign it. When I asked why, he said I was to be his co-signer on a loan.
You can understand I did not want to be crude but I did ask how much as I was writing my fool name. He looked at me, coolness trembling on disdain, and then picked up the signed paper. As he walked away he said over his shoulder: "Bad form, old boy, bad form." Well, I was ashamed of myself and didn't get up and snatch the paper back. 
 The bailout loan from the Clinton Administration to Mexico is a done deal and can't be snatched away. Maybe we ought to shut up now and be nice -- grateful that Americans got away with billions less in risk than Mr. Clinton first demanded.
Certainly most members of Congress seem terrified of being vulgar enough to press questions -- who knew what when and who benefited how much.
But here's happy news: At least some senators are promising to demand accounting and explanation from the Administration. Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, promises hearings in the Banking Committee, which he heads.
Senator Connie Mack of Florida and four other Republicans -- I seem to be writing a lot about Republicans -- have asked the Treasury to produce the documents that may show why the Administration did not warn the public until Mexico's default was days away.
President Clinton apparently was surprised when members of Congress and the public showed the bad form to protest when he suddenly came up and said here, sign a $40 billion bailout loan guarantee for Mexico.
So, faced with impudent objections, he went over the heads of Congress and public and issued a loan by executive power. But he did cut the check to $20 billion, a straight loan.
That is even riskier than a loan guarantee. And when we figure in how much American money is involved in the package of international loans, we are in the pot for at least $8 billion more. But who's counting?
Senator D'Amato for one. On the Senate floor Wednesday he broke company with the Republican leaders who had cried "Good show, old boy" when the President stepped over them. Senator D'Amato does not know from good show or old boy.
He denounced Mr. Clinton for "economic blackmail": the warnings that Mexico would crumble without the bailout, stock markets around the world would crash and veritable hordes of Mexicans would flood across the borders. As for the oil-revenue "collateral," said the Senator, we would have to send in the 82d Airborne to collect.
The Administration's line is that without the loan Mexico would become a falling domino that would bring down the whole investment network.
Strange, but America's European allies, who have quite a few marks, pounds and francs invested abroad, do not buy it. They made no direct loans to Mexico and had to be pushed by Washington into accepting the international part of the bailout.
Among other loan skeptics, I understand Mexico's great importance to the U.S. But Americans should not be offered just an aid deal for Mexico, but a square one -- with information, notice and inquiry. They are essential to U.S. democracy, not to be surrendered whenever bureaucrats or investors get panicky.
The U.S. had political capital invested in Mexico -- one reason decent notice was not given of a coming disaster. As for investors, the financial guru Henry Kaufman wrote in The Wall Street Journal that many analysts and economists had become part of a broad marketing, underwriting and distribution network that compromised their own objectivity. That is scary.
Maybe the D'Amato inquiries will tell us how many billions Mexico's top families have salted away abroad and whether anything was done to get that money back home to help their own country. Or which American and Mexican investment companies profited most and how close they are to their governments.
The hearings won't make the U.S.-Mexico botch-up more acceptable. But it could help avoid another last-minute bailout, maybe. At least senate hearings will make us feel we are not complete idiots, which we certainly would be if we silently signed the papers on the desk, with a silly smile on our faces.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL;
Poked, Prodded, Timed and Tested

BYLINE: By Thomas George 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
When running back Garrison Hearst arrived here at the National Football League scouting combine two years ago, he was eager, hopeful and full of promise. And it was here where Hearst's knee injury was discovered and where several teams teams became cool toward him. He was fortunate. He survived, slipping from the favorite to be the No. 1 pick to being chosen No. 3 by the Arizona Cardinals in the 1993 N.F.L. draft.
When safety Eric Turner arrived at the combine four years ago, he was a top prospect but several other defensive backs had caught more of the pro scouts' fancy. Turner, however, ran the 40-yard sprint in under 4.4 seconds. Run under 4.4 and you turn heads. And Turner certainly did, vaulting himself into a higher draft spot, all the way to the second pick, owned by the Cleveland Browns, in the 1991 draft. 
 Welcome to the N.F.L. scouting combine. You can fall. You can rise. You can discourage. You can impress.
And you do so before more than 900 N.F.L. personnel, including owners and coaches and trainers and physicians and even psychiatrists. It is here each year in early February where the best college football players are poked and prodded, timed and tested. This year's session opened yesterday and concludes on Monday.
It is a major stepping stone for the N.F.L. draft on April 22.
All season long, pro scouts have scoured the nation scrutinizing the best that college football has to offer. Some scouts say that as much as 70 percent of their evaluation of players' abilities comes from their seasonlong look. Here at the combine, they gain the chance to reaffirm their beliefs -- or create new ones.
"I don't see a lot of guys rise from these workouts but quite a few of them fall," said Steve Trimble, a defensive assistant coach with the Jets last season who has since joined the New Orleans Saints in a similar role.
"One important thing you look at is how a guy runs here," said Jon Kingdon, the Los Angeles Raiders' director of player personnel. "But even if you run badly, you can make that up in a private workout later. The players have built-in excuses. It's the middle of winter even though they are running in a domed stadium. They haven't had a lot of work since their season was over. So, you can fall but you can get right back up. What we've seen more of over the years is an increase in size. These players just keep getting bigger and bigger, and it's not steroids, because we test for that. The steroids and the other drug tests have come back with more negatives in recent years. That is also a good sign."
Some view this event as a huge meat market with more than 300 players attending. The players are grouped in three categories: offensive and defensive linemen; quarterbacks, receivers and running backs, and linebackers, tight ends and defensive backs. Among the activities are the 40-yard sprint, weight lifting, various skill drills, intelligence and personality questionnaires and medical examinations. Among the popular players here this weekend are Miami defensive lineman Warren Sapp, Alcorn State quarterback Steve McNair and Penn State quarterback Kerry Collins.
Some college stars come but refuse to work out. They know they are not in their best shape and save their workouts for later, private dates on their campuses. It is the personality aspect of this combine that makes it most worthwhile, Kingdon said.
"Because of the money you are investing, you have to know as much about the player off the field as you do on the field," Kingdon said. "Here you get to look the guy in the eye and find out something about him, so the interview process here has sort of exploded. And you get to watch him compete against the best from around the country."
It is a coaching convention, of sorts. Long-time friends in the coaching fraternity meet and new friendships are made. Unemployed coaches come with resumes in hand. Ideas are shared.
So, with everyone looking at the same thing, how can so many mistakes be made in the draft? How does a team with two picks in the first round pass over a guy who becomes an All-Pro for someone else? It happens because scouting is such an inexact science. You can measure someone's time in the 40 and the weight they can bench press. Measuring heart and dedication is another matter.
The combine began in 1982 and was held in several other cities, including Dallas, New Orleans and Seattle, before settling here in the mid 1980's. Some of the top performances ever? Well, Deion Sanders, now the flashy cornerback from the San Francisco 49ers, arrived and ran close to a 4.3 in the 40. Chris Spielman of the Detroit Lions ran a horrible 40 but then excelled in the 20-yard shuttle, showing his lateral movement and many of the quick reaction traits that have made him one of the game's best linebackers.
The exceptional this year? A good place to look is among offensive linemen. Scouts here say that position is the deepest among all groups.
The most successful N.F.L. teams use a combination of three areas -- the draft, free agency and trades -- to build their strongest rosters. Most N.F.L. teams, however, still yearn to build from within, to obtain their own players from the start and to train them from Day One in that team's particular system. Free agency has altered that formula but has not destroyed it.
Thus, here, in part, is where Super Bowls are won.

HEADLINE: New Claims by Jobless Fall

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The number of newly laid-off Americans filing claims for jobless benefits dropped by 8,000 last week to the lowest level in more than two months.
The Labor Department reported today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 318,000, down from 326,000 in the week that ended on Jan. 28. 
 It was the smallest number of new claims since 316,000 were filed in the week that ended on Nov. 26. Many analysts had expected little change from the previous week.
Except for a two-week period at the beginning of the year, claims have been about the 325,000 level since last summer. This level, analysts contend, reflects a strong job market.
