HEADLINE: Republicans Advance Proposal To Replace the Welfare System

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
House Republican leaders moved today to undo more than a half-century of social welfare policy by proposing to eliminate the right of poor women and children to receive cash assistance from the Government.
In place of the welfare program established 60 years ago as part of the Social Security Act, Republicans said they wanted to make a lump sum payment of $15.3 billion a year, which the states could use "in any manner reasonably calculated" to assist needy families with children. This represents the amount spent in 1994; there would be no allowance for inflation. Benefits would no longer be automatically available to people who met certain criteria. 
 Republican leaders reaffirmed their commitment to the most hotly debated features of their proposal, which would deny cash assistance to hundreds of thousands of unmarried teen-age mothers and to most immigrants, including legal aliens.
These provisions, fleshed out today with new detail by Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, immediately encountered a barrage of criticism from some Republicans, from opponents of abortion and from liberal defenders of child welfare programs.
In a speech at the United States Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Shaw, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, said the Republican proposal embodied "tough love," using hard measures to save poor people from a life of dependence on the dole.
The subcommittee will begin voting on welfare legislation next week. House Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, has promised a floor vote on the bill by mid-April, as part of the Contract With America. The Senate appears likely to support major changes to require welfare recipients to work. But Senator Bob Dole, the Republican floor leader, predicted last month that neither teen-age mothers nor legal immigrants would be cut from the rolls.
In a confidential memorandum to President Clinton on Jan. 19, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, harshly criticized the Republican proposal to abolish the individual entitlement to welfare benefits and replace it with a "block grant" to the states.
But the White House has taken a much more ambiguous position. Indeed, some Administration officials say President Clinton has sent subtle signals to Congress that he will not oppose converting the main cash assistance program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, into a block grant to the states.
At a news conference today, Mr. Clinton shied away from explicit criticism of the Republican proposal. The President, a former governor, said he was "willing to go a long way" toward letting the states design their own welfare programs, as governors have demanded.
Mr. Clinton spoke in general terms, saying: "There is a national interest in making sure that the food, the nutrition, the health care of the children of this country are protected."
Officials at the Department of Health and Human Services, the Treasury and the Labor Department have said they want the White House to take a firm stand in favor of preserving the entitlement status of Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Mr. Clinton has so far avoided a confrontation with Republicans, saying only that the Federal Government should set national standards to protect poor children.
Under current law, poor people can file suit to get welfare benefits to which they are entitled. Mr. Shaw's bill would abolish "all entitlement of individuals to benefits" under Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
The Federal Government and the states now share the cost of this program. Mr. Shaw's proposal would eliminate any requirement for states to continue spending their own money, though Republicans said they hoped the states would do so. The Federal Government expects to spend $12.5 billion, or 1 percent of the Federal budget, on the program this year, while the states are expected to spend $10.3 billion.
Breaking with his party, Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, denounced the proposal to deny cash assistance to children born out of wedlock to women under 18. In an interview today, Mr. Hyde said it was unfair to punish children for parents' behavior. "The children need clothing, shelter and nurture," Mr. Hyde said. "You don't want to reward promiscuous pregnancy, but on the other hand, you don't want to make the children suffer for the transgressions of the parents."
The Roman Catholic Church and the National Right to Life Committee also oppose this part of the Republican bill, saying it would probably increase abortions. "Many pregnant teen-agers will feel compelled to have abortions if they feel they cannot provide for their children or get A.F.D.C.," said Douglas D. Johnson, chief lobbyist of the National Right to Life Committee.
Mr. Shaw's bill would prohibit states from using Federal money to give extra welfare benefits to women who had additional children while they were on welfare. Many opponents of abortion object to this provision too.
Some Republicans also denounced the proposed denial of benefits for legal immigrants. Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican whose Miami district includes many Cuban emigres, said the proposal would cut off aid to "many permanent resident aliens who have paid taxes and are willing to get drafted and fight for the United States."
Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, described the prevailing view of his party. He said the Republican bill was "strong on punishing children and weak on getting their parents to work." Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, said, "This proposal is tough and mean, and it's directed at our most vulnerable citizens."
In June 1994, Mr. Clinton sent Congress a bill "to end welfare as we know it." Under his proposal, welfare would remain a right, and the bill would not cut off benefits for unmarried teen-agers. It would allow states to cap the amount of payments so there would be no extra allowance for children born to women already on welfare.
The Clinton bill would provide welfare recipients up to two years of education and training and would guarantee publicly financed jobs for people who could not find jobs in the private market. Under Mr. Shaw's bill, welfare recipients would have to work to get cash payments after two years, and in no event could they get assistance for more than five years.
Illegal immigrants are already ineligible for most welfare benefits, but legal immigrants have long been eligible for such assistance.
Mr. Shaw said he and his Republican colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee were planning a radical change. "Our bill will cut off most welfare benefits for most legal immigrants," he said. "Those age 75 and older will continue to receive welfare, and so too will legally recognized refugees."
In addition, a summary of Mr. Shaw's bill, prepared by his staff, says that noncitizens could qualify for some education and training programs, so they could obtain jobs and become productive citizens. Mr. Shaw said: "There will be some flexibility for the states. The details are still being worked out."
Mr. Clinton would permit legal aliens to get benefits, but he would tighten the eligibility rules. He would require American citizens to take greater financial responsibility for the immigrants they sponsored.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, in his office preparing a speech he gave yesterday on revamping the nation's social welfare policy, including denying cash assistance to poor mothers and children. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A16)
 
Chart: "IN THEIR OWN WORDS: From the G.O.P. Welfare Proposal"
 
Cash Grants
Spending on cash welfare will be capped for five years, saving taxpayers $7.6 billion.
States will be prohibited from using Federal tax dollars to:
--pay cash welfare to mothers under 18 who have children out of wedlock
--give extra payments to families that have more kids while on welfare
--pay cash welfare to a single family for more than five years.
 
Child Care
About a dozen current Federal child care progams will be merged into a block grant.
States will be given enormous flexibility to better serve their residents, simplify programs and save taxpayers money. We will at last do away with the old canard that more Federal spending equals more compassion.
 
Reducing the Rolls
Drug addicts and alcoholics will no longer be considered disabled.
Non-citizens will no longer be eligible for most welfare programs. (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Backed by Business, G.O.P. Takes Steps To Overhaul Environmental Regulations

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Emboldened by their recent legislative victories and urged on by a powerful coalition of business groups, Republican lawmakers are taking the first steps toward redefining the basic premises of many environmental regulations.
Legislation moving rapidly through the House of Representatives would substitute economic calculations for health considerations as the determining factor in writing regulations governing air pollution, water quality, hazardous wastes and the like. 
 Two House committees late Wednesday night approved the legislation, which would subject every major new health, safety and environmental regulation to an elaborate process of scientific review to quantify the targeted risks. At the same time, the legislation would forbid any new regulation from being issued without a demonstration that its expected costs would be justified by its benefits.
"We took the first steps toward bringing the Federal regulatory monster under control," said Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who heads one of the committees that approved the bill.
The proposal, intended to roll back regulations that businesses consider unnecessarily costly, is part of the House Republicans' Contract With America, and the House is expected to take it up in two weeks. Companion bills have been introduced in the Senate, including one sponsored by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader. Three bills that are part of the contract have already sailed through the House, and two of them have passed the Senate.
While the Clinton Administration supports some elements of the Republican agenda, its senior officials have expressed alarm over the bill on regulations.
"What this does is undermine every single environmental and public health standard in the country," said Carol M. Browner, head of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Although risk assessment and cost-benefit analysis are commonly used to examine proposed regulations issued under existing laws, they are arcane and often hotly disputed methods. So environmental laws often direct agencies to base their regulatory decisions primarily on broad health goals and on judgments of what pollution control methods are most suitable to help protect health and safety.
In drafting the new legislation, House Republicans this week turned those precedents upside down, just as they have been up-ending old assumptions across the political landscape ever since the election.
The bill's opponents said changes in the fine print of the bill had vastly expanded its scope, affecting not only how bureaucrats write regulations but also reversing fundamental decisions made by previous Congresses.
For example, Ms. Browner said, the Clean Air Act requires the agency to provide an "adequate margin of safety" in protecting the public's health by limiting the emissions of toxic pollutants, which can cause cancer, miscarriages and other medical problems. The new law, she said, would supersede this requirement and many others like it, requiring a calculation whether preventing these illnesses was worth the price of controlling the pollution.
A powerful alliance of industry groups is pushing the legislation hard, saying that it is only reasonable to insure that the costs of regulations do not exceed the benefits. The National Association of Manufacturers and trade associations representing plastics, electric utilities, food manufacturing and other industries are lobbying for the bill.
Environmental groups have assailed the measure, saying it is designed to wrap regulators in the red tape of risk assessments, studies, and litigation.
Ellen K. Silbergeld, a toxicologist affiliated with the Environmental Defense Fund, said the bill would "encourage use of junk science and hamstring programs designed to protect health, safety and the environment." The environmental group testified at the Commerce Committee's hearings on the legislation last week.
Until shortly before the Commerce and Science committees met on Wednesday, however, it was not clear that the proposals under consideration would explicitly supersede the existing criteria for making regulatory decisions.
"Notwithstanding any other provision of law," the bill approved by the committees said, "the requirements of this section shall supplement and, to the extent there is a conflict, supersede the decisional criteria for rule-making otherwise applicable under the statute pursuant to which the rule is promulgated."
Ronald White, the director of environmental health at the American Lung Association, said this change would make it much harder for the non-profit health organization to lobby for tougher air pollution regulations. The group, for example, is seeking tougher air quality standards for small particulate matter, which health studies show causes tens of thousands of deaths each year, and for sulfur dioxide, which can provoke asthma attacks.
Under existing law, those standards are set purely on the basis of what is healthy, Mr. White said, not on the basis of how much it would cost to clean the air. "There is a basic premise that people have a right to breath air that is not going to make them sick," he said. JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

HEADLINE: Let's Get Government Out of the Tractor Seat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Feb. 6 front-page article on the coming political fight over farm subsidies overlooks a key part of the policy debate. At issue is not just the cost of subsidies to the Treasury, but also the huge, indirect costs of misguided agricultural policies to rural communities, farmers and other links in the food chain of industries. 
 Perhaps the Government's chief policy error is the futile attempt to prop up crop prices by taking cropland out of production. During the past decade land retirement schemes have idled an annual average of 60 million acres -- 15 percent of total cropland -- in a failed attempt to manipulate prices by limiting supplies. These supply-management programs no longer work in a global economy where foreign competitors increase production in response to United States "set asides" and go after our customers.
During the same decade world demand for grains grew 18 percent, and global demand for oilseed crops grew by 28 percent, but United States production levels were flat, and foreign growers captured additional market share at the expense of American growers.
Acreage idling has a devastating effect up and down the chain of food and agribusiness industries. Government subsidies don't fully compensate farmers for the lost production and income opportunities.
Meanwhile, rural communities suffer because acreage cutbacks limit sales by agrichemical retailers, seed suppliers, tractor dealers and other Main Street businesses.
Lower crop volumes hurt grain elevators and merchants, barge operators, railroads and food processors. Even beef, dairy, hog and poultry growers are negatively affected by the limited supply of feed grains. All of this adds to the cost of food at home and subtracts from competitiveness abroad.
Compounding the problem is the lack of planting freedom. Growers are encouraged to plant subsidized "program crops" (such as wheat, corn feed grains, cotton and rice), even when the market is signaling for alternative crops, because diversification will jeopardize the acreage base upon which future Government payments are determined.
In other words, programs cause producers to grow for the program rather than for the market.
The food and agricultural system -- stretching from input suppliers and farmers to processors and retailers -- employs 21 million people and generates 16 percent of the nation's income.
The system has served consumers well by providing the world's most varied and least expensive retail food supply.
But it's time to get government out of the tractor seat and free up the food and agricultural system to compete in the new era of liberalized trade. That's why the Coalition for a Competitive Food and Agriculture System, consisting of more than 80 companies and trade associations representing all sectors of the food industry, have come together to work for market-oriented reforms in the 1995 farm bill.
 
STUART HARDY
Manager, Food Policy
United States Chamber of Commerce
Washington, Feb. 6, 1995

HEADLINE: Sweden's Social Policies Put Us to Shame

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Deficit Reins In Sweden's Welfare State" (front page, Feb. 2) portrays Sweden's social and economic policies and its citizens as childishly naive. By leaving out information, you give a conservative American bias against Sweden's government-intensive economic and social approach and add fuel to American anti-government hysteria. 
 You mention that the Swedish Government has been forced to reduce the $100-a-child monthly payment it provides to families regardless of need. Sweden has been experiencing population decline for more than a decade, and this subsidy is designed to encourage population growth. It has shown success and is an example of effective social policy, not wasteful big government.
You conclude with a Swedish woman's suggestion that the Government develop a program wherein one of Sweden's 13 percent unemployed could take her job while she took off a paid year or two.
Since unemployed Swedish workers receive almost full compensation, this woman was not suggesting some new expensive social program but a way to spread the available work around that would help to keep the unemployed productive.
You make it seem as if Sweden is being forced to wake up to the reality the United States has figured out: big government and high taxes are wasteful and must be scaled back.
For more than half a century Sweden has been a potent example of how effective governmental economic and social involvement can be. It has provided its people with one of the highest standards of living in the world, along with amazingly low poverty and crime rates.
Compare the United States with Sweden in any negative social indicator, from drug use to teen-age pregnancy to domestic violence: Sweden puts us to shame. Sweden does not need to take a lesson from the United States.
 
ERIK RHODES
Costa Mesa, Calif., Feb. 7, 1995

HEADLINE: Give Lower West Side A Green Waterfront

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Feb. 4 news article on Roland W. Betts, the developer of the Chelsea Piers, on the Hudson River between 17th and 23d Streets in Manhattan, makes for an entertaining read. Unfortunately, it misses the point, which is not personalities but the future of the waterfront.
The waterfront is the last open space in Manhattan. It is on one of the great rivers of the world. To use this precious space for a glorified gym and shopping mall is shortsighted. There are many places in our city to build gyms and malls. There is only one waterfront.
One hundred fifty years ago, when New York had another large open space, it was not developed. Instead, a great park was built. Not only did Central Park become one of our cherished landmarks, a green sanctuary for millions of New Yorkers and visitors, but its presence also served as the engine for the development of the Upper East and West Sides for the next 100 years.
An all-green waterfront park with views of the Hudson would make the Lower West Side bloom and provide far more permanent jobs than dozens of Chelsea Piers. Like Central Park it would be an esthetic, social, environmental and economic boon. It would be real and lasting urban planning.
 
STUART WALDMAN
New York, Feb. 6, 1995
The writer is president of the Federation to Preserve the Greenwich Village Waterfront & Great Port.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Donald G. McNeil Jr. 

 BODY:

'Nunsense' Closing
"I don't know if we've just nunned everybody in New York to death or if it's just that everyone's suffered in the past year," says Dan Goggin, the author, director and producer of "Nunsense" and "Nunsense II." "But it's better to go out while you're hot than to run out of steam in the summer and have to sneak out of town."
Thus endeth the run. On Feb. 26, after more than nine years, the singing, dancing, wisecracking, habit-wearing kick line of Mount St. Helens High is leaving town. The cast and the "Nunsense II" set are going to Ford's Theater in Washington for what they hope will be 22 weeks. The "Nunsense I" set will winter in Maui and Las Vegas, picking up casts. 
 Financially, the show has "run real close to the line for the last year or so," Mr. Goggin said. Adding "Nunsense II" in October rejuvenated sales somewhat, but when Ford's asked for the New York cast, it made more sense to move lock, stock and rosary than to spend the money for a new cast and set at the John Houseman Theater.
However, there may be new orders. Mr. Goggin has ideas of bringing the show back in late fall to assay a brief, lucrative run at a Broadway house, if he can find a big-name star who can do for a wimple what Glenn Close does for a turban. "There are people who only want to go to a Broadway show, and we can play that game for a little bit," he said. "Or I may do something like 'Sister Mary Amnesia's Country Jamboree' at Town Hall for the holiday season."
And, he said, "Nunsense" the television series is looking closer to reality too. Ora pro nobis.
 
'Big' Too Big For Broadway
 When is a show too big to find a home? When it's "Big." It's the musical version of the Tom Hanks movie about a boy who gets his wish to be adult-sized and stumbles into the takeover of a toy company. It's in pre-production now for July previews in Boston.
Its problem? With 30-odd cast members directed by Mike Ockrent and dancing to Susan Stroman's choreography on hefty sets by Robin Wagner, there are few theaters that can hold it. The really big ones are locked up by well-dug-in shows, from graybeards like "Cats" to new hits like "Sunset Boulevard." James Freydberg, one of the "Big" producers, is hoping for an Oct. 12 opening date -- somewhere. " 'Victor/Victoria' has a deposit on the Marquis," he said. "The Neil Simon isn't exactly a musical house, but it has 'Shlemiel the First.' When 'Tommy' goes, the St. James is supposed to get 'Busker Alley.' The Shubert has 'Crazy for You' -- and even if it has some bad weeks, it has a rich producer, and besides, our creative team worked on 'Crazy' and they're taking cuts in royalties to keep it open. That's the ultimate Catch-22.
"So here we are: a $ 10 million musical, everything ready and no place to go."
 
Chic Fades Into Mystique
 The play is set in the 1960's in a Greenwich Village apartment, where two best friends are holding the social event of the season, a fund-raiser for the Black Panthers. Sound familiar? "Radical Chic" was the title when the Manhattan Theater Club announced last summer that the Arthur Laurents play would be the last show of its season in May. Then Tom Wolfe, author of the famous book by that name about a Black Panther fund-raiser at Leonard Bernstein's apartment, objected. Titles can't be copyrighted, but public fights are ugly anyway. For a while, some listings had "Unconditional Sex" as the title of the Manhattan Theater Club's play (offering no explanation); the theater was saying only "a new Arthur Laurents work." Now there's a new title, and at least it rhymes with chic: "The Radical Mystique."
Mr. Laurents, in Seattle this week to open another new work, "Jolson Sings Again," declined to return telephone messages. But he left word that he'd decided his title was "too narrow and too limiting" and renamed it for his own reasons.
 
A Handout for the Little Guy
 Everyone knows that magazine with the yellow logo that the usher thrusts into your hand. But go to a small theater and you may get just a sheet of construction paper with nary a trivia column in sight. You may even have to go find it yourself in a pile in the lobby. This is the business that Encore magazine is fighting for. It serves 37 theaters with names like Cucaracha, Tada!, WPA and Irondale Ensemble. Editorial space is in the $ 125-a-page vicinity, depending on how many copies a theater needs; it also sells ads. Its publisher, Tom Holmes, has just overseen a redesign and transition to color.
Mr. Holmes, who bankrolled the business with his unemployment check and laid out the first issues on the floor of his studio apartment, loves little theaters and is exasperatingly modest for an entrepreneur. He has to be forced to admit that he'd like to whip the competition or turn a profit. He all too quickly confesses second thoughts even about his own redesign. The new, smaller typeface is cleaner looking, he said, but "there's kind of a controversy over how it reads in a darkened theater."
His gossip columnist, whose nom de smear is Addison DeWitt, the critic in "All About Eve," threw a fit about the loss of his 1940's-style logo -- an ingenue whipering in a rake's ear -- even though it clashed with the magazine's other logos.
"I think I'll bring it back," Mr. Holmes says, soldiering on. All he needs now in those theaters: ushers.
 
Footlights
 *The Shakespeare marathon forges on. Coming to Central Park's Delacorte Theater this summer: "The Tempest," directed by George C. Wolfe and opening on June 15. "Troilus and Cressida," directed by Mark Wing-Davey, opens Aug. 3. No casts yet. The last time the New York Shakespeare Festival did "Tempest" was in 1962, with Karen Black and Charles Durning; it did "Troilus" in 1965.
*The Theater Guild is sending a musical version of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "State Fair" screenplay on a 20-city tour this August. And where will it open? In Des Moines, at the Iowa State Fair.
*It doesn't happen often. "Beauty and the Beast" will open in Los Angeles on March 21 with most of the original New York cast, including Terrence Mann, Susan Egan and Tom Bosley.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 11, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in the On Stage, and Off column in Weekend yesterday about the closing of "Nunsense" on Feb. 26 misstated the theater at which the musical is playing. It is the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, not the John Houseman.
Another brief report in the column, about New York Shakespeare Festival productions, gave incorrect dates, provided by the festival, for previous shows. The festival last staged "The Tempest" in Spanish in 1991 and in English in 1981, not in 1962. It last staged "Troilus and Cressida" in 1974, not in 1965.

HEADLINE: When Art Puts on a Party Hat: A Guide to Gallery Openings

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
PAINTERS and sculptors create, for the most part, in solitude and silence. Ideally, their works are contemplated in the same way. But that is not how they are thrust upon an unsuspecting world. In late-20th-century New York, art takes its first bow in a room as loud and crowded as a commodities trading pit and as smoke-filled as an off-track betting parlor. The fruits of genius are toasted with Chilean chardonnay and honored with offerings of suspect cheese. For a mad two hours, artists, critics, hangers-on, insiders, befuddled outsiders and outright scroungers mingle, collide, preen, dish, fawn, toady, snub and, as a last resort, take a fleeting glance at the art on the wall.
This ritual, played out hundreds of nights a year in galleries great and small, uptown and downtown, is known as an art opening. It is held, as a rule, the night before a show officially opens, or at the end of the show's first day. It is given as a courtesy to the artist who, after toiling long and lonely hours in his studio, has earned a chance to stand in the spotlight and bask in semi-sincere praise. For a brief, intoxicating moment, the heavens will align properly and move the artist to his or her rightful place: the center of the universe. 
 It's a funny little ritual, with all sorts of hidden rules, taboos and stylistic quirks. Uptown openings are very different from SoHo openings, though not always. Some galleries roll out a full bar. Others offer soda water and call it a day.
The form has evolved from the jug wine, paper cups and fistfights of the 1950's to the Champagne and celebrity openings of the 80's to the increasingly no-frills gatherings of the 90's.
Some SoHo galleries have given up on openings entirely -- the gallery-hopping of the 80's simply became too popular, and some gallery owners no longer feel up to giving a party for several hundred strangers. Others limit admission to invited guests, and no longer mention anything about the opening on the cards they mail out. But the form survives because, like birthday parties, weddings, and the bishop's annual blessing of the animals, it serves a cultural purpose.
"It's something you do for the artists and the community," said Jay Gorney, a SoHo dealer. "Real business is done before or after. Openings are about the artist having a chance to greet colleagues, friends, enemies."
It can make for a peculiar spectacle. Hollywood films have tried to satirize New York openings, but without much success. Applying the same logic that allows a secretary to live in a two-bedroom Manhattan apartment, film makers present the typical opening as two dozen Armani-clad poseurs circulating quietly with a glass of Chablis in hand.
If it takes place downtown, people wear crazy color combinations and huge earrings. The art is never ridiculous enough.
A real opening looks more like a casting call for six unrelated films and free lunch at Joe's Bar. On a recent Saturday night at the Cristinerose gallery, the following human specimens rubbed shoulders in the space of a few square feet: a tall man in black, with a long pigtail and a broad-brimmed deacon's hat; an Alpinist with climbing boots and gnarled stick; innumerable men and women with shaved heads; lots of young men in Army surplus gear; a young woman wearing a neatly pressed Keebler elf hat with tassel; a Morticia Addams look-alike in a floor-length tight black velvet coat and a crushed velvet Cat in the Hat chapeau. There were fashion plates, fashion victims and fashion disasters. There was lots of black, but lots of everything else too.
Go to enough openings, and you will inevitably encounter the German couple, both bald, who wear matching vinyl dresses and high heels. You will mingle with the celebrated group of moochers (their doings were recently chronicled in New York magazine) known as "gallery bums." You will also see, these days, especially downtown, lots of babies and dogs.
For their supposed beneficiaries, the artists, openings are equal parts agony and ecstasy. On the plus side, there's praise, attention and an opportunity to see the work -- and have it seen -- outside the studio. On the minus side, the work and the artist are painfully exposed.
 
A Duty One Can't Shirk
 The satirical painter Jack Levine, who is 80, has been exhibiting for well over half a century. He attends to support friends when they have a show. He shows up for his own openings only because he can't avoid it.
"The idea of being there and meeting this one and that one, whose names I'll never keep straight, of trying not to make waves and even, at times, be gallante -- I'm not trained for it," he said. "Of course, a lot of artists are hogs for it."
Most aren't. The word "dread" comes up a lot. "I had one artist who insisted that I provide a stash in the back room, a bottle in a bag," said Mr. Gorney.
Lauren Wittels, the former director of Luhring Augustine Gallery in SoHo, said, "You feel you're up there on a big stick and people can say anything and throw anything." Tonight, Ms. Wittels opens her own SoHo gallery. It will have a public opening. Carl Fudge, a British painter, will be the figure on the stick.
The fear is well founded. The excited buzz of conversation at an opening, when it actually turns to the art on the wall, is often a cocktail of malicious witticisms, snide remarks and put-downs that later evolve, in post-opening gab sessions over dinner or drinks, into full-length scorching critiques.
 
Warming Up Adjectives
 First, though, the artist must be congratulated. This is the touchiest part of the ritual. It is important for friends and acquaintances to establish physical contact with the artist and make it clear that they have done their duty by showing up. (To make doubly sure, interested parties sign the guest book at the gallery's main desk, which the artist and the dealer will scrutinize the next day.) It is bad form, however, to cut in while the artist is doing a snow job on a potential buyer, buttonholing a critic or curator or licking the shoes of a more important artist.
The minimum acceptable burnt offering is "Congratulations." But this is also the formula when you hate the work but can't leave without saying something. "The show looks great" suggests that you don't actually despise the work. Good friends will elaborate a bit and single out a painting or two for more specific praise, which the artist often interprets as an implied criticism of the rest of the work.
Worst of all are the well-meaning souls who start out with warm congratulations and proceed to explain, in great detail, why the composition falls apart in several paintings.
If the congratulators sometimes falter, perhaps it's because they sense that the clock is ticking.
"I don't want to spend 30 minutes talking to someone about their lower-back problem," said Joe DiGiorgio, a landscape painter. "Both people's eyes are traveling around the room anyway, looking for someone they should be talking to or making contact with."
Often, the encounter between artist and congratulator becomes a test to see who can be ruder to whom, thereby clarifying status relations. No wonder everybody needs a drink.
Laura Nash, who makes illuminated Fiberglas sculptures, recently got a creepy feeling of deja-vu when a race of aliens appeared on a repeat episode of "Star Trek: The Next Generation."
"They had dark, severe suits, baggy but tapered at the ankles," she said. "They were very tall and thin and had a look of cold disdain. I thought, 'Gee, this looks just like the art world.'"
 
Food for the Eye Alone
 For everyone but the artist, openings can be great fun, a chance to meet, greet, look, listen and network. Early in the 80's, when the art market was booming and not only artists but their dealers assumed celebrity status, the custom developed of making the rounds and moving from one gallery opening to another.
"The word spreads very quickly about where to go," said Walter Robinson, an editor at Art in America and a producer of the cable program "Gallery Beat." "There's always one person in a group who knows where the openings are. It's sort of a sign of being on the inside, because this isn't published anywhere."
Some of the fizz has gone out of the Champagne, however. Pinched by tougher economic times, many galleries have cut back on the food and drink or eliminated refreshments entirely. "The days of waiters and tuxedos and silver trays, with rare exceptions, are gone," said Craig Cornelius, a dealer who recently began exhibiting and selling out of his Greenwich Village loft.
 
Fielding the Uninvited
 The cutbacks also solve a growing problem in SoHo: growing numbers of unwanted visitors.
"We used to do them religiously on Saturdays from 4 to 7, serving white wine to anyone and everyone," said Susan Brundage, the director of the Leo Castelli Gallery. "But as they became parties for people off the street, we switched nights and locations."
For the neo-primitivist painter and sculptor James Brown, for example, the gallery held an opening from 5 to 6 P.M. and gave the artist and his friends a cocktail party at a restaurant from 6 to 8.
"That way, the party becomes more focused on the artist and the exhibition rather than being a free-for-all," Ms. Brundage said.
John Post Lee, of Bravin Post Lee, said that he used to serve bottled beer at openings but that the gallery, which opened in 1990, had to give it up. "There was a certain contingent of aggressively frugal alcoholics," he said. "I'm not talking about a class of people, but a group of identifiable faces and names who'd use the openings as a way of drinking."
The old circuit has also frayed as galleries have experimented with new ways of presenting work, new hours, and more private gatherings, limited to the artists and an invited group of collectors and writers.
It doesn't take much for the old embers to burst into flame, though. When galleries have openings that fall on the same Saturday (as many will, just before the Whitney Biennial on March 15), the gallery-crawl resumes at full strength. When three new galleries on West 22d Street in Chelsea held their first openings last Saturday, their walls could barely contain the crowds.
Besides, a little austerity goes a long way. "The openings were toned down tremendously last year," said Jack Tilton, a SoHo dealer. "In a way it was hip not to go to an opening. But this year, it's O.K. again."
 
Galery Hopping
 Here is a sampling of receptions for the opening of new art shows today through next weekend at Manhattan galleries. All are free and open to the public.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Governor Signs Bill Overhauling Welfare

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts today signed into law a measure establishing one of the most restrictive welfare systems in the nation, legislation that cuts benefits, stops payments after two years and requires many recipients to work or perform community service.
While dozens of states have enacted some of these principles in one form or another, Massachusetts is the first to incorporate all three into an overhaul of its welfare system. 
 Under the new law, which must still be approved by the Federal Government before it can go into effect, parents already on welfare will no longer receive increased benefits if they have more children.
"We are obliterating, today, the mistakes of welfare as it has existed for decades," said Governor Weld, a 49-year-old Republican, after he signed the measure into law.
Critics warned that the law would make the poorest people in Massachusetts even poorer.
"Homeless shelters and foster care systems are going to be flooded with people," said Betsy Wright, the executive director of the Massachusetts Human Services Coalition, a nonprofit agency that studies poverty. "And those are much more expensive programs than sending welfare checks to people."
The law's many substantive changes are reflected by a semantic change: it renames the state's Department of Welfare the Department of Transitional Assistance.
Governor Weld, who is sometimes mentioned as a candidate for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination, has made overhauling the state's welfare system one of his priorities. "This is not a political victory so much as it is a triumph for families and children who have been trapped on welfare," he said.
Able-bodied welfare recipients with school-age children will be entitled to 60 days of benefits if the new law is approved. After that they will be required to get a job or perform community service at homeless shelters, hospitals, nursing homes and similar places.
About half of the state's 105,000 welfare recipients are considered to be able-bodied as defined by the new law; of those, about 20,000 have school-age children and will be eligible for 60 days of benefits.
Ms. Wright maintained that businesses and industries did not have enough jobs for 20,000 untrained workers, and that community service would not give welfare recipients the skills necessary to find good-paying jobs. "It keeps people from getting job training and going to school," she said of the new law, "so it traps people in the low-wage end of the economy."
The new law would also cut welfare benefits by 2.75 percent across the board and would requires teen-aged parents to live at home or in an approved setting, and to finish high-school in order to receive benefits. After two years, benefits would be cut off altogether.
Donna Gikes, a 34-year-old mother of three in Lowell, Mass., was one of several hundred women on welfare who protested the new law on Thursday, just before the bill won final legislative approval.
Ms. Gikes said that she would love to have a new job but that finding one was not easy. "I need to get a job," she said, "but I also need day care, and I need training."
Ms. Gikes also worried about seeing her benefits cut. She now gets $579 a month, $450 of which pays her rent. "There isn't much left if you add it up," she said.
Some critics find it paradoxical that Massachusetts, which had one of the most liberal governances and national politics of any state in the country in the 1970's and 80's, plans to enact the nation's strictest welfare overhaul law. In the elections last November, when the Republicans were being swept to power across the country, Massachusetts re-elected a liberal incumbent, Senator Edward M. Kennedy. In the 1972 Presidential election it was the only state to vote for George McGovern over Richard M. Nixon.
But its political climate has changed since 1990, when Mr. Weld, a former United States Attorney, was elected as a fiscally conservative but socially liberal governor. He was overwhelmingly re-elected to a second term last November.
The new law is scheduled to take effect on July 1, the start of the next fiscal year in Massachusetts. The state must first apply for a waiver from the Department of Health and Human Services to change the rules governing Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the primary state-Federal welfare program.
The Clinton Administration's policy has been to approve waiver requests for new welfare programs as long as they are constitutional, protect the interests of children and cost no more than the current programs.
 
 
 
AROUND THE NATION: How Other States Have Overhauled Welfare
 Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts signed a new law today that stands to give his state one of the most restrictive welfare systems in the country. Massachusetts is not alone in its efforts to overhaul the welfare system. Many states are changing the rules that govern Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the large welfare system operated as a partnership between the states and the Federal Government. Some states no longer increase benefits to families that have more children while on welfare; some now require welfare recipients to work or perform community service, and some place time limits on benefits. (Massachusetts plans to do all three.) Here is a look at what some other states are doing with their welfare systems:
 
CAPS ON BENEFITS RELATING TO FAMILY SIZE
 
ARKANSAS: does not increase welfare benefits to a families that have more children while on welfare.
 
GEORGIA: does not increase benefits for children born to families that have been on welfare for two years.
 
INDIANA: does not increase benefits for children conceived while their families are on welfare.
 
NEW JERSEY: does not increase benefits for children born to a families on welfare.
 
WISCONSIN: in most cases does not increase benefits to families that have more children while on welfare
 
TIME LIMITS OR WORK REQUIREMENTS:
 
COLORADO: in five counties, parents able to work or join training programs must do so after two years of welfare benefits.
 
CONNECTICUT: recipients in New Haven and Manchester must work 15 hours a week after two years; 25 hours a week after three years; and 35 hours a week after four years.
 
FLORIDA: most families limited to two years of benefits in any five-year period; after two years they are guaranteed the opportunity to work at a job paying more than their welfare benefits.
 
GEORGIA: recipients without children under 14 years old who refuse to work or leave employment without good cause lose their benefits.
 
INDIANA: up to 12,000 recipients considered ready to work will get help finding jobs and have their benefits cut off after two years.
 
IOWA: most parents will be required to get training or they will lose their benefits for six months.
 
MICHIGAN: recipients are required to seek employment or get job training.
 
SOUTH CAROLINA: recipients are trained and given 60 days to find a private sector job; if they cannot find work they are required to perform community service.
 
SOUTH DAKOTA: recipients who get job training can receive benits for two years before they are required to get a job or perform community service; recipients who go to school can receive benefits for five years before they must get a job or perform community service.
 
VERMONT: most recipients must do community or public service jobs after two-and-a-half years of benefits.
 
WISCONSIN: benefits are limited to two out of four years, with some exceptions. after recipients have exhausted their benefits they cannot go back on welfare for three years.
(Source: The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services)

HEADLINE: Arafat Asks U.S. to Rescue Israeli Talks

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Frustrated by the lack of progress in Middle East peace talks, the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, called for United States intervention today to rescue his negotiations with Israel from stalemate.
Mr. Arafat, who heads the Palestinian self-rule authority in the Gaza Strip, made a similar appeal to Russia and Norway, both of which have been brokers in getting the long-struggling enemies to talk to one another. 
 But the true focus of his plea was the Americans. Dr. Ahmed Tibi, a senior adviser to the Palestinian leader, said the immediate goal was to have Washington press Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin to ease a border closing that has kept Gaza and West Bank Arabs from badly needed jobs in Israel.
"The United States should tell Israel to lift the siege, first of all, and also to release prisoners," Dr. Tibi said. "If Rabin can't make a courageous decision by himself, then someone should help him, and the Americans are the ones to do it."
Shaken by a series of Islamic suicide bombings and wanting to restore a sense of security among its people, Israel has for the last three weeks kept out virtually all Palestinians, notably more than 50,000 low-paid day laborers.
A new poll suggests that Israelis overwhelmingly want the territorial closing to last. So even though Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today that he knew the restrictions were inflicting serious harm, and hoped they would be lifted "very soon," there was no sign of when that might happen.
The twin issues of Israeli security and Palestinian economic needs have fully eclipsed what the two sides are supposed to be discussing: how to expand Palestinian self-rule beyond Gaza and Jericho, on the West Bank.
After talks between Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin broke down on Thursday, a senior Palestinian official said the two sides were in a crisis. While playing down such talk, Mr. Rabin acknowledged that "there were differences" that had to be worked out before he meets the Palestinian leader again next week. Whatever the preferred language, there is little question that negotiations are deadlocked, with no obvious way out.
Israel did not react formally to the call for United States intervention, but officials gave it an icy reception, one of them waving it off as "posturing" by Mr. Arafat. Based on the record thus far, it seemed unlikely that the Clinton Administration would plunge into a dispute between two parties that for the most part have worked out agreements on their own.
A clearer sense of American intentions may emerge on Sunday when Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to meet with Mr. Peres and with his counterparts from the Palestine Liberation Organization and the only two Arab countries to have signed peace treaties with Israel -- Egypt and Jordan.
On a visit to Japan before he heads to Washington, Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt warned today that peace talks were "almost at the phase of make or break."
The stalemate also shows graphically how, despite the heralded peace agreement signed by their leaders in 1993, Israelis and Palestinians still talk to each other from behind walls of mistrust and misperceptions.
Israeli officials say they understand the Palestinians' economic plight and resentment of what they see as collective punishment. But they add that their security needs come first, and insist that the Palestinian Authority in Gaza work harder to block Islamic radicals.
In turn, Mr. Arafat says he understands Israel's safety fears. But he adds that the Israelis must understand his need to appear strong, and when Israel seals off his territory at will, he hardly looks to other Palestinians as though he is in command.
Although he himself has not publicly said so, some of his aides assert that Israel is using the security issue as an excuse to freeze the peace agreement in Gaza and Jericho. Israeli officials say that is not so.
But the newspaper Maariv warns of "a vicious circle" that neither side seems able to break. "If Rabin doesn't help Arafat prove to the Palestinians that peace pays off, Arafat will not be able to gain control over the opponents of peace," the Israeli daily said in an editorial this week. "But if Arafat will not succeed in overcoming the terrorist organizations, Rabin will not be able to help him."

HEADLINE: Democrats Call Republicans Too Lenient on Welfare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
House Democrats today criticized the work requirement in the Republicans' latest welfare proposal as too lenient, and they said the plan should put more emphasis on finding jobs for poor people.
But the House Democratic Caucus refused to take a stand on one of the most important issues in the debate: whether poor people should have a right to cash assistance as an entitlement. 
 That right has been embedded in the welfare program for 60 years, guaranteeing benefits to all who meet certain eligibility criteria. This feature of the program automatically injects Federal money into states suffering severe economic problems, but it makes the total cost difficult to control.
House Republicans and many Republican governors say the money should be distributed to the states in a lump sum, or block grant. The House Republican bill would provide $15.4 billion a year, the amount the Federal Government spent in 1994 on cash assistance, with no allowance for inflation or increased need.
States could use the money in any way they wanted to help indigent families with children or to discourage childbearing outside marriage.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, said the Republican proposal did "nothing, absolutely nothing" to replace welfare with work and to prepare recipients for jobs.
Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, said the Republican proposal contained virtually "no work requirement" for welfare recipients. Representative Richard E. Neal, Democrat of Massachusetts, said: "Welfare reform needs to be tough but fair. Individuals should be provided with the opportunity to work, and if they do not want to work, then their benefits should be denied."
Nearly five million adults get benefits under the main cash assistance program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children; about 7 percent of them work. The Republican bill would require states to raise this proportion to 20 percent by 2003.
When asked whether the program should remain an entitlement, Mr. Gephardt, like President Clinton, seemed to waver.
"It's an interesting question, but frankly it's irrelevant to what we're talking about today," Mr. Gephardt said at a news conference with 18 other House Democrats. "What we are talking about is requiring work. You can do that if you retain welfare as an entitlement, and you can do it if you go to a block grant."
Republicans said they would welcome Democratic amendments to establish more stringent requirements for welfare recipients to work. They also said they were pleasantly surprised that the Democratic Caucus had so far not taken a firm stand in favor of preserving the entitlement status of Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a longtime student of social welfare policy, was critical of both the Republican proposal and the response by Mr. Clinton, who said on Thursday that he might support the Republican bill "if it promotes work and family and protects children."
"You cannot abandon children," said Mr. Moynihan, the ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee. "You just cannot do it. The White House had better be a lot clearer in this regard than it was yesterday.
"To abolish the A.F.D.C. program 60 years after it was enacted would be a retrograde and cruel measure directed at children. I can't imagine it coming out of the Senate Committee on Finance."
Noting the President's comment, Mr. Moynihan asked, "Promotes work and family by turning children out into the street?"
He said he wondered what people elsewhere would think of the United States, adding, "We used to stand for social progress in the world."
The Republican bill would require welfare recipients to participate in some type of "work program" after they had received cash assistance for two years. States would design the work programs, and the requirements would vary from state to state. But no family could receive Federal welfare benefits for more than five years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, foreground, said yesterday that a Republican welfare proposal did "nothing, absolutely nothing" to replace the current system with work. With him at a news conference were other Democrats, including Representative Lynn Woolsey of California, lower right, and Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington's delegate to the House, left. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Family Spirals Downward In Waiting for Agency to Act

SERIES: Bias Agency Adrift: A periodic report.

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
On Aug. 19, 1992, Al B. Tatum called in sick and took his bottled-up fury over co-workers' taunts and slurs to the Milwaukee office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Mr. Tatum, who is black, filled out Charge No. 260920645, alleging racial discrimination by his employer, Cooper Power Systems.
The torrent of slurs was so unrelenting, he has said, that he eventually quit his job. 
 Almost two and a half years have passed since Mr. Tatum filed his complaint with the agency that Congress created to enforce civil rights laws in the workplace, and his case has still not been resolved. But in that time, the Tatum family, like thousands of others enmeshed in the E.E.O.C.'s complaint process, has spiraled from crisis to crisis.
Mr. Tatum, 33, said in a recent interview at his new home in Kansas City, Mo., that he could not find work paying even half of the $12 an hour he had earned at Cooper Power Systems. So he took his $15,000 in savings and started a restaurant in Milwaukee. It failed. The Tatums then slipped from the cusp of the middle class, losing the $41,000 ranch house they had been buying.
Late last year they moved to Kansas City, to a $360-a-month apartment and jobs, but earning only two-thirds of what they were when Mr. Tatum was at Cooper Power and his wife, Debra, 37, was an insurance claims processor.
The files of the E.E.O.C. teem with Al Tatums: about 100,000 unresolved cases at the end of 1994, double the backlog of just two years ago.
The commission's new chairman, Gilbert F. Casellas, has acknowledged inefficiencies in its procedures and said he found the headquarters overstaffed. He said he wanted to dispatch some of those people to field offices, where processing delays were most acute. But the big problem, he said, is a woefully inadequate budget.
Civil rights lawyers and the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative arm, raise questions about the commission's procedures and competence. But even they say that its budget -- $233 million this year -- leaves it ill-equipped to do what it is supposed to do.
The result is that with the exception of emergencies -- cases involving people with terminal diseases or facing physical assault at work, for example -- complainants typically wait nine months to a year in a "pending stage" before an investigator even starts gathering evidence. It is normally another six months to a year before their claims are rejected or resolved. "The agency is supposed to be there to give ordinary citizens an effective way to enforce their civil rights," said Patrick O. Patterson, whose Milwaukee firm, Hall, Patterson & Charne, represents Mr. Tatum. "But it functions as a sort of obstacle."
Congress further burdens the agency by increasing the number of workers it must protect, recently adding workers with disabilities. From Oct. 1, 1992, to Oct. 1, 1994, the cases the agency received jumped 54 percent; its budget grew only 9 percent.
Responding to the budgetary crunch, the agency has reduced the number of investigators to 732 from 762. Still, with salaries consuming 78 percent of the agency's budget, there is little left to spend on equipment that could help fewer investigators work faster.
The toll of the resulting delays, complainants say, goes beyond the frustration of waiting. Like all crime, illegal discrimination is best tackled fast, when evidence and memories are fresh. But at the commission, investigations can become archeological digs.
"Documents get lost or destroyed," said Mr. Patterson, a former lawyer for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. "Evidence gets stale. Witnesses move or die or they forget what happened."
Many complainants just give up. They change jobs, move and get on with their lives while the bias or bigotry they challenged persists to become fodder for new cases.
A breakthrough in Mr. Tatum's case came on Jan. 3, 1995. The agency notified his lawyer, Gretchen Miller, that it had found merit in his accusations. It said it would invite Cooper Power Systems, a manufacturer of big electrical transformers, to negotiate a voluntary settlement and payment to Mr. Tatum. "It was about time," he said.
Cooper Power, a division of Cooper Industries Inc. of Houston, has denied Mr. Tatum's accusations, saying the company acts fast to stop discrimination. It may refuse to negotiate, so there might still be a lawsuit and more delay.
 
The Problem
Seeking Help, Finding Hurt
 Al Tatum, 6 feet 4 inches, trim and soft-spoken, was the last of 15 children of a General Motors worker and a part-time maid.
He went to work at Cooper Power, 18 miles from Milwaukee in Waukesha, in 1988 after nine years with an airline maintenance company that closed. In various jobs at Cooper Power, running a press, driving a forklift, going on the road to repaint customers' transformers, he sometimes worked solely with whites. He said the harassment at Cooper Power, which he never encountered in his first job and has not faced in his Kansas City one, began almost immediately.
The materials Ms. Miller submitted to the Federal commission are a recitation of slurs and epithets that support Mr. Tatum's accusations. Mr. Tatum said the epithets remained on the restroom walls for weeks despite his complaints to supervisors.
In November 1989, Mr. Tatum and his lawyer wrote: "Mr. Tatum's work name tag appeared on one of the stalls in the men's room. When he complained about this to a supervisor, he was told that it was just a matter of his co-workers 'having fun.' "
On May 24, 1990, a fake "Application Form for Mike McGee's Militia" was put on Mr. Tatum's desk in the warehouse. Michael McGee, a black Milwaukee Alderman, had threatened violence against the city unless it spent $100 million to improve economic conditions for blacks. The form, a part of Mr. Tatum's file with the commission, asked:
"Yo Mamma's name:
"Yo Daddy's name (if known):
"Yo auto: Cadillac. Lincoln. Financed. Stolen.
"Yo marital status: Common law. Shacked up. Gay.
"Yo place of birth: Free clinic. Alley. Zoo. Colonel Sanders. Unknown.
"Yo prior experience: Govt worker. Evangelist. Dope dealer. Postmaster. Pimp.
"Note," it said at the bottom, "No photo is necessary since yo all look alike anyway."
Four months later, The Milwaukee Journal began an article about racial tensions in the city with an anecdote about Mr. Tatum's finding the form.
Harassment escalated after the article, Mr. Tatum said.
After repeated complaints to supervisors and to their supervisors, he said, he was sent on the road for six months, removing rust and repainting transformers. A co-worker who Mr. Tatum said had been slighting him was sent along and subjected him to almost constant taunts, he said
David H. Watson, a division vice president for employee relations at Cooper Power, said the company acted immediately to find the source of the militia form. He said it also investigated Mr. Tatum's other accusations.
"We don't take these matters lightly," Mr. Watson said. "Tatum I know because I have a log. He has filed a discrimination charge. We have strongly denied any and all allegations or charges of racial discrimination that have been made by Mr. Tatum."
Mr. Watson said he would not discuss the charges in detail while the case was before the bias commission. But, he added, "we obviously feel the allegations he has made are not supported by circumstances or events."
 
The Time
Twisting Turns Of Complaint
 His first dealings with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission were reassuring, Mr. Tatum said. Three weeks after he filed, he said, the Milwaukee office called to say he would be assigned an investigator.
At the same time, Miriam R. Katzman, a lawyer specializing in workers compensation, was developing a a claim for Mr. Tatum separate from his bias case. Ms. Katzman maintained that Mr. Tatum had suffered psychological injury on the job.
A doctor, Crain H. Bliwas, examined Mr. Tatum in November 1992. In a letter to Ms. Katzman, a copy of which Ms. Miller submitted to the bias commission, Dr. Bliwas said that Mr. Tatum "has experienced extreme work-related stress and that this stress has been a substantial and material cause of this patient's disability."
Dr. Bliwas said that Mr. Tatum was "unable to engage in any gainful employment of any kind" and that "certainly he would not be able to continue working at Cooper." His overall assessment, the doctor said, was of a "major depressive disorder."
But the commission was nowhere near looking into Mr. Tatum's accusation.
"November 1992 came," Mr. Tatum said. "Christmas passed. I called them in February. 'Oh, you have an investigator now,' they said. The investigator tells me he's going out there to investigate. I called him a couple of weeks later. 'You been out there?' 'No I haven't had a chance. We're backed up.' "
Such delays are common. The commission routinely warns its clients that their charges must undergo a five-stage process, including a pending stage of a year or so during which they languish in the backlog.
The Milwaukee district office carries one of the heaviest loads of the 50 commission offices nationwide. Chester V. Bailey, the office director, said each of his 23 investigators dealt on average with 143 cases, 30 more than the national average.
"The charges are controlling us now," Mr. Bailey said. "We're doing the best that we possibly can under the circumstances. We need more funding and ultimately more staff."
 
The Hope
End Is Near, Yet so Far
 Once the pending period ended, in February 1993, Mr. Tatum's case seemed to be moving. Two months later, his investigator interviewed people at Cooper Power; a month later he met with Mr. Tatum and his lawyer.
Mr. Tatum said the investigator told him that he thought the accusation had "reasonable cause," or evidence enough to qualify for a suit, and that it was likely to be referred to the agency headquarters in Washington for a ruling on who would sue, the agency or Mr. Tatum.
In July 1993, Mr. Tatum said, the investigator said the case would be completed in September. But in September, the investigator said he had to go back to Cooper Power.
Mr. Bailey declined to discuss this specific case. But he said that sometimes, when the research on a case was nearly complete, employers and complainants introduced new information that required more work.
The investigator returned to Cooper Power seven months later, on March 24, 1994. By then, Mr. Tatum's restaurant was consuming the last of his savings. Mrs. Tatum was carrying the family, including two children, on her $12-an-hour job, and the couple was having trouble with mortgage payments.
Summer came, and Mr. Tatum finally gave up on Milwaukee. Moving alone to Kansas City in August, he found work as a $5.25-an-hour baggage handler at the airport and took a room at the Y.M.C.A.
By October, the Tatums were $10,000 behind in mortgage payments, so Mrs. Tatum gave the house back to the bank, moved herself and the children into an apartment with her husband and looked for another insurance job.
A month later, the family's fortunes picked up. Cooper Power settled Mr. Tatum's workers' compensation claim with a $10,000 payment without a finding of the cause of his illness. He kept $6,701.50; his lawyer, Ms. Katzman, received most of the rest, a ratio typical in such cases.
The new year has brought even better times. The family began saving to buy a house after Mrs. Tatum found a $12-an-hour job like the one she left in Milwaukee.
Then came the commission's Jan. 3 letter, a breakthrough in the case if not its end.
"I have considered all the evidence disclosed during the investigation," Mr. Bailey wrote, "and find that there is reasonable cause to believe that there is a violation" of Mr. Tatum's civil rights.
Mr. Bailey invited Mr. Tatum and representatives of his former employer to join in "reaching a just resolution of this matter," including consideration of compensatory and punitive damages.
Failing that, Cooper Power and Mr. Tatum are assured a day in court.

HEADLINE: A President-Turned-Patton Directs Peru's Jungle War

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Alberto K. Fujimori, known to many on Wall Street as the President who gave his country the world's highest economic growth rate last year, is now reveling in a new role, as Peru's Patton.
"Today, we bombed Tiwintza with 17 planes -- it was a saturation bombing," Mr. Fujimori said in an interview Thursday night. He was recounting his order to have Russian-made Sukhoi 22 bombers "soften up" an Ecuadorean military redoubt on an Amazon hilltop near the border. "Our Mirages gave cover in case enemy planes appeared," he said, referring to Peru's French-built fighter planes. 
 Poring over a war map, Mr. Fujimori used a ballpoint pen to indicate his troops' thrust up a disputed river valley, saying, "I'm sending in 1,000 counterinsurgency troops, all with jungle combat experience."
As Peru's border conflict with Ecuador stretches into a third week, with 47 confirmed dead and 88 wounded, Peru's President shows no sign of settling for anything short of an outright military victory.
Though pensive in the one-on-one interview in the quiet of the Presidential Palace, Mr. Fujimori was jaunty, even triumphant, in a taped television interview that was broadcast across the nation a few minutes later.
"They are crying uncle!" Peru's leader said, using local slang to dismiss an Ecuadorean appeal for a "humanitarian truce" during which bodies could be retrieved from the jungle. "There is no room for a truce at this point in the hostilities."
With peace talks in the Brazilian capital, Brasilia, showing little progress, the United States and Brazil announced today that they were suspending all arms shipments to the two countries. Peru acknowledges losing two Russian-made helicopters and one Canberra flight training plane in the fighting.
On Thursday, an Aeroflot cargo plane arrived here with what Mr. Fujimori described as "spare parts" for Peru's largely Russian-equipped army.
Fresh from visiting an army field hospital in Bagua, Peru's main staging area, Mr. Fujimori said on Thursday that he was "certain" that the fighting would be over by the end of this month. Referring to military tensions along Peru's 1,000-mile border with Ecuador, he said, "We hope the fighting does not expand."
In a war largely without witnesses, the fighting is taking place in a remote, mountain jungle that is so dense that a 60-man Peruvian patrol was located Thursday after wandering lost for several days. The soldiers were treated for dehydration and insect bites.
In this thick rainforest, as little as 300 yards separate Ecuadorean and Peruvian positions.
"Our big surprise was that Ecuador was well prepared with artillery in these high places," Mr. Fujimori said, returning to his war map. "We dispersed our troops and quickly engaged with Ecuadorean troops." Fearful of shelling their own units, Ecuadorean gunners stopped using artillery pieces, Mr. Fujimori said.
Each side blames the other for starting the conflict. Mr. Fujimori charged that Ecuador fired the first shots on Jan. 26.
Citing his three trips in the last two years to visit his northern neighbor, he also said that he had repeatedly appealed to Ecuador to demarcate the 48-mile stretch of border now in dispute.
"I said to Rodrigo Borja: 'Invite me and I'll come,' " Mr. Fujimori said in a reference to Ecuador's former President, who received the Peruvian leader in Quito in 1992. Warmly greeted by Ecuadorean crowds, Mr. Fujimori was the first Peruvian President in memory to visit the nation.
With both countries now locked in low-level warfare, Mr. Fujimori blamed the falling-out on Ecuadorean politicians seeking popular support and on Ecuadorean generals seeking to retain their privileges.
While the border issue is traumatic for Ecuadoreans, most Peruvians show little interest.
"We had to put an ad on television to explain what the Rio Protocol was all about," Mr. Fujimori said, referring to a 1942 treaty. The agreement recognized Peruvian ownership of a huge Amazon area that Ecuador had lost to Peru in a war the previous year.

International

John B. Neff is doubtful about the stock market in general. Mr. Neff, manager of the Windsor Fund since 1964, discussed stocks, interest rates and natural gas in a recent interview. [31.]

Lenders and builders are trying new incentives to lure home buyers, as mortgage rates rise and home sales fall. Early rate locks, small cash payments, warranties and discount financing are among the extras being offered. [31.]

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise Modestly, With Consensus Absent

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Even a report showing only modest inflation was not enough to inspire the listless financial markets yesterday, sending the leading stock indexes up only modestly.
 After rising as much as 14 points, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,939.07, up 6.39 points, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 1.27 points, to 481.46. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 4.99 points, to 790.43. 
 Despite four consecutive drifting sessions, the Dow managed to eke out a 10-point gain for the week. But the prices for the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond slipped, as its yield crept up to 7.67 percent yesterday from 7.63 at Monday's opening, indicating pessimism on inflation.
 A market consensus, sometimes slow to develop, is largely absent for the moment. Nine days after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the seventh time within a year, investors in the stock, bond and currency markets are still unsure whether interest rates have peaked, hence whether it is a good bet to buy shares, bonds and dollars.
 Despite a clearly favorable track record on inflation and strong fourth-quarter earnings, normally bullish signs, many traders are on the sidelines.
 Contradictory statements by Federal Reserve Board members are partly to blame. Susan Philips, a Fed governor, said in a speech Wednesday that inflation was "not yet all gone," a seeming signal that the Fed would raise rates again. But earlier in the week, another Fed governor, John P. LaWare, seemed to imply that the Fed had finished tightening credit. "We may be at the cusp of what we're trying to accomplish," he said in a Monday speech.
 Yesterday, the Producer Price Index, the major bit of market-moving news in a tepid week, lifted stock prices for only 20 minutes. At its market-moving peak, the news lifted the Dow by about 14 points, or three-tenths of one percent, and the S.& P. 500 by about 1.2 point, or two-tenths of a percent.
 That is paltry considering that the rise in the index, three-tenths of 1 percent for January, was less than Wall Street economists' expectations of four-tenths of 1 percent.
 The big stock winners yesterday were airlines. The major carriers reported that their January figures for paying passengers were on the rise. And Delta Air Lines angered travel agents by cutting commissions, a move followed by other carriers, including American Airlines and Northwest Airlines.
 UAL, the parent of United Airlines, rose 5 1/4, to 97, in heavy volume; Delta closed at a 52-week high of 56 3/4, up 4 in heavy volume; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 3, to 60 1/4, and Northwest rose 1 7/8, to 21.
 Clinicom, a developer of medical software, rose 4 5/8, to 19 1/4, after reporting that its fourth-quarter earnings almost tripled.
 Few stocks had big falls. Cascade Communications, which designs telecommunications equipment, fell 25/16 , to 639/16 . It reported on Thursday that its fourth-quarter net was 28 cents a share in contrast to a loss of 3 cents a year earlier.
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal with 297.5 million shares changing hands.
 The most active stock, at 9.1 million shares, was Cisco Systems, a computer software developer, which fell 15/16 , to 351/16 .
 In Tokyo, stocks recovered yesterday after three consecutive declines. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 191.80 points, or 1.06 percent, at 18,291.35.
