HEADLINE: American Insurers Seek More Business in Japan

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 10

 BODY:
When an earthquake devastated parts of western Japan last month, the AIU Insurance Company rented a boat, 100 hotel rooms, 50 mobile phones, 20 vans and trucks and a fleet of motorbikes and bicycles. Then the American company sent in claims adjustors, who distributed food, water and blankets as they tried to reach 3,000 policyholders to assess damages.
 This approach may have been the right one, not only from a humanitarian standpoint, but also from a business standpoint for AIU, a subsidiary of the New York-based American International Group Inc., which is trying to expand its share in Japan's $400 billion insurance market, the largest in the world outside the United States. 
 Although little known abroad, Japanese insurers like the Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company have been among the world's biggest and most profitable financial companies. Long unchallenged by outsiders, they enjoyed profits virtually guaranteed by regulators and grew at the same blistering pace as Japan's overall economy.
 Now, however, insurers are in the public eye in Japan because the earthquake showed how well they managed not to accept risk but to evade it through policy restrictions.
 "It's regulated," said Rie Ota, an analyst at Baring Securities (Japan) Ltd. "If the industry doesn't make a 5 percent profit, it can apply to the Ministry of Finance for an increase. If it makes too much money, it returns the profit to the policyholders."
 But these days, Japan's insurance titans are facing an array of new challenges, symbolized by AIU's rush to the scene of the earthquake around the city of Kobe on Jan. 17. The earthquake is expected to lead to $2 billion in claims for Japanese nonlife insurance companies, and while the companies think that is plenty, there is public criticism that they got off too lightly. Overall damage from the earthquake was around $100 billion, perhaps more.
 "It's sad but true that there's very little risk to domestic nonlife insurance companies," said Alicia Ogawa, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. "The little guy gets ripped off, and the Japanese people will stand there and take it."
 At the same time, deregulation is coming to Japan -- too slowly for the taste of some -- and one result is that a burst of new competition will shake up the industry and probably erode profitability. Staid companies will increasingly have to grapple with new entrants, foreign competitors and direct mail.
 The earthquake last month killed more than 5,000 people and destroyed or damaged about 100,000 homes, buildings and other structures. But only 3 percent of the people in the Kobe area had earthquake insurance, partly because premiums were so high. And even people who had it are limited to about $100,000 in claims on a demolished home -- about the cost of a parking space in Japan. For furniture and other household property, the maximum payment is $50,000.
 Many policyholders, however, cannot get even a fraction of that. Until last year, people with insurance for earthquake but not fire, or for fire but not earthquake, got nothing if their houses burned down after a quake. This caused an uproar last year after an earthquake struck Hokkaido in northern Japan, and the rules were changed.
 Now, if half or more of a house is destroyed by an earthquake-induced fire, people with fire insurance can receive up to $30,000 for residences and small retail shops and $200,000 for industrial operations.
As if to cushion the industry's payments, although it was in fact coincidental, fire insurance premium rates rose across Japan on Feb. 1.
 Reacting to public indignation, the Government suggested last month that it would raise the ceiling on how much money a family with a damaged home is legally allowed to receive on a claim. And life insurance companies declared they would pay full policy benefits regardless of exclusion clauses, so that they would end up paying hundreds of millions of dollars on claims from the quake that hit Kobe.
 If total individual claims for any one earthquake exceed set amounts, Government subsidies kick in on a sliding scale. Since the Government does not offer subsidies for corporate earthquake coverage, neither Japanese nor foreign insurance companies sell much commercial earthquake insurance here.
 But many foreign companies operating in Japan demand earthquake coverage and obtain it overseas.
 "Foreign companies will pay more in losses than their market share," said Ross E. Matthews, regional vice president at AIU. "All it takes is a factory to get hit, and you've got $100 million right there."
 The American International Group, which owns AIU and had a small share of marine and commercial insurance in the Kobe area, expects earthquake losses of only $50 million on total sales of $4.3 billion in Japan. A representative from the Cigna Insurance Company said its losses would probably be even less.
 An official at Lloyd's of London said that losses related to nonmarine reinsurance in Kobe, where it had a quarter of the market, would amount to $100 million.
 Although only a small minority of consumers had earthquake insurance, Japanese are generally avid buyers of insurance, especially life insurance.
 The Japanese spend nearly twice as much per capita on life insurance as Americans, and the nonlife insurance industry is particularly lucrative. Foreign companies had long looked at the Japanese market, and a few had been involved in it; then an agreement reached last fall by Japanese and American negotiators expanded foreign companies' access to the Japanese insurance market.
 While the agreement was welcomed at the time, the Japanese market is proving a tough one for American insurance companies, and many are not trying to enter it at present. Operating costs are very high, and Japanese companies and individuals frequently buy through established relationships.
 Because the industry is highly regulated, premiums charged by competing companies are identical. This means that foreign companies cannot offer lower prices to build business, but instead have to find other strategies to attract clients. Some focus on service, while others try to develop new kinds of insurance or drum up business through direct mail solicitations.
 For the most recent American entrant, the UNUM Corporation, based in Portland, Me., it took nearly 10 years of preparation to open for business in Japan this year. UNUM sells a product that typical Japanese insurance companies do not touch: disability insurance.
 Some foreign companies are hoping that the recent criticism of the Japanese insurance companies in the wake of the earthquake will create new opportunities for outsiders.
 "It's a very bad disaster," said Theresa T. Carney, regional vice president of Cigna. "But an unexpected impact for foreign insurance companies is that some companies that never thought of coming to foreign insurance companies are now coming and asking, 'What can you do for us?' "

HEADLINE: Agee Is Out at Morrison Knudsen

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10

 BODY:
After an emotional six-hour board meeting here that ended late Thursday night, the Morrison Knudsen Corporation announced early today that William Agee had resigned from all of his positions at the giant construction and transit equipment company, effective immediately.
 Mr. Agee, 57, left this morning to return to his home south of here in Pebble Beach and was unavailable for comment, a company spokesman said at a news conference. 
 Mr. Agee's departure as chairman and chief executive closes a difficult chapter for the company, which is known for building the Hoover Dam, the Trans-Alaska Pipeline and rail equipment like new high-tech cars for the Metro-North Railroad in New York. In the six years that Mr. Agee guided the company, he failed to generate steady growth in operating profit. As problems and complaints about his management arose, employee morale sank, the stock price fell and he left the corporate headquarters in Boise, Idaho, and tried to run the company from his Pebble Beach home.
 Now Morrison Knudsen faces a host of difficulties, including a sizable loss for the fourth quarter and the year and defaults on the terms of its revolving credit agreements with banks.
 Only 10 days ago, Mr. Agee had planned to leave the chief executive post "sometime this year" and stay on as chairman until 1998, when he would turn 60. But last week, a small group of Morrison Knudsen directors began pressing Mr. Agee to leave sooner, so that new leaders could be recruited to deal with the company's financial crisis.
 Stepping in today as acting chairman is William P. Clark, a director who pushed for Mr. Agee's immediate removal, according to people familiar with the board's deliberations. Mr. Clark, 63, served in the Reagan Administration as national security adviser and Interior Secretary. He now operates an international consulting business from his ranch near Paso Robles, Calif.
 Today he said his first priority was "to restore confidence among all our constituents, especially our 14,000 employees and their families, the financial community, our great clients and, certainly, our shareholders."
 Mr. Clark said that he had talked to the company's banks and that they "were highly appreciative of the action." He added, "With the board now fully informed and active with management, I am confident that the banks will cooperate with us."
 In New York Stock Exchange trading, Morrison Knudsen shares rebounded slightly today to close up 62.5 cents each at $10.25 a share. The announcement of Mr. Agee's resignation was made before trading began in New York. Several Wall Street analysts who follow the company's finances said they were taking a wait-and-see attitude. "This is still a very fluid situation," one analyst said.
 The board said it would announce its 1994 financial results during the week starting Feb. 19.
 Mr. Clark emphasized today that his tenure as chairman was "strictly temporary." Stephen G. Hanks, the executive vice president, was named acting chief executive. Mr. Clark said the board's search committee, which he heads, would continue to seek a permanent successor to Mr. Agee.
 Perhaps to underscore the break with that past, Mr. Clark said today that he intended to return the company's board meetings and its management focus to the Idaho headquarters. "Considering this company's great history and mystique, we have to recognize that its heart is in Boise," he said.
 Mr. Hanks, 44, said at the news conference that the company had not yet negotiated a severance package with Mr. Agee. His current employment contract, which expires on Dec. 31, calls for him to receive a severance benefit equal to twice his base compensation, including salary, bonus, health plan and pension benefits, under certain circumstances. But it was not clear how his departure today would be treated under that contract.
 A person familiar with the details of the protracted meeting Thursday night said: "Everyone was just too tired to take it up. That will come later."
 Mr. Agee's compensation package included a $750,000 base salary and a bonus structure that along with noncash compensation produced a salary as high as $2.4 million in 1993. Mr. Hanks said that the bleak financial results for 1994 eliminated the possibility of a bonus for Mr. Agee but that his total 1994 pay package would not be disclosed until the company's proxy statement is released next month.
 In addition to resigning from his positions at Morrison Knudsen, Mr. Agee also stepped down from the chairmanships of MK Rail and MK Gold, two former subsidiaries that were spun off as free-standing companies during his tenure. MK Rail announced today that Michael Farrell, its president, would also assume that company's chief executive post, formerly held by Mr. Agee. MK Gold has not announced a replacement for Mr. Agee as chairman.
 Assisting Mr. Hanks at Morrison Knudsen will be Robert A. Tinstman, 48, who will become chief operating officer, Mr. Tinstman is now president of the company's mining group. A mining engineer by training, Mr. Tinstman has been with the company 20 years.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Fall on Weight of New Supply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell yesterday as investment firms struggled to sell some of the $40 billion of notes and bonds they purchased in the Government's quarterly debt auction this week.
 The bond market "did have a major seller, and that was the U.S. Government," said Van Hoisington, president of Hoisington Asset Management, a Dallas firm with $2.7 billion in assets. "Anytime you have a major seller, the markets decline." 
 The Treasury completed its debt auctions on Thursday with the sale of $11 billion of 30-year bonds. Earlier in the week, it sold $12 billion of 10-year notes and $17 billion of 3-year notes.
 The price of the new 30-year bond fell yesterday. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.67 percent from 7.65 percent, where it was priced in Thursday's auction.
 "The market is definitely feeling the weight of the supply," said Monty Cleworth, who manages $300 million in bonds at Founders Asset Management in Denver.
 Bond prices initially rose yesterday after the Government reported that producer prices rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in January. But prices retreated after traders saw evidence of inflationary pressures in the data. The report also showed that raw material prices like crude oil and iron ore rose as much as 1 percent.
 While the report failed to unsettle the market, it was "not the kind of news that will get much more money drawn into the market," said Daniel Callahan, head trader at Paine Webber Inc.
 To be sure, some analysts and investors have concluded that bond yields will keep falling because the Federal Reserve may have increased interest rates enough to keep the inflation rate from rising. As measured by the Government's Consumer Price Index, inflation ran at a 2.7 percent pace last year, unchanged from 1993.
 "There's still a conviction rates are stable or even moving lower," said William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds. "That's a strong conviction out there."
 If the recent rally is losing steam, "some of that is to be expected, given we've had the auctions," said Patrick Retzer, who manages the $65 million Heartland U.S. Government Securities Fund in Milwaukee. "We've got to move higher here very soon to keep this rally going," he said. "We're losing momentum."
 Municipal bonds fell yesterday for the first time in eight sessions amid expectations that new bond issuance will increase after several weeks of declining sales. States, cities and agencies are scheduled to offer $2.24 billion in new bonds next week, up from $1.95 billion in the last five days.
The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer's index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose to 6.53 percent yesterday from 6.51 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Are Higher On Signs of a Lower Supply

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Copper prices surged yesterday in reaction to a drop in inventories that reflected solid consumer demand.
Continued strength in coffee prices, along with higher grain and crude oil prices, lifted the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities 1.26 points, to 233.93. 
 This week, copper prices recovered half of the 10 percent drop of the previous two weeks. The slide had been prompted in part by worries that higher interest rates in the United States would cause an economic slowdown, dampening demand.
But the market was bolstered yesterday by signs of a diminished supply. The London Metal Exchange, the world's principal respository for refined copper, said its warehouse held stocks of 301,525 metric tons, down 1.5 percent from three days earlier.
Copper for March delivery gained 2.85 cents, to 134.4 cents a pound, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
In an announcement after the close of trading, workers settled a weeklong strike at the huge Empresa Nacional de Mineria copper refinery in Chile, the world's top copper producer.
Coffee prices rose for a fourth consecutive day, encouraged by reports on Thursday that the Colombian National Coffee Federation would set a minimum export price on its coffee beans.
Also prompting the jump was news that Central American nations had withheld 238,042 bags of coffee, which weigh 132 pounds each, in January as part of a plan to limit supplies to the market.
Coffee for March delivery gained 3.85 cents, to $1.6275 cents a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Wheat and soybean prices rallied after the Government issued a report trimming supply projections and on renewed expectations that China would make large purchases of American agricultural products.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for March delivery rose 7 cents, to $3.765 a bushel, and March soybeans gained 3.5 cents, to $5.5775.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Takes a Tumble, Following U.S. Bonds Lower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday, following American bonds lower after a report on producer prices in the United States showed rising raw material costs.
"The dollar was very tied in with the bond market today," said Ross Taylor, head of foreign exchange at Daiwa Securities (America). 
 Bond prices, which are sensitive to any signs of accelerating inflation, can steer the direction of the dollar because international investors need to buy dollars when they want to buy United States bonds and sell dollars after they have cashed out.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5192 German marks from 1.5286 marks on Thursday and to 1.2820 Swiss francs from 1.2927 francs. The British pound advanced to $1.5630 from $1.5575. But the dollar rose against the Japanese yen, settling at 98.93, compared with 98.90 yen on Thursday.
The dollar was buoyed against the yen by dollar purchases from Japanese investment and insurance companies, Mr. Taylor said. They are acquiring dollars to buy United States bonds, attracted by those bonds' high yields relative to Japanese bonds, he said. United States 10-year notes yield 7.64 percent, compared with 4.63 percent for Japan.
Initially, bonds rose and pushed the dollar higher, after the Labor Department reported that its Producer Price Index rose a smaller-than-expected three-tenths of 1 percent in January.
"The P.P.I. numbers were a little better than expected, and bonds liked that," said Earl Johnson, currency adviser at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "So the dollar went up at first." Later in the day, however, said Dave Glowacki, senior currency dealer at NBD Bank in Detroit, "the bond market didn't like some of the P.P.I. components, and a selloff of the dollar coincided with the selloff of bonds."
The dollar also suffered from heightened tension in the Chiapas state of Mexico, traders said. On Thursday, President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon ordered army troops and federal police agents to arrest the commanders of the peasant uprising in Chiapas as criminals.
Such economic and social unrest has hurt the dollar because of the close economic ties between the United States and Mexico. The turmoil has benefited the German mark and Swiss franc, as investors seek a safe-haven currency. Since the Mexican Government devalued the peso on Dec. 20, the dollar has fallen 3.5 percent against the mark.

HEADLINE: Producer Price Index Up 0.3% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Despite sharply accelerating costs for many basic materials, inflation remained at bay in January as American producers obtained only modest price increases on goods at the stage just before they reach consumers, Government figures showed today.
 The Producer Price Index for Finished Goods -- what companies receive for items ready for sale to the final business or individual user -- rose three-tenths of 1 percent, as the biggest jump in energy prices since August was offset by the biggest decline in food prices since May. 
 After factoring out the volatile food and energy price swings, the "core" rate of increase in producer prices was two-tenths of a percent in January, after a revised increase of three-tenths in December.
 The report produced a seesaw reaction in financial markets. Initially, the bond market rose as traders jumped to the conclusion that the continued signs of low inflation improved the prospects that the Federal Reserve might not tighten credit further in coming months.
 But with more time to look at the Labor Department report, experts found the 1 percent surges in prices of both intermediate and crude goods to be more sobering. Bond prices skidded into negative territory, pushing rates higher. [Page 43.]
 In recent months, many companies have managed through a variety of means to absorb sharply higher costs for items ranging from cardboard cartons to aluminum without substantially increasing the prices of their own products. That pattern continued in January, but some economists expressed concern that the price pressures at earlier stages of production might not stay bottled up indefinitely.
 "There is a clear conflict of forces in the producer price data," said John E. Silvia, an economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. He noted that intermediate-goods prices have spurted 5.2 percent in the last 12 months, more than triple the 1.6 percent rise shown by finished goods.
 Such a situation cannot be sustained indefinitely, he contended, predicting some combination of lower profits and higher prices. Lower profits would be bad for stocks; higher prices would help drive down bond prices.
 Some companies are already suffering from a squeeze between the higher costs they pay for raw materials and intermediate goods and the competitive pressure from inflation-sensitive consumers who want prices kept down.
 Take Custom-Bilt Metals, a small California-based distributor of building products, with annual revenues of $25 million. It has been raising prices to the point where "our customers look at us like we're crooks," said Drew Popson, vice president of the company. Nonetheless, profit margins are "getting hammered," he said.
 He said his company was hit with a 10 percent increase in the cost of packaging and paper on Feb. 1 and two increases for aluminum this month that total 21 cents a pound. "There are price increases everywhere," Mr. Popson said. He said that Custom-Bilt had raised prices at least 5 percent each month since September but was approaching the limits of that strategy, so it had begun to urge customers to substitute, say, steel gutters and downspouts for aluminum ones.
 At the White House, the President's chief economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, said the finished-goods index showed "very good performance." She said intermediate goods showed "some signs of price pressures" dating from mid-1994 and dismissed crude prices as a category that moved too erratically to cause concern.
 Still, some of the January increases were stunning. Among intermediate goods, nondurable factory materials jumped 2 percent, after a 1.1 December advance. Paperboard was up 4.9 percent and plastic resins, organic chemicals, synthetic fibers and phosphates all accelerated.
 Durable factory items jumped 1.8 percent, with aluminum mill shapes soaring 9.6 percent. Semifinished steel mill products and cold-rolled steel sheets and strip were also up more than they had been in December. Paper boxes and containers jumped 2.4 percent, triple the December increase.
 Plywood, however, perhaps reflecting sluggishness in housing, fell 3.1 percent, and copper and brass mill shapes rose at a slackened pace.
 Crude goods other than food and energy soared 3 percent after advances of 2.3 percent and 3.1 percent in the two preceding months. Iron and steel scrap rose 4.8 percent and price increases quickened for wastepaper (up 17.4 percent), raw cotton, pulpwood logs, and construction sand and gravel. Copper base scrap rose at a slower pace, 1.4 percent, compared with 6.2 percent in December.
 The heaviest of the price increases could be over, some analysts noted. "Spot prices for base metals have faltered in recent weeks, suggesting that the commodity price surge may be ending," Merrill Lynch told clients today.
 But interest rates may well have further to rise, said Kenneth Safian, proprietor of Safian Investment Research in White Plains. Using the intermediate-goods index as the inflation gauge, the real interest rate on long-term Treasury bonds -- the difference between the stated interest rate and the rate of inflation -- is now less than 2.4 percent, the lowest since February 1981. This is only half the real rate calculated using the Consumer Price Index, which is a lagging indicator.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Incentives Growing For Buyers Of Homes

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
WITH interest rates rising and home sales slipping, bankers and builders are trying to entice home buyers with such goodies as small cash payments, warranties, locked-in interest rates and discount financing.
 The inducements come on top of a substantial easing in credit terms early last year. To assist low-income home buyers, many lenders started permitting borrowers to have higher levels of debt, to have less than two months of cash after closing and to put just 3 percent down when the Federal National Mortgage Association agreed to begin buying such loans. 
 Market forces are driving the latest changes. Sales of new homes fell in November and December, the latest months for which data are available, and demand for mortgages has fallen off as much as 50 percent in the last 12 months.
"Lenders are out there beating the bushes, and you've got some out there who are starving," said Keith Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates, a mortgage research firm in Butler, N.J.
 Fleet Mortgage Group, which has 85 offices in 35 states, acknowledged that it wanted to bolster business. "Looking at the market conditions, we need to be a little more aggressive," said Karen Spagna, regional sales manager for Fleet Mortgage, which is based in Columbia, S.C.
 The big mortgage company is offering existing customers $250 off closing costs if they refinance a mortgage or take out a new home loan. It is also allowing pre-approved home buyers to lock in an interest rate 30 days before a home buyer's contract is signed. "Prior to this, you couldn't enter into a rate lock until a purchase contract was signed," Ms. Spagna said.
 In yet another twist, Fleet is providing a free three-month warranty on heating and central air-conditioning and refrigerators. "As people are moving into a new home, it is often a time when they are strapped for cash and quite concerned about taking on initial obligations," said Charles Begley, a senior vice president with Fleet Mortgage.
 Builders' inducements can be even more generous. This winter, Eddy & Lewin Homes in Amherst, N.Y., offered $3,000 discounts on homes priced at $105,000 to $132,000.
 "It was effective -- I sold them all," said Thomas E. Lewin, vice president of Eddy & Lewin. "If the economy is doing great, you don't need to give incentives."
 Incentives are most common in winter when sales are slowest. Toll Brothers Inc., a major builder in the Northeast based in Huntingdon Valley, Pa., is offering financing at below-market rates on some homes until May. For example, a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is available at 8.25 percent for borrowers willing to pay an origination fee of three points. A point is equal to 1 percent of the total loan amount. The rate is substantially below the average fixed-rate 30-year mortgage, which was 9.15 percent on Feb. 7, according to HSH Associates.
 Buyers should not expect too much in rate discounts, though. "You can only cut rates so far," Mr. Gumbinger said.
 According to HSH, the average rate on a fixed mortgage is more than two percentage points higher than a year ago. The average rate for a one-year adjustable mortgage, at 6.76 percent, has risen more than 2.5 percentage points. "The lowest you are going to find today is probably about 5.25 percent, and that's with three points," Mr. Gumbinger said.
 Some borrowers, particularly those with good credit, might be able to negotiate with a lender for a better deal. Mr. Gumbinger recommended asking for a quarter percentage point off the origination fee, not a lower interest rate.
 "That's generally where their commission comes from, and you probably won't get more than a quarter point," he said.
 At the very least, home buyers should be able to find good service -- something often lacking during the refinancing boom of recent years.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Bill to Curb Antitrust Exemption On Way

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If any optimists remain, if anyone believes a negotiated settlement with the owners will propel striking baseball players back to work, developments in Washington and New York yesterday served as a sharp reminder that the best hope still lies with Congress or the National Labor Relations Board.
 Although Congress is not prepared to pass President Clinton's binding arbitration bill, it will get a chance to endorse a bipartisan bill that, if adopted, would prompt the players to end their strike, which today completes its sixth month. 
 Senators Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, announced yesterday that they would introduce a bill next Tuesday that would repeal baseball's exemption from antitrust laws as it affects labor relations.
 In a letter released by Hatch's office, Donald Fehr, head of the players' union, wrote to the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, "If the bill becomes law, I will recommend to the members of the Major League Baseball Players Association that we end the strike."
 Repeal of part of the exemption could lead to the players' return because it would enable them to challenge in court any new work rules the owners might unilaterally implement.
 The labor board has leaped back into the dispute because the clubs, which a week ago agreed to restore baseball's old work rules, have ignited a new phase of their increasingly incendiary relationship with the players.
 With the clubs already having delegated exclusive authority to the Player Relations Committee to negotiate individual player contracts, their labor lawyers have informed the Players Association in the last two days that they will not conduct salary arbitration, will not recognize the free-agent collusion provision and will not negotiate individual contracts with players or their agents but only with the union.
 The players could also return to work if labor board developments lead to a Federal court injunction that would prevent the clubs from changing the work rules that were in effect until Dec. 23, when the owners declared a negotiating impasse.
 However, in either case, Congress or labor board, if the players ended their strike, the owners very likely would lock them out. The owners have vowed not to play the 1995 season under the old economic system.
 Unlike the binding arbitration bill, the Hatch-Moynihan bill would not impose a settlement or a means to a settlement on the two sides.
 "Rather," the senators said in a letter to their colleagues, "it would simply remove a serious impediment to settlement -- an impediment that is the product of an aberration in our antitrust laws."
 The owners have long insisted that removal of the exemption or any part of it would not lead to an agreement. But the players, for just as long if not longer, have argued that their inability to sue in court over a unilaterally implemented system has given the owners an unfair edge in negotiations.
 Hatch and Moynihan said the aberration in the laws "has handed the owners a huge club that gives them unique leverage in bargaining and discourages them from accepting reasonable terms."
 Moynihan introduced a bill on the first day of the 104th Congress that would repeal the entire exemption. The new bill would not affect franchise relocation, the minor league reserve clause or the amateur draft. Moynihan said he looked forward to "an end to this painful strike as soon as possible."
 No end, however, is in sight in the antagonistic acts between the owners and players.
 When Fred Feinstein, the N.L.R.B. general counsel, informed Chuck O'Connor, management's chief labor lawyer, on Feb. 3 that he was inclined to issue a complaint against the owners based on the union's unfair labor practice charge, the clubs agreed to revoke the salary cap system they implemented Dec. 23 after declaring the impasse.
 They also agreed to restore "the status quo that existed prior to implementation." Union officials believed that status quo included all of the elements of the expired collective bargaining agreement and filed a new unfair labor practice charge with the board last Tuesday after the P.R.C., the clubs' labor arm, said it would handle all individual contract negotiations.
 But in telephone calls and letters, the P.R.C. further advised the union that it had added other new wrinkles, eliminating salary arbitration and the collusion provision, which bars clubs from acting in concert with other clubs in the pursuit of free agents.
 In a letter yesterday, O'Connor also told Fehr, "The P.R.C. will not negotiate with individual players." The P.R.C., he wrote, will negotiate with the union.
 "They're taking the position that their promise to restore the status quo applies only to mandatory subjects for bargaining," Doyle Pryor, a union lawyer, said. "Their position is that salary arbitration and individual negotiations are not mandatory subjects. We believe they're wrong on the law. Whether they're wrong or not, it's inconsistent with the promise they made to the N.L.R.B."
 The board has begun its investigation of the union's latest charge. O'Connor deferred comment to an aide, Rob Manfred, but Manfred did not return a call.
 Earlier in the week, Feinstein, the N.L.R.B. general counsel, issued a statement in which he said that in his discussions with O'Connor, "I made clear that the P.R.C. would act at its peril in making any changes in terms of employment other than restoration of the pre-Dec. 22 status quo."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 13; Column 4; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1415 words

HEADLINE: Thieves in the Idea Marketplace

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
"I can't deal in my mind with ROM's," Beverly Sills confessed. "My children are better at computers than I am."
But Miss Sills, the chairman of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, retired soprano and former New York City Opera director, said she had caught on fast when she walked the streets of China and Japan and saw "thousands, literally thousands, of my CD's with covers I had never seen before." 
 She was being ripped off. And so, perhaps, was her reputation. Many of the illegally produced compact disks mixed selections she had never recorded together, including duets with singers she hadn't sung with.
At a time when the computer-fostered piracy of copyrighted music, films, computer software and other intellectual property has set off a trade war between China and the United States, Ms. Sills's concerns are shared by many artists, policy makers, lawyers and technology experts.
With the computer serving as the world's biggest copier -- swiftly replicating not only text but also paintings, video and music for manipulation as "new" works -- how, they ask, can the original creators and owners be protected and compensated?
"What we have is a process that's created, in our words, a borderless, unpoliced public access to information, anytime, anywhere," Ivan G. Seidenberg, the president and chief operating officer of Nynex, said at a recent conference. "And so basically there are almost no rules associated with what one can do."
At the same time, computer technology is opening up extraordinary new channels for dispersing culture: museum exhibits viewable on home and classroom terminals, along with forums with arts experts, CD-ROM compact disk players with "read-only-memory" for interactive teaching and entertainment, and concerts and other events transmitted live over an interactive global video-telephone system.
But according to leading figures in the arts and humanities, technology is fast outracing the law, and the unauthorized copying, manipulation and sale of creative property, at home and abroad, are disrupting licensing structures that date to the founding of the American Republic.
More than 100 of these leaders, including Ms. Sills, gathered at the Museum of Television and Radio in December for a conference on the impact of new technologies on intellectual property rights and the arts. In subsequent interviews, some of them expanded on the issues.
"Everybody is just terrified over what ownership is," said Red Burns, the director of the Alternate Media Center at New York University and a pioneer in interactive television. Institutions, she said in an interview, "live in mortal fear of being sued."
Similar themes were sounded at the conference. "So long as original works were packaged in books and films and records and paintings, things we could actually store and handle, the notion of owning brain work seemed to hold," said Ernest L. Boyer, the president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and the commissioner of education under President Jimmy Carter.
"But," he said, "when it became possible to send digital signals effortlessly and instantaneously from one hard-disk drive to another, information began to slip past the traditional gate keepers of the culture."
"I have no idea where all of this, legally, will lead," Dr. Boyer said, "except perhaps to what one lawyer friend of mine approvingly described as 'vistas of endless litigation.' "
Yet litigation is a costly and cumbersome way to resolve issues, many people in the arts agree. And events are moving too fast for the law.
The quandaries affect not only writers, artists, composers and other "content providers" whose creations lie open to cyberthieves. They also concern actors, dancers, musicians, teachers and other interpreters of intellectual property; presenters like producers, museums, publishers and television; providers of technology like telephone companies and computer hardware and software manufacturers; foundations and other sources of financial support, and finally the consumers and audience, the public.
"We're attempting to get the parties to understand they need each other," said Martin E. Segal, a former chairman of Lincoln Center and the chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts, who convened the conference along with Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman of The New York Times Company.
But the problems often defy consensus, particularly where creators of art are concerned. "I don't see this as anything but a disaster for creative people," said Garrison Keillor, the author and radio humorist. "I think there's a collision coming, and I'm pretty confident that the authors are not the guys at the wheel. I think the author is the deer in the headlights."
Anti-theft devices don't necessarily work, said Stephen Sondheim, the composer and lyricist, citing the routine piracy of cable television signals and the circumvention of anti-copy codes on videocassettes. "I know people who have machines that can uncopy-protect it," he said. "They rent it from their store, they copy it."
But many see promise as well as peril ahead. Maxwell L. Anderson, the director of the Michael C. Carlos Museum at Emory University in Atlanta and a guru of the new technologies, cited his museum's growing digital outreach. Visitors to the Carlos can electronically browse the exhibits at computer kiosks or buy CD-ROM's of the shows to play at home. On the Internet, they can visit the museum from home 24 hours a day and engage in periodic live forums with the staff.
The Whitney Museum of American Art and the National Museum of American Art of the Smithsonian Institution have also launched themselves into cyberspace. "There is something about the anonymity and informality of the electronic technologies that encourages really free and occasionally irreverent expressions of opinion," said Elizabeth Broun, the national museum's director.
So long as pictures are reproduced with a limited palette of only 256 colors, there is little likelihood of piracy, Ms. Broun noted. But to guard further against infringements, she said, the museum will restrict its offerings for now to items to which it holds title.
"Like lots of other museums," Ms. Broun said, "we've looked at the veritable minefield of legal issues surrounding copyright and we have concluded that at least for now, while cyberspace is a chaotic wild west frontier full of highway bandits and subject to only the roughest kind of vigilante justice, we will just focus on our rich public domain collections."
Joel de Rosnay, director of development and international relations of the Cite des Sciences et de l'Industrie in Paris, said he foresaw a day when everyone would walk around with computers and small re-inscriptable CD's. "Then everybody will be transformed into a potential thief," he said. But, he added, "I would like to look at those people as potential co-creators."
He said original material could be locked by codes until the user sent payment by E-mail. Billing users of telecommunications is already a routine part of telephone service.
The digital world, in fact, does allow artists and their public to communicate uniquely, one on one. Thus, said Brian Kahin, the general counsel of the Interactive Multimedia Association, "contract is taking precedence over copyright as a means for managing the flow of information on this environment."
In one innovative effort to resolve intellectual property rights, the Getty Art History Information Program of the J. Paul Getty Trust teamed up late last year with Muse Educational Media, a nonprofit museum group, to distribute art images and information from six museums to seven universities.
Under the collaboration, called the Museum Educational Site Licensing Project, the museums will put digital images of some 3,000 of their artworks on the campus computer networks of the universities, including Columbia and Cornell, without charge through mid-1997.
"The economic, the legal, the technical only go so far," said Alan J. Friedman, the director of the New York Hall of Science. "All of these solutions, to some extent, will require a social contract, a measure of trust, a measure of faith in the system working. We are all taking a risk. On the other hand, we don't have any choice."
Jacob Druckman, a composer and Pulitzer Prize winner, put it another way. "Cars get stolen," he said. "We don't give up cars just because of car thefts."

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ADMITTING THE HOLOCAUST: Collected Essays, by Lawrence L. Langer. (Oxford University, $23.) Mr. Langer, a retired professor of English, illuminates the literature of the Holocaust -- the chronicles of ghetto and camp, the fiction and poetry wrought out of the horror, the representations in film and on television. Mr. Langer is also the editor of ART FROM THE ASHES: A Holocaust Anthology (Oxford University, $30), a remarkable collection of personal accounts, both by well-known survivors and by victims otherwise obscure, and of fiction, poetry and art related to the cataclysm.
 
ALL THE DAYS AND NIGHTS: The Collected Stories of William Maxwell. (Knopf, $25.) Stories, balanced, gentle and humane, concerned above all with reconciliation, from six decades of work by a master writer and editor who is now 86.
 
THE CUNNING MAN, by Robertson Davies. (Viking, $23.95.) The hero of this wise and entertaining novel, a chronicle of personal and social change in Toronto, is a doctor whose superb diagnostic skills rest on shamanism and Platonism as well as scientific medicine.
 
DEMOCRACY ON TRIAL, by Jean Bethke Elshtain. (Basic Books, $20.) A thoughtful professor of ethics argues that the weakness of democratic institutions in America reflects the replacement of rights conceived as immunities from government interference by rights conceived as individual entitlements.
 
FELICIA'S JOURNEY, by William Trevor. (Viking, $21.95.) Mr. Trevor's latest novel concerns an unmarried, pregnant, vulnerable Irish girl, wandering England's industrial Midlands until she encounters a predatory Englishman whose monstrosity remains long concealed.
 
GIVING AWAY SIMONE: A Memoir, by Jan L. Waldron. (Times Books/Random House, $22.) An absorbing personal history of the author and her family, women who for five generations failed or declined to keep their children.
 
GOOD COP, BAD COP: Detective Joe Trimboli's Heroic Pursuit of NYPD Officer Michael Dowd, by Mike McAlary. (Pocket Books, $23.) Mr. McAlary, a New York newspaper columnist who followed the case closely, reports on a police corruption investigation that appears to have been frustrated by departmental solidarity.
 
HOW LATE IT WAS, HOW LATE, by James Kelman. (Norton, $21.) A novel about a Glasgow ne'er-do-well that charms, persuades and illuminates, though it is written not only in salty talk but in the Glaswegian language.
 
OUT OF EGYPT: A Memoir, by Andre Aciman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) A splendid rendition of life over 50 years or so in the prosperous business class in Alexandria, ending with the expulsion of the author's Jewish family.
 
THE PAPERBOY, by Pete Dexter. (Random House, $23.) An eerie and beautiful novel whose emotionally alienated title character, a reporter in quest of facts only, is outmaneuvered by violent half-wits who know what they want.

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: The Last Refuge of Everybody

BYLINE: By David Oshinsky; David Oshinsky, a professor of 20th-century history at Rutgers University, is the author of "A Conspiracy So Immense: The World of Joe McCarthy" and a forthcoming book on race and punishment in the South.

 BODY:

THE POPULIST PERSUASION
An American History.
By Michael Kazin.
Illustrated. 381 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $24. 
IN the 1990's, it is hard to find a political candidate, a media star or an advertiser who does not claim to be a populist. Bill Clinton, Ross Perot, Jesse Jackson, Pat Robertson, Rush Limbaugh, Bruce Springsteen, Madonna -- all portray themselves as the voice, the offspring or the champion of ordinary people. How bad have things become? Hewlett-Packard, Michael Kazin tells us, recently advertised a Populist printer, "perfect . . . for the masses"; "erstwhile neo-Nazi David Duke . . . helped start a tiny Populist Party in 1988," and Banana Republic has introduced a line of men's cotton "POPULIST pants . . . for the individual in everyman."
There was a time, writes Mr. Kazin in this perceptive and passionately liberal book, when the language of populism had real meaning to the people who used it. Throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries, he says, populism implied a noble assemblage of common folk, employing the power of mass democracy to confront the forces of privilege and greed. Farmers, factory workers, progressives and prohibitionists all raised the populist banner to battle "predatory interests." His own "People's Party" was "the protest of the plundered against the plunderers," declared Tom Watson, a turn-of-the-century populist leader, "of the victim against the robbers."
As his title, "The Populist Persuasion," indicates, Mr. Kazin, a professor of history at American University, is more interested in the rhetoric of populist movements than the movements themselves. Beginning with the antislavery crusade of the 1840's, he skillfully surveys more than a century of mass protests, using imagery and symbolism as his guides. For most of its history, he notes, populism was associated with the left. Its language praised the toiling masses and linked political virtue with manual pursuits. But in time, this vision blurred, a relic of simpler days.
Following World War II, populism changed its political course, moving sharply to the right. The harsh cold-war climate and the return of prosperity served to discredit left-wing movements and ideas. In this new age of mass advertising and material abundance, most workers came to view themselves as consumers and taxpayers, not as members of an exploited class, and seemed less concerned by the power of big business, which provided them with good jobs, than by the growth of big government. For the first time, Mr. Kazin notes, the vocabulary of populism, of grass-roots protest, became a vehicle "to thwart and reverse social and cultural change rather than to promote it."
Mr. Kazin is well aware of populism's darker side. Its rhetoric had always stressed the fight between good and evil, between a virtuous majority and an unworthy elite. Populist spokesmen tended to portray their opponents as the enemies of ordinary people -- and thus of democracy itself. To illustrate these points, Mr. Kazin provides a superb portrait of William Jennings Bryan, who in the early 1900's preached majority rule on issues ranging from prohibition to evolution in the public schools; and another of Father Charles E. Coughlin, whose crusade in the 1930's for "social justice" degenerated into ugly attacks upon Jews.
In the 1950's, this intolerant strain was coopted by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, a self-proclaimed "country boy" who spoke of a giant internal conspiracy, directed by the liberal establishment, to advance the Communist cause. McCarthy didn't last long at the top. The rhetoric of populism is that of crisis, and his wild charges were muted by the election of President Dwight Eisenhower in 1952, the death of Stalin in 1953 and the subsequent armistice in Korea. Still, McCarthy showed that the anxieties and discontents of working people could be directed against the new liberal elite. This made him, as Mr. Kazin deftly details, a trailblazer of sorts -- a right-wing messiah of the masses.
In the 1960's, liberalism faced angry assaults from both ends of the political spectrum. On the left, radical college students tried -- and failed -- to convert the nation's growing antiwar sentiment into a political movement with "revolutionary democratic" goals. Mr. Kazin is sympathetic to these students, partly, it appears, because he was one of them. Yet his larger point, that their clumsy use of populist rhetoric offended an overwhelming majority of Americans, is surely correct. Wasn't a college education the ultimate privilege? What gave them the right to be angry at all? The black writer Julius Lester expressed an all-too-common sentiment when he described these students as "perhaps the first radicals anywhere who have sought to make a revolution in a country which they hate."
A backlash was inevitable. The chaotic social and political protests of the 1960's further weakened the nation's liberal leadership without producing a credible alternative. In short order, Mr. Kazin writes, a new populist spokesman arose to fill the void: George Corley Wallace, a working-class Southern Democrat with a segregationist history and striking national appeal.
Mr. Kazin sees Mr. Wallace as the godfather of the modern American right. (More traditional conservatives like Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona play a minor role in this account.) The problem, however, is that Mr. Wallace does not fit neatly into a conventional box. As the Governor of Alabama, Mr. Wallace supported many New Deal reforms. And as a Presidential candidate in 1968 and 1972, Mr. Kazin notes, he "explicitly favored a Government that aided the common folk -- as long as it stayed out of their schools, their unions, and their family lives."
What makes Mr. Wallace and his rhetoric so vital to Mr. Kazin's story is both his visceral attachment to these common folk and his open sympathy for their deepest passions and fears. Mr. Wallace, Mr. Kazin says, was the first major Presidential candidate of this century to identify himself as a working man. His 1968 campaign literature portrayed him as "a former truck driver married to a dime store clerk." He courted the kind of sneering jabs that appeared in a major intellectual journal about his "ill-cut suits" and his "graying drip-dry shirts," Mr. Kazin writes. His constituents were people much like himself, he boasted: average Americans who worked hard, loved their country, believed in God, paid their taxes and obeyed the law.
RACE was always central to the Wallace message, as Mr. Kazin makes clear. Yet Mr. Wallace rarely criticized blacks per se; his targets were the arrogant liberals who looked down on white working people and meddled endlessly in their lives. A typical Wallace speech skewered Federal judges who mandated forced busing and affirmative action programs; "pseudo-intellectuals" who promoted a permissive culture of crime, sex and drugs; and faceless bureaucrats, living comfortably in the suburbs, who spent billions of hard-earned tax dollars on failed programs for ungrateful minorities. "Some of his best applause lines," Mr. Kazin tells us, "came at the expense of the anonymous professor who 'knows how to run the Vietnam War but can't park his bicycle straight.' " When student hecklers appeared at his campaign rallies, Mr. Wallace brought roars of approval by shouting: "You young people seem to know a lot of four-letter words. But I have two . . . you don't know: S-O-A-P and W-O-R-K."
In the weeks before the 1968 Presidential election, public opinion polls showed Mr. Wallace at a hefty 21 percent, only 7 points behind Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, the Democratic nominee. But Mr. Wallace faded badly, the victim, it appeared, of his own excessive zeal. In October, he chose Gen. Curtis LeMay, the retired Air Force Chief of Staff and tireless advocate of atomic warfare, as his running mate on the American Independent ticket. "I don't believe the world would end if we exploded a nuclear weapon," LeMay told startled reporters. Indeed, he added, the testing of hydrogen bombs in the Pacific had been an environmental asset because the rats on Bikini atoll "are bigger, fatter and healthier than they ever were before."
Governor Wallace received about 10 million votes, or 13.6 percent, evenly split between North and South. His campaign revealed the first sightings of the Silent Majority, as well as the obvious limits of his own raw appeal. "In his clever, snarling way," writes Mr. Kazin, George Wallace "was too authentically populist, too candid and impolitic an outlet for the rage of his mostly male, mostly working-class followers to attract other voters who simply wanted the nation's troubles to end."
According to Mr. Kazin, the Wallace lesson was refined by Republicans like Presidents Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan, who learned to exploit the same mass resentments in a more respectable way. Mr. Reagan, in particular, presented a gentler vision of the Wallace message -- a vision of what must be protected rather than who should be beaten down. He emphasized the identical issues, from defense of family to an economic order based on merit and hard work, in a manner that attracted mainstream voters. The fact that Mr. Reagan's rhetoric was often at odds with his Administration's policies did not seem to matter. He had captured the language of populism, says Mr. Kazin, and that was enough.
Mr. Kazin finished his provocative book before the 1994 Congressional elections, which may explain his cautious optimism about the future of left-liberal politics in the United States. He believes that the "populist persuasion" -- the ideals and rhetoric of mass democracy -- can be refashioned by the left in a less strident, more meaningful way. But this will not be easy. Few Americans can recall a time when the common folk had shared interests, the welfare state was in favor, and the labor movement was strong. And fewer still, I suspect, would agree that "left" populism speaks to their present needs and humane instincts, while "right" populism caters to their resentments, hatreds and fears. The political landscape has changed dramatically in the past five decades, and casualties abound. For those in power today, the message should be clear: populism is a deep, enduring impulse with a very fickle past.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1649 words

HEADLINE: Paying The Price For Blowing The Whistle

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
FOR three years, Arnold Gundersen was awakened by harassing phone calls in the middle of the night. He became so concerned about his family's safety that he bought a large dog for protection. The problem? He was a whistle-blower, one of those who take on the dismally unpopular role of exposing what they find to be unsafe or unlawful practices in the workplace, especially the nuclear workplace.
"It feels like you're in a fort surrounded by Indians, and you send for help," Mr. Gundersen said. "You hear the hoofbeats of the cavalry in the distance as it finally comes toward you. But they start shooting at you." 
 Mr. Gundersen, who lives in Warren, told of the day in 1990 when he discovered radioactive material in an accounting safe at Nuclear Energy Services in Danbury, the consulting firm where he held a $120,000-a-year job as senior vice president. Three weeks after he notified the company president of what he believed to be radiation safety violations, Mr. Gundersen said, he was fired.
He is fighting a $1.5 million lawsuit filed against him by his former employer for continuing to discuss the alleged safety violations publicly after agreeing to an out-of-court settlement. Mr. Gundersen said he believes he was blacklisted, citing an April 22, 1991, letter concerning him that the company sent to 78 people. He also says he was harassed and fired for doing what he thought was right.
Mr. Gundersen's case, according to a number of whistle-blowers and others interviewed, is not uncommon, especially in the nuclear industry. Even though nuclear workers are encouraged to report potential safety hazards, those who decide to do so say that they risk demotion and dismissal. Instead of correcting the problems, whistle-blowers and their supporters say, industry management and government forces attack them as the cause of the problem.
Driven out of their jobs and shunned by neighbors and co-workers, whistle-blowers turn to each other for support. Several in Connecticut have formed an informal network with those in other states.
"There's no support," Mr. Gundersen said. "It's just us, talking on the phone late at night. Just our ragtag group." Mr. Gundersen, who holds a master's degree in nuclear engineering, said blacklisting in the industry made it impossible for him to find another job in his field. He worked as a dump truck driver before taking a $20,000-a-year job as a teacher at the Forman School in Litchfield. He and his wife, Margaret, have exhausted their savings, and their house is in foreclosure. The Gundersens and their two children are looking for a place to live.
Michael L. Cioffi, vice president and assistant general counsel of American Premier Underwriters Inc., the former owner of Nuclear Energy Services, said Mr. Gundersen was laid off because of a reduction in staff. The company was sold in 1993.
Although whistle-blowers are protected under Federal and state laws, a number said the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which monitors the nuclear industry, fails to keep whistle-blowers' names confidential. Their claims are supported by results of an investigation begun in 1992 by the commission's Office of the Inspector General, which found the commission fails to protect whistle-blowers from retaliation and fails to resolve their complaints quickly.
Sixteen whistle-blowers interviewed during the investigation described experiences ranging from physical threats and attacks to psychological intimidation on and off the job, according to a report on the investigation published in 1993.
One whistle-blower told of a co-worker pointing to a charred mannequin used in firefighting exercises and saying the whistle-blower could end up in a similar state if his behavior did not change. The offender was disciplined, but the whistle-blower developed post traumatic stress disorder, a neurosis following an abnormally stressful experience, such as military combat or assault.
The report also detailed, although the investigation did not independently verify, other whistle-blowers' stories, including being forced off the road by an unfamiliar car while driving home from work, unidentified people shooting at a whistle-blower's home from a vehicle, poisoning of family pets and harassing phone calls late at night.
A total of 609 complaints of retaliation against whistle-blowers filed with the nuclear commission and the United States Department of Labor resulted in only 44 investigations and just 7 enforcement actions during four and a half years. A team established in 1993 to review the nuclear commission's whistle-blower protection program made 47 recommendations to improve the environment for workers who raise safety concerns. Some of those proposals have been carried out, while others have yet to be completed, Beth Hayden, deputy director of the commission's Office of Public Affairs, said.
After he lost his job, Mr. Gundersen said he had nightmares, his blood pressure went up and he suffered from impotence. He was so depressed that he came close to committing suicide, he said. "It was a question of whether I would drive my car into a tree or blow my brains out," he said. "I saw myself as a provider. I figured that if I couldn't feed my family, at least the insurance money would support them, so I decided to drive the car into a tree, because it would appear to be an accident."
But, he said, "Ultimately, I decided I would rather fight than run."
The authors of the book, "The Whistleblowers," Myron Peretz Glazer and Penina Migdal Glazer, surveyed 64 whistle-blowers and followed many from the early stages of their resistance through the final outcome.
The Glazers described the group generally as being made up of conservative people devoted to their work and their organizations who built their careers -- whether as professionals, managers or workers -- by conforming to bureaucratic life. Most had been successful until they were asked to violate their own standards of appropriate behavior in the workplace. Invariably, they believed they were defending the true mission of their organization by resisting unsafe or unlawful practices.
Donald Del Core Sr., a whistle-blower who lives in Uncasville, spends much of his time offering advice to others who say they have been punished for blowing the whistle. Mr. Del Core said he receives about 20 to 25 calls a year. "I advise them on the different agencies involved in their problem and where they may seek some relief. In all cases, I recommend that they contact a lawyer," he said. "And I provide confidentiality."
Mr. Del Core said he was working as an instrument and controls technician at the Millstone nuclear power plant in Waterford when he was fired in 1991 for whistle-blowing. He filed harassment, intimidation and discrimination complaints against Northeast Utilities, owner and operator of the plant, and took the company to court after his dismissal. Finally, Mr. Del Core said, his financial situation drove him to settle out of court.
"I wanted to fight. But I had a second mortgage and was collecting unemployment," he explained. "It was as if I was giving the store away. Everything I believed in and felt strongly about I had to throw out the window. It was either financial ruin or take a settlement agreement and try to put my life back together."
After investigating Mr. Del Core's charges against Northeast Utilities, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission found that, although some discrimination and intimidation may have occurred, Mr. Del Core was fired not for whistle-blowing but rather for disruptive behavior. The manager of nuclear information at Northeast Utilities, Anthony J. Castagno, also denied Mr. Del Core was fired for whistle-blowing, saying the reason for his dismissal was a breakdown in working relationships. "Sometimes it is in the best interest of everyone to settle," Mr. Castagno said, "rather than continuing to fight this in court or in the media."
Still fighting for vindication, Mr. Del Core wrote a letter last March to United States Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, who has acted as an advocate for whistle-blowers, asking that the commission's investigation be reopened. He said he still has not received a reply.
Shortsightedness and concerns about the cost of having to shut down a nuclear plant prevent government and the nuclear industry from listening to whistle-blowers, said James Riccio, a lawyer with Public Citizen, a consumer advocate organization in Washington. "The nuclear power industry is fighting for its life," Mr. Riccio said. Wall Street analysts predict that as many as 25 reactors will be shut down by the year 2000 because they cannot compete with gas-fired turbines, he added.
We the People, a nationwide whistle-blower organization based in Rowley, Mass., has become a strong link in the whistle-blowers' network. Formed by Stephen B. Comley in 1986, the group seeks to protect whistle-blowers' identities, research their concerns, provide legal defense and offer moral support. "The biggest problem is getting someone in Washington to listen," Mr. Comley said.
Mr. Comley became a whistle-blower in the mid-1980's when he questioned safety practices at the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire. When We the People began making safety allegations public, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission demanded in Federal court to know the source of those allegations. Mr. Comley refused to reveal his sources and was found in contempt of court, resulting in a fine of $1,000 a day and narrowly missing going to jail. The fine has grown to more than $400,000, Mr. Comley said, the Internal Revenue Service has attached his personal tax refunds and a Federal attorney has threatened to attach his property. Would he take such risks again to make nuclear plants safer? "I don't know how I couldn't do it again," Mr. Comley replied.
