HEADLINE: A Generation's Heritage: After the Boom, a Boomlet

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
Once again, it's the invasion of the stroller people.
Chappaqua, a quiet Westchester County suburb that a generation ago was a haven for young families, is seeing history repeat. The World Cup Gymnastics and Nursery School added nine new classrooms last summer and recently voters approved a bond issue to expand the primary schools. The kiddie pools at the swim clubs spawn 3-year-olds like tadpoles. And when the Ragamuffin Parade turned off Greely Avenue last Halloween, dozens of MacLaren strollers were parked in the eddy, holding next year's marchers. 
 "I remember one day standing on the checkout line at the supermarket and seeing a woman with a belly, and I realized I hadn't seen that for the longest time," Alice Ozaroff, who moved to Chappaqua in the 1960's, said. "Then there was another one. And all of a sudden it was like an ant colony."
Chappaqua is not alone. All over America, a new generation is making itself felt in nearly every aspect of social, economic and political life, even though its members are barely 3 feet tall.
Every year since 1989, according to the Census Bureau, there has been a bumper crop of more than four million births in the United States -- a magic number for demographers, because the last time the birth rate climbed above four million was in the baby boom.
The new surge -- which population experts call the baby boomlet, the millennium generation or the baby boom echo -- has the potential, as its members age, to shape American society as profoundly as their illustrious namesakes. If the baby boom is a pig passing through a python, the python has taken another gulp.
Demographers and pollsters see the boomlet's effects in everything from the sales of multimedia computers to the success of "The Lion King," last year's top-grossing movie, to policy issues like health care and welfare.
"We have seen in the last five years or so a real focus on family-related issues," said Bradford Fay, a vice president of Roper Starch Worldwide, a polling and market research company. "You see it in television programs. You see it in the 1992 family-values issue that came up. And you see it in the emphasis that we're placing on home life."
The boomlet startled the demographers at the Census Bureau, who predicted in the late 80's that births would not climb above four million annually. In 1989, however, there were 4.041 million births, and in 1990 the figure shot up to 4.158 million. Since then the figure has declined slowly but has remained above four million a year.
Several trends converged to produce the increase. Baby boomers, after declaring in their youth that they did not want children, changed their minds in dramatic numbers in their 30's and 40's. At the same time, a younger generation began having children in their 20's. And a wave of immigrants has brought newcomers who traditionally have more children than native-born Americans.
The boomlet generation is far more racially and ethnically diverse than its predecessors, which some demographers see as a harbinger of increased racial tolerance. But others fear a generation further polarized along lines of race and class.
"The really scary part for those kids is they are shaping up to be a generation of haves and have-nots," said Susan Mitchell, writer of "The Official Guide to the Generations" (New Strategist, 1995). "There are 6-year-olds in affluent places who are logging onto computers themselves, practically on the information highway already. But then there are 6-year-olds who have never seen a computer."
Education, many hope, will level the playing field, but as the babies of '89 and afterward enter kindergarten, schools almost everywhere are facing enrollment crunches. Districts that shut down buildings during the baby bust that followed the baby boom a generation ago are being forced to convert libraries to classrooms, add trailers and beg for new construction money at a time of falling government aid to education and a revolt by homeowners against higher property taxes.
Kindergarten enrollment rose 7.2 percent from 1988 to 1993, from 3.357 million to 3.597 million, according to the National Center for Education Statistics, a research arm of the Department of Education. Preschool enrollment over the same period was up 14 percent, from 2.621 million to 2.984 million.
At the private Horace Mann School in Manhattan, the admissions office began taking requests for application forms for entering 3-year-olds for the fall of 1995 the day after Labor Day 1994. The school stopped sending out the forms days later, after more than 300 requests for about 40 places.
While many fear that enrollment pressures will further erode the quality of public education, some demographers see a coming era of education improvements as baby-boom parents become preoccupied with their children's schooling.
A Roper poll last July found that 22 percent of the general population ranked education as one of their top three concerns. But among parents with children under 18 the number rose, to 30 percent.
As a consumer market, the echo generation is already a force to be reckoned with, as small children influence their parents' choices of big-ticket purchases. Boomers who grew up in the back seats of station wagons swore that they would not be caught dead driving their parents' cars; when they had children of their own, they discovered the minivan.
"What minivans did was make it acceptable for a boomer to buy a Dodge or Plymouth or Chrysler," said Christopher Cedergren, senior vice president of the Autopacific Group, a consultant in Santa Ana, Calif.
That the ugly duckling van is basically a station wagon that dare not speak its name has been a bitter pill for some boomers. "A couple of our friends who never foresaw themselves as having a minivan, which epitomizes suburbia in the 90's, didn't like the idea," said Steve Schifrin of Highland Park, Ill., who bought a 1989 Plymouth Voyager after the birth of his second child, deftly transferring the cellular phone from his BMW to the van.
Similarly, the personal computer industry is experiencing astonishing growth, in significant measure thanks to multimedia machines bought to run programs starring dinosaurs and Reader Rabbit. Sales of computers equipped with CD-ROM rose nearly 50 percent last year, to 5.9 million, according to the Link Resources Corporation, a research company in New York. "Right now the majority of stuff on CD-ROM is geared to children," said Helen Rosen, an analyst at Link.
Cheryl Russell of Ithaca, N.Y., bought a home computer with a CD-ROM drive last year -- a decision made largely with her two children, 6 and 2, in mind. Now her 2-year-old daughter removes her thumb from her mouth to use the mouse. Ms. Russell, a former editor of American Demographics magazine and a publisher of demographic reference books for business, predicted that a generation raised on interactive learning would grow up with ever-higher expectations of instant responses from business and government.
In entertainment, the burgeoning young audience has helped give Walt Disney Studios a string of animated hits since 1989, beginning with "The Little Mermaid" and extending to "The Lion King," which grossed $300 million at the box office last year.
Matt Mazer, executive vice president of Nest Productions, which last year released "The Swan Princess," said an animation boom was being driven by the knowledge that even if films did not fare well at the box office, profits could be made on home video sales. Indeed, Disney films represent one-fifth of the $5 billion market for home video sales.
"Parents create libraries of home video products the same way our parents used to buy things called books," Mr. Mazer said.
The 90's sometimes seem to be the child-safety decade, spawning laws about bicycle helmets, high-rise window guards and community notification of released sex offenders.
"The parents of the busters bought the line that you do your thing and I'll do mine," Ms. Russel said. "Many boomers might have believed it for a while. But then they said, 'Whoa, that's not going to work for my kids.' I think the boomers will insist on much more supervision of their kids."
Now that boomers are reveling in parenthood, national politics often seems to revolve around protecting the home front, from health care to crime to orphanages.
"In the last 10 years there isn't a single important political issue that has not been effectively rephrased as being a child issue," said Neil Howe, co-author with William Strauss of "Generations" (William Morrow & Company, 1991). He cited the national budget deficit, which is attacked as a burden to future generations, and environmentalism, which has been repackaged from its anti-establishment roots in the 70's into a matter of stewardship for the sake of children.
Bill McInturff, a prominent Republican pollster in Alexandria, Va., predicts that the great political showdown of the late 90's will pit children's advocates against defenders of Medicare and Social Security.
"A third of our budget is going to 14 percent of the population, while 1 of 6 kids is in poverty," Mr. McInturff, a boomer with young children of his own, said. "This is going to be a fight over who gets the money, our kids or our parents. In the next three to five years all policy will revolve around that battle."
As the boomlet children come of age, will they have as revolutionary an influence on American society as their parents? Probably not, say most demographers, who see the new generation continuing long-term trends toward individualism, mobility and technological mastery in American society.
Watts Wacker, a market analyst at Yankelovich Partners in Westport, Conn., whose business card reads "resident futurist," calls children under 12 the "Alexander the Great generation," after the Greek who conquered his known world by age 18.
"This generation has that much focus," Mr. Wacker said. "They know how to take care of themselves and be their own boss, because their parents have always worked. They have an unbelievable sense of being self-sufficient and confident. They're all Macaulay Culkins. They feel very comfortable about handling what life's throwing at them."

HEADLINE: The Grabbing of the Green;
Acquisitive Parks Dept. Is Wily Scavenger for Bits of Land

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
At a time of city budget cuts, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern is aggressively enlarging his emerald empire, even as he admits that his agency cannot adequately care for the parks it has.
From the salt marshes of Jamaica Bay and Staten Island to the vacant lots of Harlem and the Bronx, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation last year acquired 416.2 acres, a total roughly the size of half of Central Park and the most land acquired since 1983. 
 Mr. Stern has managed to enlarge the city green in large part by following a path from the past, namely that of Robert Moses, who combined guile and a keen knowledge of the city's bureaucracy to create the modern park system during the depths of the Depression.
Like Mr. Moses, today's park-land grabbers avoid spending new money by mining other city agencies for most of their parcels -- taking over vacant lots, parking lots and properties of tax evaders that fall into city hands.
More than three-quarters of the land acquired last year was bought with money used to settle legal claims against polluters. Most of the rest was already city land, converted from small parcels on vacant lots, city esplanades and piers.
But critics complain that the parks people are expanding beyond their means to properly maintain these lands, although Mr. Stern has won the favor of environmentalists and city budget planners.
"Why acquire what you can't maintain?" Mr. Stern asked.
"The answer is that land and parks are forever. People will enjoy these parks as long as we have a city."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani endorses the program. "If possible, we want to increase our park land and open spaces," Cristyne F. Lategano, his press secretary, said.
And the acquisitions draw raves from park advocates. "It's something we're thrilled about," said Marcia Reiss, policy director of the Parks Council, a research and advocacy group. "Park builders have to take the long view because land is so precious."
Indeed, some proponents of open spaces advocate an even brisker pace. Next week, the Trust for Public Land, a national conservation group, plans to release a report calling for the acquisition of 286 more acres of park land: 189 acres in private hands and 97 acres of publicly owned land.
Its recommended acquisitions range from sites on the Harlem and Hutchinson Rivers to Udalls Cove near Douglaston, Queens, to Staten Island's Mount Loretto shoreline to a site on West Broadway in SoHo.
But others argue that proper management of existing resources should be the prerequisite for any expansion. "I would be very leery of it," said Betsy Gotbaum, Parks Commissioner for Mayor David N. Dinkins, adding that until parks are properly maintained, acquisitions should be low on the list of priorities. "You tend to create a situation that could be potentially dangerous -- not only to the Parks Department but also to the children."
Dean Mead, senior research associate for the Citizens Budget Commission, a fiscal watchdog group, said his analyses show that the agency is already conducting a policy of triage, knowingly letting maintenance go in many parks. "Acquiring more park land is counterproductive because they can't care for what they've got now," he said.
Commissioner Stern answers that land generally goes up in value and is often forever lost to other uses anyway. He advocates "landbanking," until there is money to pay for development. "Some parks don't come to life until a couple generations after they're acquired," he said.
Three basic kinds of parks are being added to the system, according to Jane Cleaver, director of park land for the department. They are wilderness areas on the city's fringes, small parcels adjacent to existing playgrounds, and new, medium-sized parks in areas with no or few existing parks. Much of the land fell to the city when owners failed to pay property taxes.
Each parcel must be discussed thoroughly with concerned neighbors and go through a formal review process that ends with parks being placed on the official city map by the State Legislature. Before that, every parcel must be approved by the city's Land Use Committee, a multi-agency group.
But for a fiscally pressed city administration, the negligible price is eminently right. Wilderness land on the city's fringes has usually been bought with settlement funds from oil spills in Staten Island's Arthur Kill and monies won from cases involving illegal dumping in Jamaica Bay, among others lawsuits. The total exceeds $18 million, with more than half this amount already spent on acquisitions. Other settlements are being negotiated. The settlement agreements require these funds to be used for park acquisitions or other environmental purposes.
Other land already belongs to city agencies, such as the Department of General Services and the Economic Development Corporation. Only a small proportion has to be bought from private owners. And even in these transactions, Ms. Cleaver is almost always able to avoid using city money: she normally gets state grants from a special conservation fund.
Maintenance costs are low. The wilderness areas usually require only the building of a fence. No park or playground is acquired anymore unless local residents formally agree to maintain it, Mr. Stern said.
The economic downside is that land mapped as park land cannot be used for any other purpose unless a state law is passed to take back, or "alienate" its special status. And even then, legislative tradition requires that at least an equivalent amount of new park land be set aside.
The acquisition strategy harks back to the methods of Robert Moses, who was flatly told by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia that there was no money to buy parks. Mr. Moses responded by assigning a staff member to comb through the records of every publicly owned piece of land in New York City. By raiding the property of agencies from the Board of Education to the Transportation Department, Mr. Moses increased the number of city playgrounds from 119 to 179 in his first six months on the job.
Mr. Stern, who refers to Mr. Moses often in conversation and speeches, has two aides -- "tigers," he calls them -- leading the day-to-day charge to acquire more parks. One is Ms. Cleaver, who has been involved in acquiring parks for 26 years and says she makes it a practice to walk every square foot of a site.
She also follows squarely in the Moses tradition of raiding other agencies' real estate. She expects to have completed by Wednesday a two-and-a-half-month-long inventory of all vacant property under the jurisdiction of the Department of General Services to determine which parcels are next to existing playgrounds. The idea is to acquire these and fence them in. Then, when the playground is next remodeled, it can be enlarged.
It is important to strike swiftly. "For every piece of land, there is only a small window of opportunity," Ms. Cleaver said. "All the pieces have to line up."
Among her current projects are pushing through ball fields in Brooklyn's Bushwick section and Queens's Broad Channel and a community park on the Lower East Side, and adding some private lots to a windswept bird sanctuary at Brant Point Park in Far Rockaway, Queens.
"Our job is to look at land and see it not as it is, but what it will be 10 years from now," she said. "We're in the dream business."
The other aide is Mark Matsil, director of the department's Natural Resources Group. His contributions include persuading courts to direct awards won from polluters of public lands to his acquisition initiatives, as well as providing proof of an area's natural importance, to back up Ms. Cleaver's paper trails.
In area, Mr. Matsil's acquisitions are far bigger. Indeed, 84 percent of the property acquired last year was on Staten Island, where there has been an aggressive effort to add to the city's inventory of remote natural lands, usually wetlands with interesting bird populations. This effort has been greatly aided by a general awareness that Federal and state laws so limit use of wetlands that wildlife sanctuaries are often the only possible alternative.
These acquisitions often involve working cooperatively with other city agencies. At Four Sparrows Marsh in Brooklyn's Mill Basin section, Mr. Matsil persuaded the Economic Development Corporation to move a condominium development back from a fragile wetland and to build a barrier of trees and shrubs to protect it. The swampland and the barrier area were recently assigned to the Parks Department, and the development is going ahead.
Mr. Matsil said a cooperative attitude has been key to his agency's success in winning land assignments from other agencies. "You've got to select your battles so you're not perceived as land-hungry usurpers trying to create fiefdoms everywhere," he said.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Individuals' Accounts Spur Many to Make Donations

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Sandra Westin knows the dread and frustration of losing a job. She knows the ache of rejection and isolation. So when she read the story of Aida D., a jobless woman who has been helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Ms. Westin's response was heartfelt.
In a letter to the fund, she offered her typewriter to Ms. D., who has been writing cover letters by hand. The story, she said, mirrored her own struggles. 
 "I'm also sending a check to the Neediest Fund -- something I try to do annually, but was not motivated to do this year until I read your moving story and realized, but for a little cash and a lot of luck, it could have been me," wrote Ms. Westin, a Manhattan resident. "Perhaps my typewriter and contribution will bring her luck -- I truly hope so."
Thousands donate to the fund each year out of habit. But occasionally a contribution comes in response to a particular story. In such cases, the donors' reactions might be based on personal experiences.
Helga Lob sent $50 after reading the story of Joyce B., a Queens woman who was trying to reconstruct her life after two brain surgeries.
"My husband died of a brain tumor nine years ago, after five surgeries," wrote Mrs. Lob, of Fort Lee, N.J. "I know how difficult it is, and want to help her. Please apply my donation to her case and cause."
For Mary T. Brown of Merrick, L.I., it was the case of Denis Sivets, a 10-year-old boy from Tajikistan, a former Soviet Republic, who was seeking treatment for a rare disease in New York. Mrs. Brown, who sent $10, wrote that she cried after reading about the Sivets family's hardship.
"I, too, am the mother of a profoundly retarded son who does not speak," she wrote. "Sometimes life is very unkind but we must have faith, as I'm sure you do. You are a very special family. Just remember you are in my prayers."
The Neediest Cases Fund was started in 1912, after Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The Times, met a beggar on the street. The man had no money and no place to sleep, so Mr. Ochs gave him a few dollars and offered him a job. Soon after, Mr. Ochs came up with the idea for the fund. Helping a stranger had given him a sense of satisfaction, and he wondered if one man's feeling might be the basis for a city's goodwill.
The first campaign raised just $3,630.88 from 117 contributors. In the past 11 weeks, more than 11,000 donors have sent nearly $4 million to help the city's poor, sick, elderly and disabled. This year's campaign ends on Feb. 28.
A number of readers responded to the case of Max Epstein, an artist who has lived in poverty since he was struck by a car in 1986. Although he now receives social security benefits and food stamps, he cannot afford art supplies.
A group of artists in Lambertville, N.J., offered to establish an account for Mr. Epstein at a supply shop. And Hospitality Art, a Manhattan art dealership that owns some of his silk screens, offered to donate them to an auction in order to raise money for him.
Another story that kindled great response was that of Dorothea Y. and her autistic son, Jonathan. Mrs. Y. has suffered two brain aneurysms and recently lost her job, but was determined to maintain stability for her son.
"I was especially taken by this story because here is someone coping continually and in a short period, she is facing her worst fears," wrote Susan Berne of Manhattan, who sent $200. "She is a woman to be admired; a fighter and survivor not only for herself, but also for her son.'
Gloria Kogan of Manhattan promptly responded to the story of Erika B., a Holocaust survivor whose husband was murdered years ago in Queens. Mrs. B. suffers from depression, loneliness and various health problems.
"I am approximately the same age as Mrs. B. who has suffered from so many coincidental outbreaks of misfortune," wrote Mrs. Kogan, who gave $25. "Perhaps this will help in a small way to put her back on track. I wish her well."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Battle of the Briefcase

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When I was in Hong Kong recently I noticed a small item in the paper reporting that a prominent democracy campaigner from Shanghai, Dai Xeuzhong, had been sentenced to three years in prison for tax evasion. Now that's interesting, I thought. The Chinese have been telling the U.S. that they just can't track down all those pirate factories ripping off American compact disks, movies and software, but they managed to track down the tax returns of Mr. Dai, out of 1.2 billion Chinese. Funny people these Chinese leaders. They have no problem with the needles; it's the haystacks that elude them.
 Why? Because the pirate factories are owned and operated by provincial governments, ruling families or the army and are cash cows for all of them. They need to keep them going to underwrite lavish life styles, to finance government budgets or to employ some of the millions of Chinese who have left the countryside and are roaming the cities for work. That's why when the central authorities in Beijing, who have good copyright laws on the books, pull levers to enforce those laws, the levers come off in their hands. 
 That is also why this copyright dispute with China is about so much more than whether Barbra Streisand collects an extra $100,000 a year in royalties. It's about what could be one of the most important questions of U.S. foreign policy in the 21st century: What if China can't go straight? That is, what if the system there remains so trapped in the half-light between reform and corruption, between state control and regional autonomy, between truth and lies that China finds itself incapable of playing by the global rules?
 The Chinese are so used to lying to themselves that they think they can lie to the world and no one will call them on it. When the U.S got fed up last month, broke off the copyright talks with Beijing and slapped China with $1 billion in sanctions, the Chinese were shocked. They denounced Lee Sands, the top U.S. negotiator, and complained that he left Beijing "without even saying goodbye."
 Imagine that -- he didn't even say goodbye! President Clinton deserves credit for his bluntness. In today's one-superpower world, if the U.S. doesn't confront the Chinese on this issue, no one else will. The craven Europeans and Japanese are behind us all the way -- way, way behind us. So far behind us you can't see them because they are too busy trying to gobble up market share that U.S. companies might lose as a result of this confrontation.
 The trick for the U.S. is to find a way to put enough pressure on China to make it conform to international trade norms, without putting so much pressure on it at once that the U.S. and Beijing get into a cold war on a broad front. (It's one thing to fight a cold war with a hollow Soviet economy that produced television sets that blew up and tractors that were more valuable as scrap metal. It's another to fight a cold war with 1.2 billion people, whose economy grows at 10 percent a year.)
 The key to such a nuanced strategy is the U.S. business community. China's leaders understand that their power depends on their ability to keep expanding their economy. They will only go after the pirates when we make it clear that their economy won't attract investment if they don't. The only way to do that is to demonstrate that U.S. business is on the side of the Administration.
 In a real war, you count tanks and soldiers. In a trade war, you count C.E.O.'s. And what is interesting about this dispute over copyright laws is that the balance of briefcases now favors the U.S. That's because the U.S. business community has discovered that China doesn't want to just import U.S. goods. It wants to import U.S. technology, so it can make everything itself. And if China is ripping off Mickey Mouse emblems today, it will be ripping off auto designs tomorrow. In fact, it already is. The Big Three U.S. auto makers are backing Mr. Clinton -- even though Beijing has singled them out for retaliation -- because China has already ripped off Chrysler technology and produced a knock-off Jeep.
 The two sides have scheduled last-ditch negotiations for this week. You don't need to be Clausewitz to handicap this one. It's real simple: If Mr. Clinton can hold his business brigades together, the Chinese will cave. If he can't, the Chinese will walk -- and you can be sure they won't say goodbye.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Owners Chose Their Course

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When President Clinton held a news briefing after the most unusual bargaining session in baseball labor history, he twice mentioned the absence of a commissioner.
"There is no baseball commissioner," he said, explaining why he was taking the unusual step of asking Congress to pass a bill imposing binding arbitration. "We'd lost the World Series, millions upon millions of dollars in lost income is at stake, and a lot more as well." 
 Responding a moment later to a question asking him to compare his action with previous Presidential forays into labor disputes, he said, "This is far more in the nature of a unique set of circumstances where there isn't a commissioner and there should have been to resolve this."
The next day, standing in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, where the players' and owners' groups had gathered the previous evening, Clinton said, "If we had a baseball commissioner, maybe none of us would have been in here."
At his own news conference after he returned from the White House, Bud Selig, who is acting as commissioner but rejects the idea that he really wants the job, was asked about the President's remarks.
"I talked to the President about that tonight," the Milwaukee Brewers' owner said. "I would remind you that there have been seven work stoppages under commissioners before this. It's that same mythology that we keep crafting all the time -- if there was a commissioner."
The difference, of course, between those seven work stoppages and this one is that those stoppages stopped. This one, fueled by the absence of a commissioner or Energizer batteries, keeps going and going and going. This stoppage, already the longest in sports history, begins its seventh month today.
The next day Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, addressed the President's remarks.
"His reference to no commissioner," Fehr said, "just reminded me that we all knew this was coming more or less when, two and a half years ago, Fay Vincent was fired and the owners began to talk about going to war with the players and the necessity of removing a commissioner who could act in the best interests of baseball so they could have the fight we're now having. That sequence of events, given the timing of it and how accurately it has presaged this dispute, tells us a lot about what the mind-set of the owners has been."
If the owners' ouster of Fay Vincent presaged this never-ending dispute, Selig himself presaged the ouster of Vincent.
Following the seventh work stoppage under a commissioner, the owners' lockout in 1990, Selig wrote what he called an "analyzation" of the lockout, the negotiations and the settlement. Selig and Jerry Reinsdorf, the Chicago White Sox owner and silent force, still blame Vincent for undermining the owners' position and negotiating a deal when, Selig wrote, the players were a day or two away from caving.
"The commissioner's involvement, while well-intentioned, is a destructive mechanism," Selig concluded, adding, "There is no doubt in my mind that the commissioner and his entire office should never again participate in labor negotiations or even labor-related matters."
In the summer of 1992, Selig and Reinsdorf, acting on Selig's "analyzation," asked Vincent to relinquish his authority in labor-related matters. He refused, and three months later he was gone from all commissioner-related matters.
Selig and Reinsdorf have offered other reasons for the move to end Vincent's tenure prematurely, but Selig's own written words, which never before have surfaced, speak distinctly to their motives.
 
The Dysktra-Angelos Spectrum
 Before the owners get too excited about and place too much stock in Lenny Dykstra's questioning of the union's position in negotiations, they might want to remember that one of their own, Peter Angelos, has criticized management's position far longer and louder.
Angelos represents 1/28 of the owners, Dykstra 1/1100 of the players. Even if Dykstra's view prompted other insecure players to speak up, it is highly unlikely that the owners could expect a ground swell of defections, any more than Angelos's stance on replacement players has led other teams to refuse to field teams.
The difference is the owners will try to punish Angelos; union officials will only try to explain to Dykstra why they think he is wrong and how his public comments don't help the players get a deal.
 
Big Hit, Big Miss
 They played together in the Detroit Tigers' system, the four of them. None made it big (only one made it out of the minor leagues), but they succeeded in other ways, Jim Leyland and Gene Lamont as major league managers, Bob Gilhooley and George Kalafatis as major league player agents.
Kalafatis, a New York high school and college star, died a week ago, leaving behind his status as the strongest hitter, by all accounts, of the friendly four when they were in the minors. They first played together at Rocky Mount, N.C., in 1967, Leyland and Lamont as catchers, Gilhooley the shortstop and Kalafatis the first baseman.
"George managed to pick off all of my throws and save me from further embarrassment," Gilhooley related. "Lamont was the better catcher. Although he wasn't much of a hitter, George had the most power. I was the best hitter. Leyland was a scrappy guy, played to the maximum of his skills. I couldn't field, but I could hit. George had great power, but he struck out a lot. He should have got a chance at Tiger Stadium."
Lamont, the Chicago White Sox manager, who roomed with Kalafatis for five or six years in the minors, offered a similar scouting report: "hit home runs, struck out a lot."
Leyland recalled a game he played with Kalafatis at Montgomery, Ala.
"The first time up one night against Birmingham," the Pittsburgh manager recalled, "George hit a double, and the next four times up he hit home runs."
Why didn't Kalafatis make it to the majors?
"He couldn't hit," Leyland said. "He had good power, but he couldn't hit. Gilhooley was a pretty decent hitter but not a good fielder. I never got out of Double A and was a backup at that. That's what teed me off, not being in Double A but being a backup."
 
 
Critic's Corner
 The Trial (anyone who needs to ask which one shouldn't bother) has prompted an idea that could enhance the listening or viewing pleasure of fans of any persuasion -- replacement players (owners) or replacement games (players).
The Trial has created the largest group of professional second-guessers ever, lawyers appearing on every television and radio show commenting on the performance and the tactics of the prosecution and the defense.
Baseball always has a small army of out-of-work former managers and coaches. Each station or network that carries games could hire one or two, not only helping to reduce unemployment but also adding to the enjoyment of the game. These professional second-guessers could instantly assess the moves made by the managers in the dugouts and suggest ways that they could have had bigger innings or short-circuited big innings against them.
The only problem is these professional second-guessers would have to compete with the people who already fill those roles -- the broadcasters and commentators.

HEADLINE: Flat-Tax Proposal Rewards Go-Getters

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Robert Kuttner's "Instead Close Loopholes" (Op-Ed, Feb. 8) concludes that "the very idea of a flat tax is a reversal of the well-established principle of taxation based on ability to pay." That "principle" has been employed to justify marginal tax rates of up to 90 percent, although that confiscatory level has dropped to approximately 42 percent. But the notion that ability to pay should guide taxation is morally bankrupt. 
 The indolent pauper who has squandered the countless opportunities in the United States for training and employment owes to society a moral debt for contributing nothing to its strength; whereas the persevering high-income earner is entitled to moral credit for conduct that contributes to the pleasure of others and augments the nation's wealth.
 High incomes should be taxed no more heavily than lower incomes; they should receive lighter taxation to reward conduct that most advances the happiness of others.
 As a practical matter, taxing the impecunious will yield little if any revenue. It should thus be forgone not because of moral scruples but because the game is not worth the candle.
 Mr. Kuttner's contention that progressive taxation "is sensible economics" and "sound fiscal policy" wars with all experience and intuition. Reducing the tax rate would effect a corresponding rise in the incentive to work, boosting prosperity. Hong Kong is illustrative.
 That tiny but densely populated British colony, bereft of natural resources, has surpassed the mother country in per capita income in the last decade with a 15 percent flat-tax rate, a sharp contrast to Britain's progressive rate structure.
 House Majority Leader Dick Armey's flat-tax proposal is no survival-of-the-fittest law. Its generous exemptions would remove an additional 10 million individuals from Federal income tax rolls. It would also puncture bloated entitlement programs that redistribute wealth to unproductive members of society. Such hundreds of billions in subsidies to sloth are morally perverse and a dead weight on the economy.
 
BRUCE ELLIS FEIN
Chicago, Feb. 8, 1995
The writer was an intern for Representative Dick Armey.

HEADLINE: On the Subject Of Highway Tolls

 BODY:
Once again, it tolls, and the toll increases. As a longtime commuter and traveler in the N.J./N.Y. area and N.J./Washington corridor, I believe it is long past the time for a fresh look at the entire situation. Perhaps our new governors can be persuaded to apply some new thinking to the toll issue.
Is there not a way to devise a registration-based system that would eliminate both the need for and the colossal waste involved in the toll collection process? 
 New Jersey should consider the full economic costs of collection, not just the maintenance of toll booths and the labor costs of the collectors, but the tens of thousands of hours lost in lines associated therewith. Also, the gasoline consumed, the wear and tear on vehicles in this process, not to mention the mental wear and tear.
Surely one could tax vehicle registration in the tristate area to pay the lion's share of the bills for the currently tolled units of the highway system. Tristate vehicles would be taxed, stamped and freed of all toll lines at all presently tolled sites. If you own a vehicle, for any purpose, you benefit from the full system and should contribute to it, whether you use the bridges and tunnels daily, or only on occasion. If you are in business, your business benefits in the same way.
One could also provide special toll lanes for out-of-area vehicles so that passers-through could pay their fair share.
We should be spending less money fighting about toll increases or buying new computerized gadgets to collect fares, and more on providing better transportation services at every level.
SETH M. BODNER
Summit

HEADLINE: Vietnamese Open Office To Improve U.S. Ties

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
When Hanoi opened its first diplomatic office here last week, the chief of liaison was met with angry shouts from protesters. In the days that followed, however, the downtown suite of offices has filled up with flowers from American companies eager to do business with the former foe.
As Vietnam and the United States move gingerly toward full diplomatic ties, the strains of the past and the hopes for the future overlap awkwardly. 
 Le Van Bang, the chief of the new, six-person liaison office, describes his role as helping to tell America of how Vietnam has moved on since the Communists emerged victorious and unified the country nearly 20 years ago. As he shows a visitor around the rambling and largely empty downtown suite of offices, decorated with tapestries of pagodas and the orange and yellow Vietnamese flag, he stopped to read the cards from some of the floral tributes.
"All these flowers are from American companies," said Mr. Bang. "For instance, this one is from a company that clears mines from the ground."
As Hanoi's representative to the United Nations for the last three years, Mr. Bang said that 80 percent of his time was spent trying to smooth relations between the United States and Vietnam. During those years, he traveled around the United States, meeting with Vietnamese-Americans, American business people and veterans' groups to promote the image of a new Vietnam.
"I tell people about the new foreign policy to be friends with everyone," said Mr. Bang. "Many are surprised when I tell them we are now a free market economy, that we encourage private ownership."
It is also his job to help resolve the issue of Americans still missing in Vietnam.
State Department officials say lack of progress on the issue of American soldiers still listed as missing in action and other Americans unaccounted for remains the main stumbling block on the road to full diplomatic relations.
On Friday, a State Department official said that while the United States is heartened by Vietnam's increased cooperation, returning 61 sets of remains of Americans during the last year, "the remains of 2,100 servicemen are still missing, and further steps towards diplomatic normalization will not continue unless there is tangible progress."
Mr. Bang also tries to help Americans caught in Vietnam's red tape. One of the first phone calls he received in his new post was from a representative of the Vietnam Veterans of America, who was calling because he was having a problem securing visas for a delegation to visit Vietnam.
"I intervened, and the next day they got the visas," said Mr. Bang.
Mr. Bang is swift to describe the warm relations he enjoys with groups like the Vietnam Veterans of America. But Paul Skogland, the group's executive director, stopped short of calling the increased diplomatic relations a positive development. "Once something's a done deal," he said, "we try to make the best of it."
The opening of the Vietnamese liaison office on Wednesday coincided with the release of the State Department's annual report on human rights around the world. In the report, the State Department said that "Vietnamese citizens did not have the right to change their government, or to assemble, associate or speak freely, and the Government continued to arrest and imprison people arbitrarily."
Mr. Bang attributes the report's criticism to cultural and economic differences between the United States and Vietnam. "Here the press criticizes the President openly," he said. "Traditionally, in Vietnam, that is not acceptable."
As for arbitrary arrests, Mr. Bang said: "We still consider security a very high priority. If you are going to do something that causes disorder, we have to take care of that."
Mr. Bang and his staff plan to move into the old South Vietnamese Embassy by March, as soon as renovations are completed. However, Mr. Bang anticipates that the move will only mean a change to more spacious quarters, not an increase in diplomatic stature.

HEADLINE: Traffic Jams Around Princeton Rekindle a Highway Debate

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Drivers who live within a 30-mile radius of this university town keep a playbook on local roads that is often as complicated as the ones memorized by Super Bowl quarterbacks.
Reverses, buttonhooks, end-arounds and a lot of Hail Marys are called upon to get in and out of the area on roads so choked with traffic and construction that they seem to surrender only three yards and a cloud of dust at peak hours. 
 It's been a dozen years since New Jersey officially spurned a new north-south pathway for Interstate 95 through the middle of the state. Environmentalists and landowners feared it would bring congestion and developmental clutter to the farmlands and gently rolling estates of Mercer and Somerset counties.
But every day, fallout from that decision piles up at stoplights and intersections between Trenton and New Brunswick, making many people wish they could turn back time and build the high-speed roadway.
"It would've spared us a lot of problems we see today," said Mimi Summerskill, owner of La Follette winery and vineyards at Belle Mead, north of Princeton, where upscale French chateau style houses bloom on former farmlands and Route 206 is packed during weekday rush hours with commuters.
"What we have now in the area is development without the interstate highway," said Mayor Marvin Reed of Princeton. "It will be solved only when everything comes to a standstill and drivers look around for other routes."
But there is no going back.
The project died a formal death in 1983 when the 27-mile stretch of I-95 was taken off the drawing boards by Washington. Now any hope for relief would have to depend on money from the state at a time Trenton is in a penny-pinching mood.
Princeton, where Routes 206 and 27 converge, is under siege daily by motorists and truckers groping for a way through the region. A few miles to the east is Route 1, one of the most congested arteries in the state, a four-lane divided highway that seems endlessly under construction. Cars and trucks back up for miles at traffic signals and motorists exiting new shopping malls and office clusters feel the need to make kamikaze dives into oncoming vehicles.
It's not only stop-and-go traffic that has local officials worrying.
For Barbara Wolfe, who just ended a three-year stint as Mayor of East Amwell Township in southern Hunterdon County, it is the sight of a steady stream of tractor-trailer rigs barreling along Route 31 in the Hopewell Valley about 10 miles northwest of Princeton, a two-lane blacktop designed for small farm vehicles and local autos.
"It's dangerous for cars and school buses to share a small country road with 18-wheelers," said Ms. Wolfe, citing a state Department of Transportation survey that found that truck traffic on Route 31 more than doubled last year from 700 to more than 1,700 trucks a day.
The study said the increase was a direct result of the completion last year of the portion of I-287 in northern New Jersey that connected with the New York State Thruway and the Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson. By using Route 31, truckers found a toll-free link in western New Jersey between the I-95 and I-295 loop around Trenton to the south and -- via I-287 -- to New York State and New England, skirting congestion around New York City.
The maximum toll at present for trucks traveling one-way on the turnpike between the Delaware Memorial and George Washington bridges is $ 20.80, according to the Turnpike Authority.
The Route 31 survey was completed before the portion of I-295 called the Trenton Complex, which loops through the capital and south through Bordentown, was completed in December, another closing of a "missing link" that some fear will encourage even heavier use of Route 31 by truckers.
Department of Transportation officials, however, say the new road may relax rather than exacerbate the problem by giving truckers easier access to the turnpike.
"A lot of major construction has been accomplished at the Trenton Complex and along Route 1 in recent years," said Dennis Keck, assistant commissioner for planning at the Transportation Department.
"Is traffic free-flowing and uncongested?" he asked.
"No, of course not," he answered. "But has significant relief been provided? Absolutely!"
It's difficult for some commuters like Patrick Kreger, an auditor for the International Business Machines Corporation who lives in Lawrence Township, not to be skeptical.
"Yeah, if I leave home at 6 in the morning and return late in the evening, I'm O.K.," Mr. Kreger said. "But if you hit these roads at 7 to 9 A.M. and 4 to 7 P.M. you're going to sit in traffic, there's no beating it."
Local traffic problems were already evident when opposition to I-95 gathered strength in the 1970's. Industrial parks housing pharmaceutical and biotechnology corporations joined research firms associated with Princeton University along the Route 1 corridor.
New housing by 1980 had doubled the 1960 population of prestigious Princeton satellite communities like West Windsor Township, overburdening local roads and sending warning signals to landowners in more sparsely settled Hopewell and Montgomery townships that they were next in line for change.
The boom continued in the 1980's; West Windsor's population doubled again to 16,021 by 1990. But with I-95 slicing away to the south in a new direction, Hopewell Township gained only 697 residents in the decade.
The ensuing recession, however, put a new twist on attitudes.
"When the economy went sour people went looking for more ratables to help their property tax problems," said Dianne Brake, executive director of the three-county Middlesex Somerset Mercer Planning Council. Ratables are properties that have been developed and are appraised for tax purposes. Putting up new housing on undeveloped land without roads, schools and sewers ran counter to the orderly growth that encourages development where public infrastructure already exists, she explained.
Nonetheless, as the economy recovers developers are turning toward less settled areas like Hopewell and Montgomery townships, the strongholds of anti-I-95 sentiment, for construction that will feed more traffic into the congested roads of neighboring towns.
"The irony is that a place like Hopewell, which had many residents who killed I-95, is now putting in ratables along our town line that will impact our roads," said Gretel Gatterdam, a councilwoman in Lawrence Township, a community that had championed I-95. "All the ratables will be in Hopewell but the traffic will be on our streets."
Washington gave New Jersey $ 246 million in lieu of I-95 construction costs to finance a number of projects deemed necessary to help the area improve its road and build new ones. But the money has been spent and several key projects were never started, killed by local opposition.
Another new road, Route 92, planned as a bypass north of Princeton, was never built. Turnpike commissioners voted recently to proceed with designing the roadway, but residents have asked Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to block the work. An aide said she would decide what to do later this month. If the Turnpike Authority gets the go-ahead, the new highway would run between Exit 8A of the turnpike and Route 27.
For commuters who despair of seeing the day when local roads become manageable, there is always rail service running between Princeton and New York. The hitch is that obtaining a long-term parking permit at the Princeton Junction train station is like buying a season ticket for the Giants football games: the waiting list is at least two years long and some permits are passed down within families like precious precious heirlooms.
 
Other Road Choke Points
 Most motorists don't need experts to tell them the Long Island Expressway, Cross Bronx Expressway and numerous other highways, tunnels and bridges in the metropolitan area cannot handle the traffic loads placed on them. But traffic counselors for American Automobile Association clubs in the region and Port Authority planners offer insights on lesser-known major roads with chronic congestion problems that no amount of patchwork solutions will relieve for the rest of the century. Here is their dirty dozen.
 
Long Island
 
MEADOWBROOK PARKWAY : "Inadequate capacity at Northern State and Southern State interchanges."
 
SEAFORD OYSTER BAY EXPRESSWAY : "Poor interchange design at Long Island Expressway."
 
New York City
 
VAN WYCK EXPRESSWAY : "Inadequate capacity and grading ... airport traffic at Belt Parkway connection."
 
BELT PARKWAY : "Substandard design and capacity ... roadway deterioration ... flooding."
 
MAJOR DEEGAN EXPRESSWAY AT CROSS BRONX : "Ramps back onto Deegan."
 
SHERIDAN PARKWAY IN THE BRONX : "Connector to Cross Bronx heads west only; must use side streets to connect with eastbound lanes."
 
New Jersey
 
ROUTES 17 AND 23 : "Bottlenecks leading to newly opened sections of I-287."
 
ROUTE 10 IN MORRIS COUNTY : "Tremendous growth of mall and commuter traffic avoiding major routes ... reduced speed limit but still can't handle volume."
 
ROUTE 206 IN SUSSEX COUNTY : "Secondary road leading to I-80 ... not designed for heavy traffic."
 
ROUTES 1 AND 9, NEWARK AREA : "What's worse -- the trucks or the traffic lights?"
 
I-287, SOMERSET AND MIDDLESEX COUNTIES : "Forget it at rush hours ... try back roads."
 
ROUTE 18, NEW BRUNSWICK : "A major route with endless malls."
 The Princeton article also misstated the route of a proposed road, Route 92. It would run between Exit 8A of the turnpike and Route 1, not Route 27.

HEADLINE: FILM;
In the Wings: A Film With Few Clothes and No Regrets

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
HIGH OVER MALIBU, THE FULL MOON is so perfect it could have been installed by lighting technicians. Aloof, it casts a cool light on the seething movie scene below, a show-biz party on the patio of a preposterously vulgar beach-front mansion. The partygoers, who include a more than healthy sprinkling of leggy young women in very short, very tight spangly dresses, mill around a swimming pool. Off to one side, a Lucullan buffet table bends under the weight of 10-pound lobsters on beds of seaweed, innumerable super-shrimp, heads of broccoli and cauliflower, bunches of grapes, and mega-loaves of bread. Neon pink flamingos near a classical colonnade provide a subtle touch of class.
Paul Verhoeven, behind the camera for the first time since "Basic Instinct" in 1992, fusses over a small detail in the scene. It is a key moment in "Showgirls," a drama that ventures, untentatively, into the sex-saturated world of Las Vegas lap dancing, strip clubs and top-of-the-line topless revues. A smarmy Vegas singer, played by William Shockley, is supposed to breeze past two men in togas, Roman sandals and gilded laurel wreaths who will announce his entrance with a trumpet blast. "The left trumpet a little lower, yeah?" says Mr. Verhoeven. "Good. That looks silly enough." 
 As the scene progresses, Mr. Shockley moves toward Nomi (Elizabeth Berkley), a former stripper who has just been named the lead dancer at a Vegas hotel. "I love your songs," she tells him.
Mr. Shockley leers, leans close and whispers in her ear that he loves something about her, too. It's not her songs. The remark is flippant and breathtakingly crude. Behind the camera, the 56-year-old Mr. Verhoeven smiles delightedly. It's a good moment. It's got sex, aggression and spectacle, everything that "Showgirls" promises to deliver in copious quantities. Well, not a lot of sex, actually, all things considered.
"This is one of our decent scenes," says Mr. Verhoeven. "Of course, we have a rape inside on the second floor -- so it's never completely decent."
Never even close to decent. "Showgirls" stands a very good chance of earning an NC-17 rating, which means that the film will be off-limits to viewers under 17, and guarantees that many theaters will not show the film and many publications will not advertise it. Mr. Verhoeven's contract, moreover, does not require him to make the trims that would bring "Showgirls" back into R territory. For the first time since the ratings system was introduced in 1968, a Hollywood studio -- in this case, MGM -- is treading into adults-only terrain with its eyes wide open. If it succeeds, the film may rewrite the rules that govern Hollywood's treatment of sex on the screen. For several years, film studios have flirted madly with NC-17, only to back off at the last minute and make the cuts needed to earn an R. Just one NC-17 hit would turn attraction into love.
MGM is taking the gamble because it needs a hit, desperately. The faltering studio, which was acquired by the French bank Credit Lyonnais, its main creditor, in 1992, can point to only one box-office winner since "Thelma and Louise," last fall's surprise hit "Stargate." With "Showgirls" the potent combination of Mr. Verhoeven and the scriptwriter Joe Eszterhas -- whose last joint effort, "Basic Instinct," sold $ 352 million worth of tickets around the world -- was simply too attractive to pass up.
"WE'RE BETTING Paul will make an astonishing film," said John Calley, the president of MGM's United Artists division, which will release the film in the fall. "We made the deal knowing what we know about the film, and we will support the film that we get." Better than that, the studio is already exercising bragging rights in anticipation of a ratings board dust up. Mr. Calley said he has not seen any footage of the film.
"Showgirls" tells the story of Nomi, a tough young woman who hitchhikes to Las Vegas and finds work as a lap dancer at a strip club, a job that requires her to sit on the laps of male customers, unclothed, and "dance" a simulation of the sex act. Nomi aspires to greater things, namely to replace Cristal (Gina Gershon) as the star of a topless revue. She pursues this goal ruthlessly, at great cost to herself and her friends.
The film, with a soundtrack by Dave Stewart that will include original songs by David Bowie, Thrill Kill Cult and the artist formerly known as Prince, has already been dubbed "Fleshdance" in tribute to an earlier movie that also had a script by Mr. Eszterhas. The new film has been described as "All About Eve" minus the clothes and the wit.
The same ratings board that sent Mr. Verhoeven back to the editing room for the violence in "Robocop" (1987) and "Total Recall" (1990), who imposed cut after cut on the sex scenes in "Basic Instinct," will no doubt have many suggestions to offer after seeing "Showgirls." The film includes three lavish production numbers, one of them an S&M fantasia, all of them featuring wall-to-wall nudity. Nomi treats the hotel's entertainment director (played by Kyle MacLachlan) to a lap dance that registers high on the Richter scale, and she has a sizzling encounter with her dance teacher. As he did in "Basic Instinct," Mr. Eszterhas has thrown in a titillating touch of bisexuality, adding extra interest to the relationship between Nomi and Cristal.
Cut the more humid moments, the production numbers, the hot and heavy groping, the lesbian nibbling, and you're still left with a film in which nearly all the female characters spend most of their waking hours with no clothes on.
"There is nothing to say that this movie will be an NC-17," said Frank Marshall, a co-producer of the movie, striking a hopeful note. "It doesn't contain a lot of violence, and it doesn't contain a great deal of sex. What it does contain is a great deal of naked bodies."
Mr. Eszterhas, who dropped by the set of "Showgirls" recently and saw some of the lap dance sequences, said, "It looks like an NC-17 to me."
Normally, directors are required by contract to deliver a film with an R (for "restricted") rating, which means that viewers under 17 must be accompanied by a parent or adult guardian. The NC-17 rating was created in 1990 as a nicer-sounding alternative to X, which had become identified in the public mind with pornographic films.
The rating was first applied to "Henry and June," about a menage a trois involving the writer Henry Miller, which included several fairly explicit sex scenes. The film, shown in only 307 theaters, wound up earning a modest $ 11 million, a figure that still makes it the most successful NC-17 so far. Other films rated NC-17 were "Romper Stomper" (sex and violence), "Bad Lieutenant" (ditto) and "Wide Sargasso Sea" (sex, including frontal male nudity). Two recent films, "You So Crazy" and "Clerks," earned their NC-17's by talking too much about sex -- though the rating on "Clerks" was reduced to an R on appeal.
The rating has serious economic consequences for film companies. Some theater chains will not show an NC-17, and most theaters in malls are forbidden by contract with mall owners to show such movies. With fewer viewing outlets, a film's chances of turning a profit are narrowed. Moreover, Blockbuster Video, Kmart and Walmart, which account for more than half of the video sales in the United States, will not handle NC-17 titles.
MR. VERHOEVEN, however, refused to make "Showgirls" without retaining complete creative control. And after three box-office smashes in a row, culminating in "Basic Instinct," he was in a position to get what he asked for.
"When I first read the script, I told Joe I wouldn't consider it unless we found a film company that would give the O.K.," he said during a late-night break in shooting. "I didn't want to go through the 'Basic Instinct' experience, going back to the M.P.A.A. 300 times. I would have to continually compromise every scene."
To make "Showgirls," and bring down the costs for the film, which has a budget of $ 35 million, Mr. Verhoeven agreed to defer 70 percent of his $ 6 million director's salary until the movie turns a profit. (Mr. Eszterhas, who will also be a producer on the film, has already been paid $ 3.2 million for writing the script.)
Mr. Marshall said the film can still succeed with an NC-17 rating but it will face an uphill climb. "Basic Instinct" took in $ 15 million in its first weekend. Assuming the same level of consumer demand, "Showgirls" with an NC-17 rating would probably take in only $ 8 million, because of the limited availability of theaters, Mr. Marshall estimated.
"In some ways, it's uncharted territory," said Gerry Rich, the executive vice president for worldwide marketing of MGM/United Artists, who will oversee the advertising campaign for the film. But he also said that the studios' fear of NC-17 may be outdated and that enough theater chains and advertising outlets are available to make a commercial release possible.
"If you go to the networks and the stations, the regulations are not set in stone," he said. "There are certain restrictions -- for example, commercials for an R film have to run after 9 o'clock, and those may be more stringent for NC-17. But there are a plethora of options, and we are not as reliant on the networks as 10 years ago. We wouldn't have gone into this if we felt it was impossible to release an NC-17 in a commercial manner."
Mr. Verhoeven, meanwhile, presses on, seemingly indifferent to the gathering storm. "I'm not a crusader," he said. "I'm too amoral to care. And it's not to shock. I just don't want to shock myself by cutting my film."
As Mr. Verhoeven tells it, he was instantly attracted to the project, which gives him free rein to indulge a highly developed taste for spectacle, color and excess.
"The artistic interest for me is extravagance as a style; otherwise it's just extravagance," he said. "I want to tell a story using this excessive visual style. And Las Vegas is excessive in every respect."
Ms. Gershon, who makes her entrance in the film emerging from an exploding volcano, said: "Paul goes to the edge, and honestly, I think that's the only way to do this movie. I do feel that it's a really interesting world that's worthy of depiction."
Mr. Verhoeven is an odd fish, a European intellectual with an untamed appetite for the cinematic equivalent of red meat. Growing up in the Netherlands, he feasted on action-packed Hollywood fare. Although he holds a doctorate in mathematics and physics and used to be infatuated with French New Wave and the films of Fellini, he tends to invoke as models "Ben-Hur" or "Gone With the Wind," films that grab viewers viscerally and pull them right into the screen.
"The chariot scene in 'Ben-Hur' is one of the best ever shot and edited," he said. "For 10 minutes, with no music, there is nothing but bumpa-bumpa-bumpa." He worked his arms up and down like pistons, acting out the pounding of horse hooves.
Mr. Verhoeven is also capable of spending 15 minutes analyzing the subtle deployment of actors' bodies in Orson Welles's "Touch of Evil" when explaining his finickiness in shooting Mr. Shockley's entrance onto the patio.
So, the Verhoeven approach: technical finesse, earthy tastes, a lurid imagination and a zest for putting the "big" back in "big screen." Plus a genuinely subversive streak, evident in the satiric touches in "Robocop" or the kinky plot turns of "The Fourth Man," his last Dutch film, whose gay protagonist pursues Renee Soutendijk in the hope of reaching her not-too-bright but well-muscled boyfriend.
Viewers of "Basic Instinct," by the way, might find something familiar in Ms. Soutendijk's performance as an ice-cold blonde with a very scary pair of scissors. They might also be surprised to know that Mr. Verhoeven's films include historical dramas about a poor family in 19th-century Amsterdam ("Keetje Tippel") and Dutch resistance fighters during World War II ("Soldier of Orange"), a swashbuckler set in 16th-century Europe ("Flesh and Blood") and a gritty look at a Dutch motorcycle gang ("Spetters"). In "The Fourth Man," Mr. Verhoeven created a new genre, the psychosexual religious thriller.
"In my mind -- and Paul and I have had a real Sturm und Drang relationship -- he is the most viscerally exciting director in the world," said Mr. Eszterhas. "He takes chances. He doesn't go with the formula. Most Hollywood directors are gutless, but he has guts."
It is therefore plausible when Mr. Verhoeven, who seems to be game for anything, says he took on "Showgirls" for the simple reason that he always wanted to direct a movie with singing and dancing. For a tantalizing year or so, it looked as if he was set to direct Arnold Schwarzenegger in a big-budget epic, "The Crusades," but the bigness of the budget -- at around $ 100 million, more than enough money to have financed the real crusades -- has put the project on hold.
"Showgirls," which Mr. Verhoeven had begun developing with Mr. Eszterhas even before the script was written, suddenly moved up to the front burner, just in time to rescue Mr. Verhoeven from doing a remake of "Moby-Dick." It was a close call. "Big whales," he said, wincing. "No, thank you. Shooting would be a nightmare."
Lose the whale. And bring on the dancing girls.
Even if the ratings board doesn't pounce, Mr. Verhoeven's stylistic study in excess may earn him and Mr. Eszterhas another round with some of the same groups that attacked "Basic Instinct" as a cheesy exercise in exploitation. Mr. Verhoeven shrugged off the critics, but Mr. Eszterhas, badly rattled, tried to change his own script to defuse the accusation that he had linked bisexuality and homicidal tendencies in an unseemly way. The attempted rewrite led to a bitter public argument between the two men.
This time, Mr. Eszterhas is talking a tougher line. "In the 90's especially, clubs featuring lap dancing are very successful across the country," he said. "That is an interesting phenomenon, one that is worth exploring artistically.
"Frankly, I'm tired of people looking at books or movies within the narrow politically correct confines. We are not saying all women are lap dancers, or that all lap dancers behave the way they do in this picture. If it means we are going to take certain political groups on, Paul and I are ready for it."
Ms. Gershon points out that her character and the one portrayed by Ms. Berkley (familiar to viewers of the television series "Saved by the Bell" as the goody-two-shoes overachiever Jesse) are tough, independent-minded women who play by their own rules. They just happen to play with no clothes on. Where's the problem? "When you go to see a Las Vegas show, you're not going to see people dancing in mumus," she said. "People will just have to accept that."

HEADLINE: 'Oversexed, Overfed, Over Here'

BYLINE: By Kenneth Harris; Kenneth Harris's most recent books are "The Queen" and "Margaret Thatcher."

 BODY:

RICH RELATIONS
The American Occupation
of Britain, 1942-1945.
By David Reynolds.
Illustrated. 555 pp. New York:
Random House. $30. 
"IT is difficult to go anywhere in London without having the feeling that Britain is now Occupied Territory," George Orwell wrote in 1943. There have been other books about the impact of some three million American troops on Britain in 1942-45, but they have been based on reminiscences. David Reynolds, a fellow of Christ's College, Cambridge, uses recollections, interviews and memoirs for "Rich Relations," but he has also made immense use of archival material in Britain and the United States, most of it hitherto neglected. He deals not only with the soldiers and the British man in the street, but also with British and American high politics and strategy, especially with the relations between Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Franklin D. Roosevelt and between top generals on both sides. This is international history in the broadest sense, embracing power and culture, policy and society, high politics as well as "real life," to provide an illuminating account of what the "occupation" meant to ordinary people.
"Rich Relations" is impressive in its authority and scope, yet very readable -- a remarkable feat. Many of the quotations are amusing, the comments witty but warm. It is hard to imagine a more comprehensive look at this extremely interesting and important subject, and it is not surprising to learn that Mr. Reynolds has been working on it for 13 years.
Nobody -- well, hardly anybody -- wanted the G.I.'s in Britain. That certainly included the majority of soldiers themselves, who were largely conscripts. Their parents did not want their sons, or daughters, sent into a war zone. Nor did Roosevelt; it might well lead to defeat in the next election. His Army Chief of Staff, Gen. George C. Marshall, was only too aware of the complex political and social problems the occupation would create. The G.I.'s hated the damp, dreariness, cold and mud of life in huts in winter on Salisbury Plain; they hated the "class" in their own Army that required them to salute their own officers, and initially many of them found British civilians cold and standoffish.
Only two groups of Americans relished being in Britain: a few top generals, who saw prospects of swift promotion in being overseas and feuded enthusiastically to get it, and the black soldiers, who, in spite of the occupation's de facto segregationist policy, found themselves better treated in Britain than they could ever have thought possible in their own country. Most British people didn't want an American occupation, either. In principle, yes; they sensed what the British Chiefs of Staff told the War Cabinet in May 1940 -- that without "full economic and financial support" from America, "we do not think we could continue the war with any chance of success" -- and they saw that such support would entail an occupation. But, in practice, the presence of the Americans brought many irritations, the main ones conveyed by that old crack: the Yanks were "oversexed, overpaid, overfed and over here."
The American was paid about three times as much as the British private. The differential also affected relations between G.I.'s and civilians; when thousands of British men were serving overseas, many of the sweethearts and wives they left behind were susceptible to American spending power. Even the difference in uniform caused problems. Off duty in a pub or on the dance floor, the British soldier wore battle dress and black hobnailed boots, quite different from his officer's service dress; but off duty the American in his service dress and rubber-soled brown shoes was almost indistinguishable from his officer -- at any rate, to many British women.
The main complaint of the British civilian from 1942 to 1944 was the amount of time the Yanks spent hanging around in Britain apparently doing nothing. Would they ever fight? Could they? Britons living near airfields knew that the Americans were doing plenty, of course, flying B-17's and B-24's in almost nonstop shifts to bomb German military and industrial plants, and suffering appalling casualties. D-Day changed everything. Almost overnight the British people became aware that the Americans could fight, that they had played the major role in the success, and suffering, of the invasion of France. Well before the end of the war in Europe, Mr. Reynolds says, the British people knew that "victory in the West was overwhelmingly an American triumph."
IN his opinion, there are at least several ways "in which the American occupation worked with other prewar, wartime and postwar trends to shape or sharpen British images of the United States." What was foremost, he says, was "the impression of American wealth." Few Britons, he points out, realized that most G.I.'s were having a far better life in the wartime Army than they had lived only a short time before in the years of the Depression. General Marshall believed that it was essential for morale to "coddle" soldiers who, in Mr. Reynolds's words, had been "sent far from home for a somewhat nebulous cause." Mr. Reynolds believes that the sight of the Americans enjoying their abundance confirmed the "glittering movie images" Britons had absorbed before the war. He maintains that it promoted in the British a sense of what came to be known as "consumerism . . . the endless production of goods and labor-saving devices, with demand encouraged by advertising," though the British had to put up with many years of austerity after the war before they could indulge their new acquired appetite for that.
Culturally, he says, "the G.I.'s -- jitterbugging and gum-chewing -- accentuated a trend that began during the Jazz Age of the 1920's and continued on via the gyrations of Elvis Presley to the present day." Finally, the British were made aware as never before of American might -- "the truly awesome sight of American power wending its way down to the ports of southern England; the news coming back from Normandy and the Ardennes to show that G.I.'s were real soldiers; the growing evidence . . . that America was the dominant partner in the alliance."
As for the G.I.'s, they had learned what it was to be comparatively wealthy and how much they owed that to being American. They returned home from bomb damage everywhere to a homeland booming with high employment. They were aware of America's power and prestige as never before. They shared a general superiority complex. Citing a 1945 poll of American servicemen reported in the Harvard Educational Review, Mr. Reynolds says, "Contrary to the hopes of publicists, war service abroad 'had not after all provided an education in internationalism.' " In fact, he concludes, "one might hazard the view that they returned even more American than when they departed."
