LENGTH: 1401 words

HEADLINE: Small Businesses, Global Markets

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
AS a partner in a small but expanding manufacturing business, Herbert Schwartz sometimes sweeps the floors, makes the morning coffee for his 20 employees and answers the phones. At the same time, he monitors the fortunes of the peso's rise and fall in Mexico, keeps close tabs on politics in the former Soviet republics and stays abreast of the latest trade policies in India -- countries where the engineer-turned-businessman markets temperature-resistant, ceramic-based products.
Aremco, Mr. Schwartz's Ossining-based firm, sells adhesives used in assembling everything from B-2 Stealth bombers and women's hair dryers to factory equipment in developing markets. One of the products, called Pyro-Putty -- a glue that can be used to repair steel machinery and car manifolds -- has become a hot-ticket item in recent years at automotive centers throughout the world, especially in countries where replacement parts for older vehicles are not available. 
 His business is typical of many other small and medium-size companies in Westchester that increasingly are marketing products and services worldwide. "Global is the big word today for us," Mr. Schwartz said, explaining that 25 percent of his business last year was exports -- up from just 8 percent several years ago.
Global is also the latest buzzword among large corporations in Westchester, like Reader's Digest in Pleasantville, where the first Polish edition of the magazine is about to be published.
During a speech last month to the World Trade Council of Westchester, a subsidiary business organization of the Westchester County Association, James P. Schadt, president and chief executive officer of the Reader's Digest Association, the parent of all Digest business, said the company's mission was to become "a truly global operator."
After the fall of the Berlin wall, the company began distributing its magazine in East Germany, and in 1991, it entered Hungary and Russia. Two years later, it was circulating Reader's Digest in the Czech Republic.
Mr. Schadt said that the Polish edition, to begin in May, is expected to expand his company's international operations, which account for more than 50 percent of its $3 billion in sales. Reader's Digest now publishes in 17 languages to 100 million readers worldwide.
Joel W. Barkan, New York district director for the United States Department of Commerce, said: "It's a small world after all. You can't travel the globe now without finding a Bayer aspirin in the medicine cabinet or a Pepsi or Coke in the refrigerator." He continued: "Not too many years ago it was esoteric to expand even to Chicago or Harrisburg, especially for small and medium-size companies. In the 1990's, expansion means foreign markets, especially as the domestic ones become saturated."
In response to the growth of international trade in Westchester, the Commerce Department is opening an export assistance center next month in White Plains, which will be staffed by a full-time world trade specialist to help businesses find markets and obtain financing, Mr. Barkan said.
He said the strongest emerging markets for domestic businesses include Mexico, Argentina, Brazil, Peru and Chile in Latin America and Malaysia, Indonesia, Taiwan and South Korea in the Pacific Rim.
At Citibank in Manhattan, Aftab Ahmed, director for trade, finance and global products, also cited Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, the Ivory Coast and Eastern Europe as key export destinations for many New York area businesses.
In its last fiscal year, which ended in July, Reader's Digest as an example reported $396 million in sales in its Pacific Rim destinations, including Australia, India, Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong and Japan. It also reported during that period $1.3 billion in European sales.
At Aremco, which is privately owned, Mr. Schwartz would not release sales figures, but he said some of his strongest markets were Japan, Poland, Israel and Greece. He said his business also sells products to former Iron Curtain countries in addition to Poland where temperature-resistance glues are being used to repair deteriorating power plants and factories, and to India.
For most businesses, though, the former Soviet republics continue to be "tough markets," Mr. Barkan said, because their infrastructure -- transportation, roads, legal services, telephone systems and banks -- are poorly developed.
"It's O.K. for a large multinational company like Pepsico to get involved," Mr. Barkan said, "but for a small-to-medium company, it's still rough. They have to be able to move goods from Point A to Point B, make a telephone call or make sure a contract is enforceable."
Pepsi-Cola International, headquartered in Somers, maintains a staff of 75 people in its Moscow office and oversees 19 franchised Pepsi plants, which are locally operated and managed throughout Russia.
Mr. Barkan credited passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement with accelerating the pace of expansion globally and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade with setting trade standards that are enforceable through the World Trade Organization in Geneva.
He also said the devaluation of the peso would prove to be only "a temporary setback" and that Mexico would "become more like the 51st state than a foreign country."
The following types of companies are faring best in the international market place, said Stephen Koller, director of the international division of the New York State Department of Economic Development: food-processing firms, manufacturers of medical equipment, imaging and optical companies, small electronics parts manufacturers and suppliers of telecommunications equipment and services.
The owner of one manufacturing company, Kings Electronics in Tuckahoe, reported, however, that business was down from 10 years ago because of new foreign competition, especially in Europe. Leon Fassler, vice chairman of the company, said he was turning to new markets in Canada, Latin America and the Pacific Rim to market coaxial and triaxial connecters and related products used in communications systems and for broadcasting.
Also, manufacturers of auto parts, printers and publishers, financial service providers and software developers are finding strong international markets, Mr. Koller said, adding that the growth of many international businesses has been spurred by advances in telecommunications, which allows them to communicate easily with companies overseas.
In White Plains, for example, Dr. Alan Teck, an international economist, edits three publications on global trade from a home office, surrounded by computers and fax machines, which keep him abreast of the latest world market developments. Teck Enterprises' publications include The Financial Times Currency Forecaster and The Financial Times Global Investor.
But the shifting political scene in Eastern Europe and the reduction of tensions in the region, while a boon to some businesses, has meant less trade for others.
Jan R. Endresen, president of the family-owned Aerotech World Trade Corporation of White Plains, said the fall of the Berlin wall signaled the beginning of a slowdown for his company, which distributes aviation parts and equipment for commercial and military applications.
"We watch the politics all over the world very carefully," Mr. Endresen said. "Conflicts are good for businesses." Also, he said, the company has been affected by "the huge shakeout in the airlines industry" in the United States and Europe. In addition to expanding markets for his company in the Far East, Mr. Endresen said, the company was expanding into telecommunications, electronics and fiber optics to compensate for its other losses.
In response to increased activity abroad by local companies, banks reported that they were providing new services to help businesses negotiate in foreign markets.
James B. Joyce, president of the Westchester-Putnam division of the Bank of New York, said there were more than 100 commercial customers in Westchester doing business overseas -- about a 20 percent increase in the last several years. The bank provides letters of credit and loan and collection services and helps customers "navigate through the maze" of international business, Mr. Joyce said. "A lot of our job is educating companies about how international business is done."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
A Song for Products Long Unsung

BYLINE: By PAUL LUKAS; Paul Lukas is the editor of Beer Frame: The Journal of Inconspicuous Consumption and a columnist for New York Press. This article is adapted from material that originally appeared in those publications.

 BODY:
GRUMBLE, grumble, grumble. Everyone complains about bad products, and often this criticism is richly deserved. But far too many praiseworthy products are unjustly ignored. It is time to redress the balance.
 
* Why the Shoe Fits. How many of us have taken a moment to appreciate the Brannock Device? This is the gizmo, invented decades ago by one Charles F. Brannock, that measures your shoe size. A workaday function, sure, but its chrome-and-black metal design, sliding parts and remarkably balanced asymmetry (much like the human foot itself), combine perfectly the industrial and the aesthetic. 

* Marlin Perkins and More. The mere mention of Barnum's Animal Crackers sends Shirley Temple's prepubescent voice warbling through my brain. But despite such annoyances, Animal Crackers always deliver the goods. The simplicity of shortbread, the kick of creating animal amputees and decapitatees as you eat -- who could ask for more?
True, these Nabisco products are not perfect. For example, the Animal Crackers menagerie includes a black panther, a leopard and a tiger, three felines that look distinct enough on the box but are virtually indistinguishable in cookie form. Just try to tell which is which when you're sitting in a dark bar, washing down your Animal Crackers with a 75-cent short beer.
Such minor quibbles, however, are no match for the feature that sets Animal Crackers head and shoulders above such snacks as Cracker Jack and Gummy Bears. I refer, of course, to the very satisfying string handle attached to each box.
The string was not part of the original 1902 package; it was added later that year to encourage consumers to hang the boxes from Christmas trees. While this marketing angle seems far-fetched to me, the string is charming, soft and 100 percent cotton. And if you remove it from the box and make a miniature lasso, you can even play Marlin Perkins with your Animal Crackers, which goes to show that interactive media are not limited to the Internet.
 
* Chutes and Letters. Mail chutes bring a bit of fun to even the dreariest high-rise, and the key is that they are transparent. Cutler Mailing Systems of Rochester might have made the whole chute out of steel or aluminum. Then, when you dropped your letter in the slot, that would be the last you'd see of it, the same as with a normal letter box. Big deal. But during those few moments when I see my letters begin their trip down the chute from the 39th floor, I can appreciate the magic of the postal system and, of course, worry that my letter will somehow get stuck on the 17th floor.
 
* Peddlers and Poker. Or consider the McGill High-Speed Changer, invented in the 1930's and distributed today by the J. M. Galef Company of New York. I first noticed this sturdy change-making device on a Good Humor man's belt in 1969. He just pressed the little levers and out came a seemingly endless supply of coins. As a 5-year-old with no concept of money, I found the light-industrial sound -- ka-chunk, ka-chunk -- even more satisfying than the coins themselves. So I dubbed the device a ka-chunker.
Today I have my own ka-chunker, a used one. How much money has ka-chunked its way through this object, I wonder. Was it used by a Good Humor man? And when did the pennies rack fall into disuse? It surely must have, once peddled products fell under the pricing tyranny of five cent increments.
Also, the ka-chunker is an unbeatable accessory for low-stakes poker ("I'll see your 50 cents" -- ka-chunk, ka-chunk -- "and raise you 75" -- ka-chunk, ka-chunk, ka-chunk). And in an economy ruled by electronic fund transfers and credit cards, the ka-chunker reminds us that cash isn't just liquid, but also solid.

The Economy
 The American International Toy Fair is in danger of having its scope and influence reduced. The biggest threat is the fundamental evolution in retailing patterns in the United States toy industry, in which many toy orders are placed well before the toy fair offers itself as a showcase. [Page D1.] 
 Orange County created the new position of chief executive and filled it by hiring William J. Popejoy from the private sector. By selecting someone with no experience in government, Orange County seems to be testing a suddenly popular philosophy that says government should learn to operate like a business. [D1.]
 American manufacturers are increasing prices for some of their products because of strong demand in a robust economy. But participants in the latest National Association of Manufacturers meeting say they are concerned that the Federal Reserve's actions might kill off the demand. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
 Among the largest networks, CBS has fallen to third place from first in one television season. It also finds itself at a competitive disadvantage in appealing to viewers younger than 50 years old. CBS executives say a list of new programs is being developed to pull the network out of its slide. [D1.]
 Two magazines devoted to black history make their debuts in conjunction with Black History Month and reveal a trend in the way small niche magazines are being published by leading media companies that work in partnership with small entrepreneurs who have the ideas. [D6.]
 Sex sells, according to three women's magazines in Britain that have been testing the adage as it applies to women by replacing pie recipes with a lot of pictured flesh. One of the magazines, Marie Claire, which used to be aimed at women with more intellectual interests, saw its circulation rise 27 percent, to 398,019, in 1994 from 1993. [D6.]
 Outside magazine is featuring a chewed-up stick, among other colorful images familiar to people who love the outdoors, in its latest ad campaign for trade publications for fields like apparel, travel and outdoor gear. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Companies
 Steven R. Berrard, president of Blockbuster Entertainment, is under investigation in Texas for possible perjury in connection with a 1991 lawsuit against Blockbuster, a division of Viacom Inc. Viacom denied that Mr. Berrard committed perjury. [D2.]
 The Pioneer Electronic Corporation will clone Apple's Macintosh, becoming the first Japanese company to do so. Known for its laser video-disk system and audio equipment, Pioneer does not make personal computers but believes it must to compete in the so-called multimedia age. [D2.]
 
International
 Who will be the next president of the World Bank? It will likely be one of these three prominent Americans: Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and a former chief economist at the World Bank; Stanley Fischer, also a former chief economist at the bank and now a deputy managing director at the International Monetary Fund, or James D. Wolfensohn, a New York investment banker who is chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. [D1.]
 
Today's Columns
 A California company has patented an artificial limb as light-weight sports equipment in hopes that more people who wear prostheses will ski. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]
 Though General Magic faces many unknowns as it tries to create a wireless computing industry, its initial public stock offering was received well by investors. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

ELITE HOSPITALS FACE CRISIS
New York's elite medical centers are facing their worst financial crisis in decades, caught between newly powerful health maintenance organizations demanding deep discounts and state and Federal legislators planning to cut millions of dollars in hospital payments to balance budgets. 
 Some of these teaching hospitals may not survive the decade, health-industry analysts say, and those that do will emerge transformed. A1.
 
NEW YORK WANTS TO BE A HIGH-TECH MECCA
As a mecca for writers, graphic artists, musicians and film makers, New York is poised to become one of the country's centers for the emerging multimedia industry, which combines visual and audio elements like animation, video and music to create films, CD-ROM's, television programming and virtual reality. A1.
 
MUSLIM WITNESS IS FLOWN TO U.S.
A South African Muslim man who provided the tip that led to the arrest last week of the suspected mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing has been flown with his wife and small child from Pakistan to the United States and placed under a witness protection program, a Pakistani official said. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
BRATTON STARTS PARING HIS BUDGET
Two days after his deputy commissioner for public information quit in a feud with City Hall over staffing cuts, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton huddled with top department officials to comply with the Mayor's order to cut his budget. Aides and advisers to Mr. Bratton said that he had assured them he wanted to remain Commissioner and told them that whether he stayed was up to the Mayor. B3.
What's so baffling about Mayor Giuliani's housecleaning is that there is no clear explanation of what most of the dozens of people dismissed did to attract his ire. Metro Matters, B3.
 
WHAT SUSPECT DID NOT KNOW CAN HURT
The man who snatched the purse of an elderly woman in Far Rockaway, Queens, did not know she was a Catholic nun. And he didn't know about her "little angels" -- two Emergency Medical Service technicians who chased and cornered him for the police. B3.
 
SINGLE FATHER GETS HELP FOR CHILDREN
Mickey Irizarry has been a single father for his three children since 1986, the year, he said, his life was nearly ruined. That year, two of his sons were killed in an electrical fire, all his possessions were destroyed, he lost his job, his wife of 15 years became addicted to crack and he had to go on welfare. But while getting counseling with his children, Mr. Irizarry learned of Girls Vacation Fund Camp. B2.
 
MAN HELD IN SHOOTING DEATH OF WIFE
A Queens man, who relatives said had recently been released from prison, shot his wife to death and wounded two other relatives in the couple's home at 541 Grassmere Terrace in Far Rockaway, the police said. The wife's brother described the suspect, Peter Garcia, 33, as a large, muscular man who was released from prison about a month ago. He said Mr. Garcia had served a one-year sentence for ransacking Eveyln Garcia's house and threatening the couple's infant daughter with a knife. B4.
 
REGION
 
PATAKI RAISES MONEY FOR PARTY
Unlike Mario M. Cuomo, who was often criticized by Democrats for not helping his party raise money, Gov. Pataki has enthusiastically assisted fellow Republicans capitalize on goodwill toward his administration. B5.
 
WHAT A DAY FOR A GAME IN THE PARK
There must be a reason three guys from New Jersey would pick one of the coldest days of the year to hop a bus to Manhattan, head to Central Park, and play touch football on a field packed solid with ice and in wind that made the temperature feel as low as 4 degrees. B4.
 
FIGHT RAGES OVER NORWALK POLICE
Amid repeated allegations of police brutality, leaders of black and Hispanic groups in Norwalk, Conn., are pressing for an independent board to look into complaints against the police. But the Mayor and the police chief are adamantly opposed. B8.

HEADLINE: Toy Fair Is Facing Challenges

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
On its sparkly, fun-loving surface, at least, all is well and business is booming at the American International Toy Fair, which opens today in Manhattan.
The venerable trade show, with its festival of news releases and celebrity-party invitations, has signed up more exhibitors this year, 1,640, than last year to hawk their Barbies and Power Rangers and Matchbox Lamborghinis. 
 Indeed, in its 61st year in Manhattan, the toy fair is expecting 20,000 buyers from 30 countries, just as many as last year. And its exhibition space in the Jacob K. Javits Center was booked solid by November, with a waiting list of 300.
Yet today, as fairgoers -- the public is not invited -- jam the famously overcrowded elevators in the Toy Center at Fifth Avenue and 23d Street before heading to exhibits in the Javits Center later this week, the toy fair is facing worrisome new challenges. Industry executives and experts say the New York toy fair is in danger of having its scope and influence sharply reduced in the future.
One problem, they say, is the relatively small size and high costs of the Javits Center, compared with show halls in other cities. An even bigger problem, they agree, is the fundamental evolution in retailing patterns in the $18 billion United States toy industry -- where many toy orders are placed well before the toy fair offers itself as a showcase. This trend may have already discouraged the participation of Hasbro, America's second-largest toy company after Mattel Inc.
"The potential is that we may not show in New York next year," said Wayne Charness, a spokesman for Hasbro, which has three showrooms in and near the Manhattan Toy Center. "The publicity and high profile may not be enough for the expense."
He said the company, which was surpassed by Mattel in sales last year, for the first time since 1985, would "save in the millions" if it left the toy center. "Toy Fair is becoming less important, except as a showcase, because by this time the major retailers, and even nonmajors, have already had two or three looks at our line," he said.
Yet another challenge comes from the little-noted but fast expansion of an upstart, the Dallas International Toy Import Show held in the Dallas Market Center in January. That show has the potential to siphon off important elements of the New York toy fair in future years, some industry executives say.
John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development in New York, calls the Dallas show "a serious competitor that is trying to lure our toy industry." In an interview last week, he said of the New York fair's exhibitors and buyers, "We hope that they won't take too seriously Dallas's siren song."
Any diminishment of the New York fair would be a blow to more than just the prestige of New York City, which derives $175 million of economic benefit from the trade show, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Beyond the revenue-generating year-round presence of the toy center, the toy fair itself accounts for 50,000 room-nights in hotels and helps fill restaurants, taxis and department stores. Thousands of display builders, designers and other vendors get work, as well as 1,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild who are hired as toy demonstrators.
The New York toy fair "is very healthy, and certainly we are committed to New York for the moment," said David A. Miller, president of the Toy Manufacturers of America, a trade group of 235 toy manufacturers and importers that sponsors the show. "But in 1998 and 1999, we would have to study whether Toy Fair is still the most efficient way to do our job."
The New York fair has long been the industry's annual carnival, showroom and high-stakes crap shoot, in which buyers traditionally place their bets on new products. In the old days, the fair was the equivalent of opening night for many a toy and toy line.
"But all of the major companies show their product lines more than six months before Toy Fair," said Sean P. McGowan, a toy industry analyst for Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company. "No new major categories are unveiled at Toy Fair."
"Toys 'R' Us and the other mass retailers want the opportunity to get in early and be part of the new introductions," he added. "For the large companies, Toy Fair is more about showing toys to the press and to Wall Street and their smaller customers."
Michael Goldstein, chief executive of Toys "R" Us, said his buyers spent "considerable" time at the toy exhibitions in the Javits Center. "But we are buying all year round," he said, "and we're not using the New York toy fair to get down orders. For us it's not an order-writing time."
Mattel remains loyal to the fair. "We have no plans to change our commitment to Toy Fair in New York," said Glenn Bozarth, a company spokesman. "The New York toy fair continues to be the major toy venue. For buyers and Wall Street, New York is the one time of year when all eyes are on the toy industry."
But that unqualified enthusiasm is hardly universal, in part because of the Dallas show. Frank Reysen Jr., editor of Playthings magazine, a monthly trade publication, said a lot of the major retailers were doing "serious buying" in Dallas, adding, "I think Dallas is definitely going to be a factor this year."
In Dallas, where the toy show ran from Jan. 19 to 27, "the reaction to our show has been phenomenal and our impression is that we will expand," said Bill Winsor, the chief executive of the Dallas Market Center, which has 850,000 square feet of exhibition space, in contrast to 770,000 at the Javits Center.
The show takes advantage of the Dallas Market Center's status as a free-trade zone, allowing exhibitors to bring in showroom samples through United States Customs without paying import duty.
Mr. Winsor said 300 foreign manufacturing companies attended last month. Toys "R" Us, the only retailer participating during the show's first two years, was joined this year by 85 others, including Target, Sears, Caldor and Bradlees. Mr. Winsor said manufacturers including Hasbro, Tyco and Mattel's Fisher-Price unit have rented permanent toy showrooms in the market center.
The Dallas event is a letter-of-credit show that gives domestic manufacturers a price break with producers in Hong Kong, Shanghai and other foreign ports if they can buy in advance, without the need for Toy Fair.
Mr. Winsor was diplomatic when asked if the Dallas show was trying to supplant New York's. "The toy fair fulfills a very important purpose," Mr. Winsor said of the New York event. "But what's happened is that there has been a migration of major buyers from it. And that handful of buyers is controlling 80 percent of the market."
Mr. Goldstein of Toys "R" Us, the most important toy buyer worldwide, said of the Dallas show: "It's not comprehensive like the show in New York. The major manufacturers only show lines related to their importing divisions."
Mr. Miller of the Toy Manufacturers of America said that while some people in the industry "would like to see Dallas as a substitute for the show in New York, it's a great leap in the imagination to take it that far." Dallas is a specialty show, he added, and, unlike the New York show, has "no sizzle."
"A number of our members who exhibit there have said that this trend is the way it's going to go," Mr. Miller said. "It will possibly become more important, and if it does, then we'd get involved because our members would want us to," he said. The Toy Manufacturers of America was invited to be a sponsor of the Dallas show this year, Mr. Miller said, but declined.
In the short run, Mr. Miller foresees little change. "But in 1998, who knows, maybe things will be different," he said. "We're doing a major study of our toy fair, and we'll try to chart a course that will keep this fair viable."
Deputy Mayor Dyson said New York was working hard not to lose the toy fair. The Giuliani administration has already offered assistance to the trade show, he said, and has arranged for extra police help.
He spoke proudly of the reduction in the combined city and state hotel occupancy tax to 15.25 percent from 21.25 percent (in Dallas, the comparable tax is 13 percent). And, in a plea to the fair's visitors, Mr. Dyson said: "Give us a little more time to turn the place around. We're trying to lower the cost of doing business here, and to address the quality-of-life issues, making the streets still safer and cleaner and freer of graffiti and the other things that detract from people's enjoyment of the city of New York."
For many toy exhibitors, the conditions of concern are not the world outside but the crystalline spaces of the Javits Center. Many toy industry executives, who insisted on anonymity, complained about the center's limitations, citing problems that have plagued the hall since its 1986 opening, including limited space, high costs and wasteful labor rules.
"If Javits were twice the size, it could handle any trade show in the United States," Mr. Miller said. Last spring, Fabian G. Palomino, former president of the center, which is a state authority, proposed that the center's floor space be doubled. But after the defeat of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Palomino stepped down and plans are on hold until a replacement is named.
Mr. Dyson said he sympathized with critics of the Javits Center, adding that exhibition costs were 50 percent higher than in the McCormick Center in Chicago and that the cost of labor "is 280 percent higher than at the McCormick Center, as a result of archaic work rules and too much continuing mob influence in what goes on at the Javits Center."
Mr. Dyson said the Guiliani administration "would like the Governor to give us control of the Javits Center so we can do what we did with the Fulton Fish Market, so we can put in management reforms that will make it competitive with convention centers in other cities."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1754 words

HEADLINE: A Son Sees Reflection in the Water;
Kennedy Scion Shuns Public Office for Beloved Reservoirs

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 12

 BODY:
When Robert F. Kennedy Jr. walked into Andrew Cuomo's bachelor party in June 1990, his eye was drawn to the bar: there, sitting alone on a stool, was the groom's father, then the Governor of New York.
But rather than just exchange pleasantries, Mr. Kennedy was seized by an urge to buttonhole Mario Cuomo about his pet concern, New York City's giant watershed. And so he did, for the better part of an hour. 
 "Nobody else was talking to him," Mr. Kennedy recalled. "So I made him sit and listen to me."
Bobby Kennedy Jr. has been making a lot of people listen to him these days, even though he has not followed the political path taken by his older brother, Joseph Kennedy, a Congressman from Massachusetts, and his older sister, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, the recently elected Lieutenant Governor of Maryland.
Instead, the third of Robert and Ethel Kennedy's 11 children has carved a less conventional niche, becoming a zealous advocate for the protection of the upstate reservoirs that provide New York City with its drinking water. Over the last decade, he has developed a reputation as a bit of a nuisance when it comes to making his point.
He has done so using a combination of tools: his extensive contacts, a law degree, an intimate understanding of the environment and, of course, his name.
"I have enough friends and family who are in the House and Senate," he said, "so if I want legislation, I have the access."
His role has become increasingly high profile in recent months, as New York City has come under pressure from Federal officials to devise a better way to keep its reservoirs clean or face an order from the Environmental Protection Agency to build a huge filtration plant that could cost $4 billion to $8 billion.
While Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, like his predecessors, has been eager to avoid the costs of filtration, the alternatives he is pursuing -- buying land that abuts the reservoirs and restricting development within the 2,000-square-mile watershed -- have met resistance in the Catskill communities that rely on the area for their livelihood.
But if there is one thing on which the city and the Catskill towns can agree, it is that Mr. Kennedy, 41, has been a thorn in their side. Although he agrees with city officials that a multibillion-dollar filtration system can and should be avoided, he has chided the city for "stalling" in its commitment to buy tens of thousands of acres of Catskill land as a buffer around the reservoirs. (City Department of Environmental Protection officials say that the delay has come at the state level, not theirs.)
Mr. Kennedy has also labeled as "weak" a series of proposed watershed regulations that the city drafted recently, with Catskill advice, including measures that would allow treated sewage to continue to flow into the reservoirs.
Mr. Kennedy has been willing to resort to radical tactics to state his case: in the fall of 1993, he oversaw the creation of a public service campaign that speculated about how much of Amy Fisher's urine was seeping into a city reservoir from the sewage of the nearby Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, where she was an inmate. At the urging of the Dinkins Administration, which was in the midst of a re-election campaign, Mr. Kennedy never ran the ads. But he said the incident caught Mr. Dinkins' attention and won Mr. Kennedy a two-hour talk with the then Mayor.
This spring, he plans to turn up the heat on the Giuliani administration and the Catskills by filing nearly 40 lawsuits on behalf of Hudson Riverkeeper, an environmental watchdog group that employs him as a lawyer. His targets: nursing homes, schools, hospitals and others within the watershed that, he has charged, have been pumping untreated sewage into the reservoirs without penalty from the city.
"We're doing something Marilyn Gelber ought to be doing," he said, referring to the city's Commissioner of Environmental Protection.
His aggressiveness has brought results in the past. His first target, in 1985, was a dank seven-mile creek in Newburgh, N.Y. He put together a list of all the polluters simply by walking the creek, end to end, then filed two dozen lawsuits against various businesses and agencies that had been dumping waste there. His actions drew the attention of the Department of Environmental Conservation and led to the clean-up of the brook, said Judith Ferry, a D.E.C. lawyer who worked on the case.
"He was the genesis of this happening," Ms. Ferry said.
Four years later, he successfully sued New York City to stop it from adding Hudson River water laden with chlorine and alum sludge to the dwindling West Branch reservoir because, he maintained, the chemicals were polluting the drinking water.
"He is relentless," said Albert F. Appleton, the Commissioner of Environmental Protection in the Dinkins administration. "He is very dedicated to his goals, always keeps coming at you and is not easily put off."
But his bearing has not prevented him from collecting his share of detractors, including Ms. Gelber, who said she admires his "passion" but not his resistance to compromise. "Intellectually, I think his arguments are often good and provocative," the Commissioner said. "However, as a practical matter, he is not a consensus builder. He is not someone who wants to see more than one side of an issue."
Numerous Catskill residents and developers agree. To them, his call for tighter regulations within the watershed threatens the economic growth of their region.
"I characterize him as a carpetbagger," said Orville A. Slutzky, whose family-operated ski resort, Hunter Mountain, sits within the watershed. "Let me get Webster's dictionary because I never remember to quote it right: a nonresident who meddles in politics."
But Mr. Kennedy, who lives within the watershed in the Westchester community of Bedford, remains unfazed. Indeed, he has not ruled out a run for office some day. For now, however, he says he remains content with his work, which has included environmental advocacy expeditions to British Columbia and Latin America on behalf of the Natural Resources Defense Council.
"Until I get some sign to do something else," he said, "I'll keep doing this."
Mr. Kennedy, who is also a professor of environmental law at Pace University in White Plains, says he regards his name as "a gift," one that he has not hesitated to use to open doors at places like the E.P.A. He also has a presence that is, to some, evocative of his father, who was assassinated in 1968 while seeking the Democratic nomination for President. Senator Edward M. Kennedy sees the likeness in his nephew's "piercing eyes," which he describes as "somewhat sad.'
As a child, Mr. Kennedy wanted to become a veterinarian. But that ambition was sidetracked at age 14, when his father was killed. Feeling an obligation to "pick up" where his father "left off," he attended Harvard, graduating with a degree in history and literature in 1977, and the University of Virginia, where he earned a law degree in 1982.
After marrying a fellow law student, Emily Black, he briefly worked as an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, a job he had left by early 1983. And then his personal problems became national news. In September of that year Mr. Kennedy was arrested in Rapid City, S.D., and charged with possessing two-tenths of a gram of heroin. His photograph was on the cover of People magazine.
He had, he said at the time, traveled to South Dakota to seek help for drug dependency. In February 1984, after completing a five-month treatment program, Mr. Kennedy pleaded guilty to the heroin charge and was sentenced to 800 hours of community service. Asked recently what he had learned, Mr. Kennedy declined to answer.
"That's not something I want to talk about with the press," he said. "I have other places where I talk about that." But in an earlier conversation, he described 1984 as the year he "reevaluated" his life, deciding: "I was going to do what I wanted to do."
Mr. Kennedy said that his love for nature had begun early. His curiosity, according to his mother, was apparent as early as at 6 months old, when a beetle flew into his playpen on the patio at Hickory Hill, the family homestead in Virginia.
"He was creeping toward it, trying to check it out," Mrs. Kennedy recalled. "I just thought, wow, most kids would have been trying to get away from it."
Soon, he was rounding up snakes, raccoons and rats as pets, and accompanying his father on hikes in the Olympic Mountains with Justice William O. Douglas and on whitewater rafting trips with John Glenn.
And then there are his hawks. Mr. Kennedy received his first pet hawk from his father when he was 12, and has kept a succession of them since. To see him run through the woods following his hawk, Kucheen, as she pursues a squirrel is to see the ordinarily reserved Mr. Kennedy at his most animated.
"Ho-ho-ho-ho-ho-ho-ho!" he shouted on a recent Saturday, alerting the brown and gray bird to a nest in a walnut tree. "See how smart she is," Mr. Kennedy said, beaming. "She sat on that dray and drove out four squirrels."
Asked if falconry was an appropriate pastime for an environmentalist, Mr. Kennedy responded that not all environmentalists were animal rights activists. "You're not really interfering with what they would be doing if you weren't there," he said. "They're letting you come with them on a hunt."
Mr. Kennedy believes that the wilderness should be kept pollution-free for the benefit of people.
"We are not protecting the environment for the fishes and the birds," he said. "We're protecting it for the sake of humanity."
To that end, Mr. Kennedy approached John Adams, the executive director of the Natural Resources Defense Council, who hired him in 1984 to set up an advocacy center in Garrison, N.Y. Soon after, he met John Cronin, the head of the Riverkeeper organization, and he has been drafting environmental lawsuits for both organizations since.
Mr. Kennedy has a son, Bobby, 10, and a daughter, Kathleen, 6, both with Ms. Black, from whom he was divorced last spring. He has since married Mary Richardson, a Manhattan architect. They have a 5-month-old son, Conor.
Mr. Kennedy realizes that comparisons with his father are inevitable. He is approaching 42, the age his father died. By 42 his father had served as Attorney General and as a United States Senator.
"I'm proud of what my father and uncles did," he said. "I don't have to do what they did. I love what I do."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an environmental-law professor, is also an advocate for the protection of the upstate reservoirs. He and his son Bobby, 10, and a pet hawk, Kucheen, made a recent weekend trip to the woods near Mount Pleasant, N.Y. Mr. Kennedy at an environmental litigation clinic at Pace University. (Photographs by Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)(pg. B1)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%); MARYLAND, USA (79%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: Pakistan Officials Hope to Repair Ties With U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 12

 BODY:
After Pakistan's swift deportation of the suspected mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing, the Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is hoping that its action will give a new impetus to Pakistan's bid to improve frayed relations with the United States.
By allowing American agents to join in a raid on a rooming house here on Tuesday that led to the capture of the suspect, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, and by approving his return to the United States on an American military aircraft eight hours later, "Pakistan has been able to prove our cooperative and friendly attitude toward the United States," said Husain Haqqani, an aide to Ms. Bhutto and the Government's chief spokesman. 
 For decades, officials here had few reasons to worry about relations with the United States. But a combination of factors in the late 1980's put an end to the era in which Pakistan received favored treatment as Washington's most important ally in the region. Those factors included the Soviet military withdrawal from Afghanistan and the subsequent breakup of the Soviet Union, the rise of Pakistan as a major center for heroin trafficking and Islamabad's covert nuclear weapons program.
Now, the hope among top Government officials is that the case of Mr. Yousef, in which Ms. Bhutto waived procedures that could have delayed the deportation for weeks or months, will stimulate efforts by Pakistan to mend ties with Washington. With Prime Minister Bhutto due in the United States in April for her first official visit since returning to power in an election 17 months ago, Mr. Yousef's capture here came at an ideal time for the Pakistani Government.
Five days after Mr. Yousef was flown to New York, officials involved remain reluctant to speak openly about the case, partly out of a desire not to provoke radical Muslim groups that have stirred anti-American passions in the past. So far, the low-key policy appears to have succeeded, with no public demonstrations on the Yousef affair and scant coverage of it in most major newspapers, some of which relegated the story to inside pages from the start.
One top official, who discussed the case on condition that he would not be identified, said that the relative quiescence of groups like Jamaat-i-Islami, a hard-line Muslim group with seats in Parliament, reflected the reluctance of even strongly anti-American politicians and Muslim clerics here to be seen as supporting what the official described as "the worst kind of terrorist."
The official added, "Who wants to stand up and argue the case of somebody who tried to blow up a building with thousands of innocent people in it?"
But another reason for the Government's reticence has been its hope to avoid too close a review of its handling of the deportation. Setting aside procedures that had previously delayed deportation proceedings for drug traffickers and others wanted in Western countries, Ms. Bhutto approved a shortcut in which a middle-level judicial official signed the deportation order, apparently without ever seeing Mr. Yousef, and at a point when the American plane was already on stand-by for the flight to New York.
A Justice Ministry official familiar with the events said that besides Ms. Bhutto, no high-ranking Cabinet minister even knew of Mr. Yousef's arrest, which the official said had been coordinated by the United States Embassy and officials of Pakistan's military intelligence wing, the Inter-Services Intelligence Agency. Perhaps most striking, said guests at the rooming house where Mr. Yousef was seized, American agents with handguns in holsters underneath their suit jackets were allowed to join the raiding party that stormed Mr. Yousef's second-floor room. Previous reports said he had been seized in a hotel.
By acting as she did, Ms. Bhutto was following a policy of reaching out to the United States on a broad front of issues. Since returning to power for her second stint as Prime Minister, she has abandoned the socialist legacy of her Pakistan People's Party and emphasized economic policies that rely on selling off nationalized industries and providing incentives for foreign investors, a turn that has been strongly supported in Washington.
With Clinton Administration encouragement, American energy companies have announced plans to invest billions of dollars in projects to build coal-fired power plants that are seen laying the base for new industrial growth. Under prodding from the Washington-based International Monetary Fund, the Pakistani Government has made new efforts to cut the deficit spending that has run up large international debts. It has also pledged to crack down on widespread tax evasion by wealthy Pakistanis that is said to have resulted in a shortfall of about 60 percent in Government revenues.
Of more immediate concern to Washington, Ms. Bhutto has also ordered a crackdown on some of the drug barons behind the trafficking that sends hundreds of tons of heroin to Europe and the United States each year. While deportation proceedings against seven suspected drug barons wanted by the United States have moved slowly, the Government has taken another step long sought by Washington, freezing or sealing bank accounts, properties and other assets of top traffickers and carrying out heavily armed raids in remote frontier areas to arrest other top drug figures.
These steps have been taken as the United States, under a 1990 Congressional law forbidding aid to Pakistan as long as it continues with its secret nuclear weapons program, has cut off all economic and military aid, except for programs that assist with family planning and narcotics enforcement. Although the cutoff has stanched an aid flow that was worth nearly $600 million a year in the late 1980's, Ms. Bhutto has said that there will be no abandoning of the nuclear program unless India, Pakistan's traditional enemy, does likewise.
A Foreign Ministry official said that bitterness over the aid cutoff had given way to a recognition that Pakistan has no choice but to seek the best possible relations with the United States.
"There is nowhere else to turn to," he said. "We need investment, and with our relations with India at a dead-end, we can't afford to be on the wrong side of the United States."

HEADLINE: Price Rises By Factories On Increase

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11

 BODY:
After months of trying, the nation's manufacturing companies, in a growing number of cases, are managing to increase the prices of some of their products, although rarely by as much as they would like.
The reports of price increases were much more frequent at the winter meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers, which ended today, than they had been at the fall meeting, in September. In many cases, the manufacturers passed along their higher costs for materials. But strong demand in a robust economy made the price increases possible, and the manufacturers expressed concern that the Federal Reserve, by raising interest rates, might kill off the demand. 
 "If you assume that incomes are relatively fixed, then when rates rise for car loans and mortgages, there is less money left over for discretionary spending," said William D. Marohn, president of the Whirlpool Corporation, which recently raised the prices of its appliances by 2 percent on average, the first general increase in a while.
The Fed's goal, by reducing demand and spending, is to keep the annual inflation rate from rising. It is now less than 3 percent, but if the manufacturers were to raise prices by more than 3 percent a year, that would help to pull up the inflation rate. In interviews with nearly two dozen of the 130 executives gathered here for the two-day directors' meeting, very few said their price increases exceeded the inflation rate.
Nevertheless, they seem to expect that to happen. In an informal poll, slightly more than half of the 88 executives who participated said they expected the annual inflation rate to rise this year to 3 to 4 percent, an increase they said would not lead to a major acceleration of inflation. By a two-to-one margin, they also said the Fed should hold off on any further rate increases until the economy absorbed the impact from past increases. In the interviews, a few said the impact was already evident.
"Our orders suddenly fell in January," said J. Richard Derickson, chief executive of the Hiwasse Manufacturing Company in Jacksonville, Ark., which makes aluminum trim for refrigerators and other kitchen appliances. "I am not seeing orders canceled, but they are being pushed out into the future."
In Mr. Derickson's view, the appliance manufacturers are suffering from falling sales, and that is why they are slowing their purchases from Hiwasse. The appliance manufacturers say this is not so; their business is good. Whatever the case, Mr. Derickson sought an 8 percent price increase late last year -- his first increase in four years -- to help cover the rising cost of the aluminum used in his trim.
"You would have thought I had asked for their first-born; they hollered," he said of the appliance manufacturers. He settled for 5 percent.
Tire manufacturers, beset by a similar rise in materials prices, have had better luck. Until last fall, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's price increases had averaged less than 2 percent a year. But an increase of 3 to 4 percent in the fall and another next month of 3 to 5 percent are changing the pattern. Goodyear was the first to act, but other tire makers soon followed, and the increases have stuck.
"It would appear that we are all in the same predicament," said Stanley C. Gault, Goodyear's chairman. "There are only a few raw materials that go into tires, and they are all moving up in price."
Cooper Industries Inc., which makes numerous products, is more typical of the manufacturing experience as described in the interviews here. Prices have risen recently by 2 percent or so for its hand tools, lighting fixtures, fuses and other electrical products, says Robert Cizik, the chairman. "The business is strong, but we have to hold our market share," he said. "If we go up too much, foreign competitors will move in and then it will be a long process to get the markets back."
Cooper also makes spark plugs, competing in particular against Japanese and European manufacturers, and that has prevented any price increase. "If the auto companies don't get the prices they want they go to someone else," Mr. Cizik said. "Price increases come where there is clearly limited competition and strong demand and you don't have to deal with a lot of manufacturing capacity elsewhere in the world."

HEADLINE: Rights Group Issues Criticism Of Arafat Rule

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Human rights are in a "perilous state" under Palestinian self-rule, threatening the prospects for regional peace, the United States-based Human Rights Watch/Middle East said today.
In a 50-page report, the monitoring group accused Yasir Arafat's police force in the Gaza Strip of arbitrarily rounding up political opponents and mistreating some of them. Press freedoms have also been violated, it said, and the Palestinian Authority, which administers self-rule, has failed in its first nine months to show "a commitment to installing a rule of law." 
 The study broke little new ground, for most of its findings had already been reported by foreign news organizations. Nonetheless, it was the first full assessment of the authority's performance by an international group, and it was important also because charges of human-rights violations were long a basic component of Palestinian resistance to Israeli occupation of Gaza and the West Bank.
"The perilous state of human rights in the Palestinian self-rule areas poses a grave threat to the prospects for a durable peace in the region," Human Rights Watch said in a separate statement. It was referring to conditions both in Gaza and the autonomous West Bank district of Jericho, but its main focus was on the crowded, poverty-ridden coastal strip, where Mr. Arafat has put his headquarters.
An Arafat spokesman, Nabil Abu Irdeineh, waved off the report as "inaccurate" and said it was "done in a short time," but he did not specify what errors he saw in it. Mr. Abu Irdeineh added that "the Palestinian Authority is still in the beginning of its rule" and is "serious about implementing law and order in Gaza and Jericho."
Human Rights Watch did not spare Israel in its study, pointing out that it remains the occupying power throughout most of the territories.
In particular, the group denounced Israel for the border closings it periodically imposes on the West Bank and Gaza, including one ordered after a Palestinian suicide bombing that killed 21 Israelis on Jan. 22. Such restrictions, which keep tens of thousands of Palestinians from low-paying jobs in Israel, amount to collective punishment and have "devastating effects" on the territories' fragile economy, the report said.
As the latest border closing entered its fourth week, the Israeli Government announced that it would be continued for at least seven more days, making it one of the longest bans ever imposed on Palestinian entry into Israel.
Environment Minister Yossi Sarid said Israel had "solid information about possible terror events" expected in the days leading up to Feb. 25, the first anniversary of the massacre in which a Jewish settler killed 29 Muslim worshipers in the West Bank town of Hebron. No "responsible person" could lift the ban this week, Mr. Sarid said.
But Israeli officials acknowledge that the restrictions are inflicting serious harm. For instance, Gaza is reported to have only a two-day supply of gasoline left. Israeli fuel deliverers stopped going there after a security guard accompanying a truck convoy was killed by Palestinian gunmen.
In its report, Human Rights Watch devoted a good deal of attention to Palestinian police roundups of Islamic militants and others opposed to Mr. Arafat. These sweeps have usually followed assaults on Israeli targets, and almost invariably those arrested are released after several days. Nearly all, the study said, "appear to have been targeted for their suspected political affiliations rather than because they were accused of direct involvement in the attacks."
Most of the political targets are not mistreated, the report said, but some prisoners, especially those accused of collaborating with Israel, have been beaten. Two men have died in custody.

HEADLINE: Mayor Seeks Aid Reduction For Hospitals

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
As part of his effort to close a $2.7 billion budget gap, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to ask Gov. George E. Pataki to reduce the amount of money hospitals receive for treating the poor and disabled under Medicaid, officials said yesterday.
Because New York City pays part of the cost of Medicaid, the cuts would help it balance its budget, but would also cause even deeper reductions in financing for its municipal hospital system. 
 The cut in hospital reimbursement rates, to be unveiled with the Mayor's preliminary budget on Tuesday, represents a major part of Mr. Giuliani's plan to ask Albany to go much further than the Governor proposed in slashing spending on public assistance and Medicaid.
The harshest effects of the cuts would be felt by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which would lose $300 million under the Mayor's plan, according to one official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The corporation, an independent agency that operates the city's 11 municipal hospitals, already stands to lose an estimated $800 million in financing under the Governor's plan. The combined blow would total $1.1 billion, more than a third of the corporation's $3.2 billion budget, and could hasten the closing of one or more of the city's 11 municipal hospitals.
The reductions, officials said, would also add new impetus to Mr. Giuliani's effort to sell or turn over the operation of some of those hospitals to private, nonprofit organizations. "All we're doing is accelerating what's already happening," said the official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The Mayor's aides declined to discuss the details of his budget plan or to specify a percentage cut in hospital rates.
In all, Mr. Giuliani's preliminary budget plan is expected to propose $1.2 billion in savings in public assistance and Medicaid, otherwise known as entitlement programs, by asking the Governor to go much further than the reductions he proposed in his budget earlier this month. The additional cuts would save the city $400 million more -- $300 million in Medicaid and $100 million in welfare -- than the estimated $800 million in savings under the Governor's budget proposal.
To achieve the added savings, the Governor and the State Legislature would have to agree to increase the state's overall cut in welfare and Medicaid from $1.9 billion to roughly $2.5 billion, officials said. Because the Legislature sets the rates for hospital reimbursements statewide, the Mayor's reductions would affect spending not only in the city, which accounts for two-thirds of welfare and Medicaid spending, but around the state, squeezing public hospitals and, to a lesser extent, private ones as well.
Mr. Giuliani's Medicaid proposals could face an uphill battle in Albany, where the Democrats in the Assembly have long fought to protect health care for the poor while the Republicans in the Senate have fought to protect the rates for hospitals.
The Mayor could also face resistance from the City Council, whose members, while glumly acknowledging the need for painful measures, could balk at cuts that force municipal hospitals to close.
"It's pretty clear, based on what H.H.C. officials have said, that closings can't be ruled out," the Council's spokesman, Michael S. Clendenin, said yesterday. "If that happens, it will show that these kind of cuts hurt not only the poor, but also working people and a significant part of the city's economy."
The Mayor's plan underscores the extent to which he now relies on Mr. Pataki, the Republican Governor whom he vilified during last year's campaign. And it shows how much Mr. Giuliani's fiscal policies parallel the Governor's, even as Democrats in the Capitol and City Hall warn of disaster for the city.
Speaking generally of his plans after watching a basketball game at Manhattan College on Saturday, Mr. Giuliani said, "What we will demonstrate is that we'll be able to take advantage of the direction that the state is going to find some rather huge savings for the city."
Mr. Giuliani is scheduled to appear this morning before the joint fiscal committees of the Legislature to express support for Mr. Pataki's budget and, aides said, to make a personal pitch for further cuts. The Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, Democrat of Queens, will testify, but is likely to offer a starkly different analysis of the budget.
In addition to the cut in hospital reimbursement rates, officials said, the Mayor's plan is expected to propose additional restrictions in the complex regulations governing Medicaid payments. These would be similar to Mr. Pataki's proposal to limit payments, for example, for home care for the disabled or elderly.
Mr. Giuliani will also call on the Governor to make still deeper cuts in welfare, even though Mr. Pataki has already proposed the deepest cuts in the 60 years the state has offered welfare programs, officials said.
The Mayor, they said, would propose larger cuts in grants for able-bodied single adults and mothers with children than the 25 percent reductions proposed by Mr. Pataki, as well as added restrictions on eligibility. The Mayor is also expected to call for limiting benefits to 90 days every two years, rather than 90 days every year, as Mr. Pataki proposed, producing savings for the city in the future as welfare rolls decline.
The cuts in social services are only a part of the budget plan that Mr. Giuliani will present on Tuesday to close a projected $2.7 billion budget gap in the fiscal year that begins in July. Today, he will deliver a speech on the budget at 5:40 P.M., which will be broadcast live on Channel 1.
The Mayor has already met with the city's union leaders and received a pledge to help find $600 million in savings on health care, pensions and work rules, in exchange for a pledge by Mr. Giuliani to avoid layoffs of municipal workers once again.
His plan will also, officials said, cut spending in the city's myriad agencies by $600 million, exempting few areas of service, and include $300 million in privatization proposals and other initiatives. This year's plan, for example, will move ahead with a plan abandoned last year to sell the commercial licenses of WNYC, the city's radio and television stations, the officials said.
Still, the most dramatic effect of the Mayor's plan could be on the hospitals corporation, which receives 72 percent of its funding from Medicaid. The agency has already cut the size of its work force by 3,600 workers, to 47,000, and closed some beds to cope with reductions in the city's contribution to its budget, which now stands at roughly $250 million.
A spokeswoman, Audrey Kelly, said the corporation expected to shoulder reductions as the city and state grappled with their fiscal difficulties. "We've already said the reductions we're looking at from the state will force us to restructure our health care system," she said. "The restructuring process is already under way. These cuts are going to hasten the process."

HEADLINE: THE NEEDEST CASES;
Single Father Receives Help in Meeting His Children's Needs

BYLINE: By ROBERT WADDELL 

 BODY:
Mickey Irizarry has been a single father for his three children since 1986, the year he said his life was nearly ruined. That year, two of his sons were killed in a fire, all his possessions were destroyed, he lost his job, his wife of 15 years became addicted to crack and he had to go on welfare.
After the fire, Mr. Irizarry said, his wife became distraught. She neglected her children, stole money and stayed out with her friends until 2 or 3 in the morning, he said. 
 Mr. Irizarry and his wife divorced, and he gained sole custody of his children, Marcie Ann, 13, Jeffrey, 6, and Melanie, 4. He now cares for them himself in their apartment in the Audubon housing project in Harlem.
"Who he is is so rare," Marcie Ann said. "That's what makes his so unique. He can relate to you, and he's so patient. When you find these kinds of people, you try to hold on to them."
While attending family counseling with his children, Mr. Irizarry learned of Girls Vacation Fund Camp. He felt that his daughter would benefit from camp, as he did when he was a child. Marcie Ann attended camp for four years in a row, hiking, swimming and learning archery. She gained so much confidence in her swimming that she tried out for her school's team, and made it.
This summer, Marcie Ann hopes to return to camp as a counselor-in-training. "I feel boxed in in this apartment," she said. "How many times can I go around this ugly block on my bike without getting bored?"
Girls Vacation Fund Camp receives funds from the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of seven organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund's 83d annual appeal began on Thanksgiving Day and will continue through February. Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, Neediest Cases has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled.
So far this year, the fund has received nearly $4 million from thousands of individuals and foundations. All the contributions go directly to the charities, which use them to help people like Mr. Irizarry and his children.
"I always thought bad things would happen to me, but not at this magnitude," said Mr. Irizarry, an unemployed printer. "I haven't had a life since the fire. All my savings went to pay for funeral bills and hospital bills. Now I have no savings, just welfare."
But he said it made him happy to see his children happy, and he concentrates on his children's needs and their education.
As the oldest child, Marcie Ann helps her father care for the two younger children. Even though neither admits it, Marcie Ann is kind of a surrogate mother to her younger siblings.
"I don't want to happen to her what happened to me," Mr. Irizarry said. "I had to take care of my three younger brothers and sisters. I don't want that to happen to her. As long as she's happy, I'm fine."
Mr. Irizarry gives a lot of credit to single mothers. He says that single parenthood is a real job. "These are my kids. My mother's too old. My grandmother's too old. If I don't do it, who will?"

Contributions to the fund are deductible on Federal, state and city income taxes to the extent permitted by law.

HEADLINE: A Tight Race to Head the World Bank

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Three prominent Americans are angling to replace Lewis T. Preston as president of the World Bank. Mr. Preston, 68, disclosed this month that he has cancer, and he is widely expected to retire soon.
The principal contenders for the post, which has always been held by an American, are Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and a former chief economist at the World Bank; Stanley Fischer, also a former chief economist at the bank and now a deputy managing director at the International Monetary Fund, and James D. Wolfensohn, a New York investment banker who is chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. 
 Insiders at the World Bank say Mr. Wolfensohn, 61, has been campaigning actively for the job, promising additional cuts in the World Bank's large and well-paid staff. Mr. Preston has already announced a 12 percent reduction over the next two years in an effort to answer accusations that the bank is overstaffed.
Mr. Summers, 40, has a reputation for intellectual brilliance, but his manner can be abrasive. In 1992, when at the World Bank, he infuriated environmentalists by drafting a sarcastic internal memo arguing that because many developing countries are underpolluted, dirty industries should be encouraged to move to them. The memo was promptly leaked by staff members seeking to embarrass him.
Mr. Summers helped orchestrate the Clinton Adminstration's Mexican rescue package, which may have damaged his standing with members of Congress who opposed the measure.
While Congress has no formal role in choosing the World Bank president, the Administration is currently engaged in delicate negotiations with Congress over financing for the World Bank's International Development Agency. The I.D.A. is supported by taxpayer money from the aid-giving industrial world and provides inexpensive loans to the poorest developing nations.
The Administration is asking Congress to pay the last installment of America's $3.75 billion contribution to the 10th I.D.A. agreement -- worth a total of $18.5 billion -- which expires at the end of this year. It also hopes to win Congressional backing for an 11th agreement.
Mr. Fischer, 51, is the least known of the three. But he is highly respected as an economist and administrator.
The sudden rush to lay claim to the World Bank's top post -- which pays $190,000 a year plus a $90,000 expense allowance -- comes as the institution has been under sustained attack from a variety of critics.
Environmentalists accuse the World Bank of backing large development projects that create havoc with the balance of nature. Others doubt the efficacy of development aid in general. While a third school argues that the bank still prefers working with bureaucratic and often corrupt governments, rather than directly helping individuals in the private sector.
Last year, when the World Bank and the I.M.F. observed their 50th anniversaries with a joint ministerial meeting in Madrid, the critics tried to disrupt the celebrations with a protest campaign using the slogan "50 years is enough."
To secure a long period of stable management, officials of the bank say the Clinton Administration is looking for a president young enough to serve at least two five-year terms.
Mr. Preston and his two predecessors, Barber B. Conable Jr. and A. W. Clawson, each served a single term. The World Bank's previous head, Robert S. McNamara, served from 1968 to 1981.
The Administration had started looking for a World Bank president before Mr. Preston disclosed his illness on Feb. 1; Mr. Preston was scheduled to retire in 1996, before the end of the President's current term.
Mr. Preston has decided to appoint his deputy, Ernest Stern, as acting head. Although Mr. Stern had resigned from the bank before Mr. Preston's announcement, he agreed to stay on an extra month. He is joining J. P. Morgan, the big New York investment bank.
In the nearly three and a half years that Mr. Preston has led the bank, he has placed less emphasis on increasing the volume of lending to the developing world and more on improving the quality of the projects it finances.
In particular, he has emphasized lending for health, education, family planning and social issues, as well as for environmental protection and private-sector development. The World Bank has become the largest single source of external financing for AIDS programs in the developing world. Last year, it lent more than $2.4 billion for environmental safeguards in poorer countries.
The World Bank president is formally appointed by the representatives of its shareholder governments who sit on the executive board. By custom, however, the candidate is nominated by the executive director from the United States. All appointments have been by consensus and without a vote.
Under an informal agreement, the World Bank job goes to the United States and the directorship of the I.M.F. to Europe.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
The Mayor's Housecleaning: Past Deeds or Future Fears?

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
USUALLY, when a mayor dismisses people from their jobs, there is a tangible reason. A bridge collapsed. Or a budget wasn't balanced. Or someone was accused of malfeasance. What's so baffling about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's housecleaning is that there is no clear explanation of what most of the dozens of people dismissed did to attract his ire.
Some spokesmen were caught telling the truth, awkward as the truth may have been, and the Police Department's spokesman not only balked at trimming his staff but also burnished to a bright shine Police Commissioner William J. Bratton's image, which apparently did not please the Mayor. 
 But what wrongs did everyone else commit, exactly?
Answers to that question have been ambiguous at best, which suggests that the dismissals of about 40 people so far may reflect less about past deeds than the Mayor's fears of what is to come as he prepares to announce his latest budget.
THE economy is no better, spending cuts are getting deeper, the state and Federal governments are cutting, too, and city agencies are already suffering. The Mayor prides himself on being a good manager, but some of his agencies, including the Youth Services Department and the Human Resources Administration, are in disarray, and with a city budget gap of $2.7 billion, more may follow.
That has to have an impact. The poorest New Yorkers, so dependent on city services, tend to feel budget cuts immediately. The poor generally do not vote in large numbers, but members of the middle class do, and while it takes longer for service reductions to hit them, the cuts certainly will affect them by 1997 -- the Mayor's re-election year.
Under those circumstances, Mr. Giuliani's strategy looks increasingly like one that many of his predecessors favored in tough times. It is known as circling the wagons, making sure that city government, as much as possible, is made up of loyalists.
Right now, as the Mayor sees it, according to one adviser, "he's out there, he turns around and the whole team isn't behind him. Or, as the First Deputy Mayor, Peter J. Powers, said, "a lot of people are off agenda" -- meaning they are not sufficiently committed to shrinking government.
If some have dragged their heels, it is easy to understand why: the mission of people who work in city agencies is not to shrink government but to deliver services. That may not be as valid a premise today as it used to be, but it certainly was in what no w seems a different era, when Edward I. Koch, David N. Dinkins and Abraham D. Beame were Mayor.
Most of those who were dismissed joined government in those days. It is probably less a matter of ideology than one of human nature that some have been unenthusiastic about withholding or reducing services to people who need it, which is the impact most budget cuts have, despite the ubiquitous propagandizing about "streamlining" and "downsizing."
ACCORDING to one mayoral adviser, Mr. Giuliani wanted commissioners to make staff changes last fall. But, probably because the Mayor was distracted by his role in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's re-election campaign, the message was not delivered firmly, and the commissioners "were out there dawdling," the adviser said.
They are "dawdling" no longer because their choice comes down to following the Mayor's orders or, it would appear, leaving -- the intention speculated about Mr. Bratton. The Police Commissioner says he is staying for now, but whether he and other commissioners will tolerate City Hall's intervention in the long run is unclear.
Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines submitted his resignation last year, when the Mayor insisted that he dismiss his press secretary and budget director. But the Board of Education, which is not under the Mayor's direct control, supported Mr. Cortines and he stayed. So did his two appointees.
Mr. Giuliani does have the power to order any personnel changes he wants in non-Civil Service jobs. And getting tough with his own staff might help with the municipal labor unions, from whom the Mayor wants $600 million in concessions. But will the staff changes give him what he expects?
Certainly it cannot be difficult to reduce the number of public information officers in the Police Department -- now up to 38 -- and replace some police officers with civilian employees. Perhaps the Mayor will also reduce the size of his own press office, which, at 17 employees, is more than double the staff of 8 in that office during Mr. Koch's first term in the late 1970's.
But is it really likely, as the Mayor seems to think, that public information directors who are handpicked by City Hall can put a more positive light on the news in a town with such competitive news media? The events of the last few days raise an even more fundamental question: whether commissioners who have been denied the most elementary responsibility of office -- selecting their own staffs -- will be as enthusiastic about reinventing Mr. Giuliani's government as Mr. Giuliani is.
