HEADLINE: New York Striving to Become Technology's Creative Center

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
For years, New Yorkers watched passively as the San Francisco, Boston and Seattle areas became technological giants, building powerful high-tech industries that attracted the country's best technical minds.
But New York is a part of the latest technology wave. As a mecca for writers, graphic artists, musicians and film makers, it is poised to become one of the country's centers for the emerging multimedia industry, which combines visual and audio elements like animation, video and music to create films, CD-ROM's, television programming and virtual reality. 
 In recent months, membership in a New York group for people interested in these new media forms has mushroomed. Tiny companies are sprouting, mainly in downtown Manhattan, to cash in on the appetite for virtual reality, which uses interactive three-dimensional images, and CD-ROM's, souped-up compact disks that combine audio and video.
New York University has started a center devoted to these new media. Microsoft, the giant software company, is looking to set up a special office here to scout out these projects.
"The early phase of the evolution of multimedia was focused on developing the technology and infrastructure," said Chris Jones, a director of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit research organization. "Now, the ability to wire everyone is in place and the focus is shifting to developing the content. For that, you need artists, musicians and writers. That's where this area has a diversity of talent that is unmatched."
Recognizing this foundation for growth, city officials and major local corporations have been meeting to discuss ways to help turn New York into a bigger magnet.
The New York City Partnership, a business and civic group, has joined Nynex, Con Edison and the International Business Machines Corporation in an effort to open a multimedia incubator in a downtown Manhattan building. The 350,000-square-foot center will provide office space, equipment and conference and research facilities at a discount for about 150 emerging firms.
"What we're trying to do is create an environment and a facility that will make it more attractive for these companies to be here in the New York City area instead of going somewhere else," said Carl Symon, I.B.M.'s vice president and general manager for the northeastern region.
Another group, which includes Time Warner, McGraw-Hill and Forbes, has been meeting at I.B.M.'s midtown office each month since last summer, discussing ways to finance and build a base for new media companies in the area.
"Content is becoming king, and New York is where that content is developed," said Joseph Ripp, the chief financial officer for Time Inc. "We're discussing how do we start promoting that idea and how do we get venture capitalist to invest in this area."
For these big entertainment and communications firms, there is plenty at stake. Growth is slowing in traditional forms of media like publishing and broadcasting, leading companies to look to multimedia as a new avenue for expansion. With the advent of affordable digital technology, industry analysts estimate that about 60 million homes will have personal computers with CD-ROM drives by 1998.
While media companies already own major book, magazine and movie divisions, most lack the expertise to turn them into multimedia projects and thus are seeking the help of smaller new media companies that have these capabilities.
For example, Scholastic, the New York-based publisher of children's books, took its popular Magic School Bus series to Music Pen, a small New York new media company. Together, the two produced a CD-ROM titled "The Magic School Bus Explores the Human Body."
"The large companies bring brand recognition and consumer franchises to the party, and the smaller companies bring the technical skill and the understanding of how to mix it all together," said Brian T. Horey, a general partner at Lawrence, Smith and Horey, a New York venture capital firm interested in investing in new media companies.
New York is hardly expected to supplant Northern California's Silicon Valley or Boston's Route 128 as the nation's leading centers of high technology. But a growing multimedia industry is taking shape here. At New York University, for example, a Center for Digital Multimedia has been established with the help of a $1 million state grant.
The New York New Media Association, an organization of business owners, consultants, graphic artists, actors, musicians, lawyers and accountants, has grown from 8 members to more than 600 in less than six months.
And although its economic impact on the city is still unclear, the multimedia industry is certain to provide new avenues for the more than 800 companies that produce commercial software.
Not long ago, it would have been unheard of for a fledgling entrepreneur like Sandra Newton to leave the Silicon Valley for Manhattan. But at a Cybersuds, the term members of the new media association use for their meetings, Ms. Newton, a self-proclaimed "valley girl," explained why she just moved her multimedia consulting business from San Francisco to New York.
"I'm here to get artists wired," she said. "You know, New York is the place to start building a virtual community of artists."
Other evidence of the growth can be found in the number of major corporations, including the Sony Corporation and Microsoft, that are setting up divisions in the city to create and develop multimedia businesses. "Because music and book publishing companies are looking for ways to distribute their products interactively, I think you'll see more people coming in here," said Olaf Olafsson, president of Sony Electronic Publishing in New York. "There's a great talent pool in New York."
As part of Microsoft's multimedia developers group, employees in the office are seeking "to jump-start all the publishers and content owners into doing multimedia," said Frederic De Wulf, Microsoft's manager of new business.
But perhaps the most visible evidence of new media growth can be found in downtown Manhattan, where much of the city's creative community is concentrated. From the Flatiron district to TriBeCa and SoHo, dozens of new media entrepreneurs are hanging out shingles. In fact, so many are now situated in these neighborhoods that some in the business have taken to calling the area "Multimedia Gulch" and Business Week magazine dubbed it "Silicon Alley."
One such company, Music Pen, epitomizes the phenomenon. Founded by Yee-Ping Wu and Philip Lui, a couple who met while studying at the Juilliard School of Music, the company has grown from seven employees to 50 over the last year.
Inside Music Pen's sprawling loft overlooking Union Square, designers, writers, animators, producers, composers and technologists are working on some 15 new CD-ROM titles scheduled for release this year. Besides The Magic School Bus series, the company also is working on projects with Bertelsmann Music Group and Viacom New Media.
Reflecting the marriage of disciplines in the industry, Music Pen's offices are furnished with computer terminals, sound studios and a baby grand piano. "Back when I was performing as a concert pianist," said Mrs. Wu, the company's president, "if you had asked me if I thought I'd be in the technology business, I would have said you were crazy. "It's delightful to see that the future of technology has so much to do with creativity. In New York, you have a wide variety of culture, race and ability, and a wide variety of businesses. This is all making multimedia a part of the city."
Among other successful companies in the area, Byron Preiss Multimedia has produced numerous CD-ROM titles, including "The Seinfeld Screen Saver." And Curious Pictures, which uses digital technology to create television commercials, has combined live action, computer generated graphics and three-dimensional animation for products including Dannon yogurt and Taster's Choice coffee.
But despite New York's advantages, the idea of setting up shop in the city remains a daunting prospect for many new media outfits. They choose to locate elsewhere because of real estate prices, restrictive small business regulations, high taxes and quality-of-life concerns.
Skeptics say that initiatives like the multimedia incubator, the downtown Manhattan building expected to open later this year, will not provide nearly enough support to small new companies trying to get a foothold in a business environment as difficult as New York's.
"The city is not offering as many incentives or as much support as company's like ours with the potential for high growth need to survive here," said Wilbert Murdock, who operates two companies, Motiontronics for Sports Multimedia Inc. and Rap Multimedia Inc., from his home in the Bronx.
Mr. Murdock's companies are developing CD-ROM titles through a joint venture with I.B.M.
But city and corporate planners are hoping that The New York Information Technology Center, as the incubator will be called, will not only offer critical support, but will centralize the city's new media companies and serve as a focal point for the industry. "When people think of high-tech in other cities they think of specific areas, but New York multimedia doesn't have a center of gravity," said Edward Martino, an I.B.M. executive involved in the incubator project.
Project organizers won't divulge the address of the building because negotiations with the city on a tax abatement are holding up the lease and preventing tenants from being signed. The center is expected to house about 150 companies. "A large number of companies are interested in a center like this," Mr. Martino said. "This can be the latchkey needed to help them grow."

HEADLINE: Queens Man Shoots 3, Killing His Wife, Police Say

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A Queens man who relatives said had recently been released from prison shot his wife to death and wounded two other relatives yesterday in the couple's Far Rockaway home, the police said.
The man, Peter Garcia, 33, was arrested at the couple's home, at 541 Grassmere Terrace, by police officers who heard the shots. 
 His wife, Evelyn Garcia, 35, was pronounced dead at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Far Rockaway shortly after the 9:45 A.M. shooting, the police said. Her son, Michael Aliciea, 17, was shot in the face, and her nephew, David Aliciea, 19, was shot in the arm. Both teen-agers were listed in stable but guarded condition yesterday at St. John's, said Ilonia Mostel, a hospital spokeswoman.
Sgt. Francis Haimeck-Mladinich, a police spokeswoman, said the officers arrested Mr. Garcia as he was leaving the couple's house, and he was charged with murder and assault. While the officers were making the arrest, Mrs. Garcia's pit bull terrier attacked the officers, and they shot and killed the dog, Sergeant Haimeck-Mladinich said.
The police said it was not clear what led to the shootings. But Ms. Garcia's brother, Joe Aliciea, said that the couple had had a stormy relationship for more than four years and that Mr. Garcia had repeatedly threatened violence.
"She was going to tell him to leave," said Mr. Aliciea, who added that his sister had provided a home and financial support for Mr. Garcia, who was unemployed.
The couple's 3-year-old daughter, Venus, was not injured in the shooting.
Mr. Aliciea described Mr. Garcia as a large, muscular man who was released from prison about a month ago. He said Mr. Garcia had served a one-year sentence for ransacking Ms. Garcia's house and threatening the couple's infant daughter with a knife.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Dumb And Dumber

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
We are told that we are moving to a knowledge-based society. The future will belong to the individual and the country that can best make the transition from brawn to brain.
No one is more committed to that vision of the future, or more convincing in expounding it, than Newt Gingrich. So it is a puzzle when he also says that he wants to wipe out the most effective instrument we have for spreading knowledge of ourselves and our world. That is public broadcasting. 
 Destruction of public television and radio has been made a cause by many voices on the right. Over recent weeks the arguments have been heard with increasing intensity. They seem to me to miss the point.
It is said, for example, that we no longer need public broadcasting because there are so many commercial broadcast and cable outlets. The market will work best, giving the customers what they need.
Market theory has, happily, triumphed in economics around the world. But it is hard to believe that those who say it can work in broadcasting, giving us all we now get from public stations, really mean what they say.
What commercial network or channel would conceivably make the investment that public television did to create and broadcast nine hours on the Civil War? Yet those Ken Burns programs told more Americans more about a formative chapter in the nation's history than anything else has.
Then there is the strictly educational role of public television. On WNET, the New York-New Jersey public station, 60 percent of all programs are for schools or for children at home. WNET has 100,000 viewers a day who are learning to read or earning high school equivalency diplomas.
Commercial broadcasting at its best cannot be expected to perform such functions. They fill a public need, one especially compelling in a knowledge-based society.
But it is not just programs designated as educational that matter in public broadcasting. Bringing large audiences to Trollope or Dickens also does. And anyone who thinks commercial television in this country will undertake such ventures cannot have watched a great deal of it lately, with its Gresham's law of violence and greed and tabloid tittle-tattle.
To that kind of rationale for public broadcasting, the critics respond with cries of "elitism!" Why, they ask, should the public pay for programs watched only by a well-to-do elite in New York and Boston and San Francisco?
What condescension toward the American people that argument reveals. Eighty percent of all Americans watch public television at least once a month. It may be more widely used by the public than anything the Federal Government supports except interstate highways.
The point is that public broadcasting offers, or can offer, higher values to everyone, rich or poor, on the coasts or in Iowa (which has exceptional public stations). It is the very opposite of elitism.
In today's terms -- and tomorrow's -- public broadcasting is the equivalent of Andrew Carnegie's public libraries. It is open to all and offers all a chance to expand their minds and enrich their lives. And the Federal contribution costs each of us about $1 a year: one of the greatest bargains around.
The comparison with public libraries was made in a thoughtful column on the public broadcasting controversy by David Warsh of The Boston Globe. He went on to another intriguing point.
Conservatives like to talk about reviving Victorian values, Mr. Warsh said: morality, industry and the like. But it was also a Victorian project to spread culture and learning to the masses through libraries, museums, public education. Why would those who profess to admire the Victorians want to suppress today's great mechanism toward those ends? Why would they want to dumb the society down?
Of course public broadcasting does not reach the ideal. But it does some things well. National Public Radio provides the only in-depth news in this country that compares with the BBC In any event, if public broadcasting is less than it could be, improve it, don't kill it.
Underneath the critics' arguments, I think, is a premise that everything in America should be commercial. If that is the value the voices of the right are really asserting, they should say so. But somehow I do not think it is Speaker Gingrich's vision. Let us see what he does, in the end, about public broadcasting.

HEADLINE: Invest in Day Care

 BODY:
In 1991 more than half of American women with children under 6 worked. Many more would surely like to, and are surely destined to -- if the Administration and the states succeed in changing welfare by requiring recipients to commit themselves to education, training and jobs. Millions of American youngsters are spending, or will spend, several of their most formative years in the charge of strangers. They are going to be cheated -- because their country has yet to give day care the serious attention it deserves.
According to a recent study of hundreds of day care centers in California, Colorado, Connecticut and North Carolina, conducted by child psychologists and economists at four universities, the care provided by most is so poor it threatens the youngsters' emotional and intellectual development. As for the parents, 90 percent of whom rated the care as "good," they were sadly misinformed, either because they did not recognize quality care or did not demand it. 
 Where quality was high -- 1 out of 7 instances -- it was in centers that could pay higher wages for highly trained workers, and more of them. Invariably, such centers had access to money beyond parental fees from Federal or state governments, universities or employers providing on-site care.
Youngsters who have had high-quality day care, the study found, have better language, premathematical and social skills than those who have not and are better prepared for school. For too long the debate over day care has been centered on how best to help working mothers. It is well past time to shift the debate to how best to help their children.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Counter-Punch Strategy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When three White House speechwriters quit in disgust, unable to get access to or direction from the top man;
When the President is rightly treated as irrelevant after submitting a weak-kneed, punt-and-pray budget that helplessly runs up another trillion dollars in debt; 
 When his staff has to explain that his bonehead play to end the baseball strike failed at night and not during working hours -- then a good case can be made that we are witnessing the disintegration of this Presidency.
But it's too soon to write him off as a half-term President. To get an inkling of any strategy, grand or petit, to resuscitate the Clinton political fortunes, I went to the White House to see George Stephanopoulos, his loyal aide, who turned 34 years old that day. As a sign of his maturing humility, we dined in the declasse "B" Mess.
"From now on, you're going to see the Liberated Clinton," George said, determinedly optimistic. "We've got a good hammer in the Republican Contract."
But didn't Clinton's notion of campaigning as a liberal against the Gingrich Contract With America nationalize the local elections and backfire in the '94 campaign? His reply: "A flawed campaign strategy is not necessarily a flawed long-term strategy."
From his responses, and from other Clinton well-wishers less inclined to talk on the record, a pastiche of plans and hopes and guesses emerges that can generously be labeled the Clinton Comeback Strategy:
1. Concentrate on espousing "responsible" middle-class tax cuts that do not increase the deficit and boast of "cutting the deficit as a percentage of G.D.P." Negotiate tolerable welfare reform, some health fixes and at year's end come up with one hot new Topic X.
2. Do the gutsy "unpopular thing" by resisting the anti-government thrust; use the veto, as in defending the popular portions of the crime bill. Hit the conservative disentitlement brigade as "weak on work, tough on kids" and use Republican majority excesses as a foil.
3. Press foreign economic policy to generate jobs; though stupefyingly dull and unpopular, it shows leadership, as in the Mexican bailout, and drives a wedge between Republican internationalists and isolationists.
4. Exploit the new majority's mistakes: for example, tie G.O.P. regulatory reform to fat-cat contributors, undermining Republican populist appeal.
This is the politics of centrist counterpunching. George makes no bones about it: "Whoever gets to the middle first, and holds it, is the winner." No wonder speechwriters like liberal David Kusnet took flight (literary agents take note). Clintonites who experienced the angry voter reaction to their lurch to the left now pray the Republicans will veer far to the right.
Arguments supporting counterpunch strategy:
1. In Clinton's first two years, necessary compromises hurt his profile as a leader, but next year the media focus will be more on Presidential effort than on legislative results.
2. He will not be responsible for every act of Congress, can sharpshoot at failures and -- most important -- lay blame for any economic downturn on Republicans.
3. The G.O.P. candidates must hit the campaign trail early in '95, while Clinton can seem to wait a year, making their actions look politically motivated and his look Presidential.
4. The nature of popularity's pendulum is to swing: "Six months ago, Bob Dole was Darth Vader and now he's Mr. Rogers," says George, answering those who think Clinton's problems will get worse before they get worst.
Clintonites used to pretend they most feared Dan Quayle, in the hope of encouraging a nomination triumph of the far right. In reality, most worry most about California Gov. Pete Wilson, because "that puts the mother lode in peril," but doubt he'll be chosen. They see the new, genial Dole as a problem; Phil Gramm less so; Lamar Alexander more so. Newt Gingrich? "We should be so lucky."
The idea is to present Clinton in 1996 as possessing the energy of youth combined with the experience of the Presidency -- "the safe choice."
Sounds bizarre; ignores the looming Whitewater and Tyson investigations; precludes more staff appointment foul-ups or a Mexican standoff; relies on a third party splitting the Republican vote.
But no old Nixon hand will say they never come back.

HEADLINE: ELITE HOSPITALS OF NEW YORK CITY IN FINANCIAL BIND

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
New York's elite medical centers are facing their worst financial crisis in decades, caught between newly powerful health maintenance organizations demanding deep discounts and state and Federal legislators planning to cut millions of dollars in hospital payments to balance budgets.
Some of these teaching hospitals may not survive the decade, health-industry analysts say, and those that do will emerge transformed: from ivory tower institutions focused on research, training and high-priced specialty care to vast health-care networks whose main task is to provide cost-conscious basic medicine, a pursuit that many have performed only as an afterthought -- and then grudgingly. 
 Already, they are scrambling to reshape themselves for leaner days: closing departments, training fewer specialists and hiring less-skilled labor to replace nurses and doctors. At Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, officials are thinking about reducing services to the poor. At Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, some nurses are being replaced by nurses' aides.
But some hospital executives worry that this overnight transformation, under threat of bankruptcy, will result in a dangerous deterioration of care for the poor, as well as a local recession caused by huge layoffs in an industry that is the city's largest employer.
"We've just gone through a period of expense reduction and cut $50 million from our budget, so there's not a lot of fat," said William Speck, president of Columbia-Presbyterian, which lost $22 million in 1993 and, after a cost-cutting campaign, only $2 million in 1994.
He said the hospital was contemplating curtailing psychiatric and dental services to the poor, if these are not covered after Medicaid cuts. Some private hospitals are now considering whether their uninsured patients should instead be stabilized and transferred to public hospitals.
Hospitals also worry that they will have to curtail the basic research that has sustained their reputations and brought the world new drugs and cancer cures. "Research will have to be self-supporting to be preserved," said Dr. Spencer Forman, president of Montefiore Medical Center, who added that research doctors would probably have to see more patients in hospital clinics to underwrite their research time. Such pressures have already caused some longtime scientists to close their laboratories.
New York's academic hospitals have long teetered on the brink of insolvency, due in part to the state's tight regulation of fees, which guaranteed survival but made it hard to flourish. Severely limited in how much they could charge patients with conventional insurance, they have relied on generous payments and subsidies from government insurers, as well as a state fund to underwrite charity care and to pay for unprofitable activities like teaching. This system is under attack.
The growth of local H.M.O.'s, which demand and receive hugely discounted fees, is already hurting revenues. Now, newly elected state and Federal legislators plan to reduce vast channels of money from Medicare and Medicaid, which cover two-thirds of patients at hospitals like Columbia-Presbyterian.
"We are in assault mode, caught in the crossfire of demands for reductions from Albany, reductions from Washington and a market that demands discounts," Dr. Forman said.
Administrators who spoke last year about preserving their academic health centers are now figuring out how to revamp them, focusing instead on survival in any form.
All the hospitals are cutting costs and aggressively expanding their primary-care capacity for paying patients, ignoring for the moment the specialty departments -- the liver transplant teams and the cardiac intensive care units -- on which their august reputations rest. New research is now more likely to focus on how to deliver care more efficiently than on basic science, with test tubes and petri dishes.
Mount Sinai Medical Center, which finished 1994 with a surplus of only $200,000, plans to borrow $100 million to put 400 new front-line doctors in satellite clinics across the area. It needs to transform itself from an "academic health science center to a regional, accessible, cost-competitive health care system," said Dr. John Rowe, the center's president. He said that the medical centers would probably have to rely more heavily on drug companies to support basic science.
To prepare for the squeeze, the New York Hospital Care Network is combining departments at its 13 member hospitals so that specialized services like radiation treatment will be closed at some hospitals and offered only at certain sites.
"Survival is going to be the name of the game for a while," said Dr. David Skinner, president and chief executive of New York Hospital.
The upheaval is all the more traumatic because it has taken the hospitals by surprise. Just six months ago, hospital presidents were easing gently into the world of managed care, anticipating some form of universal coverage as well as subsidies for teaching under a national health plan. They spent many hours and thousands of dollars lobbying for changes in President Clinton's health-care proposal, arguing that they needed more money, and persuaded legislators like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan to revoke their support of the Clinton plan. The strategy backfired, as all plans for health-care revision evaporated.
"The academic medical centers did what doctors did and what businesses did: They fought about details," said Dr. Raymond J. Baxter, senior vice president of Lewin-VHI, a health-care consulting firm based in Fairfax, Va. "No one anticipated that in doing so they would lose the whole game."
New York hospitals are already among the weakest financially in the nation, with bond ratings so poor that most are unable to borrow on the open market. Eighty percent of the hospital bonds insured by the Federal Housing Administration, a Government guarantee program for high-risk borrowers, are for hospitals in New York State. Sixty percent of the bonds are those of hospitals in New York City.
While hospitals around the country average surpluses close to 5 percent, successful hospitals in the city generally finish each year with surpluses far less than 1 percent -- often only several hundred thousand dollars -- and some perennially fail to meet their budgets.
Their financial trouble results in part from the large number of poor and uninsured patients they serve, as well as their extremely high overhead, since they emphasize research and rely on patient revenues to help finance classrooms and labs.
Although many of these hospitals have endowments and receive millions of dollars in private insurance money, they depend heavily on a variety of public funds: payments for patient treatment from Medicaid and Medicare, as well as millions of dollars in educational grants from Medicare, supposedly to compensate them for training new doctors. Those with large numbers of nonpaying patients also receive millions of dollars from the state's so-called bad debt and charity pool, created from a surcharge on all patient care in which the relatively rich hospitals shore up their poorer counterparts.
Through this intricate system, regulators assured that hospitals in the city could accomplish the sometimes incompatible tasks of producing world class research and ministering to the poor and uninsured who walk through an emergency room door. Neither mission is likely to remain unchanged.
For one thing, the fees from paying patients are dropping fast because of growing H.M.O. enrollment in New York, which is expected to surpass 25 percent this year. H.M.O.'s negotiate with hospitals for discounts, which are growing deeper. Hospital executives say they have agreed to huge bargains for fear that the H.M.O.'s, who control hundreds of thousands of patients, will take their business elsewhere.
"The bargaining has been so aggressive that the Medicare rate, which once was the floor for what we could charge, is now the ceiling," said Dr. Forman.
All of New York's academic centers are scurrying to put together networks of doctors and services to offer to H.M.O.'s. But it has not been easy for the distinguished academics who run New York's premier medical centers to bow to the business requirements of the newly powerful buyers.
"Managed care is looking for the lowest possible price in the market," said James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, a research and philanthropic group. "They are not concerned about whether a hospital covered the uninsured and how well it serves its community."
On top of that, public funds -- both Medicare and Medicaid -- are almost certain to plummet within the next two years.
The new proposed state budget includes Medicaid cuts to hospitals estimated at more than a billion dollars. Beyond that, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani hopes to trim Medicaid reimbursements even more. Hospitals find the state cuts particularly galling because they come from Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey, who only last year, as an analyst with the Manhattan Institute, was the darling of the medical community for her detailed criticism of the Clinton plan.
Medicaid payments are the lifeblood of many of the city's hospitals, where 25 percent to 75 percent of patients are covered by this form of insurance. The proposed cuts could cost Montefiore $17 million, Mount Sinai $10 million and Columbia-Presbyterian $20 million, leaving all three institutions millions of dollars in debt. After intensive restructuring and cost-cutting, Montefiore finished 1994 with a surplus of $6 million, Mount Sinai with a surplus of $200,000 and Columbia-Presbyterian with a loss of $2 million.
Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said that such cuts would result in widespread closings and "layoffs the scope of which we've never seen before."
Within the next two years, most health policy experts expect cuts of hundreds of millions of dollars in Medicare grants for education as well, a loss that will affect hospitals in New York far more than those elsewhere.
New York hospitals train 15 percent of the nation's doctors and receive well over $100,000 each year per resident for that pursuit. In theory, these payments are supposed to compensate the hospital for costs associated with teaching: call rooms for sleeping, extra blood tests that might be ordered for teaching purposes, a slightly slower pace of an operation so that an experienced surgeon might explain his technique.
But in practice, doctors in training at urban hospitals today more than pay for themselves, providing extraordinarily cheap labor in clinics, wards and emergency rooms. And many health-industry experts say that the Medicare educational payments have become yet another indirect subsidy to prop up hospitals that serve the poor and uninsured. Columbia-Presbyterian receives $60 million in Medicare payments related to education; Mount Sinai $40 million.
"The risk in a marked reduction of teaching dollars is not that teaching will stop; it's that the institution will have to close," said Dr. Forman of Montefiore. "Maybe you are giving us enough to train residents, maybe you aren't. But if you take $30 million or $40 million out of these institutions, they are in trouble."

HEADLINE: Clinton Intervenes to Help Revive Stalled Mideast Peace Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton stepped into the stalled Middle East talks today to try to give them new momentum as Palestinian leaders promised strong new efforts to crack down on terrorism against Israel.
There were no breakthroughs, but modest steps were taken to resuscitate peace efforts, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said. 
 Mr. Clinton met today in Washington with the Foreign Ministers of Egypt, Israel and Jordan and a senior Palestinian diplomat. At the meeting, Israel and the Palestinian Authority agreed to set up industrial zones in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to provide more jobs for Palestinians. They also vowed to negotiate promptly an accord that would redeploy Israeli troops in the West Bank and allow Palestinian elections to proceed.
Administration officials said that Palestinians got the message more emphatically than ever that greater self-rule was contingent on combating terrorism.
Before talks began at Blair House, Mr. Clinton told reporters: "It is no secret to anyone in the world that we are in a critical moment in the peace process. We cannot allow the rise of terror again to threaten this peace."
In a statement issued by Mr. Christopher, the Palestinians committed themselves to "preempting terror, punishing those responsible and denying those who plan and carry out terror or violence any safe haven." The peace talks have been stalled since Jan. 22, when a suicide bombing in Israel claimed 21 lives.
Much of today's talks sought to show the Palestinian people that peace efforts would bring tangible benefits. The major announcement was the creation of two Israeli-Palestinian industrial zones in Gaza and four in the West Bank. Mr. Clinton said he would ask Congress for authority to make imports from those zones duty-free, to encourage investment and create markets.
American officials said they would seek to do the same if Egypt, Jordan and Israel decided to set up a joint industrial zone near the Gulf of Aqaba.
"It is clear that we have to bring some economic benefits of peace as quickly as we possibly can," Mr. Clinton said. "And the United States is prepared to do its part."
In their communique, the United States and the four Middle East participants said they would "do all they could to support the conclusion of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process."
Speaking with uncharacteristic emotion, Mr. Christopher said it was crucial for the peace process not to fall short of its goals. "Despite all the difficulties, the parties know that there is no turning back," he said. "This is irreversible. Conditions have been changed permanently in the region, and the parties must measure up to their responsibilities."
Those responsibilities, officials said, included an end to the border closings that have kept 50,000 Palestinians from their jobs in Israel.
At a news conference after the meeting, Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, said: "We ought to make sure the Palestinian Authority will try to do what it has undertaken to do to prevent terror. We don't ask for 100 percent success, but we ask for a clear effort -- a visible, convincing effort that they are really trying to stop terror."
The negotiators also sought to address Egypt's concerns that Israel had nuclear bombs and was refusing to sign the Nucleaer Nonproliferation Treaty. In the communique issued here, Israel and Egypt agreed, in vague terms, "to pursue a mutually verifiable Middle East zone free of weapons of mass destruction, nuclear, chemical and biological."

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Mental Health

 BODY:
Depite Budgetary pressure and community opposition, group homes and community residences for the mentally ill have mushroomed as states have moved people out of large psychiatric hospitals. The deinstitutionalization has proceeded despite the difficulty of providing sevices for the mentally ill in their communities. It is more economical to keep a patient in a group home, which typically houses a dozen residents and has a 24-hour-staff, costing New York State about $35,000 a year, compared with $120,000 a year for hospitalization. Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget has alarmed advocates for the mantally ill, as it cuts community mental health programs while accelerating the release of patients from state hospitals.

HEADLINE: Russians and Chechens Agree to Truce and P.O.W. Trade

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Russian and Chechen commanders agreed today on a cease-fire and an exchange of prisoners in the civil war in Chechnya, with more talks scheduled for Wednesday, the day before the Russian President makes an important speech to Parliament.
The overall Russian commander, Col. Gen. Anatoly Kulikov of the Interior Ministry forces, met for five hours today with the Chechen chief of staff, Col. Aslan Maskhadov, at the airport in the small town of Sleptsovsk, in Ingushetia. The Russian Army commander, Gen. Anatoly Kvashnin, and the Ingush Vice President, Boris Agapov, also attended the talks. 
 There was no indication of how long the cease-fire might last or how extensive it might be. As a gesture, General Kulikov ordered an immediate halt to the use of heavy artillery by Russian forces in Chechnya, the semi-official Itar-Tass news agency reported, though doubtless the order will take time to relay. And there was no immediate indication that regular Russian bombing raids would stop.
"During the first stage of negotiations, an agreement was reached on a mutual cease-fire concerning heavy weapons," the Russian Government Press Service confirmed tonight, implying that further talks would try to broaden the truce.
"The sun is showing us that it is time to start sowing," General Kulikov told Russian television, referring to a still-distant spring. He seemed to imply that the time for wreaking destruction may be past, and that Russia felt strong enough to enter real peace talks with the Chechens, who have put up fierce resistance to the more than 40,000 Russian troops trying to crush a three-year-old Chechen claim to independence.
A Defense Ministry spokesman said, "The first steps have been made toward achieving mutual understanding."
President Boris N. Yeltsin is preparing a major report about Chechnya that he is to deliver to a joint session of Parliament on Thursday. He has announced that the operation in Chechnya is moving into a new, less-warlike phase of pacification by Interior Ministry troops, and it is likely that he wants a cease-fire in effect when he gives his speech.
Western nations like the United States have been urging Mr. Yeltsin to negotiate over Chechnya. The Americans have pushed him at least to make an offer to the Chechen side, senior diplomats said.
In the speech, Mr. Yeltsin is expected to make a "critical assessment of the military approach" to Chechnya, Kremlin officials told Interfax, which may mean trouble for the beleaguered Defense and Security Ministers, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev and Valentin N. Stepashin.
Mr. Yeltsin is also expected to repeat his commitment to economic reform and announce measures to curb inflation better, Kremlin officials say, another indication that he is trying to move beyond the Chechnya issue and reassure the West that Russia remains an eager partner.
The West and its fiduciary agent, the International Monetary Fund, are contemplating a vital $6.25 billion loan to Russia, but want to be assured that Moscow has a serious plan for economic stabilization and sharply lower inflation, which reached a year-long high of 17.8 percent in January.
Parliament, for instance, recently approved a near tripling of the minimum wage, on which many pension and other payments are based, that would blow a big hole in the budget. Mr. Yeltsin may announce that he will veto the measure.
At the cease-fire talks, the Chechen commander, Colonel Maskhadov, stressed that he had been empowered by the Chechen leader, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, to discuss "exclusively military issues," like a prisoner exchange and a cease-fire to collect and bury bodies.
The Russian Government has said it will not negotiate with Mr. Dudayev, only arrest him as a "state criminal." Moscow has said it would negotiate with individual Chechen commanders, however, to get them to lay down their weapons.
Colonel Maskhadov, who moved the Chechen military headquarters out of the wrecked capital, Grozny, last week, has promised a long partisan war against Russian forces. Many Chechen fighters fill villages near Grozny and are harassing Russian troops in the central city itself with hit-and-run raids and sniping.
The new Russian-appointed leadership of Chechnya has postponed its move to Grozny, but may try to implant itself there this week.
Mr. Yeltsin is eager to turn the war over to the Interior Ministry, a step that is important in Russian eyes because using the army domestically is unpopular here. But army troops will remain until they take the Chechen strongholds of Gudermes, Shali and Argun, Interfax said. There is no chance that those towns can be taken without the use of artillery and air power.
The last cease-fire, in early January, while Russian troops were struggling to take the presidential palace in Grozny, lasted two hours instead of the scheduled 48.

HEADLINE: Texas Joins Parade of States Colliding With Clean Air Act

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Early last month, Texas began a program to help reduce smog by 15 percent in its biggest cities. Auto-exhaust inspections were to be required during the next two years for nearly every car and truck in the Houston and Dallas areas. If Texas did not clean up the air, it stood to lose hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal money.
The state signed a contract with a company that invested $127 million in private money to set up test stations. "The skies of Texas are upon you," proclaimed bright blue billboards, informing motorists of the new $23-a-car inspections. 
 Then the testing began. A revolt ensued. And now the program is on hold.
It is the same firestorm that has swept through several other states in recent months as the wrath of motorists has combined with a wave of anti-Federal Government sentiment in state capitals to form a potent challenge to the Federal Clean Air Act, the most comprehensive environmental legislation ever enacted.
Some governors and other state leaders argue that in the controversy lie the seeds of a new approach to environmental regulation, in which states will be given far more flexibility to design ways of meeting Federal pollution standards. And indeed a middle way may emerge. But for now, even as the inspection programs are running smoothly in half a dozen states, in many more they are stalled.
In the most thorough tests, the ones that have been strongly preferred by the Environmental Protection Agency, cars are put on treadmill devices, dynamometers. The exhaust and fuel systems are then tested at a variety of engine speeds. When the equipment is working as designed, the test takes only a few minutes.
Although about 80 percent of all cars on the road pass -- that is, meet the standards imposed for a given model year -- the ones that fail can cost their owners anywhere from $50 for a tuneup to hundreds of dollars for major repairs.
In Texas, the uprising against the new inspection program was swift. Newspapers and television news programs were full of reports featuring motorists objecting to the cost or inconvenience of the tests, or both. State lawmakers said they were deluged with complaints. And many drivers said they would refuse to take the tests altogether.
Within days of the program's kickoff, the Legislature rushed to pass a three-month moratorium, which became the first measure the state's new Governor, George W. Bush, signed into law. Several legislators said they hoped the Republican-controlled Congress would amend the Clean Air Act to make the tests unnecessary or, at most, voluntary.
In Maine, intended to be a kind of pilot project for the emissions tests, the program begun last summer has collapsed. In Pennsylvania, the Legislature voted to delay its inspection program late last year, and when Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat who has since left office, vetoed the measure, it promptly overrode him.
In Virginia, Gov. George F. Allen, a Republican, recently sued to block the E.P.A. from enforcing any provisions of the Clean Air Act, including a testing program. And Gov. Pete Wilson of California, also a Republican, railed against major elements of the Clean Air Act at a Congressional hearing late last week.
"We're the ones who breathe our air," Mr. Wilson said, "not the Federal bureaucrats in Washington."
The Clean Air Act also requires reformulated gasoline, a cleaner-burning fuel blend, in most major metropolitan areas, but Pennsylvania has pulled 28 counties out of that program, and New York and Maine are considering withdrawing several counties each.
The open rebellion in Texas and elsewhere against the tests has become a major headache for the Clinton Administration, which has been under relentless pressure to grant delays in the emissions program.
The E.P.A.'s Administrator, Carol M. Browner, has granted delays to several states, including New Jersey and New York. Connecticut's program is operating without major complaints.
The E.P.A.'s approval is required for all pollution reduction programs, and Ms. Browner said she is happy to work with states to make testing procedures, and subsequent repairs for cars that fail, more convenient. But she is adamantly opposed to amending the pollution-reduction goals in the Clean Air Act.
"I do not think the standards should be weakened," Ms. Browner said in a telephone interview. "And I do not think the timeliness should be changed. The American people were told they would have clean air. We are making significant progress in that direction."
Still, if states simply refuse to carry out the tests, the Clinton Administration could be in the awkward position of having to impose sanctions under the Clean Air Act -- including withholding huge chunks of highway transportation aid -- at the end of next year, around the time of the Presidential election.
On the other hand, the emissions program could get a political boost from an unexpected source. A provision of the Republicans' Contract With America calls for the Federal Government to find the most cost-effective way to carry out its programs. When it comes to cleaning up the air, there is probably no cheaper way to do it than by fixing people's cars.
Removing smog-causing pollutants from the air costs roughly $500 a ton through a vehicle-emissions program. Removing pollutants from industrial smokestacks costs anywhere from $2,000 to $10,000 a ton, according to E.P.A. figures.
Ms. Browner said that despite a 24 percent reduction in air pollution since the 1970's, 2 out of 5 Americans live in areas that do not meet the air quality standards set by the act.
"We have protected millions of Americans from cancer, heart disease and premature death," she told a House Commerce subcommittee last week. "But more still needs to be done."
The E.P.A. has long favored centralized inspections, arguing that they are both more accurate and less prone to fraud than tests at neighborhood service stations. And most tests at neighborhood stations cannot measure nitrogen oxides, which together with hydrocarbons and sunlight form ozone at ground level. Pollution from cars can be a major lung irritant, especially among children and the elderly, and can inhibit blood circulation.
The tests were to be required in all or parts of roughly half of the states, including almost all of the Northeast. But centralized testing centers proved irritating to motorists, especially in states like Texas, where people whose cars failed were subject to what lawmakers and bureaucrats call "the Ping-Pong effect" -- having to go elsewhere for repairs and then return to inspection stations for a sticker.
Some governors and lawmakers say the clean-air standards are too onerous and should be changed. Still, in Texas and elsewhere, many lawmakers who supported testing moratoriums insist they want to use the time to set up more palatable testing programs.
State Senator John Whitmire, a Democrat from Houston who was the chief sponsor of the moratorium, said Texas ought to create "one-stop" centers where drivers could get emissions and safety inspections and renew registrations.
"What we want, obviously, is a plan that is user-friendly, that will address our clean-air concerns, but not on the basis of inconveniencing the public to the point that they do not support the program," Mr. Whitmire said.
Proposals in other states include "cash for clunkers," in which the government would pay people to trade in old cars. But there are two problems: first, it is not clear just how many miles such cars are actually driven, and second, the programs risk being excoriated as government handouts.
Still, there is logic to the approach: about 15 percent of the cars on the road cause up to 80 percent of the pollution.
The city of Sacramento, Calif., recently completed a four-mouth trial of a promising new technology known as remote sensing. Inspectors hold a device that resembles a radar gun to measure the exhaust of cars passing on the street. Cars that pollute excessively can be pulled over by the police, or a violation notice can be mailed to an address traced through the license-plate number.
The virtue of such a program is that it does not inconvenience the majority of drivers with cleaner cars; the drawback is that the technology is expensive and relatively untested.
Winston Harrington, a senior fellow and economist at Resources for the Future, a nonpartisan environmental research group in Washington, said car inspections and repairs were a sound approach to reducing pollution.
"We're looking in the right place," he said. "It's just that we haven't figured out the best way to do this."

HEADLINE: Health Costs Paid by Employers Drop for First Time in a Decade

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Medical costs paid by employers, which had been rising as much as 18 percent annually in recent years, fell last year for the first time in a decade. A decline of 1.1 percent for companies with at least 10 workers was reported yesterday by a widely followed annual survey.
Economists attributed the decline to the growing number of employees covered by cost-conscious health plans that try to eliminate unnecessary tests and procedures and negotiate lower fees with doctors and hospitals. 
 These economists said that by the Labor Department's measure, prices for such services as hospital rooms, doctor fees and X-rays still increased by nearly 5 percent last year, almost double the general rate of inflation. But employers' health costs have declined because they are simply using fewer of those services. For instance, cataract eye surgery no longer requires a hospital stay and is now typically done less expensively at walk-in clinics.
Employers' medical costs have been rising more slowly in the last few years than in the late 1980's, but not until yesterday's report was there evidence of an actual decline. Indicating that the trend might be gaining steam, a separate survey found that health maintenance organizations had lowered their 1995 premium rates, on average, by 1.3 percent.
But the employer cost survey said the declines were most often registered by large employers -- those with more than 500 people -- which cover two-thirds of all insured workers. Taken alone, smaller employers, which have been slower to turn to cost-conscious health plans, reported an increase of 6.5 percent in their medical costs.
Hospitals and doctors may be making up some of their losses when they reduce their fees for large employers by raising charges to smaller concerns.
Some companies are shifting part of their costs to workers by requiring them to reach into their pockets and pay a larger share of their medical bills.
Henry J. Aaron, direct of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, the Washington research center, said the lower employer costs could result from "offloading costs onto employees or curtailing their coverage." But David Rahill of Foster Higgins, the New York benefits consulting firm that conducted the survey, said it "didn't see much evidence of either massive cost-shifting to employees or decreases in coverage."
According to the survey of 2,097 employers, the percentage of employees and their families who were enrolled in the managed care plans jumped to 63 percent last year from 52 percent the year before.
Representatives of business said the survey's results showed they were on the right track last year in helping to defeat the Clinton health plan on the ground that the marketplace was already working to restrain medical costs. They also said that the Medicare program, which is expected to have cost increases of 9 percent annually to 2000, was still generally lacking in the kind of cost-sensitive approaches that businesses had adopted.
The survey results were "really good news," said Helen Darling, a health care economist at the Xerox Corporation, which has moved 73 percent of its employees into health maintenance organizations. She said the company's main H.M.O.'s had reduced their charges by 1.9 percent for 1995.
Mr. Rahill, a principal at Foster Higgins, said, "This is a good year for employers to be pushing for price rollbacks, especially from the H.M.O.'s" and other health plans that had big enrollment increases.
Several economists said the results were an important development, but they warned that the upward climb in costs might resume when the savings from the big switch to managed care plans were absorbed.
"Once everybody is in managed care, are you going to see a pattern of everybody's costs moving up again?" asked Stuart H. Butler, a vice president of the Heritage Foundation, the conservative research group in Washington.
Uwe E. Reinhardt a health economist at Princeton University, said, "Very few economists would bet their marbles on this being a permanent trend."
Spokesmen for small businesses said the survey did not deal with the problems of thousands of companies with fewer than 10 employees. Many of these companies dropped health insurance for their workers as prices rose. The number of working-age people without insurance rose by 6.5 million in four years to 40.9 million in 1993, according to the Employee Benefits Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington.
"The survey doesn't indicate that there are fewer small firms with health care today," Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, said. He has been lobbying Congress to authorize nationwide voluntary employer groups that could buy health care on the same terms as big companies.
Mr. Faris's federation and the United States Chamber of Commerce, which has both large and small employers as members, are also seeking reinstatement of a tax break for medical insurance for small businesses that Congress allowed to expire.
The Foster Higgins survey showed that the average cost of health benefits declined to $3,741 for an employee in 1994, from $3,781 in 1993. Employees with traditional fee-for-service insurance declined to 37 percent from 48 percent. Those enrolled in health maintenance organizations, which typically assign each member to a primary care doctor who must approve tests and referrals to specialists, rose to 23 percent from 19 percent.
Those surveyed were chosen to reflect the working population, so the results are valid for 550,000 employers with 68 million employees, Foster Higgins said. In earlier surveys, the firm simply polled a large group of big companies, mainly its own customers.
H.M.O. enrollment was swelled by "a significant number of retirees" for the first time, particularly in the West, where health maintenance organizations are strong, Mr. Rahill said. Jon Gabel, research director of the Group Health Association of America, a Washington trade group for health maintenance organizations that conducted a survey of H.M.O.'s in November, said 50 million Americans now had H.M.O. coverage, up from 41.4 million at the start of 1993.

HEADLINE: Latest Endangered Species: Natural Habitats of America

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
In the first full review of the health of the American landscape, a new Federal study has concluded that vast stretches of formerly vibrant natural habitat, once amounting to at least half the area of the 48 contiguous states, have declined to the point of endangerment.
Although the plight of individual species has been the focus of public interest, the health of the larger interconnected community of plants, animals and microbes of which they are a part -- the ecosystem, nature's functional unit -- is perhaps more important as a gauge of vitality. 
 The new report finds that scores of ecosystems, of widely varying types and sizes, have declined on a grand but largely unappreciated scale. If the remnants should vanish, say the study's authors, species adapted to them would probably vanish as well.
Thirty of the imperiled ecosystems, including some that dominated and characterized whole regions before Europeans first landed in America, have declined over more than 98 percent of their area and are considered "critically endangered," the study found. Decline was defined as destruction of a natural area, conversion of the area to other land uses -- agriculture, for example -- or "significant degradation" of ecological character or function.
"We're not just losing single species here and there, we're losing entire assemblages of species and their habitats," said Dr. Reed F. Noss, one of three biologists who conducted the study for the National Biological Service, a research organization created within the Interior Department by Secretary Bruce Babbitt in 1993. The study is to be issued by the agency within a month.
"The time is ripe for a concerted effort to identify and protect ecosystems across the United States," the authors wrote. They suggest that conservation plans be developed for each ecosystem by region, "starting with types and regions that sustained the greatest losses and are at greatest risk of further loss."
The study's findings have important implications for Federal policy at a time when laws dealing with conservation, particularly the Endangered Species Act, are under challenge by property-rights advocates and their conservative allies who now control Congress.
The concept of protecting whole ecosystems, rather than single endangered species, which is being increasingly emphasized by conservationists, is embodied in a number of laws governing Federal lands and in several public-private conservation efforts. It has also been promoted by Mr. Babbitt as the Clinton Administration's central strategy for keeping species off the endangered list while accommodating private economic interests.
But the concept is under sharp attack by conservatives who see it as a threat to private property and also fear that the mere act of identifying habitats to be protected may reduce property values.
"We can bury our heads in the sand and say we don't want to be well informed on these issues, or we can say we want to be well informed and have a database that gives us a logical rationale for making decisions," said Dr. J. Michael Scott, an author of the study who is a research biologist with the National Biological Survey. The third researcher, also from the survey, was Dr. Edward T. LaRoe 3d, who died recently.
Among the largest imperiled ecosystems, the study found, are the tallgrass prairies and oak savannas that characterized most of the Midwest before Europeans came to America, along with the original deciduous forests of the Eastern United States and more than 60 million acres of longleaf pine forests that formerly blanketed much of the Southeastern coastal plain. All of these, according to the study, are among the 30 such communities considered critically endangered.
Fifty-eight such areas have declined by 85 to 98 percent and are classed as "endangered," the study says, while 38 others have declined by 70 to 84 percent and are listed as "threatened." The 126 imperiled areas are concentrated most heavily in the eastern half of the country.
As is commonly done by ecologists, the report's authors conceived of ecosystems as relating to each other in hierarchical fashion, with smaller systems existing as elements of larger ones. In this formulation, the global biosphere is at the top of the hierarchy.
Two of the larger types of critically endangered American systems, the Midwestern prairie-savanna and the Eastern forest, together probably covered about 40 percent of the country before Europeans arrived, according to Dr. Scott.
Critically endangered systems toward the smaller end of the scale include localized ecological communities, usually named after their dominant feature as, for example, the Hempstead Plains grasslands on Long Island, the wet coastal prairies in Louisiana, sedge meadows in Wisconsin, lake sand beaches in Vermont, native grasslands in California and streams in the Mississippi alluvial plain.
Some ecosystems, like the Midwestern grasslands, have nearly been destroyed, in this case by conversion to agriculture. Others, like the oak savannas, have suffered what the report defines as degradation. This includes, for example, the suppression of fire, which many ecosystems historically depended on for their biological character and variety. Without periodic clearing by fire, a few invasive foreign species often take over an ecosystem and choke out the original and more numerous array of native plant species.
Still other areas, like the longleaf pine ecosystem, have suffered both types of decline: great swatches have been cut down, and most of the rest has been transformed by fire suppression from pine forests into hardwood stands.
The report's conclusions were based on an extensive, yearlong survey of the scientific literature, of conservation agencies and professionals and of databases maintained by the states. The survey sought to determine first what percentage of a given ecosystem had survived relatively intact; the remainder was judged to be either destroyed, degraded or both. The authors acknowledge that the data are incomplete and of "highly variable quality," that much more research lies ahead, that some of their findings should be treated as hypotheses for further investigation and that their report is not the final answer.
Still, the study, which was reviewed for scientific validity by scientists whose identity was unknown to the authors, represents the first known effort to pull together existing data and provide a continent-wide profile of the health of the natural landscape. And despite "uncertainties and unevenness in the data," the authors wrote in their report, the information "portrays a striking picture of endangerment." The documented unraveling and shrinkage of natural systems, said Dr. Scott, offers a preliminary answer to people who have questioned whether the country's natural assets are really in jeopardy.
Although much of the American landscape may look lush and green, the authors say, this is in many cases deceiving. While it is encouraging that forest cover is increasing in many parts of the Eastern United States, they say, second-growth forests may take centuries to regain their biological richness. The tree plantations that are common in many parts of the country are "structurally and biologically less diverse than natural forests of any age and contain impoverished faunas," the study report says. Replacing an old-growth forest with a tree plantation, it says, causes changes so severe that it qualifies as an absolute loss of habitat.
As ecosystems shrink and unravel, the authors say, the species adapted to them become increasingly imperiled as well. The longleaf pine ecosystem of the Southern coastal plain, for instance, is now home to 27 species on the Federal endangered list and another 99 proposed for listing.
Protection need not be restricted to pristine areas, the authors say. Indeed, they say, degraded but restorable areas may warrant more attention than those that have suffered less severe losses and are not faced with an immediate threat.
In determining which deserve priority, the authors argue, the extent of decline and the seriousness of the threat ought to take precedence over rarity as such. Instead, they wrote, conservation agencies "often focus on the curiosities" -- small, peripheral types of ecological communities, like bogs left behind by the ice age, that have never been numerous and are not facing any special threat.
Many conservation biologists advocate preserving substantial examples of remaining ecosystems as the most efficient strategy for saving as many plant, animal and microbial species as possible. They argue that this will protect many relatively common species that might otherwise become endangered, including many tiny organisms that are now unknown. At the same time, many conservationists see focusing on a relatively large area as the best way to arrange trade-offs between conservation and development.
"You need not declare an ecosystem totally off limits," Dr. Noss said. But in light of the findings about endangerment, he said, the burden of proof ought to be on developers to demonstrate that their activities will not be harmful.
Early in his tenure, Secretary Babbitt endorsed the holistic strategy based on an ecosystem approach. It quickly fell afoul of the property-rights movement, however, which had many allies on both sides of the aisle even before the Republicans won control of Congress in November. The property-rights movement has attacked the National Biological Survey as well, and Mr. Babbitt was forced to create the organization administratively when Congressional approval could not be obtained.
Those issues have not gone away, and indeed promise to resurface strongly as Congress confronts reorganization of the Endangered Species Act later this year.

HEADLINE: Urging Dose of 'Reality Therapy,' Giuliani Sets New Round of Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Saying the city's fiscal problems required a dose of "reality therapy," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani told New Yorkers yesterday evening that he would reduce city spending for a second year in a row and cut public assistance and health care for the city's poorest residents.
Although he offered few details in a brief televised address, Mr. Giuliani said the preliminary budget that he is to unveil today would wrench $600 million in savings, or 7 percent, from the city's agencies, and ask the city's unions to agree to an additional $600 million in concessions on benefits and work rules in exchange for a pledge to avert layoffs. 
 The cuts are expected to touch virtually every municipal service, but the deepest reductions will fall on the city's Board of Education. The Mayor's plan, officials said yesterday, will propose $290 million in new cuts to the board, nearly 9 percent of the city's $3.3 billion contribution to the board's overall budget, which totaled $7.7 billion last year. The officials said the Mayor would also look to the powerful teachers' union for $190 million of the union concessions.
In his address, Mr. Giuliani said that the city still faced a projected $2.7 billion budget gap for the fiscal year that begins in July, in spite of the austerity steps taken last year to reduce spending and cut the city's payroll by nearly 20,000 workers by the end of this fiscal year. And the city, he said, could no longer turn to the state and Federal governments for help.
"We must confront the reality that we cannot continue spending substantially more money than other American cities," he said in the address, which was broadcast live on local television and radio stations. "We must confront the reality that the city's fiscal problems will not be solved by Albany or Washington."
While not asking for new aid, Mr. Giuliani called on Gov. George E. Pataki to go further to reduce spending on welfare and Medicaid than the $1.9 billion in reductions Mr. Pataki has proposed. Since the city must match state spending on those programs, more cuts by the state would further ease the city's fiscal crunch.
Sounding the conservative theme he has repeated ever since Mr. Pataki swept into office after a campaign in which the Mayor supported Mr. Pataki's Democratic opponent, Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Giuliani said that he and the Governor shared a belief that spending on welfare and Medicaid needed to be cut. He called for eliminating overly generous benefits, fighting fraudulent claims and making able-bodied welfare recipients work.
In all, Mr. Giuliani's plan will include $1.2 billion in cuts to these "entitlement" programs, $400 million more than the city's estimated savings under the Governor's budget proposal. Even with the cuts, the Mayor said the city and state would still provide among the most generous benefits for the poor in the nation. "We really have no other choice," the Mayor said of cuts in those programs.
The Mayor's preliminary budget represents only the first step toward producing a budget for the 1996 fiscal year that begins in July, serving merely as a broad plan for balancing the city's budget. Many of its proposals -- particularly those in the area of Medicaid -- could face fierce resistance from Democrats on the City Council and from advocacy groups.
Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that the Mayor's cuts in education and the concession he seeks from her union members would hurt the system that teaches the city's one million schoolchildren.
"It's hard to see how the system is going to take this cut with another 25,000 additional students coming in," Ms. Feldman said. "We understand the city has big problems, but this would be terrible for education."
Even as he continues to cut spending, the Mayor also said he would move ahead with the tax cuts he first outlined last year -- mentioning specifically an elimination of the city's 4.25 percent sales tax on clothing that costs less than $100 -- as a way to stimulate the economy. That reduction would cost the city $98 million in revenue next year.
Officials also said the Mayor would begin to phase in cuts in property taxes on co-ops and condos, which now pay much higher taxes than single-family homes, totaling $70 million a year. For the owner of an average $200,000 co-op, the Mayor's proposal would save about $180 a year, officials estimated.
In all, the Mayor will propose tax cuts of $184 million, more than the $35 million in hotel and business taxes he cut last year, but modest compared to the deep cuts in income taxes proposed by the Governor.
The Mayor did not specify how he would achieve the $600 million in spending cuts to the city's myriad agencies on top of roughly $2 billion in reductions over the last year. But he did say he would ask his commissioners "to reduce the size of the city's management staff as much as they can and to embrace modern management techniques of doing more with less."
The Mayor's preliminary budget is also expected to move ahead with proposals to restructure municipal government, cutting still more jobs, consolidating smaller agencies and turning more services over to private companies.
Among the proposals, officials said yesterday, the Mayor will propose merging the construction divisions of many agencies into one capital construction agency and combining several smaller economic development agencies, moves intended to eliminate dozens of duplicative administrative jobs.
Before his televised address, the Mayor delivered essentially the same message of austerity in Albany. His appearance before the joint fiscal committees of the Legislature underscored the importance of the state's budget to the Mayor's plans, even if Mr. Giuliani did not call for new aid.
During his testimony, he repeatedly praised Mr. Pataki's budget as beneficial to the city because of the reductions in welfare and Medicaid, which account for roughly 17 percent of the city's spending.
"I see this crisis as a historic opportunity," the Mayor said of the projected deficits bedeviling the city and state budgets. "It is a chance to do what was politically unthinkable just a few years ago."
While most lawmakers treated the Mayor's proposals respectfully, State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Democrat from Manhattan, signaled the potential opposition Mr. Giuliani could face in his efforts to win even deeper cuts in from Albany.
"Frankly, I'm a bit confounded because this is one of the only times that I've been here and a mayor has come and he hasn't asked New York State for more direct assistance," Mr. Leichter said. "Frankly, I think you could have urged that the state budget be fairer to the City of New York."
The City Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, also appeared in Albany yesterday and, in contrast to the Mayor, warned that the Governor's cuts in education, reimbursements for hospitals and money for the mentally ill would hurt the city and belonged in a category of "cuts that don't make sense."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries' Prices Mixed; Trading Thin

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in thin trading, as investors worried that economic reports this week would show that the Federal Reserve had not raised interest rates enough to reduce the threat of inflation.
Few traders were active ahead of today's report on retail sales for January; that report could set the direction of interest rates for the next few days. Among the other data due, are reports tomorrow on consumer prices, industrial production and capacity utilization. 
 The price of the 30-year bond inched up 1/32 , to 9918/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 7.66 percent, from 7.67 percent on Friday. Short-maturity bills were mixed, as the Treasury held its regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills.
Dealers said the average rate at auction for a new three-month issue dropped 1 basis point, to 5.82 percent, while the average for a six-month bill rose 5 basis points, to 6.15 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The bond market may be paying particular attention to January retail sales, traders said, because they may be one of the first indications that the economy may be changing direction.
January retail sales are expected to rise three-tenths of 1 percent, or six-tenths of 1 percent excluding autos. December sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent and were unchanged when autos were excluded.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, noted that the retail number for November showed a significant downward revision, giving market participants the impression the economy was slowing.
He said the numbers in November and December might have overstated any weakness in retail sales.
"My feeling is that this number will show a small increase for January, but forecasts of January retail sales have been made more difficult because of the lack of confidence that most economists have about the December figure," Mr. Fine said. "As a result, the market may well pay as much attention to the December revision as it will to the January estimate."
The Consumer Price Index will be out tomorrow, and while it is a lagging indicator, its importance is measured by its effect on inflation expectations.
Another source of market concern yesterday, but not a chief one, was the strength of the dollar and how it might be affected by the Mexican Government's military action against the rebels in Chiapas. Supply was another, as some of the $40 billion in new securities auctioned last week have still not been distributed, and consequently many dealers are holding more than they would like.
In addition there is the $500 million global bond offering that the Federal National Mortgage Association plans to sell, competing with government securities for investor interest.
In the municipal bond market so far this year, demand coupled with fewer available new issues, has helped tax-exempt issues outperform benchmark government bonds. Tax-exempt yields as measured by the Bond Buyer's municipal bond index of 40 issues had fallen 37 basis points, to 6.55 percent yesterday, while the yield on the Treasury long bond had fallen only 21 basis points.
Some of the deals due this week that are more than $250 million include the New York State Thruway Authority and Texas Public Finance Authority.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-and six-month bills:
