HEADLINE: Despite Tough Battle, Fiscal Recovery Is Still Eluding Giuliani

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office 14 months ago, he set out to solve, once and for all, the city's underlying financial problems, whose resolution had eluded his successor, David N. Dinkins, for four years.
He prepared a budget last spring that eliminated a projected gap of $2.3 billion. When major holes opened in that plan, he imposed more than $1 billion in additional cuts and related savings. 
 He slashed 14,000 jobs from the city payroll, or about 7 percent. He consolidated some agencies. He pressed municipal labor unions for productivity measures and other concessions to make the work force more efficient.
But after all that, as he begins the long process of enacting a budget for the next fiscal year, which begins in July, Mr. Giuliani still finds himself facing a gap estimated at $2.7 billion -- $400 million higher than a year ago.
Financial experts say there are many reasons that the Mayor needs to tighten the screws further, despite a year of aggressive actions intended to curb the fiscal distress that has plagued the city since late 1989.
Foremost, perhaps, is that a brief recovery in the local economy dissipated almost as quickly as it began, leaving Mr. Giuliani and his aides scrambling to offset tax revenues that came in lower than anticipated. A sustained local recovery would have made it far easier to balance next year's budget.
But it was not just a decline in revenues that burdened the Mayor. The areas of city spending that increased most rapidly during the Dinkins administration -- debt service, Medicaid and municipal workers' fringe benefits, particularly health care -- continued to grow under Mr. Giuliani.
The continued growth of those three areas may ultimately offset most of the savings Mr. Giuliani achieved in his first year, some fiscal experts contend. Removing 14,000 jobs from the city work force, for example, could save as much as $700 million a year, when benefits and salaries are taken into account.
But the cost of benefits for the remaining 200,000 city workers in the next fiscal year is likely to grow by more than $700 million, said Jeffrey L. Sommer, acting executive director of the Financial Control Board, the state agency that monitors the city budget.
"It solves your budget problems in a given year," Mr. Sommer said of the Mayor's job cuts. "But it doesn't solve next year's growth in benefits."
Similarly, Mr. Sommer said, the city's debt service continues to grow, in part because Mayor Edward I. Koch, Mr. Dinkins and even Mr. Giuliani sometimes solved short-term problems by refinancing city debt. Debt service accounts for about 13 percent of all city tax revenues in the current fiscal year, Mr. Sommer said. In the next fiscal year, 18 percent of city tax revenues will go for debt service, he said.
"That 5 percent is a big cause of the new gap that they have to close," Mr. Sommer said. "That's why it keeps popping up."
When Mr. Giuliani and the leaders of the City Council begin this spring to debate the final shape of the budget for the next fiscal year, it will mark the fifth year of continual fiscal distress. It is a quiet fiscal crisis, compared with the the city's collapse of the mid-1970's. Then, New York was nearly forced into bankruptcy when it was unable to pay almost $800 million in short-term notes.
Dangling on the precipice, city officials discovered that their bookkeeping had been so sloppy that it was impossible to gauge the exact extent of the deficit. Investors lost confidence, and the city lost access to the financial markets.
By that measure, the current fiscal distress is relatively tame, several budget experts said. But that does not guarantee that its impact on services might not also be severe.
About 60,000 city workers lost their jobs at the height of the fiscal crisis, including thousands of police officers. Tuition was imposed for the first time in the City University.
This time, after five years of budget cutting, the effect on municipal services has been noticeable, but for many residents not so severe. But as the budget gaps get larger -- and the Mayor's options diminish -- the impact could grow sharply in coming months.
In this crisis, unlike the one 20 years ago, the city does not have partners in Albany and Washington to whom it can turn for a bailout. In the 1970's, the state government was in relatively sound financial condition, and Gov. Hugh L. Carey made the city a high priority.
He created two state agencies, the Financial Control Board and the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to help the city get a better handle on its financial condition and to instill confidence in the financial markets. He led a state takeover of several major city services, including the court system and the four-year colleges of the City University.
The Federal Government also helped with loan guarantees that which bought time for the city to install new accounting and fiscal monitoring systems, to trim its expenses and to pay back its short-term debt.
But this time, neither the Republican-controlled Congress nor Gov. George E. Pataki appear willing, or able, to help Mr. Giuliani with new aid. Mr. Pataki faces a budget gap even larger than the Mayor's: $5 billion, including about $1 billion for a promised reduction in state income tax rates.
The major assistance that Mr. Pataki and the Congressional Republicans are offering Mr. Giuliani is relief from spending required by Albany and Washington, especially on Medicaid and welfare. But it is unclear whether that would produce substantial long-term savings for the city, enabling it to eliminate the underlying budget deficit -- or whether it would seriously harm the local economy by throwing out of work thousands of hospital and social service workers, while also depriving the poor of health care.
The Mayor is likely to continue to shrink the size of the city's work force, and many fiscal experts say he also must figure out how to make the remaining workers more productive.
"Rudy Giuliani gets high marks for reducing the size of the government," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit fiscal monitor. "But I don't think you can give him high marks yet for making the government more productive."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Reporter's Notebook;
For Car Dealers, Familiar Medicine

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 13

 BODY:
It may be of some comfort to anyone who has ever bought a car that few people fall for a sales pitch as easily as auto dealers do.
"They're fish," said Jim Edwards, a Ford dealer from Louisville, Ohio. "The easiest mark in the world is salespeople, because they're unable to stand the pressure." 
 Mr. Edwards had just succumbed to a blistering sales pitch, buying a Little Giant Ladder -- "One Ladder Does It All" -- for only $349 (with freight charges and two, count 'em, two free accessories thrown in), at the annual National Automobile Dealers Association Convention here.
About 6,000 dealers and sales managers -- and some 12,000 family members, exhibitors, and assorted auto groupies -- are gathered here for four days to celebrate a banner 1994, share anxieties about an uncertain 1995 and fall for the occasional offer from one of the more than 440 exhibits of car washing machines, car lifts, screwdrivers, advertising strategies, canopies, license plate garnishes and, of course, ladders.
A record number of salespeople were flogging products to the nation's premier salespeople, amazing even some experienced attendees.
"There are even companies that take off the parts that we put on cars to put on other parts, and you kind of wonder what it's all about," said John F. Smith, Jr., president and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, who addressed the dealers on Saturday.
 
From Chrysler, Ceviche
 Because almost all auto dealers made money in 1994, there has been considerable celebration here. Perhaps the most elaborate party was given at a downtown hotel by the Chrysler Corporation.
In the lobby, one woman in a red tafetta-esque gown strummed the harp, while another played the organ, warbling "Don't Cry for Me, Argentina" and other favorites. At the door, a man with a fox skin on his head and a rifle in his hands introduced himself as Davy Crockett, while other actors in period dress portrayed other notable Texans.
Inside, as an 11-piece band blared and neon cactuses glowed, hundreds of dealers visited the free bars and gobbled shrimp, ceviche, salmon and tamales.
"Thank the Lord, Chrysler products have been well received," said Jim Rutledge, a dealer from Hampton, S.C.
 
Of Sales and Pitches
 But how long will the good times last? Far more pessimistic than the domestic auto makers, the auto dealers' association predicts that 1995 will be the last strong year of this recovery. Tom Webb, the economist for the association, said here that car and light-truck sales would rise by less than 3 percent this year, to 15.4 million.
"I'm guaranteeing that this year is going to be good," Mr. Webb said. "I'm not guaranteeing that next year will be good."
All auto sales are local, so dealers have widely varying opinions about the state of the business. Dealers in southern Texas are worried about the devaluation of the Mexican peso, while northern dealers are worried about the cold snap.
Most remain optimistic, however. "The sky is not falling, Chicken Little," said Patrick Tynan, a Denver dealer who sells Isuzu, Volkswagen, Kia and Nissan vehicles.
But they share one worry. "Everybody lives in fear of added interest rate increases," said Keith E. Crain, publisher of Automotive News, a trade weekly, who uses the convention to study dealers' views. But, he said, "the attitudes are bullish."
Mr. Crain paused, then added, "That's the ultimate ladder," nodding across the aisle to the Little Giant Ladder exhibit. "But I feel like I'm watching a Veg-O-Matic demonstration."
Steven W. Steenblik, the slightly sweaty salesman, was balanced atop one of his products, showing a cluster of rapt dealers the way it enabled him to reach more than 14 feet in the air.
With one day left in the show, Mr. Steenblik, of Wing Enterprises in Springville, Utah, said he had sold 36 ladders for an average of $400 each. "Entice 'em, get 'em on the ladder and ask for their order," Mr. Steenblik said, summarizing his technique.
Mr. Steenblik had some of the best training imaginable for his job. He put himself through college selling Chryslers and Saabs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Car dealers looked at a Romanian sport utility vehicle on Sunday at the annual National Automobile Dealers Association Convention in Dallas. The four-day convention attracted about 6,000 dealers and sales managers -- and some 12,000 exhibitors and auto groupies. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Mr. Yeltsin's Health

 BODY:
No one in Russia understands the power of political imagery better than President Boris Yeltsin, who consolidated his leadership when he helped stop the August 1991 coup by standing on a tank and urging his countrymen to resist the attempted takeover. That makes his stumbling appearance last Friday at a meeting in Kazakhstan with the leaders of 12 former Soviet republics all the more shocking and puzzling.
At a moment when his presidency has been badly shaken by the brutal Russian attack on Chechnya, Mr. Yeltsin wobbled across the sidewalk in the Kazakh capital of Almaty, desperately gripping aides for support. His face was puffy and sallow. Before canceling a later news conference, he attempted to answer questions at a photo session and was barely able to speak. These scenes were filmed by Associated Press Television, but not broadcast on the main Russian television news. 
 After years of dodging questions about his health and his drinking, Mr. Yeltsin owes his country and the world a candid accounting. The performance in Almaty moves the issue beyond the discreet conversation of diplomats, because Mr. Yeltsin's ability to govern Russia is now in question.
Russia, which has been moving into a more democratic and open era, seems eerily similar to the pre-Gorbachev Soviet Union when the faltering health of three consecutive Communist Party leaders -- Leonid Brezhnew, Yuri Andropov and Konstantin Chernenko -- was considered a state secret.
Mr. Yeltsin has complained of a bad back, and may be on medication to ease the pain. He reported a "physical breakdown" in 1987 when he was hospitalized after a confrontation with Mikhail Gorbachev that led to his dismissal from the Politburo. Supporters say Mr. Yeltsin has a low tolerance for alcohol and can disable himself for days with an evening of heavy drinking. The last sign of trouble came in the fall when Mr. Yeltsin snubbed Irish leaders waiting to greet him during a refueling stop in Ireland. Aides said he had overslept.
Whatever the problem, or combination of problems, Mr. Yeltsin cannot expect to retain authority when he seems incapacitated and offers no explanation. Moscow's political culture, beginning long before the Bolsheviks, has not been kind to wounded leaders, and even in this more democratic day the piranhas will strike swiftly. Hiding the truth about Mr. Yeltsin's health will only increase the chances for plotting and instability.
For the United States, the International Monetary Fund and others considering expanded financial assistance for Russia, Mr. Yeltsin's behavior can only encourage doubts about the condition of a developing democracy where something as critical as the health of the president is cloaked by his staff. If Mr. Yeltsin remains committed to untangling Russia from its authoritarian past, he and his doctors must quickly come clean.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Little Change As Batch of Data Is Awaited

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday as dealers anticipated that this week's economic reports would show signs of accelerating inflation, hurting American stocks and bonds.
The dollar slipped against the yen as Japanese exporters sold dollars and bought yen to bring money home before the end of the Japanese fiscal year on March 31, traders and analysts said. In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 98.72 yen from 98.93 on Friday. 
 In early trading, the dollar fell to 1.5161 German marks, its lowest level since Feb. 2. The dollar later recovered to 1.5212 marks, up from 1.5192 on Friday. The dollar edged up to 1.2855 Swiss francs from 1.2820. The British pound slipped to $1.5625 from $1.5630.
The currency market's concern about inflation revived after the producer price report for January, released on Friday, showed a 1 percent rise in raw materials and semifinished goods, sending bond prices lower.
Dealers said yesterday that they were expecting more clues about inflation from a spate of economic numbers due this week, including January retail sales figures today and the consumer price report tomorrow.
"Everyone will look at the bond market to see which way it's going, and then the dollar will probably follow," said Jim Raphael, currency trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City.
But more signs of inflation could also reignite speculation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again soon, currency traders and analysts said. Higher rates often help the dollar by making interest-bearing deposits in the United States more attractive, but in recent weeks currency traders have been focusing on the possibility of higher inflation and how that would be bad for bonds.
Dollar sales by Japanese exporters depressed the dollar against the yen yesterday, traders said. The exporters earn money in dollars, which they must sell for yen when they send revenue home.
Japan runs a $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States, leaving its exporters with a hoard of dollars to exchange for yen.
In each of the last two years, the dollar has declined against the yen during February and March because of the repatriation of funds, said Joe Francomano, a trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in New York.
"There's nothing you can put your finger on that's going to help the dollar against the yen with repatriation looming," he said.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Huskies' Men Join Women as Leaders of the Pack

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
More than two decades after the passage of Title IX called upon universities to provide equivalent athletic opportunities for women, Connecticut created an unprecedented form of equality yesterday: two teams in the same place, from the same place.
The Connecticut men (19-1), one day after their emotionally taxing victory at Syracuse, were voted No. 1 in the Associated Press news media poll and the CNN/ USA Today coaches' poll for the first time. The women's team (21-0) retained the top spot it has held for a month with its victory at Seton Hall. 
 The surprise is not that it happened, but that the same school had never appeared at the top of both lists since the first women's poll 19 years ago. Not at Chapel Hill, where North Carolina's women's team won the 1994 national collegiate championship and the men won their tournament the year before. Not at U.C.L.A., where the dynastic achievements of the men overshadowed outstanding female athletes. Not at Virginia or North Carolina State or Iowa, where the accomplishments of the women have built upon the traditions established by the men.
"It's rarefied air," said Dee Rowe, a special adviser for athletics at Connecticut, the men's basketball coach from 1969 to 1977 and a part of the Storrs campus for 26 years. "It's stratospheric. I don't know that I'm a wordsmith, but it is stratospheric."
And yet the response to the accomplishment was muffled by the absence of either team on campus during Sunday afternoon, and perhaps by the tasks to come. A part of campus that has been the scene of spontaneous bonfires in the past was reportedly quiet on Sunday, and gathering places, while crowded and loud, were not unusually crazy.
"They were excited," said Sean Scraba, an owner of Huskies, a bar and restaurant on the Storrs campus. "But I don't think you'll see anything until Tuesday night. People kind of go on their merry way. Maybe kids are more civilized these days."
The women's team, which learned of the victory at Syracuse before the trip home from Seton Hall, did not practice yesterday and players were unavailable. "It's almost like it was expected," said Geno Auriemma, the coach of the women's team. "It's like they thought: 'Of course we're going to win. Of course they're going to be No. 1.' It wasn't: 'Can you believe what happened?' It hasn't been that way at all."
Or maybe the status of Storrs as the center of the basketball universe, while temporarily directing attention away from the state's economic problems, could not obscure the immediate task of the men.
The game tonight between Connecticut and Georgetown at Landover, Md., will mark the third time in 11 days that the nation's top-ranked men's team appears in the Washington area. The last two games caused the No. 1 teams to forfeit their ranking, following the Massachusetts loss at George Washington on Feb. 5 and North Carolina's defeat at Maryland a week ago tonight.
On Sunday evening, as the Huskies traveled south following their victory at the Carrier Dome, the meeting with Georgetown was a challenge for some other day. "I'm not sure we needed wings to get from Syracuse to Washington," Jim Calhoun, the men's coach, told reporters before practice yesterday. "The flight didn't seem bumpy. The food was great. People slept wonderfully.
"Somehow, an hour-and-20-minute flight seemed to take 50 minutes. If we lost, it would have seemed to be over two hours. It was just a special night."
Last night, the Huskies planned a private tour of the White House, an experience that will make fans nervous even if the plans began long before the No. 1 ranking took shape. If the White House is normally a destination that follows a championship season, so is Disney World, where the team rested during spring vacation last year on the way to Miami for a regional semifinal loss to Florida.
Even if a loss to Georgetown could cause the Huskies to become another disposable No. 1 team, the longtime followers of the program could appreciate being there. Decades before the bright campus arena, the sellout crowds for men and women and the command of the Big East conference, New England's best teams were usually considered less worthy than established powers from traditional leagues.
Rowe remembered his senior year of high school, 1947, when Holy Cross won the national championship at the old Madison Square Garden and the train station at Worcester, Mass., became the scene for an unforgettable celebration. Now comes a season in which Massachusetts and Connecticut have taken their turns at No. 1.
"If you've never been there," Rowe said, "and Connecticut has never been there, to be No. 1, it's very special. It's a great accomplishment, even if you're just queen for the day. Nobody in my neighborhood has been there."

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Empty Stadiums, but Very Full Coffers

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
Hooray for public financing of baseball stadiums!
Three cheers for lotteries and wine, booze, cigarette, hotel and sales taxes! Without 'em, Oriole Park at Camden Yards, Jacobs Field, The Ballpark at Arlington, Coors Field and Comiskey Park would not exist. And without 'em, they wouldn't pay for themselves, even during the baseball strike. 
 The philosophy behind municipalities bankrolling new stadiums is not to rely on the revenues from team rent or other ball park revenues, but to have cities and states issue bonds that are paid off via taxes or a lottery.
What makes this method of financing so alluring is that the public keeps paying when there are no fannies in the seats, in the off season or during a strike. The taxes will even keep flowing during replacement baseball.
Public financing does not judge the quality of play. Even if the fans will.
And while there will be fans or legislators who will squawk that taxes keep paying for stadiums shuttered by a strike, the relatively painless forms of taxes (and lotteries) will probably keep any rebellion at bay.
"If this goes on a lot longer, I can envision people saying, 'We won't support this,' " said Robert Baade, an economics professor at Lake Forest College in Illinois and a critic of public spending on sports facilities. "But getting governments to turn things back won't happen very easily."
If not for the dollars guaranteed by taxes and lotteries, the stadium bond issues would not exist. Rent or other stadium revenues are far from enough.
"We don't have to worry about bond failures," said Bruce Hoffman, the executive director of the Maryland Stadium Authority, operator of Camden Yards.
"The effect of the strike doesn't affect our ability to service our bonds," said John McMichael, the vice president of business operations for the Texas Rangers, who moved into The Ballpark last year. The $135 million bond issue that provided most of The Ballpark's backing comes from a half-cent sales tax. Each year, the cost of paying, or servicing, the debt is $11 million. Tax collections for the past year are running at $15 million.
And the sales tax keeps paying and paying and paying.
The biggest problem caused by the strike is that, games or no games, the Rangers must pay the city its annual rent of $3.5 million a year. But it's not so bad. Player salaries and operating costs are way down, too.
"It's a burden, but the rent was important for our financing," McMichael said. "It affects our cash flow, but not the financing of the ball park."
To run Chicago's Comiskey Park, the state provides the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority with $18 million a year for maintenance costs and debt service on $150 million in bonds. Proceeds from a 2 percent hotel tax, enacted to finance the stadium, provides $8 million; $5 million, each, comes from the state and Chicago. No rent from the White Sox is needed to pay the debt.
Because the strike reduced the White Sox's payments to the authority from $2.6 million in 1993 to $912,670 in 1994, however, the state will get a smaller rebate.
Last week, three Illinois legislators who are upset over the strike threatened to cut off the hotel tax to help force a settlement. But the stadium authority said that cutting off the tax would only hurt its ability to send the state a surplus.
At Cleveland's Jacobs Field, "sin taxes" on alcohol, wine and cigarettes back the $117 million in stadium bonds that financed the bulk of construction.
Of $16 million collected in taxes, $10 million went last year to pay debt on the bonds. Another $1.4 million went to pay the debt on a bank loan, and the rest went to pay debt on the stadium's sister facility, the Gund Arena.
Of course, sin taxes are strike-resistant because people drink and smoke regardless of the state of Donald Fehr and John Harrington's relations. Collections have fallen a bit over the past two years because people are smoking less, said Tom Chema, executive director of the Gateway Economic Development Corporation, which operates Jacobs Field and the Gund Arena.
Although the strike slashed the Indians' rent payment by about $1.1 million, to $3 million, the shortfall did not harm Jacobs Field rent payments. It did give Gateway the chance to pay off some debt on the Gund Arena, however.
There are no financing woes in Baltimore. The Orioles paid only $7.5 million in rent, below the expected $10 million. But the $20 million needed to cover debt service and operating costs at Camden Yards were more than covered by rent, other stadium revenues and a whopping $26.7 million raised by instant lottery sales. Surplus revenues go toward financing a football stadium.
"We can do without any rent from the Orioles," said Hoffman.
Has the strike had an impact on the credit worthiness of the stadium bonds? Hardly, said Mitchell Zietz, senior management consultant for Public Financial Management, a Philadelphia financial firm, said: "All it does is make credit analysts sharpen their pencils a bit and say, 'What if?' "
Sam Katz, a prominent consultant on stadium financing, said: "Although an element of risk that's a little more real now, the rationale for public financing of sports facilities will continue to overwhelm the criticism."
That, of course, is a 900-word lesson in why George M. Steinbrenner 3d has never offered to spend his own money to get himself a new stadium for the Yankees.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Quoth the Audience, 'Nevermore'

BYLINE: By AMY M. SPINDLER 

 BODY:
By the final, frigid day of the New York men's fashion collections last Wednesday, audiences no longer looked as if they were taking notes on the clothes on the runway. Rather, they might have been composing their own personalized versions of Edgar Allan Poe's "The Raven." Never has fashion presented a vision as dark, dreary, weak and weary as this one for men for fall 1995.
What was most significant in this uninspired group of almost 30 shows, produced for the first time under the auspices of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, was that the drabness seemed completely unintended. There was no coded message about a treacherous economy nor any new resolve to blend in with the concrete city landscape. As comforting as such rationales may be, it seems the designers used fashion week mainly to show the clothes that men already wear, with no coherent vision of what men should be wearing. 
 The shows operated heedless of headline news that even the International Business Machines Corporation is no longer "suiting" its employees. They operated in flagrant disregard of an emerging body consciousness among men, who, like women, look bulky in draped clothes and heavy fabrics. Ignoring the less commercial fashion directions from Europe, the shows offered no fashion direction of their own.
Which was why Ralph Lauren's off-the-runway vision -- a solid, impeccably fitted suit hugging the shoulders and nipped at the waist -- drew such raves from viewers. Mr. Lauren's newest suit, which he modeled himself in his showroom, is the antithesis of a languid, loose Italian one: it enhances the upper body, chiseling it. Mr. Lauren said that even if I.B.M. was retiring the suit, men would still want to look powerful, an effect his suit provided. Under a new purple Ralph Lauren label, the suits will run $2,000 and will be tailored in stores.
What Mr. Lauren has in common with the other two designers in the New York triumvirate, Donna Karan and Calvin Klein, is that he has succeeded in creating a Ken for his Barbie. A woman who wears these designers' clothes will want her man to wear the counterpart collection.
Ms. Karan's men's show was, like her women's collections, for aspirational New Yorkers. If the stereotypical New Yorker wears black, so did her models. Her collection was cool and subtle, with models in shades, and colors to match -- black leather peacoats, black shirts with dark ties under suits, sharp black double-breasted suits with bright white shirts beneath, all ready to be photographed for a moody New York movie. It was also one of the few shows with sex appeal: perhaps Ms. Karan understands best how women want to see their men.
Mr. Klein's men looked as if they had been shot from a petroleum-jelly-coated vacuum tube. Their hair was straight and plastered to their heads (think Marcia Brady), their clothes stripped of all excess. The only color was an occasional slash of a jazzman-thin tie, in a burgundy he called "bloodstone." As with his women's collection, the strength was in the subtraction. But there was a sadder quality to these clothes, like the dress of the poet who wanders the world asking, "Is that all there is?" before tying his tie in a noose and heading for a tree.
The most directional clothes -- sometimes directional to a fault -- were by Richard Tyler, Jon Weiser for Artifact and John Bartlett.
Mr. Tyler, still aching from his break with Anne Klein, showed a resolute collection, redolent of the velvet days of the Rolling Stones. Suits were fitted to accommodate exhaling only, each outfit combined with a calculated eye on the applause meter: a purple velvet jacket with purple tie and shirt, a silver sheen washed over tweed, a rusty spread-collar suit, a trench belted over bright red plaid tapered trousers. The models all looked like rock stars skulking out the stage door after a concert, a fake fur thrown over a shoulder, a fedora pulled low, shoulders hunched to avoid recognition.
It is perhaps no surprise that Mr. Weiser, who combs all of Europe for distinctive clothes to set his Charivari boutique apart, produced one of the most successful shows in New York. There was nothing bleak here, and a lot that was new: pullovers in Persian lamb and fake fur; colorful Chinese silk brocades cut into vests, shirts, jeans and jackets; Carnaby suits with silky shirts beneath, and sculptured Mad Max leather trousers and jackets.
John Bartlett's libretto was a little hard to follow this season. Was the inspiration Luke Skywalker, the hero brought to mind by swashbuckling suspenders that crossed the body? Was it Bambi, suggested by models in aqua suits with antlers stuck into their coiffed hair? Was it gangsters gone soft in gray suits with candy-colored shirts and pink fedoras? Mr. Bartlett has a fine mind, but he left most of his audience behind this season. What looked right were body-enhancing trousers, slim fitted one-button jackets and trim cardigans and striped sweater vests.
Robert Massimo Freda has been promoted as a tailor in the publicity surrounding his award this year from the Council of Fashion Designers of America. Yet, that seems to translate only into a love of fabrics, not fit. One pair of pants was so voluminous it dragged on the runway. Others were rolled at the cuff two or three times to avoid that fate. The result over all was of small men in big men's clothes, not a look many men would understand.
Tommy Hilfiger often seems to fashion what the Monkees were to music: a creation of marketing. While no one can argue with his financial success (his company, which is publicly owned, reported his salary at $3.5 million for the year ending March 1994), he has much to prove as a designer. The strongest message from his show was "Men can mix." Three-piece suits, in plaids, pin stripes and tweeds, were swapped back and forth in every combination. It's a game most men can play with what they already own. The Hilfiger line, the Nautica collection designed by David Chu, and Hugo Boss all seemed to be more about flexing commercial clout than advancing fashion. What was lacking was what every designer label needs: a signature.
There was an identity at Tommy Zung, where the designer played with proportions and Asian influences to create men's clothes with the cinched waist of a kimono and the seduction of a smoking jacket. New Republic, designed by Thomas Oatman, showed a zealously Anglophile collection right down to black velvet knickers and Norfolks for evening. Richard Edwards, designed by Richard Bengtsson and Edward Pavlick, perfectly captured the demands of hip dressing, with nudges to sports jerseys and clothes in just-got-paid bright white and vivid colors, and flattering jean-cut trousers. Industria was at its salt-of-the-earth best, this season adding belted back jackets to its sumptuous staples.
But there was no stronger signature for men's wear than that of Wolfgang Joop, who matches the money he spends on advertising and runways with ideas and humor, dollar for dollar. A magenta satin suit with a red turtleneck! A purple one with electric-blue turtleneck! Leopard fedoras with pin-stripe suits!
Here was something to watch. As for most of the other shows, watching the models walk down the runways was like watching men walk down the street. And no one needs to set aside four special days, indoors, under hot lights, to accomplish that.

HEADLINE: White House Forecast Says Rates Could Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton's economic advisers, suggesting that the Federal Reserve's drive to slow the economy to a more sustainable growth rate is on the right track, predicted today that short-term interest rates could start to fall before the end of the year.
Also, disputing the assertions of a vocal minority, the economic advisers reluctantly concluded that the long-run growth potential of the American economy had not substantially improved. 
 "The preponderance of the available empirical evidence supports the conventional wisdom that the economy's productive capacity is expanding at roughly a 2.5 percent annual rate," the President's Council of Economic Advisers said in its annual report on the economy. A slight rise in productivity in recent years, the report said, is being offset by slower population growth.
Some analysts say the economy can expand much more rapidly without causing inflation to accelerate. That position makes them critical of the Federal Reserve's yearlong policy of trying to slow the economy by raising interest rates.
The council predicted that with the higher interest rates, the economy would achieve a "soft landing" this year. Indeed, by bringing the actual growth rate of the economy -- which reached 4 percent last year -- closer to its long-run potential, the Federal Reserve will not need to keep raising interest rates, the advisers said.
"The moderation in growth, we think, will lead to some easing in short-term interest rates," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the three-member panel.
The Administration forecast that the economy would expand 2.4 percent in 1995, measuring from the fourth quarter of last year to the fourth quarter of this year.
The report disputed the predictions of some analysts from the auto industry and elsewhere that an overdose of higher interest rates might tip the economy toward recession.
Among the council's predictions were that the yield on three-month Treasury bills would drop to 5.5 percent in 1996 from the current 5.95 percent; that the rate of increase in consumer prices would climb six-tenths of a percentage point, to 3.2 percent, and that the unemployment rate would average between 5.5 and 5.8 percent, or about the same as the January rate of 5.7 percent.
At a photo session in the Oval Office to highlight the report, President Clinton attacked Republicans who have said his budget does not do enough to curb the budget deficit.
"I find it amazing," the President said, "that people who were here digging the country in the hole I've been digging us out of are now saying I'm not getting us out quick enough. Where were they, and where are they?"
Citing House Speaker Newt Gingrich among other Republican leaders, Mr. Clinton said that "all those people, including the Speaker" helped quadruple the deficit during the Republican Presidencies of Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
Mr. Clinton did not mention that Democrats had control of both houses of Congress for 6 of those 12 years and that they ran the House of Representatives for all 12 years.
In its detailed analysis of how rapidly the economy can expand on a sustained basis without driving up inflation, the council noted that some analysts said output could grow perhaps as much as 5 percent a year, or about twice the 2.5 percent accepted by "most mainstream" economists.
Such analysts point to an increased growth of productivity in the last five years or so, perhaps the result of new technology being effectively harnessed by a new generation of middle managers operating in slimmed-down corporations.
But the council, while finding a "hint" that productivity growth has picked up, said it "pales in comparison to the decline that occurred earlier in the postwar period."
Over all, the council concluded, there is no basis yet "for adjusting one's view of the appropriate stance of monetary and fiscal policy."

Economic Forum Set
 WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- President Clinton said today that he would convene an economic conference for the end of March similar to the one he held during his transition to the Presidency two years ago.
"I think it would be a good thing to get those people back together, not only to review the progress that has been made, but more importantly, to look at the thorny problems that remain," Mr. Clinton told reporters in the Oval Office.
He said that two years ago the focus was on getting the nation out of recession. Now, he said, the emphasis should be on the "squeeze" facing the middle class and the need to "spread the benefits of economic recovery" to a wider group.
The White House spokesman, Mike McCurry, said the forum would be held in late March at a site still to be determined.

HEADLINE: Mexican Economic Slide Has Only Begun

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Mexico's Banks: A Weak Link in the Rescue Plan" (Business Day, Feb. 9): 
 The weakness of the Mexican banking system was pointed out by the economist Carlos Heredia at a Jan. 13 news conference we organized at the National Press Club. Mr. Heredia, a former Government economist who now works for Equipo Pueblo, an independent think tank, also predicted the mortgaging of Mexico's oil reserve to guarantee a United States bailout plan.
Unlike your coverage, Mr. Heredia saw the pending banking crisis
as a symptom of an economy crumbling at its very foundation after 12 years of "structural adjustment" promoted by the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the United States Treasury.
The changes brought about during this "adjustment" have resulted in the economic polarization of Mexican society with a score of new billionaires, a shrinking middle class and a burgeoning number of poor. Removal or restriction of Government support and tight credit have devastated small and medium-size industrial and agricultural producers, while imports have increased (even more under the North American Free Trade Agreement), further undercutting local production.
Mr. Heredia called on the international financial institutions and the Mexican and United States governments to admit that the "structural adjustment" policies -- privatizations, wage restraint, cuts in social services and subsidies, elimination of trade barriers and removal of restrictions on foreign capital -- had failed. He warned that a United States bailout would only postpone the collapse of an export-oriented, import-dependent economy reliant on speculative foreign capital.
But the Clinton Administration and the I.M.F. have accompanied bailout funds with requirements to intensify policies that first caused the crisis.
 
TONY AVIRGAN
Washington, Feb. 9, 1995
 
The writer is communications coordinator of Development Gap, an aid and development advocacy group.

HEADLINE: Strategies on Mexico Cast Aside

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The peso's crash has knocked American businesses off course, forcing many to postpone their dreams of exploiting the vast market to the south. At the same time, other companies are rushing to expand investments in Mexican factories that will increase their exports to the north.
These shifts suggest that the North American Free Trade Agreement's second year will have far fewer benefits for many American companies and their workers than its first year. 
 Wal-Mart Stores, which has seen Mexico as the next stage after its push across the United States, has cut shipments to Mexico and stopped work on 25 new stores, many already well under construction. American beef prices have fallen as Mexican ranchers, desperate for dollars, unload their herds north of the border, while Mexican consumers buy much less American meat. The Mexican auto market, where American-made vehicles account for half of all sales, has seen sales fall about 40 percent since the devaluation.
These days, trucks still back up on the Mexican side of the border, but seldom on the United States side.
"Very much less southbound; no decrease northbound," said Michael Miles, executive vice president of the Miles Group of El Paso, which handles trade shipments and warehousing.
The effects of the peso's fall, which makes American goods more expensive in Mexico and Mexican products cheaper in the United States, are too fresh to document with figures. But reports from companies so far confirm the predictions of many analysts. As Mexico suffers a slump expected to turn last year's American trade surplus with Mexico into a large deficit, the United States economy is likely to suffer job losses of tens, perhaps hundreds, of thousands.
Some companies are forging ahead, confident of Mexico's long-term growth. The trade pact's critics, however, are claiming vindication. "The U.S. trade surplus with Mexico was a function of the high value of the peso rather than the liberalization of the economy," said Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research center that has been critical of the North American trade accord.
The pact was billed as much narrower than Europe's broad economic union. But the drop in the peso highlights how much more closely the fortunes of Mexico and the United States are bound together than they were before.
To support the Mexican economy, which late last year virtually matched Japan's as the second-largest market for American exports, after Canada, the Clinton Administration has been forced to offer $ 20 billion in loans as part of a $ 50 billion international rescue package. Mexico -- barred by the trade agreement from reviving past protectionism -- responded to the crisis by speeding the opening of transportation, communications and finance to foreign investors, even committing once-sacrosanct oil revenue to secure the American loans.
"Has Nafta turned out to be more all-embracing than we expected?" asked Sidney Weintraub, director of the United States-Mexico Project at the University of Texas in Austin. "Yes, once you have a partner of that nature, you have to come to the rescue in a way you wouldn't have earlier. The two countries, like it or not, are deeply intertwined."
Many companies have coordinated their North American operations so closely that labor unrest in Mexico resulting from the peso's plunge led to production shutdowns far to the north. A wildcat strike that began two weeks ago at a Thomson Consumer Electronics plant making television components in Juarez, Mexico, threw 1,300 workers off the job at a television assembly plant in Bloomington, Ind., and another 500 at a factory making plastic cabinets in Indianapolis. Thomson sells television sets under the General Electric and RCA brand names.
The Mexican workers, outraged over the plunging value of their money, demanded a 30 percent raise. They returned to work last week with a 13 percent raise, but the American workers were idled for a week.
"You must recognize that Juarez is a dollar-based economy" just across the border from El Paso, said Richard J. Knoph, a company spokesman. "Workers are paid in pesos."
The peso's fall, making it cheaper to export to the United States, has fired the interest of several companies in building or expanding factories just across the border. Bryan Cook, director of business development for the Parque Industrial del Norte in Reynosa, Mexico, said a number of large companies have called him since the currency's collapse. 'They were looking, but now we've crunched the numbers again," he said. "At least five companies want to accelerate their plans."
The trade pact, which took effect in January 1994, produced gains that surprised even its supporters. Shipments between the United States and Mexico rose more than 20 percent, in both directions. Last year's momentum, however, has stalled.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas estimates that the peso's collapse will cost 20,000 to 30,000 American jobs this year, in part because exports to Mexico will decline by $ 10 billion, or more than 20 percent. Some private economists expect the job losses to run much higher.
Labor leaders contend that the predicted job losses fail to reflect the full impact on American workers. They point out that the threat to move south of the border, made more tempting by the peso's fall, can lower wages or force unions to swallow bitter settlements.
Last summer, the Leviton Manufacturing Company got a thousand members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers at a Warwick, R.I., electrical outlet plant to accept a two-year wage freeze. Otherwise, the company said, the production would move to Mexico, where Leviton already has several factories.
"The intent of the negotiations and the agreement was to preserve their jobs in Rhode Island by sharing cost concessions with the company," said Richard Millar, Leviton's vice president of marketing.
Despite the present turmoil, which makes forecasting so difficult, American companies from General Electric to Nike still see vast opportunities emerging in Mexico.
G.E.'s exports to Mexico, for example, rose 68 percent last year, to about $ 300 million, with locomotives, electrical and medical equipment selling briskly. Its Mexican plants increased their sales about 18 percent, to more than $ 1 billion, with about half of that total exported to the United States.
General Electric, which has learned to shelter much of its earnings from currency storms, now plans to invest even more in Mexico, especially to take advantage of accelerated Mexican privatization in power generation, transportation and finance.
"In the long run we see the importance of the market," said Kenneth Brown, chairman and chief executive of General Electric of Mexico. "It means our strategy of investing in the country stays the same."
To protect against the volatile currency, G.E. tries to balance peso and dollar costs and revenue. Among other things, it finances factories aimed at the export market and real estate projects with leases payable in dollars.
Even if Mexican workers win some raises, companies wanting to build Mexican plants to export their products stand to come out ahead. Investment and production costs in pesos have fallen while they can reap revenues in dollars. The advantage could even lead to a shift of some low-wage production from Asia to Mexico.
Nike is negotiating to make its athletic shoes in Mexico, for the 90 million people in the Mexican domestic market first, Latin America more broadly, and ultimately perhaps the United States.
Lower labor costs resulting from the peso's plunge are one attraction, said Keith Peters, a Nike spokesman. But the long-range lure of the Mexican market inspired the company's look at the nation more than a year ago. Nike makes more than a quarter of its shoes in China, but Mexican tariffs and a United States trade dispute threaten to price Chinese imports out of Mexico.
Companies like Nike and the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation, a poultry processor in Pittsburg, Tex., say they are not about to let a short-term currency crisis chase them out of a region they see as ultimately destined for much greater prosperity.
Pilgrim's Pride put its chickens in so many more Mexican pots in 1994, thanks in part to the trade pact, that the company aimed to increase its sales by 40 percent in 1995.
Then the peso plunged. A resulting $ 4.3 million loss nearly wiped out the company's quarterly profit, and the expansion plan is under review.
Still, Pilgrim's Pride says it will persist. Mexicans, who have doubled their per-person consumption of chicken from eight years ago, still eat less than half as much as Americans.
"We still have faith in our long-term decision," said Clifford E. Butler, the chief financial officer. "One month does not make a year, and one year does not make a career."

HEADLINE: Batter Up, Already

BYLINE: By Andrew Zimbalist; Andrew Zimbalist, professor of economics at Smith College and author of "Baseball and Billions," is a founder of the United Baseball League, a partnership among players, owners and cities that plans to begin play in 1996.

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
With two days to go until spring training, and with the Republican leadership in Congress apparently unwilling to lift a finger to settle baseball's paralyzing six-month labor dispute, fans must be in a state beyond despair. But the situation is not hopeless -- at least not yet.
To get real baseball in 1995, Congress needs to get involved now. It won't do to wait until June, when some have said they plan to revisit the issue, to see if the players and owners come together. The current negotiations were opened by the owners in December 1992, and the sides are little closer today than they were then. The most significant movement has been toward ever greater rancor and distrust. 
 Speaker Newt Gingrich and his Republican colleagues have offered several arguments for staying out of the baseball dispute. None hold water. Perhaps the silliest is that Congress has better things to do with its time.
President Clinton proposed to submit the baseball dispute to a panel of arbitrators whose decision would be binding; passing such a bill would establish a fair fact-finding process and get real baseball back on the field, and it would take Congress half of an afternoon to pass it -- far less time than Mr. Gingrich spent saying he didn't want to get involved.
Republicans say Congress does not belong in the baseball industry, but that argument comes more than 70 years too late. Congress has repeatedly sanctioned baseball's anachronistic exemption from the antitrust laws, and rather than setting a clear and consistent policy, it threatens baseball with lifting the exemption every time a new senator wants an expansion franchise in his or her state.
Last June, the Players Association said it wouldn't strike during the season if the owners promised not to impose a salary cap unilaterally after the season, but the owners said no deal. The players then told Congress that if the antitrust exemption was lifted (even only the part related to collective bargaining), they would not strike because they would be able to defend themselves in court. The bill died in committee, and the players went on strike. So Congress is not only involved; it is complicitous.
 There is precedent, too, for imposing binding arbitration in labor disputes. Congress did so as recently as 1992, ending a dispute between the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers and a freight rail company. No, baseball is not crucial to the economy. But it is the only unregulated, legal monopoly we have in this country. If the Republicans really care about free markets, why do they have nothing to say about the baseball owners' attempts at price fixing through salary caps and intra-industry salary taxes, which directly affront the idea of free labor markets?
Binding arbitration is a short-term solution. Lifting baseball's antitrust exemption -- as proposed in limited form last week by Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Orrin G. Hatch -- would help in the long run, especially if it is a comprehensive measure that puts baseball on an equal footing with the other sports. (It would not, however, settle the labor dispute: the Players Association would lift the strike, but the owners would almost certainly impose a lockout and go ahead with their plan for "temporary replacement" players.)
 So to get real baseball back on the field in April, Congress must quickly revisit the issue of binding arbitration. And though the leadership's refusal to do so may have seemed final a week ago, perhaps the sight of overweight and undertalented athletes on exhibition fields in Florida and Arizona this week will give Mr. Gingrich & Company an ice-water bath of common sense.
 As long as baseball faces neither competition nor regulation, the industry will remain in turmoil. If Newt Gingrich truly understood the teachings of Adam Smith, he would know this.

HEADLINE: Peru and Ecuador Halt Fighting Along Border, Claiming Victory

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
With each side claiming victory, a cease-fire between Peru and Ecuador went into effect at noon today and appeared to halt border fighting that had raged for the past 20 days.
"The Peruvian flag waves in Tiwinza," Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, said in a speech televised Monday night, asserting that Peruvian commandos had occupied Tiwinza, the last of three border posts Peru says it has taken back from Ecuador. 
 "All Peru should know that, at this moment, the Ecuadorean troops organized in our territory have been dislodged," Mr. Fujimori said.
On the other side, Ecuador's Defense Minister, Jose Gallardo, flew to the region this afternoon with military attaches from Embassies of the United States, Argentina, Brazil and Chile. He carried a satellite-activated positioning device that he said would prove that Ecuador still holds Tiwinza and the two other posts.
Prior to the trip, the Ecuadorean military high command asserted that they "are under the control of the Ecuadorean Armed Forces."
In Lima, newspapers hit the streets today with headlines blaring: "Total Victory," "Tiwinza is ours," "The Invaders were expelled," "Mission Accomplished" and "Invincible Peru."
At Bagua, Peru's military headquarters for the campaign, reporters were shown Ecuadorean "war booty" said to have been seized at the three posts: uniforms, radio equipment, grenade launchers and rifles. Officials at Bagua said Ecuadorean forces shelled Tiwinza 90 minutes after the cease-fire deadline, but Ecuador denied this.
While politicians, generals and cartographers are expected to wrangle for weeks over the war's outcome, business executives reacted to the cease-fire with relief. In Peru, Lima's stock exchange index rose by 8 percent; and the Ecuadorean exchange in Quito jumped by 9 percent.
For nearly three weeks, a part of the world unaccustomed to war for decades became transformed. Soldiers mined international bridges, thousands of civilians fled border areas, police urged citizens to denounce "enemy" spies, and jets engaged in dog fights. The fighting left an estimated 50 people dead and 100 wounded.
Reviving old nationalist alliances that had split the region in past decades, Peruvians accused Chile of helping Ecuador, and Ecuadoreans accused Argentina of tilting toward Peru.
On both sides, security personnel assaulted "enemy" television crews. Last week, El Comercio, an influential Lima daily, cited patriotic reasons for censoring an essay by Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian novelist who lost to Mr. Fujimori in the 1990 presidential race. The offending column was titled "The Absurd War."
With Ecuador less than one-fourth the size of Peru, the war weighed most heavily on that tiny nation straddling the Equator.
Thrown on a war footing, Ecuador called up reservists, announced fines for food "speculators," tried to stem a run on banks and imposed draconian energy conservation rules.
In contrast, Peru took the war largely in stride. With double the population, double the economy and $6 billion in reserves, Peruvians were not visibly inconvenienced by the fighting.

HEADLINE: Allies Agree On a Proposal To Belgrade

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Officials of the five-nation working group seeking peace in Bosnia agreed today on the outline of a plan to suspend most of the sanctions on Serbia in exchange for its recognition of Bosnia and Croatia, a French Foreign Ministry official said.
"The principle of an exchange of sanctions relief for Serbian agreements in other areas is accepted by everyone," said the official, who insisted on not being identified.
Those other areas, he said, include Serbian recognition of Bosnia and Croatia, formal acceptance by Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic of the five nations' peace plan for Bosnia, and an agreement to use an American-backed peace plan for Croatia as a basis for negotiation. 
 A senior American official confirmed that the United States had agreed to lift all trade sanctions on Serbia if Mr. Milosevic met the conditions, and also agreed to tighten his somewhat porous blockade of the Bosnian Serbs. But the official added that Serbia would not immediately become eligible for loans from the World Bank and other international lending institutions.
Complete Serbian cooperation with international efforts to resolve the conflicts in the Balkans would presumably remove any reason to continue the United Nations sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro, which form all that remains of the Yugoslav federation. But the Milosevic Government has never received an outright promise that the sanctions, imposed in 1992, would end if certain conditions were met.
The American official said that under the plan, sanctions would be quickly reimposed if Mr. Milosevic were seen to be giving military aid to Serbian nationalists in Bosnia or Croatia.
Western officials are expected to travel within the next week to put the proposals to Mr. Milosevic. American officials are generally skeptical of the possibility that the plan will be accepted.
Of the conditions set for Mr. Milosevic, the most difficult is recognition of Bosnia and Croatia. About 70 percent of Bosnia and close to a third of Croatia are held by Serbs who were long supported by Mr. Milosevic in their refusal to join the new countries created since the old Yugoslav federation began to break up in 1991.
It would be a high-risk political course for the Serbian President, and one he has shown no sign of being prepared to take.
But the options of the so-called contact group, made up of the United States, France, Germany, Russia and Britain, appear to be dwindling as it attempts to head off a wider Balkan war in the spring.
The Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, has said he will end the mandate of United Nations troops in Croatia on March 31, awakening widespread fears that war will soon spread to the Serb-occupied areas that Mr. Martic controls. The 1991 war in Croatia ended in a tenuous truce policed by the United Nations.
In addition, a four-month cease-fire that came into effect in Bosnia at the beginning of the year appears close to breakdown.
United Nations officials said the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, had written to Yasushi Akashi, the top United Nations official in the former Yugoslavia, threatening "to open new fronts" if what he called a Serbian offensive in the northwestern Bihac area did not cease.
Mr. Milosevic gained some minor relief from the sanctions -- including a reopening of Belgrade airport -- last September when he promised to impose a blockade on the Bosnian Serbs. Despite the widespread evidence that the blockade is a sham, the contact group has persisted in trying to use him because it has made no headway with the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic.
The Bosnian Serbs continue to reject a map prepared by the contact group that would oblige them to give up a third of the territory they hold and accept 49 percent of Bosnia, with the rest going to a Muslim-Croat federation. The Bosnian Serbs' self-styled parliament reiterated this rejection today.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S SPENDING PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;
GIULIANI SEEKS DEEPEST CUT IN CITY SPENDING SINCE 1930'S

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed a financial blueprint for New York City that included the largest percentage reduction in overall spending since the Great Depression and that together with state cuts would drastically reshape municipal government and slash its services to the poor.
Embracing the philosophy of Gov. George E. Pataki's austere budget for the state, Mr. Giuliani said that the city would reduce for the first time public assistance and health care for the city's poorest residents. In fact, he called on the Governor to go further to cut those costs, which the city and state share. 
 Saying the city had been too generous for too long, the Mayor proposed a budget of nearly $ 30.5 billion for the fiscal year that begins in July, a reduction in spending from the current fiscal year of $ 1.3 billion, or 4 percent.
Not since Mayor James J. Walker cut spending by 16.5 percent in 1933 has the city seen a greater reduction.
Fourteen months into an administration already noteworthy for rounds of sharp budget cutting that simply kept spending from growing, Mr. Giuliani, the first Republican Mayor in a generation, went further and proposed to cut and restructure government in ways that would effect virtually every New Yorker, although not evenly.
In his statement accompanying the budget plan, Mr. Giuliani portrayed the "tough measures" of his plan as a necessary correction to the failed liberal policies of the past, which he said had led the city to spend beyond its means year after year.
Later at City Hall, he called it a historic change in course for New York, made possible by the new political landscape in Washington and Albany. "New York City needed to change," he said. "It needed dramatic change."
In addition to the cuts in welfare and health care, the Mayor also asked the city's municipal unions to agree to $ 600 million in savings on health care, pensions and work rules, in exchange for a pledge to avert layoffs. And he announced that he would reduce spending in city agencies by an added $ 600 million, affecting services virtually across the board -- from summer youth programs to prevention programs for thousands of troubled families to money for the City University of New York.
Beyond the spending cuts, the Mayor also proposed raising revenues in a variety of novel ways. The city would raise $ 10 million by selling advertising space in parks, although officials immediately ruled out the prospect of, say, billboards in Central Park.
At the same time, the plan proposes a few modest tax cuts, including eliminating the city's 4.25 percent sales tax on clothing that costs less than $ 100 and the first phase of a plan to reduce property taxes on co-ops and condos, as well as reductions in business taxes that the Mayor said would stimulate job growth.
The Mayor's preliminary budget -- the first step in a process that will ultimately lead to the adoption of a final budget by the City Council in June -- is very likely to provoke a more pitched ideological battle over the city's priorities than his budget proposals last year.
The Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a Democrat from Queens, said his members recognized the severity of the projected $ 2.7 billion budget gap the Mayor's plan would close. But he said the Council would resist drastic cuts in education, youth services, welfare and Medicaid, lobbying against them at the State Capitol and at City Hall. He said that many of the cuts, while expedient, would ripple disastrously through the city's economy.
"Make no mistake that many of the cuts advanced by the Mayor and the Governor would hurt not only the poor," Mr. Vallone said. "They would hurt working people. They would hurt the elderly. And they would hurt a significant part of New York City's economy."
Other Democratic Council members and representatives of liberal advocacy and social welfare organizations responded even more angrily. They said the Mayor's budget reflected the conservatism of Mr. Giuliani's fellow Republicans in Albany and Washington and the drive to roll back the city's historic mission to provide a social safety net.
"It's an unprecedented attack on the poor," said Penelope W. Pi-Sunyer, the executive director of the City Project, a liberal advocacy organization. "This Mayor is escalating the war by the Federal and state governments on the poor."
The Mayor's preliminary budget -- and the need for more cuts on top of the $ 2 billion in spending that Mr. Giuliani and the Council cut last year -- underscored the depth of the city's enduring shortfall between tax revenues and expenses, a disparity known as the "structural deficit."
The projected gap for the 1996 fiscal year has mushroomed steadily over the last year, due in part to a $ 500 million decline in tax revenues because of the flat economy on Wall Street and a $ 265 million drop in anticipated aid from the state and Federal governments.
The city's fiscal monitors and bond raters responded positively, although they cautioned that much of the Mayor's plan still required approval from the State Legislature and the unions.
Richard P. Larkin, the managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said that the plan could avert a downgrading that his agency had threatened last month. But to do so, he said, the Mayor had to win agreement from Albany to reduce the state's spending on Medicaid and welfare by $ 400 million more than even the Governor has proposed. And he would need the unions' approval for the $ 600 million in givebacks. He described both issues as "wild cards."
Jeffrey A. Sommer, the acting executive director of the state's Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, said the budget plan signaled an honest attempt to address the structural deficit. "It's ambitious," he said, "and it's moving in the right direction."
The city has had to make deep cuts in spending and raise taxes before to close projected deficits in the billions of dollars. But in most of those cases the city cut spending against projected growth and did not reduce the budget in absolute dollars, as Mr. Giuliani has proposed.
Since modern New York was incorporated in 1898, the city's budget has actually fallen from one year to the next only nine times, according to Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization, who studied the issue under the auspices of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University.
Even after the depths of the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the city actually cut spending only once, in 1980, when the total budget dropped $ 68 million, or half of 1 percent, to $ 14.3 billion.
By far, the deepest cuts in Mr. Giuliani's budget would fall in welfare and Medicaid, which account for 15 percent of the city's spending and which the Mayor proposed cutting by $ 1.2 billion.
In his state budget, the Governor proposed cutting those programs by $ 1.9 billion, saving the city an estimated $ 800 million since it shares the costs. Mr. Giuliani asked Mr. Pataki to cut a total of $ 2.5 billion to save the city an added $ 400 million.
The cuts in Medicaid could have a profound effect on the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which operates the 11 municipal hospitals, as well as nursing homes and community clinics. The combined blow of the cuts in Medicaid -- estimated to total $ 1.1 billion, or a third of the corporation's budget -- would hasten what the Mayor called a necessary restructuring of the system and, quite possibly, the closing of one or more hospitals.
"New York City has too many hospital beds," Mr. Giuliani said. "It has too many hospital beds -- on the public side and on the private side -- and New York City spends way too much money on Medicaid. It's going to have to make that correction anyway."
The city's contribution to the Board of Education would be cut by $ 230 million, or 7 percent, from this year's budget. The Department of Sanitation's budget would be reduced $ 60 million, or 10 percent, while the Department of Correction would lose $ 50 million, or nearly 9 percent.
The Mayor's budget also made permanent last year's $ 128 million cut in money for the Transit Authority for providing free subway and bus rides for the city's schoolchildren. Gene Russianoff, the senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said the reduction further raised the prospect of a fare increase for all riders.
The Mayor also proposed merging the Sheriff's Department into the Department of Finance, which collects taxes, and the Arts Commission into the Landmarks Preservation Commission. He would consolidate the legal functions of four agencies into the Law Department, and construction units of many agencies into one new agency.
While the Mayor said the spending reductions and the $ 184 million in tax cuts he proposed would stimulate growth and create new jobs in the private sector, the budget plan offered a grim view of the city's economy, saying there was little hope for a major expansion.
Still, the Mayor said the city had no other choices. Asked what he would say to the city's youth after proposing $ 20 million in cuts in youth job, education and training programs, he replied:
"What I would say to them is that New York City would still be providing more money in each of these programs than any other city in America and that one of the things New York City was not doing for you by over-spending in these areas is not providing the future for you. Youth programs are not a future. A job in a mostly private sector industry or business presents a future for you."

HEADLINE: Judge Rejects U.S. Antitrust Pact With Microsoft

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
In a decision that throws the Federal Government's biggest antitrust case into turmoil, a Federal judge here rejected today the Justice Department's agreement to settle allegations that the Microsoft Corporation, the world's biggest software company, unfairly competed with its rivals.
The decision is a considerable embarrassment for the Justice Department, which last July described its settlement as a victory that would rein in one of the most feared companies in the computer industry and which now must rebut criticism that the accord was too tame. 
 The decision reopens a huge array of antitrust issues concerning how Microsoft obtained its overwhelming domination of the software now used on more than 50 million personal computers.
As such, the ruling is a big setback for Microsoft. Most investors in Microsoft greeted the settlement with relief last summer, noting that Microsoft would only have to modify a narrowly defined array of licensing practices and that the Government had decided not to push for much more severe restrictions.
In a blunt ruling today, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin said the proposed settlement failed to address a number of the issues raised about Microsoft during a four-year investigation and he chastised the Government for refusing to explain itself.
"The picture that emerges from these proceedings is that the U.S. Government is either incapable or unwilling to deal effectively with a potential threat to this nation's economic well-being," Judge Sporkin wrote. If he was to approve the deal, he wrote, "the message will be that Microsoft is so powerful that neither the market nor the Government is capable of dealing with all of its monopolistic practices."
Saying he could not rule that the settlement would be in the public interest, Judge Sporkin said he would convene a status hearing on March 16 to consider the next step.
Neither the Justice Department nor Microsoft would comment much on the decision. "We are disappointed to learn what is being reported about the order," Microsoft said in a terse statement this evening. Anne K. Bingaman, the Assistant Attorney General for antitrust issues, would say only that the agency was reviewing the decision.
Broadly, the Government has four options. It can appeal Judge Sporkin's decision, arguing that he abused his discretion, and seek approval for the settlement as it was originally written.
Alternatively, the Justice Department can try to negotiate a new and tougher deal with Microsoft that takes account of the specific criticisms made by Judge Sporkin. If it cannot reach a new agreement, it would then have to sue Microsoft and prepare for a court case likely to last several years. Finally, the Justice Department could choose simply to drop the case entirely.
At issue in the investigation was whether Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., had stifled competition in software, particularly in the operating systems that provide the basic instructions for all I.B.M.-compatible personal computers.
Microsoft manufactures MS-DOS, the operating system used on about 70 percent of all personal computers. It also produces Windows, a program that allows a computer user to navigate between scores of applications, like word processing or entering data bases, simply by placing an electronic "mouse" on easy-to-understand graphic icons.
Rival companies, like Borland International and the Lotus Development Corporation, have contended that Microsoft tried to block companies offering other operating systems by using unfair licensing practices and other tactics. Some companies have also said that Microsoft used various dirty tricks, including what the industry calls "vaporware," to leverage its expansion from MS-DOS into almost every kind of software for desktop computers.
At one point, antitrust investigators at the Federal Trade Commission suggested that Microsoft should be forced to split itself up -- somewhat as the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company was forced to separate its local and long-distance businesses 10 years ago. Some of the Government's lawyers envisioned one Microsoft company in the operating-system business and another in the market for applications like word-processing and spreadsheets, but the whole breakup idea never progressed very far.
In July, the Justice Department reached a fairly narrow agreement that was limited primarily to licensing practices. Under that deal, Microsoft agreed to drop the practice of licensing MS-DOS to computer manufacturers on the basis of the number of computers they sold, regardless of whether the computers actaully used MS-DOS.
"We were all pretty delighted that the legal issues seemed to be behind them," said David Readerman, a computer analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. Indeed, Microsoft sales jumped 31 percent in the quarter ended Dec. 31, to $1.5 billion, and the company's profit rose 29 percent, to $373 million.
Microsoft's stock surged immediately in July on news of the settlement and has since climbed from $48.625 to its closing price today of $61.875, down 12.5 cents for the day in Nasdaq trading. Judge Sporkin's decision was announced after the close of trading.
The judge, who said he had read a book about Microsoft as well as articles in magazines and newspapers, wrote today that he was particularly concerned about evidence that Microsoft had deceptively tried to block one rival's product by using "vaporware" -- announcing a product of its own that would not actually be ready for at least several months.
Judge Sporkin wrote that the Government's proposed settlement was too narrow and would be ineffective at achieving all of its stated goals. He said the deal would not require Microsoft to adhere to any restrictions on operating systems used for high-powered work stations. He also said the Government had failed to show how its agreement would help open up the market for rivals to MS-DOS and Windows.
"What the Government fails to show is that the proposed consent decree will open the market and remedy the unfair advantage Microsoft gained in the market through its anti-competitive practices," he wrote. "Simply telling a defendant to go forth and sin no more does little or nothing to address the unfair advantage it has already gained."
Gary Reback, a San Francisco lawyer who represents a group of computer companies that have remained anonymous and have challenged the settlement, praised today's decision.
"The judge did the only thing he could have done," he said. "He was given no choice but to reject the decree because he wasn't given any information about whether the decree is valid or not."
