HEADLINE: American Express and PNC Become Favorites of Buffett

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Warren E. Buffett, the widely followed Omaha investor, is betting $2 billion that there is money to be made in money. He disclosed yesterday that his holding company had purchased stakes in two major financial services companies: 9.8 percent of the American Express Company and 8.3 percent of the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh.
 Many investors like to mimic Mr. Buffett's investments, and shares of both companies surged yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock of American Express rose $1.375, to $33.50, its highest level in eight years. Shares of PNC, the nation's 12th-largest banking company, jumped 87.5 cents, to $25, a high for the year but well below the $31.50 level reached last June. PNC has suffered unusually large investment losses resulting from the rise in interest rates. 
 Mr. Buffett is known for making large long-term investments in companies whose stocks are out of favor but whose management he holds in high regard. His holding company, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., and its various insurance company subsidiaries own big stakes in such corporations as Capital Cities/ABC, Coca-Cola and the Washington Post Company.
 Mr. Buffett has long had an interest in financial services stocks, buying positions in Geico, an insurer, Wells Fargo & Company, a San Francisco bank, and Salomon Inc., the brokerage firm. When the top management of Salomon was forced to resign in 1991 after the firm covered up false bids made in Government bond auctions, Mr. Buffett stepped in as chairman for several months.
Mr. Buffett is fond of companies with well-established brand names. The ubiquitous blue box and stern green centurion of American Express fits that bill. The company, based in New York, has also been recovering from a string of problems relating to its former Shearson and Lehman brokerage subsidiaries and losses from unpaid balances on its Optima credit card.
Mr. Buffett first bought $300 million in preferred stock in American Express in 1991 as the company was recapitalized to compensate for large losses at Shearson. That investment was converted last August into 14 million shares of common stock.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, Berkshire Hathaway said it held 27.76 million shares of American Express as of Dec. 31. In a subsequent statement yesterday, American Express said Mr. Buffett had purchased an additional 20.74 million shares this year. That gives him a total of 48.5 million shares, which are worth $1.6 billion based on yesterday's closing price.
"We are delighted with the vote of confidence that the Berkshire Hathaway share purchase represents," American Express said.
 Many investors, including those intending to take over companies, are required to disclose large stock purchases within 10 days. But Berkshire Hathaway, as an insurance company, only has to disclose its large holdings once a year. Thus the stock holdings disclosed by Mr. Buffett as of the end of 1994 could have been purchased any time that year. Shares of American Express traded between $24 and $31 in 1994.
As for PNC, Berkshire Hathaway said in its filings that it owned 19.5 million shares as of Dec. 31, worth $504 million at yesterday's closing price. PNC declined to say whether Mr. Buffett had bought or sold any shares this year. Mr. Buffett, according to market rumors, has been buying PNC shares since the end of 1993, and it is unclear how much of his investment was made before the bank's losses from rising rates were disclosed.
Many bank stock analysts are quite bearish on the prospects for PNC. Sally Pope Davis of Goldman, Sachs has rated the stock of PNC as "underperform," a Wall Street euphemism for "sell."
She conceded that there might be value for someone with Mr. Buffett's long-term view. "If you wait three years for them to get out from under their interest rate problems," she said, "the company is probably attractive."

HEADLINE: In Slow-Growth Sign, Retail Sales Inch Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Fresh signs of an economic slowdown appeared today as retail spending at department stores, auto dealers, supermarkets and the like rose in January by a relatively small amount for the second straight month.
"It seems as if consumers have slowed up on their purchases," said Kenneth T. Mayland, chief financial economist at the Keycorp National Bank in Cleveland. "Something has changed." 
 The Commerce Department reported that retail spending rose just two-tenths of a percent last month, echoing a similar rise in December. Earlier, the December figure was reported as a drop of one-tenth of 1 percent, but more complete data showed that the Christmas season was not quite as poor as first thought.
Not surprisingly, the biggest drag in January was motor vehicles and other big-ticket items that typically are among the first casualties of rising interest rates. The durable goods category fell four-tenths of 1 percent, the second straight decline after a skimpy November rise.
"Consumers look like they're pulling in their horns," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at the Boston-based Shawmut National Corporation. "I'm increasingly thinking that the Federal Reserve has done about all that it's going to do."
The Fed has raised short-term interest rates seven times over the last 12 months, doubling the overnight rate among banks to 6 percent. Economists are divided over whether the central bank will lift them again in early or late spring, but the latest report suggests that it may be inclined to halt its step-by-step credit tightening as evidence accumulates that the previous rate increases are starting to do their job. The Fed's goal is to brake the economy, which expanded at an annual pace of 4 1/2 percent in the final three months of 1994 -- too fast a rate to be sustainable without higher inflation.
Bond prices climbed today on word of the January sales figures, pushing long-term rates below 7 5/8 percent, or roughly one-half point off their recent peaks.
But even as analysts cautioned that the initial results in retailing were subject to substantial revision, they pointed to other evidence that the economic expansion was slackening. This includes sluggish payroll expansion last month, a prolonged buildup of inventories and narrower growth in consumer installment debt.
Still, consumers show some life, raising purchases of nondurables five-tenths of 1 percent last month despite flooding in California and exceptionally warm weather in much of the East that hurt sales of winter clothes.
"This year, retailers were highly promotional during the month of January and consumers obviously took advantage of even better values on top-quality goods," said Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation.
Department stores and others selling general merchandise enjoyed a sales gain of 1.1 percent last month, while sales rose 1 percent at drug and variety stores and seven-tenths of 1 percent at food stores. Much of a 1.9 percent jump at gasoline services stations, however, reflected higher prices.
Sales declined six-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars and five-tenths of 1 percent at stores selling clothes and accessories.
Among retailers of durable goods, sales at automotive dealers slumped six-tenths of 1 percent while sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent for merchants selling furniture and other equipment for the home.
Excluding the automotive group, which accounts for about 24 percent of the total, retail sales climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in January, the report showed.
At $193.22 billion, retail sales were 8 percent higher than in January 1994, or a little more than 5 percent after allowing for inflation.
In all, consumers account for two-thirds of the American economy, with about half of this spending at retail counters and the other half going for such things as car insurance and hospital care.

HEADLINE: Getting This Oil Takes Drilling and Diplomacy

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Several billion barrels of oil under the Caspian Sea lie waiting to be tapped off the stony coast of this former Soviet republic. No technical difficulties preclude a daily oil output that could eventually be equal to a tenth of what is produced each day in the United States.
But a Western-led consortium that is spending $7 billion to develop the huge new oilfields has found itself frustrated by the political realities of a region of Central Asia where Russia, Iran, Turkey and the West have historically competed for influence. 
 Over vigorous objections from the United States, Iran is on the verge of acquiring an interest in the consortium from cash-starved Azerbaijan. Even if Washington blocks Iran's direct participation, Azerbaijan will bring Iran in through the back door, oil company executives and Western diplomats here said. Iranian involvement could make the participating American oil companies ineligible for tax credits or loan guarantees from the Federal Government.
The consortium, in which four American companies hold 40 percent of the shares, faces another politically charged problem: how to get the oil to Western markets. Washington recently announced that it preferred a pipeline that runs through Turkey. That does not sit well with Moscow, which wants a pipeline that goes through Russia. But that does not suit Turkey or Azerbaijan. The other options are through Georgia, which is politically unstable, or through Iran, a route that Washington opposes.
The offer by Azerbaijan to let Iran have a stake in the project is motivated not only by money but also by a need to satisfy its nettlesome southern neighbor. Azerbaijan has already placated Russia to the north by cutting it in on the deal, which became final late last year.
The problem of shipping out oil, in the face of climatic as well as political obstacles, also affects other remote corners of the old Soviet Union, including the Russian Arctic and Central Asian republics like Kazakhstan, where the Chevron Corporation has begun pumping from the Tengiz field after investing up to $1 billion.
[Chevron, which has trouble moving its oil from Tengiz, disclosed on Monday that it would slash spending on the oilfield this year to $50 million from the $500 million originally budgeted.]
The decision on the pipeline must be made very soon, oil executives said -- though they doubted it would be -- if construction is to be completed by the time the wells start pumping an estimated 600,000 barrels a day. That is equal to 10 percent of the daily production from all the wells in the United States, including Alaska, oil executives here said. At today's prices, such production would bring the consortium something like half a billion dollars a month.
It is not surprising then that with the word out that Azerbaijan is looking to sell off part of its interest, men in pressed white shirts representing big American and European oil companies -- Exxon, Mobil, Shell, the French oil company Elf Aquitaine and the Italian company AGIP S.p.A.-- took up rooms in run-down Soviet-era hotels in this dilapidated port city this month, scrambling to join the consortium.
Western oil executives and Azeri officials have avoided disclosing details of the deal, but some oilmen said the production costs would be quite low because the reserves of 3.5 billion to 4.5 billion barrels were already proved, meaning there would be little need for exploration. The water is also relatively shallow for offshore drilling, about 500 feet.
Moreover, taking advantage of the Government's inexperience, the oil companies struck a deal far more favorable to the companies than to Azerbaijan. "They're not very good at economics," a senior Western oil executive said.
The consortium's members, in addition to the Azeri oil company Socar, include British Petroleum and Amoco, with 17 percent each; Lukoil of Russia, which has 10 percent, followed by Pennzoil, Unocal and Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company, which have about 9 percent each. McDermott International, an American oil equipment manufacturer, and Ramco Energy, a British company, each have about 2 percent, while Delta International, the Saudi Arabian group, and the Turkish Petroleum Corporation each have just under 2 percent.
This latest chapter in the politics of oil is being written where a century ago the family of the Swedish industrialist Robert Nobel began the first serious foreign exploration for oil. During World War I, the Germans, Russians, Turks and British fought for control of the oil here. After the 1917 Russian Revolution, the oil fell into Soviet hands. In World War II, Hitler coveted and failed to capture Baku's oil.
With the collapse of the Soviet Union, another oil rush began, led by Western capitalists. They were welcomed by Azerbaijan, which acquired its independence from Moscow in 1991. But Moscow wanted to keep control of the oil, and it argued that the rights to exploit the resources of the Caspian Sea did not belong solely to Azerbaijan, but to all the countries on the Caspian -- Russia, Iran, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan, as well as Azerbaijan.
Wishing to placate the Russians, Azerbaijan, which started with 30 percent of the consortium, assigned a 10 percent stake to Lukoil of Russia.
In now offering a quarter of its 20 percent share to Iran, Azerbaijan is motivated partly by its need for money, which is why it may sell some or all of its remaining stake to foreign oil companies. Socar is bankrupt and must come up with $1.4 billion for its share in the project. It does not even have the $5 million it needs to pay its share for this financial quarter, some consortium members said.
But the Government's decision to sell to Iran "is not entirely connected to finances," said Ilham Aliyev, a vice president of Socar, during an interview in his shabby office with a view of the Caspian. On his desk were calling cards from the latest representatives of oil companies who made their pitch to him.
"Iran is our neighbor," said Mr. Aliyev, whose father is Azerbaijan's President, Heydar Aliyev.
If the consortium turns down Iran's direct participation, which Mr. Aliyev said he expected because of Washington's objections, Socar would offer to bring Iran in as what Mr. Aliyev called a "sleeping partner." Under this arrangement, Iran would not have a seat at the table or a vote in any negotiations, but it would exercise political influence through Socar and share in the profits, according to oil officials and diplomats familiar with what Socar offered Iran.
The British Government, which is a major player here because of British Petroleum's lead in organizing the consortium, has no objection to Iran's participation. "What is good for B.P. is fine by us," said Britain's Ambassador, Thomas Young.
But Washington does object. The United States is opposed to Iran's acquiring "political influence or financial gain," Richard Kauzarlich, the American Ambassador here, said in an interview.
Under United States law, American companies are not barred from doing business with Iran, which its proposed participation technically would entail. But if they do, they are not eligible for any financial support from Washington, like tax credits for investments or loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank. Under the law, Washington would also be obligated to vote against loans to the project from international financial institutions to which the United States belongs, like the World Bank.
This threat becomes a serious one when construction begins on the pipeline, which is expected to cost at least $2 billion.
The most straightforward route for the oil to reach the Mediterranean, from where it would then be shipped to American and European consumers, runs through Armenia. But Azerbaijan would not tolerate that because it is at war with Armenia over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh.
Armenia could be bypassed by running about 30 miles of the pipeline through Iran, but Washington opposes that.
A third option would be to run the line through Georgia, then down and across Turkey, but Georgia has been plagued by war and political instability.
A fourth way favored by Moscowwould take the oil through Russia's Black Sea port of Novorossiisk, then on barges through the Bosporus to the Mediterranean. But such a pipeline would run through the battleground of Chechnya.
Also, Turkey is opposed to this route, arguing that it cannot allow more tankers through the Bosporus for environmental reasons. But no one doubts that Turkey, which has had a long rivalry with Russia for control of this region, is also motivated by politics.
When Mr. Aliyev of Socar was asked where he thought the pipeline would eventually be built, he said, "It will be a political decision."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Azerbaijan already has active oilfields, like this one outside Baku, but political disagreements among the region's several nations are hindering efforts to exploit the abundant offshore reserves in the Caspian Sea. (James Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Retail Report Pushes Bond Prices Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government debt securities surged yesterday as a Government report on retail sales eased concerns over inflation. As prices rose, the yield of the 30-year bond fell to a five-month low.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in January, less than expected. Analysts said that the data provided further evidence that the economy was slowing. 
 For the bond market, the report reinforced the idea held by some that the Fed would not raise interest rates during the next meeting of its policy-making committee in March. Indeed, a growing number of market participants now expect the next rate increase to come in May.
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management, a Washington-based money management firm, noted that the weak January sales report followed weak numbers in December and November.
"What it suggests from an intermediate to long-term perspective and from a Fed point of view is that the one-year of interest rate increases by the Fed has, or is, in the process of achieving the desired slowdown effect," he said.
Other analysts, however, noted that because retail sales were often subject to large revisions, market participants were eager to see the report on consumer prices in January, which will be released today.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 26/32 , to 10012/32 for a yield of 7.59 percent, down from 7.66 percent on Monday. The yield was the lowest since Sept. 8, when it was 7.56 percent. Shorter-maturity bills were also down an average of 6 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The yield on the long bond has traded in a range of 7.60 percent to 7.80 percent in the last few weeks. It is expected to remain in this pattern, Mr. Carpenter said, until the market is convinced either that the slowdown is truly in effect or that previous indications of a slowdown "have been false signals."
While encouraged by the retail sales report, the bond market largely ignored a more narrow economic report. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta released a survey yesterday that showed that its finished goods price index for the Southeast rose to 22.4 points in January, from 14.3 in December. This suggested that inflation could accelerate in the region.
Today, traders and investors turn to the report on consumer prices. Mr. Carpenter expects a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in both the overall and core numbers of the Consumer Price Index. "Remember, we also had decent producer price numbers on Friday, which foreshadows a decent C.P.I. number," he said.
The reports due today, which include data on industrial production and capacity utilization, can be viewed as lagging indicators, he said.
"They may continue to be strong even after consumer spending has begun to retrench," Mr. Carpenter said. "We probably need to see one or two more months of soft retail sales reports to confirm that the much-heralded economic slowdown is a prospect, and the much-hoped-for soft landing is feasible."
In the municipal bond market, one of the largest issues priced yesterday was a $324.1 million negotiated sale by the New York State Thruway Authority that was sold through Paine Webber. Because of good investor demand, the bonds were repriced, lowering yields about 3 basis points on the term bonds and 5 basis points on the serial bonds.
The maximum yield was 6.222 percent for an issue due in 2025. Most of the bonds are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and rated AAA by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. For those not insured, the underlying ratings are A1 by Moody's and A by S.& P. Serials ran from 4.60 percent in 1996 to 5.90 percent in 2010.
In another large bond sale, the Texas Public Finance Authority sold $300 million of general obligation refunding bonds through Grigsby Brandford & Company. These securities, like those of the New York Thruway, were repriced, lowering yields about 5 basis points on some maturities. Yields ranged from 4.75 percent in 1996 to 6.10 percent in 2015. Dealers said the bonds were rated AA by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Clinton Vows to Oppose Cut in Student Loan Program

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Throwing down another gauntlet to the Republican Congress, President Clinton vowed today to oppose any efforts to scale back direct Federal loans or interest subsidies for college students. And he implored leaders of the nation's colleges to help fight for his proposed tax deductions for post-high-school education.
Though Mr. Clinton made no mention of the word "veto," his speech to a sympathetic group of officials from more than 1,600 colleges and universities meeting here today was the latest in a series of efforts to define the ground on which the White House will fight -- from crime to welfare to foreign policy -- to preserve the President's priorities and prerogatives in the face of Republican alternatives. 
 Mr. Clinton attacked various Republican proposals for limiting direct Federal loans or eliminating Government subsidies that pay the interest costs on loans to lower-income students while they remain in school. He asserted that such notions meant that some Congressional leaders regarded education as "just another area to cut and gut" to help finance reductions in capital gains taxes for the well-to-do.
"Their proposals will cut investments in our future and increase the costs of student loans to our neediest students to fund tax cuts for the wealthy," the President told the American Council on Education. "I will fight these proposals every step of the way, and I want you to join me in fighting them, too. The fight for education is the fight for the American dream. It is the fight for America's middle class. It is the fight for the 21st century."
By portraying his stance on education as the key to providing economic security in the 21st century, Mr. Clinton expressed concern about traditional Republican concepts like safety and security even as he sought to draw a contrast between his views and theirs.
Last weekend he used the same kind of language in vowing to veto Republican plans to restructure the 1994 Federal crime bill so that local governments might use money for purposes other than hiring 100,000 additional police officers.
Similarly, the White House contends that Republican legislation to limit the President's authority to commit United States forces to international peacekeeping operations could jeopardize national security.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, told reporters traveling with the President that Mr. Clinton might discuss his concerns about the peacekeeping proposal when he played golf in Palm Springs, Calif., on Wednesday with former Presidents Gerald R. Ford and George Bush at the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic tournament.
Mr. Clinton himself said he was looking forward to redeeming a longstanding invitation from Mr. Hope to play in the tournament.
"This year he called me and said, 'I really liked your State of the Union, but you'd speak better if you'd come out and play golf with me,' " the President told reporters.
But his preferred topic this morning was education. The White House hopes to use such occasions to highlight Mr. Clinton's achievements in his first two years in office, for which it believes he did not win enough public credit, by arguing that those achievements are now in jeopardy.
The President is also seeking support for his new tax proposals, including one that offers deductions of up to $10,000 a year for college or technical training, and he urged the college officials to call and write Congress in support of his proposals.
Mr. Clinton spent much of his time defending the changes he won in federally guaranteed college loan programs. In 1993, over the objections of commercial banks, Congress passed the President's proposal to let the Government begin making college loans directly to students, and allowing them to repay them over a longer time. The intention was to eliminate the bank middleman and save money, and more than 250,000 students and 104 institutions now participate. But many Republicans remain skeptical that a Federal bureaucracy can deliver on that goal.

He urged the officials, from more than 1,600 colleges and universities, to fight for tax deductions for post-secondary education. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S SPENDING PLAN: THE AGENCIES
Schools and Hospitals Are Among the Hardest Hit in the Budget Slashing;
THE ARTS

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
The proposed city budget calls for an 17 percent reduction in the budget of the Department of Cultural Affairs, from $96.1 million this year to $80.2 million next year.
The largest chunk -- $11 million -- would come from the budget for the Cultural Institutions Group, which consists of 31 cultural organizations that occupy city buildings -- from the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Queens Botanical Garden. 
 These cuts represent a dose of bitter medicine, coming as they do after several years of static or declining Federal support for the arts, recessionary belt-tightening and a proposed 21 percent arts cut in the state budget announced earlier this month.
Additional cuts of $2.5 million would be made in grants to more than 400 arts organizations that receive city money through their boroughs, or through direct application to the cultural affairs department. Those organizations actually face $7.5 million in additional cuts, but the additional cuts would be offset by a matching-grant program that allocates some public money to match private money raised specifically for projects that increase public access to the arts or make an economic impact on the city.
In the first year of a similar matching-grant program, arts organizations found it very difficult to raise the private money. So they were skeptical that the program would succeed. WILLIAM GRIMES

HEADLINE: Mixed Signals Cause Stocks to Barely Move

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The financial markets went in different directions yesterday. Bond prices went up, the dollar went down and stocks were little changed.
It is rare for the three markets to diverge in their judgments since traders all examine the same economic data at virtually the same time. Usually the currency market, which trades around the clock, influences the bond market, which influences the stock market. 
 But it was every market for itself yesterday. The bond market appeared to focus on a retail sales report that seemed to suggest little inflation. Some currency dealers appeared to focus on a regional Federal Reserve survey that seemed to suggest more inflation. Stock traders apparently ignored both reports.
Stock traders also resisted buying stocks in advance of market-moving economic reports due today, including the Consumer Price Index, and what is expected to be a turbulent session on Friday.
Trading volume yesterday, while still light, was beginning to rise as traders started to exercise stock options, which expire Friday in a so-called double witching hour.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.04 points yesterday, to 3,958.25, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.90 point, to 482.55. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 1.20 points, to 790.62.
January retail sales rose just two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, a bullish signal for bonds because it indicated little incentive for companies to raise prices. Bonds rallied.
But the dollar, which has lately been tracking the movement in United States bonds, failed to do so yesterday, and fell to a two-week low against the German mark. While currency dealers attributed the decline largely to technical selling and concerns over Mexico, others noticed a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta. The survey showed a sharp rise in a regional price index for January, to a record 22.4 from 14.3 in December.
What stock traders are paying attention to, however, are the figures on capacity utilization, industrial production, business inventories, and, above all, the Consumer Price Index, due from the Government this morning. The figures are essential to stock traders in deciding whether to bet on rising stock prices.
After accurately predicting that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point on Feb. 1, Wall Street has failed to reach a similar consensus about the future course of interest rates and hence the course of stock prices. If the Fed raises rates again in March and indicates that other rate increases are possible, stock prices may be stuck in a narrow trading range for months.
Nonetheless, several stocks rose sharply. Cigna, a large insurance company, hit a 52-week high of 74 3/4 and closed at 74 3/8, up 3 1/8. It reported that operating net income in the fourth quarter rose to $2.54 a share from $1.98 in the 1993 period. A Goldman, Sachs analyst raised his assessment of the company to "moderate outperformer" from market performer.
Boston Bancorp rose 2 1/2, to 33 3/4, in a continued response to the resignations on Friday of Richard Laine, the chairman, and Paul Archibald, the president. The company said only that the resignations "were voluntary by mutual agreement" with the company board.
Dart Group shares fell 4 1/2, to 75 1/2, after the son of the founder, Herbert Haft, cut off his father's $800,000 salary. Integrated Health Services, a hospital management company, dropped 3 3/8, to 38 5/8, after The Wall Street Journal published an article contending there was self-dealing and other abuses at the company. Revco D.S., a drugstore chain, was off 2 7/8, to 19, after an analyst at Robinson-Humphrey cut his earnings estimate for the company.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Exodus Part II

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As Middle Eastern shouting matches go, the one last weekend at Blair House between Egypt's Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, and the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, was probably in the top ten, said one observer. While their host, Warren Christopher, watched in pain, Mr. Moussa and Mr. Peres ripped each other apart. Mr. Moussa told Mr. Peres that Israel had started the 1967 war, fulminated that Israel, with its nuclear weapons, still wanted to dominate the Middle East, and insisted that Israel was entitled to "normal" relations with Egypt, not a "special relationship."
Mr. Peres lashed back that Egypt was trying to "destroy" the peace process, and with a voice rising in anger told Mr. Moussa that before Egypt got the whole Arab world riled up about inspecting Israel's nuclear facilities, Cairo should inspect Iran's. 
 The hapless Russian observer at the session, Viktor Posuvalyuk, listened to the shouting and said: "I thought relations between you two were more amiable."
Well, Viktor, think again. There is a new rivalry for leadership of the Middle East, and it's between Egypt and Israel. Yes, 3,000 years after the Exodus, the offspring of Pharaoh and Moses are at it again.
Ever since Egypt signed its peace treaty with Israel in 1979, Egypt has worked to get more Arab states to make peace with Israel, primarily to ease Cairo's isolation in the Arab world for having been the first to walk the walk with the Jews. Over time, though, Egypt discovered that its treaty with Israel was actually a source of status and money. Egypt became the interpreter and mediator between Israel and the other Arabs, and it became the Arab address through which the U.S. conducted its peace diplomacy.
And then came the handshake. Israel started dealing directly with Yasir Arafat. Israel signed a treaty with Jordan without either country consulting Egypt (which drove the Egyptians crazy). And lately Israel has been forging economic ties with the likes of Oman, Bahrain, Morocco and Tunisia without anyone dialing Cairo. The Egyptians aren't amused. They know that an Israel at peace with the Arab world is actually more powerful than Egypt. It has more to offer technologically, it has better entree with the U.S. and, because Israel's economy is bigger than Egypt's, Syria's, Jordan's and Lebanon's combined, it will dominate any Middle East common market.
So Egypt struck back. It initiated an Arab crusade to pressure Israel to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which meant Israel either had to reveal its bombs in the basement or risk alienation from its new neighbors. Then the Egyptians put together a summit in Alexandria, with Syria and Saudi Arabia, where they flashed a yellow light to other Arab states thinking about normalizing relations with Israel.
After Israeli and U.S. complaints, the Egyptians hastily arranged a kiss-and-make-up summit in Cairo with Jordan, Israel and the P.L.O., and then attended the Blair House session. But these were just 20-second timeouts, where the Egyptians and Israelis made nice for the cameras.
Egypt today is going through an identity crisis. It had hoped that peace would shrink Israel to its natural size. Instead, peace has made Israel larger -- by giving it diplomatic and economic opportunities in Asia and the Arab world that are making Jerusalem, not Cairo, the region's center of gravity. But peace is making Egypt smaller than its natural size, because it is no longer inflated by its diplomatic role and must now compete with Israel and other Arabs as a real country.
Egypt has a choice: It can try to reassert its leadership by spoiling everything it helped to build. Or it can recognize that Egypt remains special, in its standing with the U.S., the Arab world and Israel -- but just not as special as before -- and learn to live with a medium-sized diplomatic ego, instead of extra large.
Egypt today cannot afford the Nasser model, where it leads by fighting the West, and it cannot sustain the Sadat model, where it leads by bridging to the West. It will have to find a new model for a new era.
I don't know where Egypt's search for identity will lead, but I do know that the identity of the Middle East and the peace process will be heavily influenced by where it ends.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 698 words

HEADLINE: In America;
Cruel Homeless Policy

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The night air was stupefyingly cold. If you walked directly into the wind it felt as if someone were holding cubes of ice against your forehead. The easiest thing in the world to imagine was that someone could freeze to death out there.
The man in the wheelchair had only one leg. With his back against the frigid wind that whistled through the intersection of Vanderbilt Avenue and 46th Street, not far from Grand Central Terminal, he waited in a long line for the small meal being served by volunteers from the Coalition for the Homeless. An orange. A plastic cup of chili. A half-pint of milk. 
 I asked the man if he had a place to stay for the night. He shook his head.
Two young women were handing out blankets from a coalition van. Shivering hands reached for them, as if grasping at a lifeline.
"We're doing as much as we can right now," Michael Polenberg was saying. "But the way they're cutting public assistance, the ranks of the homeless are guaranteed to swell, and we can't really handle any more."
Mr. Polenberg is the director of the coalition's food program. Even as he and his volunteers worked among the destitute on Monday night, a madcap gaggle of Republican politicians (major strategists in America's all-out war on the poor) were partying in splendor at a $1,000-a-plate fund-raiser for Senator Alfonse D'Amato. The party, at the Sheraton New York Hotel, was a smash, raising $2 million.
Earlier in the day Mayor Rudolph Giuliani (as well known for his compassion as Senator D'Amato is for his ethics) traveled to Albany to plead for cuts in state welfare programs that would go deeper than the Draconian cuts urged by Gov. George Pataki. Mr. Giuliani must balance his budget. Since the city has to match state welfare and Medicaid spending, any cuts in state spending result in reduced city costs. This is fine for the Mayor and the budget, but catastrophic for the many thousands of New Yorkers whose meager housing money will vanish, and thus will find themselves setting up light housekeeping under a streetlamp.
The welfare policies of Mayor Giuliani and Governor Pataki are more than inhumane, they are economically unsound. It is widely understood by social service administrators (Republicans and Democrats) that the contemplated cuts will result, as Mr. Polenberg noted, in a substantial increase in homelessness. That will force an expansion of the city's woefully inadequate shelter system, which is far more expensive, bed for bed, than welfare.
It costs $55 to house one person one night in a city shelter. Home relief, by comparison, is a bargain with its monthly housing allowance of $312.
As one official said when Governor Pataki announced his proposals, "There are no savings there."
But politicians are politicians, and their concerns are with power and ego and ambition. They would be shocked -- shocked! -- that anyone would expect them to be concerned about the survival of people sleeping on sidewalks in dangerously cold weather. Hah! they would exclaim, between mouthfuls of tender and succulent roast beef. Hah-hah-hah!
After feeding nearly 100 people at Vanderbilt and 46th, the volunteers from the Coalition for the Homeless drove off in two vans to distribute meals to men and women in grotesque homeless encampments around Manhattan. One stop was beneath the Brooklyn Bridge, where half-frozen men sat as still as death amid piles of tattered clothing, worn-out blankets and debris.
Another stop was in the parking area outside Housing Court, on Centre Street. "It's so cold I can't feel my feet," one man said. "I get scared when I can't feel my feet."
Other stops included a brutal, rat-infested, windswept encampment next to the East River, beneath the Manhattan Bridge; the Staten Island Ferry Terminal; City Hall Park, and the area just south of the United Nations Building, where several people were living in cardboard boxes, and at least one man was lying without a blanket or any other kind of covering on the sidewalk.
A volunteer shook his head. "When you meet someone who has been out here for awhile," he said, "you shake their hand and it's hard to believe that human flesh can get that cold."

HEADLINE: Letting Wall St. Off Easy

BYLINE: By Herbert Stein; Herbert Stein, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, was chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers under Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Several themes run through the Contract With America: promotion of free markets, objection to government regulation, concern for the middle class, strengthening of property rights. But when it comes to the passage on reforming securities law, the contract is oddly in conflict with those objectives.
Adam Smith, in the most famous sentence in economic literature, said that "it is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker, that we expect our dinner, but from their regard to their own interest." It is significant that the examples Smith used all refer to daily purchases. If the baker puts sawdust in my bread I will know it immediately, I will not buy from him anymore and I will tell my friends not to buy from him anymore. So it is in his own interest not to put sawdust in the bread. 
 But suppose that I, a member of the middle class, am buying stock in a corporation with which I have no personal connection -- hardly a daily transaction. How is it in the interest of the corporation's executives (and their accountants, lawyers and investment bankers) to make a diligent effort to tell me everything I ought to know?
How will my property rights be protected? If they are not, am I likely to know what has happened? Will I be able to distinguish between the inevitable vicissitudes of the market and inadequate performance of the people he relied on? If I find that I have been disserved, what difference will it make (as I probably wasn't going to have any more business with them anyway)? How will I tell other investors not to deal with them? And by the time I do tell enough people, won't the executives, lawyers, accountants and investment bankers be sipping their Cuba libres in Costa Rica?
Still, it is essential to the efficient functioning of our economic system that the passive investor be willing to put his money in private enterprise. To give him confidence to do that, we rely on three forces: the trustworthiness of the people who manage the money, which is generally sufficient but, alas, not always; government regulation, which is expensive, ineffective and unnecessarily intrusive; and the power of the legal system.
Although the wronged investor can seek redress in the courts, he cannot, of course, do it by himself. So there is a market demand for people who can assemble the injured investors, perform the necessary research and pursue the claims in court. A supply of people -- mainly lawyers -- exists to meet this important demand.
But the Contract With America proposes to interfere with this market. Its creators intend to interpose a court-appointed trustee between the plaintiffs and their lawyers, and to limit the ability of lawyers to seek out cases of likely misfeasance and to organize suits to obtain redress.
The House Republican leadership also wants to limit court action to cases where deliberate intent to mislead or reckless disregard for the truth can be proved. This would let responsible parties off the hook for failure to exercise the diligence that the law requires of them.
The contract presents its suggestions as if the urgent problem is to protect corporations from middle-class investors' lawyers. True, frivolous lawsuits can be an unnecessary drain on the system. But a much more serious problem is assuring the middle-class investor that the people to whom he entrusts his money will look after his interest honestly and diligently. The possibility of recourse to the judicial system is integral to that assurance, and the proposals in the contract would weaken it.
In 1993 there were 238 class-action suits in securities cases. If America is being drowned in an ocean of litigiousness, this tiny number of suits is but a drop in the ocean.
In fact, some might say that the number of suits is so small that the whole thing does not make much difference either way. But what counts is not the number of suits but the amount of dishonesty and negligence that is prevented by the possibility of stockholder suits. And that could be a lot.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Tales of Times Square: Rowboats and Ice Cream

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman 

 BODY:
HERE are three final stories from Times Square:
BOATS. If it were not for guerrilla activity in the Kurdish regions of Turkey, Mike Davis would probably not be building 25-foot-long rowboats on the ground floor of the old McGraw-Hill Building on 42d Street. 
 He is an archeologist who has spent many years working on a dig at Diyarbakir, near the Euphrates, but because of unrest, work on the project has stopped, and Mr. Davis can now spend time building boats with other volunteers.
"We have great water, but no one uses it very much," the archeologist said as he took a break. "In Istanbul, there are small boats everywhere. Anyone can rent a boat and row on the Bosporus. That's the way it should be on the Hudson."
He said that "as late as 1933 there were 41 boathouses in Manhattan, while now there is just one."
He went on to explain that the project to reverse this trend is called Floating the Apple, and that it originated after articles in boating journals urged New Yorkers to take to their waters. Like-minded people found one another. "Originally, all we wanted was to stimulate rowing on waterways that form the city's biggest open space and wildlife preserve," he said.
One thing led to another, and the group, by then sponsored by the Open Space Institute, decided to build its own boats and offer them for public use to neighborhood teams, school groups or office workers, starting this spring. A boat was designed that could accommodate as many as 10 people. Tools were contributed and the work space was provided by the 42d Street Development Corporation.
"People have come in off the street," said Mr. Davis, whom the other workers call the "chief instigator." He said foreign tourists come in to spend a few hours working. There are homeless volunteers as well as yacht club members. "We've had a few people who have built boats before and many who have never built anything." The only conflict came in deciding what colors to paint the boats.
ICE CREAM. Sembala Batchilly had never tasted ice cream during the first 22 years of his life, which were spent with his family of rice farmers in Gambia. Today, he is the assistant manager of Ben & Jerry's Times Square outlet, at 43d Street and Eighth Avenue, and an ice cream scooping champion.
"I came to New York in 1990," he said in the store. "I had an uncle in the Bronx. I spoke Saroule, my tribal language, and Mandinka and Fula and Wolof. I learned Arabic in my village. Three days a week, I worked on the teacher's farm. But I did not speak English."
After eight months of unemployment, he became a dishwasher. Somebody told him about the Common Ground program at the Times Square Hotel, which provided housing and job counseling for people on narrow margins. He got a room, and when Ben & Jerry's opened last summer, he got a job. "I started to learn English. I learned Cherry Garcia, Rocky Road and Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough," Mr. Batchilly said.
His English improved quickly. He was made assistant manager. He enrolled in a word-processing course. He was chosen to represent the store in a scooping contest, where the object was to dish out just the right amount of ice cream while rapidly filling a variety of orders. He beat everybody in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut region, and last month went to the nationals in Vermont, the home of Ben and Jerry's. He was the only Gambian.
"We had to scoop three small cones, two waffle cones, two medium cones, one large cup, one hot fudge sundae, one banana fudge royale, and we had to write 'Happy Birthday, John' in icing on a cake. I did it in two minutes and 40 seconds. It was not fast enough. I lost by 10 seconds." He said he loved Vermont, where he visited the company's stockholder meeting. He said he was saving his money for a place of his own.
PORN. The Times Square Adult Shoppers Center on 42d Street near Eighth Avenue differs from its neighboring vendors of pornographic videotapes and sex paraphernalia by offering shopping carts to customers. A few of the suits actually use them as they move through aisles arrayed in categories that, in addition to the obvious, included spanking, tickling, slaves and shoes.
By the cash register, store workers chatted casually about the cold. When they were asked if anything was selling particularly well in advance of Valentine's Day, one replied that yes, metal-studded dog collars were proving popular.
Asked where he was from, the man said he had come four years ago from Bangladesh. The conversation turned to the female Bangladeshi writer who fled her country after being threatened with execution for writings that challenged taboos on female sexuality. Did he know of her case?
"Oh, you mean Taslima Nasrin," said the man, surrounded by tons of pornography at what may still be the Crossroads of the World. "Yes, I know of it. The modesty of woman, it is a problem everywhere in the world."

HEADLINE: When Congress Faced Baseball and Struck Out

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Orrin Hatch's suggestion that it is possible the Senate might consider lifting a part of organized baseball's antitrust exemption (some editions, Feb. 9) may mark the end of a 73-year masquerade in which organized baseball pretended it was not in interstate commerce. 
 To my knowledge, the last time a Congressional committee seriously considered legislation affecting organized baseball began with a hearing before the House Judiciary's Subcommittee on Study of Monopoly Power, on July 31, 1951.
In the chair was Representative Emanuel Celler, who was also the chairman of the full committee. John Paul Stevens was the subcommittee's associate counsel, and this writer was its general counsel. Ty Cobb was the leadoff witness.
Before the subcommittee were three bills, introduced by Representatives Wilbur D. Mills, A. S. Herlong Jr. and Melvin Price. These bills would, if they had been enacted, exempt baseball and all other organized sports from the antitrust laws.
They were introduced because organized baseball feared that the decision of the Supreme Court in a 1922 case, Federal Baseball Club v. National League, would be overturned.
In that case the Court held that baseball involves "purely state affairs," with only incidental effects on interstate commerce. Consequently, baseball contracts, which were in restraint of trade, were outside the purview of Federal laws such as the antitrust laws.
In 1951 it was factually clear that baseball was big business having an impact across state lines in a multitude of ways. Moreover, the Supreme Court had decided the Federal League case on the basis of an 1868 case, which was overruled by the Court in 1944.
In 1951 the owners were defending a number of cases in the lower courts, and they expected that their exempt status would end, so they turned to Congress to save them.
Larry McPhail's testimony closed 16 days of hearings, with 33 witnesses, more than 50 exhibits and a total of 1,643 pages of transcript. The subcommittee was never able to agree on a report or to report out the bills.
All the members were lawyers. There were those who looked at the question from a legal standpoint and opposed the bills. There were others who recognized the legal argument but who advanced a concept based on the belief that baseball was more of a sport than a crass commercial enterprise. There was deadlock.
Contrary to expectations, the Supreme Court in 1953 decided Toolson v. New York Yankees in favor of the owners. It held that where a business has for 30 years developed in reliance on a Supreme Court ruling, it was not subject to the antitrust laws. Also, where Congress has not by legislation overruled the Court's decision, the Court would not reverse itself, with potentially severe retrospective effect.
Subsequent cases involving other sports and the arts did not follow Toolson. Thus, baseball has received special treatment not given to any other sport.
There is now the possibility that the adverse effect of baseball's deadlock on the general economy will result in the legislation that the club owners have so long feared and fought.
 
E. ERNEST GOLDSTEIN
Austin, Tex., Feb. 9, 1995
The writer, after a long career in government, teaches law at the University of Texas.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Baseball's Harmonious Environment

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ariz.

 BODY:
THE best professional baseball teams in the United States are conducting spring training in this flat Phoenix suburb, morning through night, rain or shine. Their seasons begin April 1. There will be no strike, no lockout, not this season, not any season.
"Not for 2,000 years," said Ito Yanagi, in a soft rain outside the Chiba Lotte Marines clubhouse. He waved his hand, as if in disgust. "We don't have that stuff." 
 Yanagi, a no-nonsense interpreter for the Japanese League's Pacific Division team, kept his head dry with a white cap that had a blue "M" on the front. The caps were everywhere on the San Diego Padres' side of the Peoria Sports Complex, on the heads of 60-plus players clattering around in their spikes and even the Japanese reporters striding alongside.
Across the complex, on the Seattle Mariners' side where the Chunichi Dragons were making similar use of an inclement day, an American father and son strolled the grounds, wearing blue Chunichi caps with their stylish white "D's". The father explained how they got the caps at the Dragons-Marines exhibition game last weekend.
"It hit me that 2,500 American fans watched two Japanese teams play, and it's the only legitimate game they may see for a while," said Dr. Tom House, nonpracticing psychologist and the Chiba Lotte pitching coach under the new manager, Bobby Valentine. "Is that crazy, or what?"
To the Japanese, the major leagues' bitter strike is simply that, another example of a gun-crazed society's shooting itself in the foot. "People have to find a way to get along," said Yanagi, who makes sure the Japanese reporters understand the three foreign (American) players, or gaijin, Julio Franco, Pete Incaviglia and Eric Hillman.
If Yanagi didn't come to that conclusion by watching our television evening news, or listening to Bud Selig and Donald Fehr, a van carrying a group of Japanese reporters in Phoenix was recently shot at by a car of youths as they shouted racial slurs.
Hillman, a Mets left-hander who had a job with the post office in Port St. Lucie, Fla., lined up had he not been signed by Valentine, was suddenly eager to move on to Japan.
"The labor situation had nothing to do with me being here," he said. "My wife and I have always wanted to see Japan, to live in a society where people have respect for one another."
Outside the United States, but still very much in the global economy, House was recently in Seoul, South Korea, finding Los Angeles Dodgers merchandise on every corner. The Dodgers have a Korean pitcher, Chan Ho Park, and have also signed a Japanese pitcher, Hideo Nomo. Their rotation could soon include a Korean, Japanese, Mexican and Dominican.
"If that's not a statement, I don't know what is," House said. "I don't know when, but I can see a couple of major league teams in Japan, one in Seoul and one in Hawaii, as the stopover on the way. Think of the potential."
Think of the potential global-generated revenue, and this labor war might seem like a battle over sand castles in the desert. "It's so nonproductive, so self-destructive that the Japanese can't relate to it at all," Valentine said.
Yes, there is a Japanese players' union. No, there isn't a snowball's chance in Arizona of the Japanese game shutting down. The minimum salary for a Japanese player is $160,000, higher than the major leagues'. There are $4 million Japanese players but they negotiate their own deals. No agents. And no free agency until after 10 years.
The difference, said House, is that Chiba and the other corporations that own the teams traditionally offer players lifetime employment. Unlike the resentment bred by imperious American owners, baseball labor relations in Japan have historically been cordial.
"The players are much less individualistic," House said. "Discipline is a way of life."
It's a harmonious working environment, occasionally disturbed by headstrong gaijin.
"We had Mel Hall last season," Ito Yanagi said, of the former Yankee, now a Chunichi Dragon. "He was a pain."
Later, with reporters from both countries waiting in the rain for Incaviglia and Franco, the two American stars slipped out a side door, and disappeared. The embarrassed Chiba Lotte public relations people apologized profusely. This sort of conduct baffled them, too.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weak Against Mark But Is Barely Off vs. the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slumped against the German mark yesterday as technical selling and concerns about the stability of Mexico combined to offset the positive effects of a rally in the American bond market.
But the dollar ended only slightly lower against the Japanese yen. Selling of yen for marks and reports of large-scale buying of United States Treasury securities by Japanese investors helped provide a floor for the dollar, analysts said. The dollar slipped to 98.50 yen, from 98.72 on Monday. 
 The dollar fell as low as 1.5065 marks, its lowest since Jan. 31, when it reached 1.5025. In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.5091 marks, down from 1.5212 on Monday.
The British pound slipped to $1.5623 from $1.5625. The pound, which fell sharply against the mark yesterday, has been weakened by concerns about a rift in Britain's ruling Conservative Party over further economic integration within the European Union.
The dollar's decline against the mark and other leading European currencies surprised many people in the market, who had expected the dollar to continue tracking American stock and bond markets in the absence of other guiding factors. Rising stock and bond prices tend to push the dollar higher, because it means higher demand for the dollars needed to buy the securities.
"The decoupling of the dollar and bond prices wasn't what most people had anticipated," said Kevin Harris, international economist at MCM Currencywatch Inc. "It's been an easy bet to watch the bond market for the past few weeks."
Bond prices rallied yesterday after the Commerce Department reported a small increase in retail sales and made lower-than-expected upward revisions in sales data for November and December. But the gains in bonds failed to benefit the dollar.
Dealers said the dollar's drop below 1.52 marks in midmorning trading in New York set off a wave of technical selling by large funds, which moved out of dollars and into marks, Swiss francs and other European currencies.
"Technically speaking, the dollar is very soft," said Rob Fullem, a trader at National Westminster Bank P.L.C. in New York. "Add in a bit of uncertainty about Mexico and you have a negative day for the dollar."
Yesterday, the Governor resigned in Mexico's troubled southern state of Chiapas, an auction of short-term Mexican Government debt produced mixed results and the peso fell sharply to close at 5.845 to the dollar from 5.695 on Monday.

HEADLINE: A Stolen Homer Returns Home, But Less Authentic Than Before

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Now you see them, now you don't.
Any way you look at it, there are two extra sailboats and some flying sea gulls in a Winslow Homer watercolor that weren't there when the American master painted the seascape in 1880. The ghostly additions materialized sometime after the painting, "Off Gloucester Harbor," was stolen in 1969 and before it reappeared in 1992. Thereby hangs a bittersweet tale, one that ended yesterday with the return of the defaced painting to its owner more than a quarter-century after its theft but with a central mystery still unsolved.
"They're not dead sure it can ever be restored," said Sophia L. Truslow, the lawyer for the owner, Ellen Jennings of Ipswich, Mass. Insurance companies, she said, won't touch the painting now. "It's not a Homer," she said. "It's a Homer and Joe Blow." 
 As told in Federal court papers and interviews with Robert Van Etten, the United States Customs Service special agent in charge in New York, the work, which had been valued at about $125,000, was one of four Homer works -- two watercolors and two drawings -- that were stolen from the home of Mrs. Jennings and her late husband, Frederic, on Jan. 16, 1969. Nothing else was taken in the break-in.
The painting is of two boys in a rowboat on calm water looking at a schooner passing in the distance to the right. (In an unusual footnote, a woman who saw the picture on loan to the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston in 1959 was able to name one of the boys as Charles O. Brigham, who had become her father-in-law. She said Brigham had told her that the boys were out rowing when the artist asked them to pose, paying one boy 10 cents and writing out a signed I.O.U. for 10 cents to the other.)
In March 1992, court records say, Peter Juvelis, an art broker from Mexico and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., consigned for sale by Christie's auction house in New York a Homer watercolor for a client, Georgina Maldonado. When Christie's asked about the history of the picture's ownership, Mr. Juvelis "stated he had no bill of sale because his client received the watercolor as a gift from a Mexican official," a Customs Service agent, Bonnie Goldblatt, declared in sworn statements.
When Christie's sought authentification from a Homer expert, whom the authorities sought to keep anonymous, she identified it as the long-missing Gloucester Harbor scene. She also noticed the addition of two smaller sailboats on the left and sea gulls in the sky, apparently to disguise the work as a painting other than the one that had been stolen.
The expert then recalled, Ms. Goldblatt's affidavits said, that two years earlier she had authenticated a Homer drawing consigned by the same Mr. Juvelis. This drawing -- "Boy Sitting on a Stump," from 1879 -- was also one of the Homers stolen from the Jennings home, but by oversight it had not been registered as missing. In that case, the court papers said, the sale went through unnoticed, at a price of $54,000.
When Customs Service agents interviewed Mr. Juvelis about the drawing in Fort Lauderdale in 1992, he again named the owner as Ms. Maldonado, who, he said, had received it from friends 20 years before, the affidavits stated.
Further investigation showed that Mr. Juvelis was married to Ms. Maldonado, Ms. Goldblatt said.
Furthermore, the agent testified, when the Customs Service asked for the commercial form documenting the importation of the Homer painting from Mexico, as required for sale transactions, Mr. Juvelis said there was none because a friend had carried it in for him.
Soon afterward, the agent's account continued, Christie's received a letter from Enrico Beteta, the economic attache at the Mexican consulate in Miami, stating that the painting had been shipped out "through diplomatic channels" to New York for Mr. Juvelis.
The investigation then showed, Ms. Goldblatt stated, that Mr. Beteta was married to the daughter of Mr. Juvelis and Ms. Maldonado. The daughter and Mr. Beteta gave the Customs Service conflicting accounts of the painting's ownership, the agent declared.
Michael I. Rose, a Miami lawyer for Mr. Juvelis, said his client had been "duped" into buying the stolen works from an art dealer in Ipswich who died years ago. Mr. Rose said he did not have the dealer's name or other details; nor, he said, could he immediately reach Mr. Juvelis in Mexico City. He described Mr. Juvelis as "an elderly gentleman in his 70's, retired and living off his children" and the money from the sale of the Homer drawing.
Mr. Juvelis maintained that he had no idea who altered the watercolor but that it had happened before he bought it, Mr. Rose said.
The lawyer said the reason that Mr. Juvelis did not originally identify Ms. Maldonado as his wife was so he could collect a brokerage commission on the sales.
The Mexican consulate in Miami was closed yesterday afternoon and there was no residential listing for Mr. Beteta.
Asked whether Mr. Juvelis had the other two missing Homers -- the watercolor "Going Berrying" and the drawing "Bo Peep" -- Mr. Rose replied, "Not to my knowledge." He said that no criminal charges against Mr. Juvelis were pending but that he faced costly civil lawsuits.
When the drawing was identified as stolen, Christie's bought it back from the buyer and returned it to Mrs. Jennings. The watercolor, which had been seized from Christie's by the Customs Service, was handed back to Ms. Truslow for Mrs. Jennings at the Customs House in the World Trade Center yesterday.
Because the defaced work was a delicate watercolor rather than an opaque oil painting, experts say it would be difficult, if not impossible, to remove all traces of the phantom additions.
"It's not the first time people tried to disguise works of art," said Mr. Van Etten, although he and his agents said they could not recall a similar instance of vandalism.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Off Gloucester Harbor," an 1880 watercolor by Winslow Homer that was stolen in 1969. It was returned to its owner yesterday, with the addition of a sailboat and some sea gulls (to the left of the rowboat). (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: Elisabeth Maxwell;
Questions Without Answers

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

 BODY:
SHE arrives, apologizing.
The driver took her first to the old La Goulue and she had to ask directions to the new La Goulue, and that is why she is late. "I don't know the town," Elisabeth Maxwell says in her French-accented English. "When I've come I've had to rely on other people's experience. Like a parcel, really, in the hands of my hosts."
As she sits, the women at the surrounding tables don't recognize her. In fact, they look right through her. The royal blue suit and watercolored silk scarf at the throat are on the wrong side of chic for the Upper East Side (where it's taupe or die), and her level of concentration is too grim even for the would-be business lunchers, male and female alike, who sneak admiring glances at their own profiles in the mirror as soon as their guests look down. 
 Mrs. Maxwell has come to discuss her autobiography, "A Mind of My Own" (HarperCollins, $25), which officially marks the end of her life as a parcel. It was an image reinforced by her late husband, the publishing magnate Robert Maxwell, to quash her attempts at independence and establishing a career of her own.
In large part, he succeeded. During 46 years of marriage she gave birth to nine children, helped Maxwell start and build Pergamon Press, a science publishing house that grew to such proportion it was sold in 1991 for $766 million, and even in the last decade of his life, as her husband's behavior grew progressively more eccentric and cruel, she remained loyal, despite his prolonged absences and repeated threats of a legal separation. Which he never acted on.
What she has to show for her efforts is spectacular ruin; debt, dishonor and the potential destruction of two sons' careers. When Maxwell died in 1991, at 68, falling overboard from his yacht, his holdings were vast, including The Daily News in New York and Macmillan Publishing, and the rush of questions was immediate. Was it murder? Suicide? Or just a heart attack? Was he trying to escape the consequences of accumulating a $5 billion debt? Did he purposely leave Ian and Kevin Maxwell liable for the pension funds of thousands of employees that he had illegally used as security against other businesses? (The other children were not employees.)
The trial for Mrs. Maxwell's sons, who have been accused of conspiracy to commit fraud, begins this spring in England. She says she is not allowed to talk about it but proves willing to talk about everything else, even the early deaths of two of her children. Her eldest, Michael, was in a car accident in 1961 at age 16 that left him in a coma until he died at 23. A daughter, Karine, died of acute leukemia in 1957 at age 3.
Mrs. Maxwell speaks with a candor and dignity that can come only from a wrenching self-scrutiny, the kind most people spend a lifetime avoiding. At 73, she radiates strength. She radiates survival.
"Once the book was written, it was out of my system, so to speak," she begins. "As soon as my husband died, I never was allowed any time to grieve. I was hoisted on a public platform from Day One. At long last I feel I've buried my husband. I have relived the whole of my life, the good and the bad, and I can speak with a certain amount of detachment. I couldn't talk about Michael's death for years. Now I can because the cutting edge of suffering is gone. It's similar with Bob's death and the circumstances surrounding it."
The most pressing issue is the fate of her sons, who she insists are not guilty. She says the financial losses she has sustained since her husband's death, including her own pension and the auction of her Oxford home and personal belongings, weigh on her far less. (For the last two years, she has lived in a borrowed apartment in London.)
"Kevin has said to me, 'Mummy, if it comes to pass, I will atone for my father.' " Her look pierces. "This is the overwhelming sadness of my life," she says. "Being left in these circumstances means nothing to me. I have had an extraordinary life. I could have had the moon if it was accessible. But to see my sons' careers in ruin, knowing their character and the kind of men they are, is unacceptable and unforgivable. That they should be left by their father in this mess." Her china blue eyes glint angrily.
If she could speak to her husband now, what would she say? "I just would like to ask him what went wrong," she says. "He was a very intelligent man, a gambler, but he knew when to stop to make a good deal. I don't understand how he could make his companies so vulnerable. It seemed very deliberate."
Her green salad and Parmesan souffle are served. "It's strange," she continues. "Toward the end of his life he wanted no constraint of any kind. I was a constraint. I was his soul. Looking at me he knew I disapproved of his life style. I was a perpetual reproach. I really have thought a lot about that. The lust for power. I regret now that he didn't die on his 65th birthday because he would have died a hero. He had a great many assets, the banks at his feet. I don't think he was ever liked, but he was admired. What demons pushed him to acquire Macmillan? He didn't need it. Why?"
I don't know," she answers herself helplessly. "Power mad. If the world recession hadn't settled in, Maxwell Communications would have become one of the largest companies. He was very modern. He saw things like Internet at a time no one else did. To be able to communicate to the entire world from a desk was a vision he had. He really was a communications man," she says proudly.
B UT when it came to personal communications, he seemed to fail. She smiles. "That was really the irony, you know. To communicate between two human beings is a very humble level, and an extremely complex affair. He didn't like doing it."
She is formidable, really in her clear-eyed assessment of where she is and how she got here. As she speaks of her family's disgrace, her reserve never falters. Yet, she is not cold. She is not uncaring. She is a realist.
Well-born to a French Huguenot family, Mrs. Maxwell studied at the Sorbonne during the Second World War, hoping to become a lawyer. She met Mr. Maxwell in Paris while working for the Welcome Committee for Allied Officers. She was Protestant, he was Jewish, she was rich, he was poor, she was educated, he was not. They married. While he traveled the world, building the business, she stayed at home helping to recreate his family, as he put it, since his parents, three sisters and one brother had been killed in Auschwitz. As their children grew, she continued to work in the company, primarily with the editors, though he refused ever to formalize her position.
In the 1980's she returned to college, at Oxford, where she earned a doctorate in French history and became a historian on the Holocaust, with an emphasis on its meaning for Christians. Maxwell still called on her to help with the business, and she always complied, in spite of his flagrant womanizing (which she writes about plainly) and increasingly erratic personal behavior.
"We had a very strange relationship," she says, sipping her coffee. "With all the ups and downs, he kept his love for me enormously protective. He was really a very sick man at the end of his life, and I couldn't imagine anyone else looking after him, although he had been very beastly with me in that last year. At the time it broke something in me, but I couldn't have stopped looking after him. It was 1987 or 1988 when our paths really diverged. His style of life was too big, too shallow, for me. I embarked on a much more spiritual path. He admired what I was doing, and I didn't understand what he was doing. I couldn't understand the reaching for more and more and more. It frightened me."
"So, yes, I feel betrayed," she says flatly. "I cannot imagine he willingly would want me or his children or the pensioners to suffer. I was left only with debts, and I can't repay them. If my friends hadn't lent me money I would have gone bankrupt myself. People like these, to me, redeem the world, and it's not only a question of money. People have been kind without a bean to give me. There is no pattern to the courage to care. Some are marvelous, while some have no heart, no brain. Cowards."
Knowing what she knows now about her life, would she do it again? She thinks. "I'll give a mixed answer," she says. "Yes. Bob has given me a life of such dimension that has stretched me so far, he has got the best out of me." She seems unaware of the present tense. "For all this I feel very grateful. I do regret now not to have left him. We would all have been better for it.
"And knowing what I know to the bitter end now, well, no one would want to see their children suffer that much. That is not acceptable."
H ER tone soon grows philosophical. "Ah, it is wonderful to pick and choose the things in life to do better." She shrugs. "The worst years of my life were 1981 to 1991. I was at his beck and call with no kudos, nothing was right. What saved me was my work on the Holocaust. From there I started a new world of studies and also a rethinking of my faith. At the time, I was really suffering a lack of confidence in myself to go it alone. It was stupid, really, the feeling" -- she bites her lip -- "that I couldn't possibly manage. To think now I'm in even tougher circumstances! That is perhaps what I reproach most to him in this putting down of my abilities, demeaning me. He really shouldn't have done that. It wasn't true. Very often my own children said, 'Why not run away?' I very bitterly regret it now," she concludes, though no anger lingers in her voice. "C'est la vie. Nothing is black and white, and with all the difficulties that came there were some great moments."
She keeps drinking her coffee, the light shining on her reddish hair. She is fearless, serene. How has she managed it?
"I tell you I had made up my mind a long time ago that lies have very small feet," she says. "I find my life is made so much simpler being myself, saying the truth. One's innocence of a misdeed gives extreme strength. And that keeps you relatively free and above the fray."
Still, she circles back, once again, to her husband. "What are the driving forces that make people do things?" she wonders. "I hope one day there will be a balance. That time passes, passions fall and eventually some truths emerge. It was really a Greek tragedy that his path should have finished the way it did. And after a lifetime, what did it take, a few months to turn it around." She shakes her head and opens her hands. "Ah, voila!" she says. The questions have no end.
After she leaves, the hostess grows curious. "Where is she from?" she wants to know. France, originally, she is told. But she lives in London now. She wants to know more, but a table of regular customers gets up to leave, and they each kiss her on both cheeks as she helps them on with their coats and sees them out the door. She returns, looking quizzical. She had a question about someone, didn't she? Ah, voila! She smiles prettily. She has forgotten.
